this is in response to whoever asked (sorry deleted it) about t.m. at
cowel theatre s.f. last nite.

if you've read "invisible landscape" and already know about the "timewave
zero" theory, this event wouldn't give you much.  basically terrence, with the
aid of a netscape browser talked about his fractal time theory and how to use
it to predict "novelty"  next year being a big year for change/novelty.

for more info see:  http://www.levity.com/eschaton/

barry

MPH on the freeway....)

They mentioned that 20 "drug overdoses" had taken place at a large
"rave party" in Oakland on Saturday night. They had some paramedic or
something on  the air talking about how he had to help two "20 year old
girls" that were lying in the street screaming hysterically. They
blamed it on a batch of "liquid acid" that was going around.

IMHO, a bad trip is guaranteed at any >1000 person rave with the
name "cyber" in it...

=  Niels Mayer   http://www.cyborganic.com/People/niels   mayer@netcom.com  =

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Oct  1 23:59:44 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id XAA16160; Sun, 1 Oct 1995 23:59:44 -0700

From: "Fred Heutte" <phred@well.com>

        "Re: Bad Acid @ Richmond?" (Oct  1, 11:37pm)

        "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: Bad Acid @ Richmond?
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I don't do acid but I've observed its effects up close for a long time.
Dosage control with the liquid form is obviously difficult, and anonymous
self-reporting I've seen indicates that the experience is much more vivid,
perhaps because there are no delivery contaminants as there are with tabs,
for example.  In several instances I observed, the "screaming hysterically"
part occurred but the individuals had no recollection of that afterwards,
reporting a dreamlike and rather pleasant state.  There seems to be some
sort of threshhold effect where a complete personality dissociation occursm,
leaving a conflicted/agonized/terrified surface which seems unchecked by
the usual conscious restraints, while the rest of the mind is off exploring
on its own plane.  

I don't have any real expertise in the psychopharmacology of acid, so if
someone does and can provide more of an explanation of that, I'd be
interested.  All I can say is that, although some people I've known stopped
taking acid after a bad trip, I can't think of any who thought it was 
anything less than an amazing experience.  I would caution against extending
that kind of anecdotal evidence to broader conclusions, but let's just say
my view of acid's toxicity and mental damage is far different based on those
kinds of self-reports than, say, alcohol, nicotine, cocaine or speed.

As proven again and again since acid went into general public circulation
in the mid-1960s, the best treatment for a bad trip is to remove excess
visual and auditory stimuli, provide plenty of human contact and have
lots of patience.  It is a very wearing experience to help someone through
a bad trip, but it's a worthwhile one.  The one thing I'm always afraid
of in those circumstances is that it's not acid at all but some other
substance (oh, the bad trips I've seen from PCP "back in the day", yow!!).

Any large-scale public event like a Cool World really ought to have
trained people available to help with this.  About the worst thing you
can do with someone on a bad trip is shove them into a police car or
ambulance and take them to a bright, sterile, unfamiliar place where
linear thinking and responsiveness are the only criteria, and where
very powerful relaxant and other drugs that are totally unnecessary
may be administered because the people don't understand how to deal
with bad trips and distinguish between acid trips and other kinds.

I've seen bad acid trips in the very Kaiser Auditorium where Cool World
was, back when the Grateful Dead used to play there.  The Dead scene
developed a whole ethos around acid, and bad trips as one part of that,
and the presence of not only Rock Med but people knowledgeable from
experience or hearsay about the stages of a trip helped minimize serious
problems over the year.  I mean, when someone takes off all their clothes
in the middle of "Scarlet Begonias" and starts flailing, what do you do
if you *don't* know what to do, right?  But the Deadheads, especially
the earlier crew, knew what to do and we can learn from that.

phred

helping someone through a bad trip really can be a tough, tiring 
expreience, especially if you are on acid yourself... in a way bad trips 
can be contagious. i agree that it would help to have people who know the 
effects of acid (both good and bad) around to help people out at any party.
but that isn't always possible for various reasons. i also agree that the 
best thing to do it to talk someone out of it, to look into their eyes 
and remind them that as a drug of the mind and consciousness, the entire 
trip is under there control- they can take it where they want it. one 
thing though, suprisingly, can bring anyone off a trip completely. it is 
a very basic drink - milk.

"Archana H. Carter" <archana@Dartmouth.EDU>:
> trip is under there control- they can take it where they want it. one 
> thing though, suprisingly, can bring anyone off a trip completely. it is 
> a very basic drink - milk.

Sounds like that advertizing firm should get on this idea quick for a 
"got milk" commercial. Hapless tripper spewing brain salad about the 
great upcoming celestial exstarvaganza and the amazing portent and
auspices of the alignment of the stars.... Straightjacket is put on ...
"got milk" ??

(NOT).

More to the point w/r/t other's comments:

(1) "rock med" will not give out any drugs whatsoever (not even
aspirin) because they're worried about liability and drug interaction.
they will hold your hand and talk you through it. (You're better off
having a friend around anyways, or someone that actually gives a shit
about you).

(2) someone made a comment about the sterility and linear thinking of
the emergency room.... i have a few doctor friends that relate their
point of view on this stuff -- i.e. why they may be a bit less
helpful/caring than you want them to be. They tend to regard these
sorts of drug-inflicted injuries as something that they didn't need to
be treating in the first place... it's not like they wanted to be woken
up, popped out of their hot tub, or spending  time with their lovely
doctor's wives/husbands rather than looking at yer twisted angst-ridden
face and listening to yer rantings... all for something that was made
illegal for a reason -- because too many people are too lame to use  a
drug that powerful responsibly. You might want to remember that next
time you're chugging acid out of the visine bottle, or next time you
decide to eat a whole sheet of blotter because you want to show your
friends how burly you are... (granted that's not the only way these
things happen, then again, too often it is...).

(Again, the above is often the "doctors" point of view -- most doctors
are hypocrites about the hypocratic oath and will treat clogged
arteries with great care (which ultimately is also a self-inflicted
injury) whereas they'll probably treat you with a lot less respect if
you've taken illegal drugs and now need their help to extricate
yourself from your problem).

(3) acid is a loaded gun, serious drugs, not candy! Unfortunately
people rarely give it the respect it is due, until they have their own
first bad trip. If they still have a brain (or had one in the first
place) they may go back and figure out "what went wrong" and not repeat
their mistakes again. To this end, anybody with a clue would know to
(a) avoid cool/cyber world at all costs; (b) ferchrissakes, remember
the importance of set and setting, and  consider that cool/cyber world
are neither good set (as in baaaaad stooopid vibe), nor good setting.

(4) someone said that "screaming hysterically" was often a result of
taking a lot of acid, the result of some kind of dissociative trip
where you don't actually feel like you're screaming on the inside.
That's ridiculous. Even if true, why would you want this kind of trip
while you're at a rave --  save these sorts of trips for a time when
you can give your own navel a serious self-examination with other
supportive friends. Why on earth people would want to take that much
acid at a place like cool world is totally beyond me. Then again, in a
past life as an occasional deadhead, i've watched people do stupid
things with acid there too -- like taking 10 hits before a show...

	- Niels.

paranoia - and you don't check yourself because it's a probable 
thing that this person would do you harm. That's one thing that's happened 
to me - worst psychedelic expereince of my life. Also corresponded
to an incredibly stupid dosage level....

This morning on the front page of the Bay Area section of the Chronicle 
is a report on 16 Overdoses over the weekend on LSD and Ecstacy.  It is a 
brief blurb of pretty much what everyone has already said.  The 
newspaper never really says which drug caused any of the overdoses and 
they refer to multiple "illegal" rave-type parties over the weekend.  I 
never quite got what they meant as an "overdose".  I think the story is
a bit unclear, lacks info., and is kind of a scare tactic, but then 
again, drugs are a scary thing to many.  Anyways, check it out if you are 
interested.

Went to Zendada (in the basement of 1015) on Friday.

The music was great:  Tracy played the sweetest set with lots of
cool vocals.  Taj's set was interesting;  he was mixing a lot funky
house in with (his usual) low sounding progressive stuff.  If you
haven't heard them lately, you should check out these two.

I found it interesting that the profile of this gig has significantly
changed since the summer.  And the change is definitely for the
better.  The size was perfect: enough people to create a good vibe but
not crowded at all.  And it was very sober.  People were actually
listening and paying attention to the music.  

SASA

A friend just called me at work and said on KALX today they were saying that 
hundreds of kids got what they thought was X but was something else (Special 
K, maybe?) and ended up wandering around Oakland lost and out of there 
repective trees....ugly... 
 
------->> aaron

Another fine weekend with the Pacific sound system.  First on
Saturday with the mini rave adjunct to the Hemp festival at the
civic center.  I managed to twitch along to the first DJ's
Jungle set, but things really took off when Tony took the helm,
followed by more greatness from Garth, Solar and then Jeno.
One thing I notice about Jeno's set is how the instant he came
on the music suddenly sounded more crisp and punchy.  I don't
think he messed with the EQ.  It just seems that he often picks
records that are recorded in a certain way.

I don't want to bore with another redundant sunset review, so
just a few notes:  Although it was in Richmond again, they
shifted the location more to the park's center.  More shade, more
grass - good move.  I thought Tracy *really* tore it up.  Also,
that was two Pacific parties in a row that Galen - owner of
the sound system - did not spin at in order to make room for
other Djs.  In his own quiet way, he is one classy guy.

Got to meet Black Adder and Reagan Reid (love the way that name
rolls off my tongue) for the first time. :)

We hope to see some of you at Splish.

Lee

To: Amy R Starkey <sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu>
From: eidrah@wimsey.com (Karen)
Subject: Re: controlling bad trips/ was Re: Bad Acid @ Richmond?
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


>That's one thing I could never understand is how people can let LSD
>control them.  It is all in the mind.  I have "talked" myself out of
>numerous bad trips and talked myself out of getting physically ill.  I
>just say to myself "it's all in your mind, Amy" then it magically
>disappears after a few long relaxed breaths.  Do others just not have the
>mind control? Or am I an exception?  I've heard of people not liking LSD
>because they feel they
>lack control.  I feel MOST in control - it's kind of like lucid dreaming...

Well, I've had a few hairy experiences on acid and have almost lost it, but
I can usually get myself out of it by finding something to concentrate on,
like drawing.  Not long ago I experienced an evil panic spiral on a trip
and only just managed to get myself out of it ... you should SEE the
pictures that emerged from my wobbling mind!!!  :)

I think some people do have better control over their minds than others ...
but I think it can go the other way and people can be TOO MUCH in control
... and since acid DOES require that you let go of yourself a little, that
can also be a bad thing.

It all depends on the person and the situation.  That's why, although I've
frequently entertained the notion of slipping acid on someone who didn't
know, I'd NEVER do it.  It's entirely too cruel.  But imagining the
consequences is amusing .... ;)

k

Hello all SFR folks!,

I am happy to give rides to folks whenever it's convenient, *however* you 
*must* pick up that ancient apparatus called a telephone and dial my number!!!  
;-)  You see, my only computer access and e-mail account right now is at work.  
Logical conclusion...I can't retrieve my messages or pleas for help or rides 
after I leave work at 5:30 or anytime on the weekends.  The only time I read my 
e-mail is when I'm here.  So, trying to reach a possible ride at 10:00 on 
Friday night won't work for me unless you call me.  

On weekdays, it's rare that I go out unless I make a plan to do so ahead of 
time.  So, if you want to go to an event during the week, you need to either 
post well before 5:30 or call me no later than 7 or 8 (if you're only calling 
for a ride) otherwise you can call up til 10:30.   

Fridays and Saturdays you can probably reach me reasonably late at home, but 
it's always best to post or call a few days ahead of time if you are 
anticipating needing a ride.  For my housemates sake though, please don't call 
after 11.   You can also call me for weekend daytime raves.

If you would like my phone number, just ask.  I live in Oakland, so only nearby 
folks please, or people willing to BART/bus it first then get ride. 

Sendin' out smiles

Rikki

Precedence: bulk


Here's a quick scene report / sermon from the weekend. Take from it what 
you will.

I was in my place durng Garth's set and the free Gathering this Saturday, 
exit stage left, basically wondering about how for some of the people 
around me this was not their first rave, and it showed, and for a lot more 
this was their first rave,(( "Look Tities!")) and how that showed. 
I mean, even though the drug culture is compatable it doesn't nessearilly 
mean any rave ideolgy is also. Case in point is the story that  
follows. the cast of characters consists of :

(8 year old?) toddler
(teenage) Skater Prick
and a sea of apathetic stoned teens.

So anyway, as I was experiencing the moment my spidey sense was picking 
up on this situation that was developing to my right. Skater Prick was 
off to my side, kind of on the outskits of the main energy around the DJ, 
and sort of roughhousing with this Kid. Having a kid brother 10 years my 
junior I know what it's like to roughhouse but even so I noticed that 
Skater Prick was being pretty calous, tossing the kid up in the air and 
then walking back to his skater friends to Be Cool. It was a roughhousing 
without hugs or roughhousing for aperances sake.
 
Now the Kid seemed to have some kind of unresolved conflict that he 
wasn't about to let go. As soon as Skater Prick turned his back the Kid 
collected a handfull of grass and pegged Skater Prick in the face. 
Friends laughed, and Skater Prick looked stupid for a moment before grabbing 
the Kid, shaking him some, shoving him away and moving back to his 
friends, with a "Don't throw shit at me you little Fucker!". I was 
planning on saying something along the lines of "Maybe you should give 
him a hug instead." to Skater Prick, but the moment escaped me.

Now, somehow the Kid managed to get some piece of trash, like a small wood 
block, and clocked Skater Prick again, this time upside the head with a 
load "whack!" the Kid than booked into the crowd and Skater Prick lunged 
after him, grabing this person a fifth of his size and screaming 
something like "Now you're gonna get motherfucker!"

Now, by nature I have a very non-confrantational personality, and 
interfering in a domestic situation that you know nothing about is not a 
very good idea. Even so, for obvious reasons, I moved down on my knees so 
that I was at eye level with the kid and between the two. The Kid 
seemed mildly hysterical so when I looked up to ask Skater Prick, who had 
moved back a bit at this point, whether this was his kid brother or his 
kid, or whatever, he just shruged and said that the Kid was with another 
group. Some teenage chick who was getting together with one of the other 
skaters then came by to take the Kid and then relcutantlly picked him up 
and sat him next to the wall before going back to her man. Skater Prick 
let it go at that. 

I kept my sitting position on the floor for a good time, pretty upset 
with the fact that a potentialy violent situation almost erupted in front 
of me and that no one else around me seemed to care. I sat there for a while 
until most of the players had moved off to their respective corners, the 
Kid up on the wall and Skater Prick off to olie with his friends. 

It's been a while since I've had to play Hall Monitor, I hate that job then 
and now because at best all it seems to do is prolong the inevitable. 
Fucked-up white trash kids will still go home to their fucked-up 
unsuprivised homes. Sometimes all you can hope for is that your actions can 
set an example.

I sat for a while and looked around at my neighboors, the majority of 
whom were doing the Kickbox-at-the-person-next-to-you-without-ever-making-
eye-contact dance, or some variation of it. I sat there for a while, 
protesting the situation that had occured until I felt it was OK to get 
up and move again. 

Sometimes the Enemy is some faceless goverment force that has only 
it's best interests in mind and sometimes the Enemy is that person 
standing right next to you among this hip underground youth culture that 
everyone is so damn proud of. I guess that one of my  points is that in 
exchange for having this great unsuprivised scene we are *all* expected 
to take a little bit of responsiblity for one another. 

Besides that incident Saturday turned out to be a rather nice day.

Live & learn.

Bolger

From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> Neils, I don't quite understand your attitude on this.  It's not that
> someone would WANT the dissociative-trip experience  . . . it's something
> that *happens*.  

My attitude on this is that a bunch of people that can't handle their
drugs are making raving associated with stupidity, drug abuse, and are
helping enforce the public opinion that there is no possible good use
for "A" and that any use at all is dangerous and foolhardy, right up
there with PCP and injecting heroin.

Maybe you didn't get to hear the embarrassing radio reports. On the
other hand, perhaps you'll now be less willing to admit that you're
going to a rave because your non-raver/coworker acquaintences will
immediately say -- "hey, isn't that one of those things where kids get
all hopped up on goof balls then have to call the paramedics cuz their
so completely out of their heads?"...

W/r/t my claiming the dissociative-trip experience (hey isn't that a
60's band??) was "ridiculous" -- i meant that it's ridiculous that
people would want to get themselves into that territory at a very
large, very impersonal, and very zoo-like rave. (again, a sign of
stupidity, inexperience, and cruelty on the part of the vendors)... i
personally don't think that such a reaction is easy to reach with "1
hit", assuming it's really just a 100 ug hit, and assuming that the
person hasn't ingested any other substances. 1 hit of acid + smoking
lots of pot, and/or opium, and/or cocaine is something that can put you
in the danger zone no matter what, or so I've seen from watching other
people "lose it" in college and at dead shows.

Otherwise my attitude comes from the fact that i can still picture
people that I knew in college  who are no longer with us, either
physically or just mentally... and it's not a pretty picture.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
=  Niels Mayer   http://www.cyborganic.com/People/niels   mayer@netcom.com  =
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

since the top of the week seems to be acid trips here's the one that ended
my use of acid,,,,,
  about a year ago Me and some friends purchased the famed "black Gel Caps"
we asat down took the gel caps (i took 1 and a 1/2 not a large dose)and
proceeded to watch disney's Alice in Wonderland (we were just goin to
hangout at home and have a good time) well after watching thee Adventures
of alice...we decided that the story mirrored life and death and that life
was a VICIOUS CIRCLE and for the rest of the trip everything led back to
this vicious circle and it got rteal scarey....now we're not junkies or
anything(the first step is denial Ha HA real funny,but seriously
folks....)We wentt out of our minds  We Drank Milk...We were in Familier
surroundings but bad shit is bad shit...

The conclusion is that after that I did acid one more time ( I always get
real powerful ShiT) AND GOT SUPER MICRODOT OR WHATEVER AND BLAZED FOR A
GOOD 16 HOURS OF UNCONTROLABLE HALLUCINATION  AT a wack rave that made me
hate Demigod for all eternity...so now I if I have the desire to "see
things" AND CAN'T TALK MYSELF INTO IT...I take shrooms (the safe and
natrual alternative)...why anyone likes to take 8 doses of e or eat an
entire sheet of blotter(STUPID!!!)is beyond me..That is straight abuse and
to those that know we should educate and stop the ABUSE IF you are using
you should use responsibly and know your limits. and to those that don't
use and are str8 edge let's all be cool with that...they are on the best
trip of all....
well that is my thing..just felt like postin once in a while...
who's goin to BASICS?
PLUR..al

I think the cow's milk thing is hooey.

I've eaten a lot of ice cream (half a pint container of Ben & Jerry's cookie 
dough) on a certain fateful evening, and it didn't interrupt or stop anything 
one bit.  It tasted great, and it felt really funny (in a happy, giggly way) 
going down.

I've eaten bowls of Captain Crunch with Crunchberries (love those flourescent 
pink crunchy puff balls of sugar) with lots of milk and it didn't change 
anything either.

I've also heard that vitamin b-12 and/or niacin will stop a trip.  Well, not in 
any dose of B-12 or Niacin that I've ever ingested.

Whoever said that getting in a calm place away from aural or visual 
overstimulation was on the right track.  A nice warm (not hot) bath and being 
tucked in under a fluffy comforter works a lot better than milk or B vitamins.

Laura

On Mon, 2 Oct 1995, Archana H. Carter wrote:

> one thing though, suprisingly, can bring anyone off a trip completely. it
> is  a very basic drink - milk.
> AC


>>Err. Yeah like the first thing I'd want on a bad trip is milk from a cow
>>pumped full of hormones & fed food with lots of pestisides & other
>>chemicals. 

   josh

Frankly, the last liquid I could think of imibing while too high would be 
milk.  Yuck.  But to make it less disgusting, would organic milk be more 
acceptable? (not that you can walk into any old store and get it, but...) I 
wonder if you could get the same results with soy or rice milk.  What compounds 
in milk help eliminate the bad trip?  Maybe its just the calcium or protein or 
something else easily found for example in a vitamin and mineral supplement.  
Hmmm, this requires more research.  I'd love to know if it were true.  It'd be 
a big drag if you were at Sunset, nowhere near a store, too tweaked to drive 
and you had a bad trip...will people start bringing milk in coolers?  (The cops 
show up, "oh what an unusually wholesome bunch of kids.  I'll have to intoduce 
my daughter to these people!") ;-)   I wonder what bartenders would say if you 
asked for a glass of milk at a club?  Yep, they'd probably think you were 
pretty darn high.

I'm certain there are fairly basic compounds out there to help eliminate a bad 
trip.  Should I make it a mission to find out for the betterment and health of 
all ravers worldwide?  As far as bad trips go physically (your grim feeling 
stomach) I know there are several homeopathic methods you can aquire thru herb 
stores, accupuncturists, chiropracters, etc., that can calm a nauseous tummy.   
Also, I don't think having a bad physical trip can always be overcome by mind 
over matter.   Some drugs carry very bad additives that would make you feel 
like crap regardless.  I know some of the less pure L is cut with certain 
things things that always give me a lower back ache due to my kidneys trying to 
filter out the poisons.  Nothing can be done about that except not doing L or 
making sure one  only gets the good stuff (which is impossible to ensure).

My 2 worth.

PLUR

Rikki

First, as a disclaimer, I'd like to say that I only went to Cyberfest 
because I got a free ticket through the radio station I dj at.  I only 
had one ticket, and NONE of my friends wanted to pay $25, so I had to go 
alone :(

Some quick impressions:
-20,000 people and NO PARKING LOT!
-Live rapping over really bad house music! (inside)
-Bongos AND a live drum set playing over really bad house music! (outside)

WHAT ARE THESE PEOPLE THINKING?????

Actually, the dj who came on after Fungo Mungo inside started his set 
with four totally sick acid breakbeat tracks, then lapsed into boring, 
cheesy, techno-housy music.  Why does this always seem to happen?  I also 
caught the beginning of Garth's set outside, and he played about 3 or 4 
killer tracks before lapsing into the boring abyss of non-descript house 
music (or so it sounds to me).

A final word:
Are there really this many ravers in the Bay Area, or did people drop in 
from outer space for this rave?  There was no place to MOVE on either the 
inside or outside dancefloors.

Another final word (of advice):
DON'T BUY DRUGS FROM SOMEONE YOU DON'T KNOW!!!

over and out,
Seth

From: rdriffle@ucdavis.edu (Rick Riffle)
Subject: Bad Acid Trips
X-Mailer: <Windows Eudora Version 2.0.2>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Regarding the talk about being able to talk yourself out of an acid trip....

It is possible to get to a state where you lose most or all of your points
of reference.  I have personnaly been in a place with *no* points of
reference.  There was no such thing as anything.  There was no way at the
time to talk my way out of or into anything, because there really was
nothing.   That may be a little hard to fathom, but I had to use every part
of my Will to get out of there.  The only thing I had was some small amount
of memory of a place with floors and trees and worlds and stuff, and I knew
that I could thought manifest.  So I decided to create a world.  Boy was I
naive.  Since I had little or no thought control at the time as soon as I
started to think the world into existance, some thought about colors brought
up another thought of the "Windows" color scheme "Hotdog Stand".  The
unwanted thoughts came in as the World was being created and I found myself
standing on a black paved street that was all greasy like the stuff you find
behind a fryer at McD's.  The buildings and sky and everything were bright
yellow and red and it smelled really bad.  No green, no plants, no blue sky
(I think it was black).  I completely thought I would never get back.  There
was no thought or recollection that "A" had assisted me in getting there.  I
messed up things on the inner planes of my being, and those screw-up's
manifested in my physical reality over the next week or so.  Lucky some
friends from a past life in Egypt mummified me and put me in a pyramid so my
thoughts would stay contained and not fuck up the rest of the world.
Eventually I woke up and unzipped the tent to see the world was still there
and everything was beautiful.  I only took one little square too.  A friend
took the same stuff and was fine, except for trying to deal with me had it's
moments (I hear).  That was the last time I took acid.  It may very well be
the last time I ever take it.  The lesson I learned was that I need to gain
alot more control over my thoughts than I had at the time.  I have since
done that, but still don't know if I'll ever do A again.   My point is, you
can't always talk your way out, or be talked out.  Why am I telling you all
of this....I  d o n ' t  k n o w...

Rick

Precedence: bulk


     
     One of the joys of sitting on a mailing list (off and on) for three 
     years or so is the cycle of discussions and the way the same 
     (mis)information gets posted again and again and discussed again and 
     again.
     
     Yes, it's educational for all, don't start flaming me now for what I 
     just said...my point is that for some reason what I just said puts me 
     in a frame of mind that makes the following an appropriate post to the 
     sfraves list.
     
     Enjoy,
     
     Laura
     
     **********************************************************************
     PSHIFT(1)       USER COMMANDS   PSHIFT(1)
     
     NAME
     pshift - paradigm shift utility
     
     SYNOPSIS
     pshift [-zzeitgeist] [-rragelev] [-v] [-c] [-wn] [+|-n]
     
     DESCRIPTION
     The pshift operator performs a paradigm shift on its input stream 
     within the context of the current or specified zeitgeist.
     
     OPTIONS
     -z      Specify the zeitgeist context.  May be specified here or
     from the environment variable $ZEITGEIST.
     
     Supported values of zeitgeist are judeo_christian (default), 
     postcommunist, new_age, and when_god_was_a_woman.
     
     -r      Specify rage level. Acceptable values of ragelev are
     ennui (default), deep_seated, and consuming.
     
     -v      Set to verbose mode.  Normally pshift operates silently;
     in verbose mode it publishes a 500+ page bestseller entitled 
     "Rethinking [input stream] in the [zeitgeist] Age", and then begins 
     soliciting honoraria until the operator types ctrl-c.
     On some systems it runs for Congress.
     
     -c      Set to collective IO.  Normally pshift takes its input
     from stdin and outputs to stdout;  in collective mode it takes its 
     input from the Collective Unconscious and writes to the Body Politic.
     
     -wn     Specify first, second, third or fourth wave.  Acceptable
     values for n are 0,1,2 or 3, with 2 (third wave) being the default.
     
     [On Sun systems, the logical waves are 0,3,2,1, which map to physical 
     waves 0,1,2,3; see Sun Technical Manual for details.]
     
     +|-n    Specifies the number of times to prepend 'post' to the
     zeitgeist context, if positive, or 'pre' if negative. The default is 
     11.
     
     EXAMPLES
     
     source $DEITY | pshift -zpostcommunist -rdeep_seated -v +1
     
     On most systems, the above command will output a hardcover volume 
     called "Rethinking God in the Post-Postcommunist Era", in which the 
     irrelevence of erstwhile religious concepts is seen to have triggered 
     a global, deep-seated rage vis-a-vis traditional sociopolitical norms 
     leading to a premature breakdown of emerging postsoviet 
     infrastructure.
     
     pshift -znew_age -rennui
     
     The above command produces no output, but privately processes a vague 
     discontent which it will share if its space is honored. May be 
     redirected to /dev/null.
     
     pshift -c -w3 -1
     
     Taking its input from the collective unconscious, the above command 
     rejects the failed socioeconomic policies of the last thirty years and 
     replaces them with a futurist, fourth wave polemic of traditional 
     values, the two-parent family, and the supremacy of the private sector 
     that was the foundation of the American utopia of the 1950s.  Use a 
     prepend value of -2 to restore the American utopia of the early 
     Industrial Age, a value of -3 to restore the European utopia of the 
     Enlightenment, -4 for catholic hegemony, etc.
     
     (note:  Requires grass root permission.  In verbose mode, it may also 
     require a $4 million advance.)
     
     SEE ALSO
     backlash(1)
     
     BUGS
     You must have root permission to use consuming rage.
     
     AUTHOR
     Robert Drucker (robert@ocean.washington.edu) copyright 1995 Robert 
     Drucker.
     Robert Drucker is a trademark of Robert Drucker.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Oct  2 17:07:48 1995

From: laural@inmark.com

Received: from cc:Mail by ugate.inmark.com
	id AA812678708 Mon, 02 Oct 95 17:05:08 
Date: Mon, 02 Oct 95 17:05:08 
Message-Id: <9509028126.AA812678708@ugate.inmark.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: More on Cyberfest!!! (Oh boy!)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I listen to Live 105 on the radio a lot, and Cyberfest was prominently promoted 
there.  Steve Masters, a (sort of ex-) Live 105 DJ, was one of the Cyberfest 
DJs, so of course Live 105 was pushing it with recorded ads, live spot ads, and 
giveaways of tickets.  

Now before you go slagging on Steve, let me just say that about a month ago he 
played SPAZ's "Space Music for Fluffheads" on his Sunday night show, and would 
throw on Future Sound of London tracks every now and again on his regular 
weekday show.

But anyway, between massive flyering, advertising on *at least* Live 105, and 
selling tickets through Bass (or was it Ticketron, or are they one and the same 
now?) this party got a LOT of promotion and exposure in circles where people 
don't usually listen to house or techno, and where people might not have any 
raver friends.  The idea of a rave appealed to 20,000 people for whatever reason
(maybe for some it was the "21-and-over-bar-tent"), so they came out to the 
party.  It does boggle the mind, though.

Imagine how cool it would have been if it had been 20,000 people, fabulous 
mind-opening music, and no "bad acid."  That could have been amazing...but 
concern for pleasing (pacifying?) that large a group and for making a profit (by
those who were peddling crap chemicals) resulted in something that rave-purists 
consider a pale reflection on what is and what could be.

I don't think the idea of a 20,000 person party is bad...I've heard first-hand 
accounts from the "old days" in England of good parties.  However, this isn't 
the "old days"...economies of scale and the influx of dealers who are after a 
buck rather than providing a service for their friends appear to make the good 
huge party an impossibility in San Francisco.

I did go to a good very large party, in January at Area 51.  That wasn't 20,000 
people, though!

Laura

In some cases people aren't aware of the dangers of over-use and in
others they pooh-pooh it, it's kind of hard to imagine a bad trip if
you haven't been on one, I guess.

But I'll certainly agree that there needs to be more awareness of the
issues and risks, which probably means overall somewhat less consumption.
And in cases like crystal, a consumption line diminishing toward zero iun
our scene would be very welcome.

phred

i'm not sure what it is about milk that makes it delete an acid trip, i'm 
not even sure if it works for everyone... given the responses to my 
message. all i know is that once i was dosed and a glass of hot chocolate 
was enough to bring me completely off the trip... even though i tried my 
damndest to stop that from happening. i also know that a friend of mine 
was in the middle of an intensely bad trip, which he told me was an 
inescapable deja-vu of a nightmare he had had, and when he was forced to 
drink to glasses of milk by another friend, he slowly but surely came out 
of it and was trippin no more. i wish i could tell you if rice dream or 
other types of "milk" would work, but since i don't know how exactly it 
all works i can't answer that.

Subject: Re: Bad Acid Trips

             <199510022338.QAA15338@peseta.ucdavis.edu> 
Date: Mon, 02 Oct 95 17:33:36 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> naive.  Since I had little or no thought control at the time as soon as I
> started to think the world into existance, some thought about colors brought
> up another thought of the "Windows" color scheme "Hotdog Stand".

Now that's a bad trip! Good thing you didn't imagine lil faerie Bill
Gates gnome-entities running around you... 

Hell, I'd take being mummified in a pyramid over that any day!

I too once said the same things that you said, didn't partake for over
2 years, but came back to it eventually, with greater care and respect
than before -- just like a mountain climber needs to go back and climb
once more after taking a bad fall.

Guidelines:
	(1) don't take it because you just want to stay awake after getting
	    too little sleep the night before.
	(2) don't mix it with anything until after you're done peaking.
	(3) don't ever do more than one hit. (unless you're trying for
	    consecutive days, however, note that this violates rule #1)
	(4) do not take it to escape. find your center, feel centered, then
            take it. if you take it to escape, the thing you're trying to
	    escape from may well "haunt you from beyond the grave"...
	(5) take it somewhere where you feel comfortable, with people you
	    feel comfortable with, and they feel comfortable with you.

basically, if just the thought of taking it doesn't give you a slight
butterfly of apprehension in your stomach (or wherever your butterfly
may flitter), you probably aren't giving it the seriousness it deserves.

You wrote: 

> as soon as I started to think the world into existance, some thought  
> about colors brought up another thought of the "Windows" color scheme 
> "Hotdog Stand".  
 
	;') Sorry, this was an obviously serious post, but the above 
	quote really cracked me up.

	And so the post isn't a complete waste of space, here's what
	I think on the subject.

	I've had an experience similar, though perhaps not quite as 
	dramatic as the one you outlined. A combination of environment, 
	general state of mind, and being dosed without my knowledge led 
	to one of the more unpleasant evenings of my life.

	This was the only time for me that I've been unable to say to 
	myself, its only a drug, in a couple of hours everything will 
	be ok, and slowly pull myself back to reality. At that time 
	the drug experience became reality; it controlled me, it scared
	me, and although in a milder form, it lasted for several days.

	Maybe it is a question of weak will, self control - but I'd 	
	never before, or ever since, experienced anything quite like 	
	that...	

	Gary

From: scary@ix.netcom.com (Gary Burns )
Subject: Graffiti for the soul.
To: SFRAVES@HYPERREAL.COM
Sender: owner-sfraves@HYPERREAL.COM
Precedence: bulk


	Not really rave related, but still...

	I spent Friday night walking around San Francisco. We were 
	supposed to be going out to have some food, maybe have a 
	drink, but the bulk of the night ended up being spent walking 
	around, enjoying the night.

	Maybe somewhere near the misson, I don't know the city that
	well, we look down and see a mess of white lines all over 
	the pavement - straight, but not really shaped as such.

	Looking closer, you notice that the shadows from surrounding
	objects have boundaries that fall across the lines - parking
	meters, the bridge overhead, a fence - they're all outlined
	in white paint. Not completely, that would be too obvious,
	but just enough so you can be sure if you notice it. 

	From the looks of it, the people that do this come out at 
	different times, there's too much outline for one set of 
	shadows. I got to wondering if people do this all over the 
	city, or if I stumbled across the only occurence.
	
	I love intelligent graffiti,
	Gary

From: FREE AND FALL AND LoVE AND LoW <madox@netcom.com>

			    The Oakland Tribune


		      Medics on move after wild party

		    Bad acid trips at all-night bash put
		       16 revelers in area hospitals

				By Cecily Burt
				Staff Writter

Oakland - Some bad acid trips during a throbbing, all-night dance party 
at the Henry J. Kaiser Convention Center kept paramedics and hospitals 
rooms working overtime late Saturday and early Sunday.

American Medical Response field supervisor Patrick Chellew said AMR 
paramedics transported 16 people to area hospitals, starting with two 
disoriented women who were found lying in the middle of the street around 
11 p.m. Saturday.

It didn't stop until 7:30 a.m. Sunday.

"Every 15 or 20 minutes we'd get another call," Chellew said.  "After the 
fourth or fifth, we sent a unit down there and set up.  We stayed there 
all night long.  I peeked inside and a core group of 5,000 or 6,000 
stayed until 5 a.m. at least, just dancing, dancing, dancing"

The Cyberfest event, an indoor-outdoor, multi-stage extraganza at the 
10th Street location, drew about 20,000 people ages 16 and up, police said.

Participants had their choice of sensory pleasures:  Holograms and laser 
light shows, a tour of Erotic City, chill zones, tribal drum dancers, 
interactive videos, and a raging fun zone with wild rides.  

At least 4 themed music stages blasted out funk, hip hop, techno acid 
house and tribal drums.  There was something for everyone, even those 
that didn't want it - like neighbors who weren't at the party.

According to a flier advertising the event, alcohol was served, along 
with a variety of "smart" vitamin drinks.  The party might have been 
fine, but some people took LSD and many of the trips turned sour, medical 
authorities said Sunday. 

The party was produced by Cool World Productions.  Tickets were $20 in 
advance through BASS, and $25 at the door.

A man who answered the phone at Cool World Productions said Sunday it was 
a peaceful event, and reports of the drug overdoses were overblown.

But Chellew said he saw what he saw.

"It made an impact on the system, a big impact," he said.  "Many of these 
cases had to be put in restraints because they were hysterical or combative.
It took several minutes to deal with each person."

Nel Morning, a supervisor at Highland Hospital, said 10 or 11 people from 
the party ended up in the hospital, too scared and too high to come down 
on their own.

The last patient checked out at 2:30 p.m. Sunday when his family came to 
pick him up, she said.

"(LSD overdoses) can be pretty serious," Morning said. "I mean, if you're 
out of your head, you can do some bizarre things."

In the middle of the festivities, one man had to be restrained and taken 
to the hospital after he shed all his clothes and tried to bite off a 
woman's belly button ring, Chellew said.

The man scraped his stomach when the woman knocked him down.

Organizers had obtained a permit and Oakland police were aware of the 
event, unlike some word-of-mouth events that are held locally in empty 
warehouses. But nobody was totally prepared for the huge turnout, and it 
ended up being a very long night, authorities said.

Stragglers still wandered the streets around Lake Merritt and the BART 
station after the party finally ended and the police and paramedics left 
about 7:30 a.m. There were no reports of violence, aside from the people 
who overdosed and had to be restrained.  A police officer injured his 
hand trying to controll one person.

Several neighbors called the police to complain about the throbbing, 
pulsating music, and the trash left behind was a sight to behold.

"It was incredible," Chellew said.  "I've never seen anything like it."

Well for the record, Im damn proud of being a Raver (and more so for being an
SF Raver).  Iv'e tripped many-a-time and quite a few alone.  Yes, It's true
that our kind have a stigma as a counterculture clan that the media explotes
as drug-ridden kids that dance all night on drugs.  We must accept this, yet
educate thoes that are introduced to the scene that theres a lot more to it.
 the enegry, the vibe.  The love and respct for each other.  I'd say 4 out of
every 5 events I go to i'm NOT on anything because the vibe itself keeps me
up... When I have a friend that's curious about A or E or whatever, I warn
them.  The trip is ususally long and how you feel inside WILL effect your
excursions.  Call me a druggie, scum, or whatever you wish...  but I will let
it be known, I wear my SFRaves badge with pride wherever I go...


Adam

futon. I find that: 'Aphex Twins: Selected Ambient Works Volume II' does 
the trick. I can't remember where I got it, but I don't think you would 
have a problem finding it;), JUST GET IT!!!

Subject: More Trip Tips
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 2 Oct 1995 21:52:34 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 1298      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Neils gave some "trip tips" in a recent post:
> 
> Guidelines:
> 	(1) don't take it because you just want to stay awake after getting
> 	    too little sleep the night before.
> 	(2) don't mix it with anything until after you're done peaking.
> 	(3) don't ever do more than one hit. (unless you're trying for
> 	    consecutive days, however, note that this violates rule #1)
> 	(4) do not take it to escape. find your center, feel centered, then
>             take it. if you take it to escape, the thing you're trying to
> 	    escape from may well "haunt you from beyond the grave"...
> 	(5) take it somewhere where you feel comfortable, with people you
> 	    feel comfortable with, and they feel comfortable with you.
> 
> basically, if just the thought of taking it doesn't give you a slight
> butterfly of apprehension in your stomach (or wherever your butterfly
> may flitter), you probably aren't giving it the seriousness it deserves.
> 
  I'd like to add:
        (6) have a watch , or some access to a reliable timepiece. If things
            get bad , you can check the time and repeat this little mantra
            to yourself - "I'll be OK by %%%%" , where %%%% is 7 hours after
            you took the last dose. Gives you a goal and some hope.

  Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

Message-Id: <199510030529.AA13999@mail.crl.com>
From: davidmin@crl.com (David Minuk)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: EXtrA:  SF Raver Freaks Out at Cyberfest
Date: Tue, 03 Oct 1995 05:23:37 GMT
X-Mailer: Forte Agent .99b.112
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

(OAKLAND) - SF Raver David Arthur Minuk, 33, has confessed to going to
a Cool World event and having a good time.  The party, an all-night
"rave" concert, featured loud dance music, a psychedelic light show,
and exotically clad dancers.
     "First off, if anyone says they saw me dancing to Steve Masters
playing "Cotton Eyed Joe" in Erotic City 2000, IT'S A DAMNED LIE!!!"
Minuk said.  Erotic City was a room given over to alcohol sales at the
otherwise alcohol-free party.  Some sources have indicated that
illegal drugs such as LSD and Ecstacy may have been consumed that
night.  "I didn't do anything, [I] just went to experience the
hugeness of it all and have a good time.  Yeah, [it] looked like some
people were on drugs, mainly acid, it didn't seem like too many people
were on speed."
     "You see, I won these tickets on the radio.  The last
Cyberfestation was a near-fiasco due to lack of water.  And I heard
about other Cool Worlds where all hell broke loose.  I wanted to go
mainly to check out the out of town DJs which are scarce in this town.
I knew they'd have a good sound system.  Sure enough, when I  got
there at 8 to pick up the tickets, the outdoor PA was already pumpin'.
The sound system was adequate, two four foot stacks, but for the
people there could have been louder - maybe if they used another pair
of stacks.  Well, they were outdoors.  The sound inside was better.
Two twelve foot stacks, and just enough echo for that big-rave sound."
     "When I got there, I gave my other ticket to a friend who was
spare changing trying to get in.  I immediately headed for the outdoor
system, where Tony [a Disk Jockey] was coming on.  The vibe was pretty
good, some responded to eye contact, some didn't.  Occasionally a huge
train of teenagers would barge into the center of the floor, dance for
a while, then leave.  Not much circle dancing, though.  I danced
through most of Tony's set, then headed past the carnival rides into
the Henry J."
     "Inside, there were a few vendors in the hallway, a first aid
station and snack bars but no corporate sponsorship.   The final funk
bands in the main room were wrapping it up for the night.  While they
finished, I took a peek into "Erotic City."  When I had my fill of
cheese, I proceeded back outside.  Behind the outdoor system, along
the "Meditation Lake" (actually Oakland Estuary), there were tents and
a chill area with blankets and mattresses."
    "By now, the place was packed, inside and out[Police sources put
the attendance at some 20,000].  The sheer size of the crowd
discouraged milling around, as moving was quite difficult and
time-consuming.  I headed for the Motha Ship, the room devoted to
hip-hop.  There was very little decoration here.  The attitude was
chill as most people stood watching some breakdancers, who were quite
skilled.  It wasn't competitive, as they would applaud each other in
turn."
     "Back in the main room, two MCs were firing the crowd up with
some cheesy chatter.  Then Armand Van Heldon played some rather
jarring trance containing some urban-style noises.  I was tired, so as
I often do, I left around 4."
     "I liked it.  It was great to see so many people dancing and
having a good time.  It was inclusive, cross-cultural,  non-elitist
and all-American.  Is this the future of rave in America?  To
mainstream society, Cool World *is* rave.  We all have a stake in what
happens next.  If you think you can do a better job throwing a big
party, go ahead and try."

I'll see some of you at Splish - I'm thinking of bringing out the
dreaded purple velour running suit...

David

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Oct  2 23:06:47 1995

From: Sindar@aol.com
Received: by mail04.mail.aol.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id CAA12758 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Tue, 3 Oct 1995 02:06:11 -0400
Date: Tue, 3 Oct 1995 02:06:11 -0400

Subject: Re: Bad Acid @ Richmond? 
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

So all of the freaks are coming out of the wood work to tell there tales huh?
 Well  being a major freak myself I guess I should tell a little from my
experience.  

I always loved LSD (still do) and always handled it better than most.  I was
always in control even when I was not.  This was my first mistake.  I ended
up one night wondering how I got to the hospital and where did every one
went.  I guess the police report that I saw later on helped fill in some of
the gaps but let me tell you police reports are not very pretty.  =o)

Im so glad we are having this discussion because it is really important.  I
know I never believed it could happen to me and to make it worse I was
considered by everyone I knew to be the least likely for something bad to
happen to me on LSD.  Well I always like to learn the hard way but I think
this is one lesson I would rather not repeat.  

I took an unknown amount of liquid (5-20 hits) thinking I was doing one hit.
 Well I got too far out in my own little world with the wrong people around
me.  If you have ever seen Altered States the movie then you know what I
ended up like.  I was primal man fighting for survival...  unfortunately this
does not work well in an apartment =o)  I'll spare you all the details but if
you are really interested e me privately and we can trade dirty details =o)
 because that is not really what is important.  

What is important is what I learned.  One thing I learned is that LSD is VERY
FUCKING POWERFUL.  It is so powerful that if you take enough you can loose
control no matter how smart, stable or experienced you are.  When it comes
down to it you can not beat chemistry by thinking positive thoughts. IMHO  

I will also echo previous statements about making sure you are really
emotionally and mentally ready to deal with the experience.  I'm sure some of
the difficult times I was having with some people who were very close to me
had something to do with it even though it was not in the front of my mind.  

It is also very important that you take anything strong in an environment
where you can feel like you have some control.  If things do start to go bad
it is really important that you can control your relevant safety.  The
control might be something as little as being able to call a friend if you
need to or being able to have a place to walk to where you can be safe and
alone if need be.  Of course having the right people around is very important
also but sometimes if you really have a full blown paranoia attack brought on
by too much LSD even good friends can become scary.  

I would like to find out what form of LSD these people took.  I have a theory
that liquid LSD is not always available because it really does cause trouble.
 It's kinda like the China White thing...  people do not realize the potency
because they are not used to it.  It is also very difficult to accurately
quantize the dosage of liquid LSD out side of lab conditions.  I know the
same month I had my experience a couple of my friends also had ODs on liquid.
 I know there is some liquid going around right now and I would be interested
to find out if the people who ODed did it on liquid.  

OK enough of my babbling...  My main point is that even after all that LSD is
still a very good thing but needs to be taken seriously and treated with
respect.  It can provide some of the best experiences (IMO) that drugs have
to offer but it can also provide some of the most terrifying.

> 
> But anyway, between massive flyering, advertising on *at least* Live 105, and 
> selling tickets through Bass (or was it Ticketron, or are they one and the same 
> now?) this party got a LOT of promotion and exposure in circles where people 
> don't usually listen to house or techno, and where people might not have any 
> raver friends.  The idea of a rave appealed to 20,000 people for whatever reason
> (maybe for some it was the "21-and-over-bar-tent"), so they came out to the 
> party.  It does boggle the mind, though.
> 
> Imagine how cool it would have been if it had been 20,000 people, fabulous 
> mind-opening music, and no "bad acid."  That could have been amazing...but 
> concern for pleasing (pacifying?) that large a group and for making a profit (by
> those who were peddling crap chemicals) resulted in something that rave-purists 
> consider a pale reflection on what is and what could be.
> 
> I don't think the idea of a 20,000 person party is bad...I've heard first-hand 
> accounts from the "old days" in England of good parties.  However, this isn't 
> the "old days"...economies of scale and the influx of dealers who are after a 
> buck rather than providing a service for their friends appear to make the good 
> huge party an impossibility in San Francisco.
> 
> I did go to a good very large party, in January at Area 51.  That wasn't 20,000 
> people, though!

In-Reply-To: <951002214930_34925950@mail02.mail.aol.com>

Dear ADam;

	I agree with Adam, even though I don't do psychodelics anymore.

	According to Dr. Timothy Leary every social revolution, has had a
counterculture drug;(ours being E, with L.S.D being a close 2nd), new forms
of music, and new belief systems assoicated with it. Ours having the
additions of some major techological developments; that are changing the
way we do and use basic services, communicate, and view our world & it's
cultures; starting to become common place. An example being the
proliferation of computers in the home, that have access to the Internet. 

	But back to L.S.D, and more specifically, the last trip I had,
which was a bad one. Yet before it, I had hundreds of great, fantastic,
mind expanding really fun trips, that bonded me forever with my fellow
participents. Does that mean people shouldn't do acid, or does it mean
that I shouldn't do acid, the answer is neither. There are no should
or shouldn't, just choices.  

	My experience with acid, was the more I did, the more intense the
visual stuff was, not the weirder. For example I would do 3 hits say, and
pass my hand in front of my face. I would then see say 6 sets of hand
trails. Where as if I did say 10 or 15 hits, I would see 17 sets of hand
trails, and things wouldn't have to move anymore for trails to come of
them. 

	Today, I CHOSE not to do acid cause I don't like being that
fragile, and so supseptable to a world which is both unpredictable, and
unfortuately often not a pretty place. Today I will not let another's
ungliness have so much control over my mind & soul. Even at a rave I've
seen and experienced things that would be unspeakable, and would have
shattered me if I'd been on L.S.D. 

	I however have never experienced the sypmtoms mentioned at
Cyberpuss, nor seen them, while on LSD, or with people who were. My
opinion is that, it sounds more like Special K is the colbrit here. As
many of you know I come from Florida, land of Killer MDA/MDMA mixtures,
more N2O than you could ever possibly do, more cocaine that I don't
understand why people do, and yes Special K, the breakfast of the totally
fucked. Yes, I LOVE SF, but ravers in Florida, would put any but, the most
robust SFRAver under the table. I have heard, and seen friends that have had
MORE BAD experiences with this drug, than good ones. So does that mean you
shouldn't take it, no, for you could have an experience that utterly
changes your life in a positive way(unlikely), or puts you in a mental 
hospital for the rest of your life(also unlikey).

	I have often seen friends, go into what ravers in Florida called
"The K Hole", where the person/self is more, but usually less there,
confused, frighten, disorientened, requiring almost constant attention,
and a quiet friendly face environment, definately not the multiple,
constant, & vibeless, stimuli that Cyberfuck offered. When I asked people
in Florida about the drug most of them said "Brian it's a REALLY 
TWISTED/WEIRD high.", and that was enough for me not to try it.

	The sypmtoms mentioned are associated with Special K overdose or
toxicity, and I would be interested in hearing how old the people were who
had a bad time, how much drug experience they had, and whether or not this
susbstance was indeed a liquid or not. 

	Special K does come in liquid form from the pharmacy and often,
but not always gets cooked down to a white power, for ease of dosage
adminstration and transportation. For if these were either first time acid
users, and or just plain naive people, then doing either acid, bad acid,
or god forbid Special K, or even worst multiple drugs, at an event like
Cyberweird, where you could lose the person next to you in a wink of an
eye. 

	Then I would say extremely poor judgement was either exerised, or
extremely poor informtaion was provided to the first time user, or the
drugs themselves were bad, or not what they where sold as. Or all of the 
above.

	But of course we will never know the truth, we can only do what were 
doing here and try and make some sense outta all the data, real, & false 
provided. 

	Somebody asked what you give people who are freaking out, violent 
or psycotic. You give them drugs found in the nueroleptic, major 
tranquilizer family, drugs like, Melarill, Thorazize, ...etc 

	You can't even crack a smile on these drugs, and they are not fun
to do, PLEASE TRUST ME ON THIS ONE, I will save you the 8 hours of walking
around like you can't move any of your joints(that's the thorazie shuffle
that Joey Ramone talks about), or care if they were about to, or were to
torture you.  It's not care free, it's just like no external stimuli has
any effect on you, even in 5 points restraits.

	But again it's about choices, knowing your street stuff, and as
Clint Eastwood put it so well, Every man(womyn, human) needs to know
his(their) limitations. 

	But some friendly advice for the uninformed, and curious, if your
gonna do it, do it around and in an environment which is both friendly,
controllable by you, or someone you trust, around people you trust, and
like, especially if it's your first time. Also before you do it, and while
your doing it, talk with that intellect that's firmly grounded in reality
that most of us have, and say to yourself, especially if YOUR INTERPRETING
THAT BAD THINGS ARE HAPPENING, that in # hours I will feel much
differently than I do know. Also, that I'm about to do a drug that will
twist what I interpret as reality, and I should expect fun, strange,
wonderful, weird things to happen to me, but they will not hurt me cause
thay are not real. Also, that I will get through this, it's only a
temporary drug. Say it as many times as your need to, have others
constantly reasure you that you gonna be fine. 

	That's what I did, and once I got my LSD legs, & HUD(Heads Up
Display), I was more than find to venture forth into more unpredictable,
public spaces. In fact once this level of confidence was established, you
couldn't keep me insidem a room with four walls.

	USE YOUR HEAD, DON"T LOSE IT

		 Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		  a.k.a. Brian DarknEs^2, LMT/EE/CET

I start off by agreeing with Niels, Cool World sounded like a bad trip from
the get go. I have yet to here anything possitive about these partys. David
gave it a good try, some people can see a silver lining behind every cloud.
 As far as the substance of concern is involved, I will state my personal
opinion that inanimate objects such as LSD are incapable of "creating" a bad
psychological experience. The experience was created in the psyche of the
individual(s) involved in the experience. In my opinion, LSD works like a
psychological amplifier. It intensifies the current psychological experience.
A musical amplifier cannot be blamed for the music it amplifies. Nor can LSD
be blamed for the psyche it amplifies. If the DJ puts on a bad record, the
amplifier still amplifies it. If the DJ puts on an awesome record, "Pump the
volume!!!!". May all our days be like kickn grooves!!! Peace and Love!!!
   CID

On Mon, 2 Oct 1995 laural@inmark.com wrote:

> Imagine how cool it would have been if it had been 20,000 people, fabulous 
> mind-opening music, and no "bad acid."  That could have been amazing...but 
> concern for pleasing (pacifying?) that large a group and for making a profit (by
> those who were peddling crap chemicals) resulted in something that rave-purists 
> consider a pale reflection on what is and what could be.

> I don't think the idea of a 20,000 person party is bad...I've heard first-hand 
> accounts from the "old days" in England of good parties.  However, this isn't 
> the "old days"...economies of scale and the influx of dealers who are after a 
> buck rather than providing a service for their friends appear to make the good 
> huge party an impossibility in San Francisco.

You are right, about San Francisco, but back in England not just good 
parties, but GREAT parties still happen. I went to two this summer - Tribal 
Gathering 20,000+ and Glastonbury 150,000+ (admittedly this one has been 
going on for a while :) I think that the problem lies in a number of 
things, one is experience (both in throwing huge parties and handling 
"bad trips") and the other is social tolarance. I witnessed brittish 
bobbies smoking out! The atmosphere at both parties was mind blowing - 
imagine 150,000 people ( -the beer boys) partying with the sole 
intention of being blissed out!!

-MicKy Finn-

Date: Tue, 3 Oct 1995 02:48:19 -0700 (PDT)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: rave book!
Message-ID: <Pine.BSD/.3.91.951003003014.16452A-100000@value.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Best selling author Michael Crichton (Jurassic Park; The Andromeda 
Strain; Our Bodies, Ourselves) has published a new blockbuster based on 
the Sf rave scene and used Ernie, of sesame street fame, as its main 
character. In the following excerpt, from the chapter "frazzled," Ernie 
has made his way back from Paraguai and cleared his name from the 
Oaklahoma City bombings. He is now at an outdoor rave, somewhere in the 
mountains near Nevada City.....

 Ernie opened his tent and heard the sound of swishing shafron. He 
pitched his head and saw red. Red chiffron. More cloth than the 73rd 
Airborn parachuting elite.
 And in all of that, he saw him. In the middle of the cloth, coccooned in 
fashion and sheer bad taste, an sfraver. 
 "Ouch! Man, this is the last time I camp in drag! I caught my $#@ damn 
heel!" the sfraver exclaimed.
 Ernie called up"hey dude, you gotta pipe?" the raver sat down, grimmacing 
as he pulled off the "LL Bean outback" pumps. Ernie lit up a bowl, and 
passed it on. 
The stranger took a deep puff,nodding "thanks. Hey, you going on that hike?"
Ernie replied "Does a bear....."

 "Apparently so" the raver answered, two hours later. They were deeply lost, 
and had come around their first carnivore faecal sighting.
 "Man, if it's that BIG coming out, imagine what he ate. I mean, his mouth 
must be big enough to fit your whole head, though that wouldn't kill you 
righ then. Noo, it would last and last and-"
 "CUT THAT OUT!" interrupted Ernie."I don't wanna hear about bears. We're 
lost, gonna be eaten, and miss the friggin party! "
 "Relax, man. This hike is sooooo green"  observed the raver.
Ernie twisted his head around and glared. He watched the fool playing with 
a pine needle and screamed:"What are you doing? Did you drop on this hike?!"
 "yeah, didn't you? Oh hey, look, I have some more, I didn't know you 
didn't have any..."
 "ahhhh! Give me the compass. I said give me-" Ernie bellowed. Ernie 
yanked it from his hands, and suddenly realised Milton couldn't find 
North if crawled up and bit him on the"assk yourself, Ernie, why do 
you have all this anger? I mean, how often can you camp, you know, 
without missing a party, with all your friends and-" the raver tried hard. 
Not hard enough. 
 Because Ernie began to run. Very hard, and he carried away the boy's 
supplies. He hid behind a tree 100 feet away, and opened the pack. A 
koosh ball. Pop rocks. An orange. And a blinking red light.
 "toys! Toys, hahahaha! We're gonna die!" It was very hard for Ernie.
The boy caught up, confused, and gave Ernie a hug. Ernie sighed, and 
thought "The thing is going to talk again."
                                 It did.
"Wanna sticker? Uhm? I got flowers and bees and crickets and oh, flowers, 
and, and.." he stammered.
 
"what was your name again?"

"Milton. Yer Ernie. I saw you on TV.This puppet is my E-Bee, he likes to 
hike tooooo!"

Ernie stared in dismay, and processed this fact. Now he new he was 
doomed. They would be lost forever. Unless, over that ridge, big bird had 
left a clue......

(end of chapter. Courtesy of reader's digest excerpts, August 1995.)

Forwarded message:
> From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com Tue Oct  3 00:25:33 1995
Recently, CID/Begroovy@aol.com posted an analogy between LSD and a 
musical amplifier:
> 
>  As far as the substance of concern is involved, I will state my personal
> opinion that inanimate objects such as LSD are incapable of "creating" a bad
> psychological experience. The experience was created in the psyche of the
> individual(s) involved in the experience. In my opinion, LSD works like a
> psychological amplifier. It intensifies the current psychological experience.
> A musical amplifier cannot be blamed for the music it amplifies. Nor can LSD
> be blamed for the psyche it amplifies.... 
> 
 But with a music amp , if you're pegging the VU meters and distorting
horribly , or your system gets into evil self-consuming feedback , you can
reach down and turn the gain down. Taking LSD is like turning up the amp
and locking the controls away for 8 hours.

 Nice analogy otherwise, in my opinion. 

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

DEAR ALL, AND ESPECIALLY BRIAN-
READ THIS AND PASS IT ON.  IT SUMMARIZES MANY OF THE SYMPTOMS OF BAD/GOOD
TRIPS, AND MANY NEWBIES MIGHT BENEFIT GREATLY FROM IT.

BRIAN, GREAT INSIGHTS!

PEACE, LOVE, AND GOOD TRIPPING-

MATT
>Dear ADam;
>
>	I agree with Adam, even though I don't do psychodelics anymore.
>
>	According to Dr. Timothy Leary every social revolution, has had a
>counterculture drug;(ours being E, with L.S.D being a close 2nd), new forms
>of music, and new belief systems assoicated with it. Ours having the
>additions of some major techological developments; that are changing the
>way we do and use basic services, communicate, and view our world & it's
>cultures; starting to become common place. An example being the
>proliferation of computers in the home, that have access to the Internet. 
>
>	But back to L.S.D, and more specifically, the last trip I had,
>which was a bad one. Yet before it, I had hundreds of great, fantastic,
>mind expanding really fun trips, that bonded me forever with my fellow
>participents. Does that mean people shouldn't do acid, or does it mean
>that I shouldn't do acid, the answer is neither. There are no should
>or shouldn't, just choices.  
>
>	My experience with acid, was the more I did, the more intense the
>visual stuff was, not the weirder. For example I would do 3 hits say, and
>pass my hand in front of my face. I would then see say 6 sets of hand
>trails. Where as if I did say 10 or 15 hits, I would see 17 sets of hand
>trails, and things wouldn't have to move anymore for trails to come of
>them. 
>
>	Today, I CHOSE not to do acid cause I don't like being that
>fragile, and so supseptable to a world which is both unpredictable, and
>unfortuately often not a pretty place. Today I will not let another's
>ungliness have so much control over my mind & soul. Even at a rave I've
>seen and experienced things that would be unspeakable, and would have
>shattered me if I'd been on L.S.D. 
>
>	I however have never experienced the sypmtoms mentioned at
>Cyberpuss, nor seen them, while on LSD, or with people who were. My
>opinion is that, it sounds more like Special K is the colbrit here. As
>many of you know I come from Florida, land of Killer MDA/MDMA mixtures,
>more N2O than you could ever possibly do, more cocaine that I don't
>understand why people do, and yes Special K, the breakfast of the totally
>fucked. Yes, I LOVE SF, but ravers in Florida, would put any but, the most
>robust SFRAver under the table. I have heard, and seen friends that have had
>MORE BAD experiences with this drug, than good ones. So does that mean you
>shouldn't take it, no, for you could have an experience that utterly
>changes your life in a positive way(unlikely), or puts you in a mental 
>hospital for the rest of your life(also unlikey).
>
>	I have often seen friends, go into what ravers in Florida called
>"The K Hole", where the person/self is more, but usually less there,
>confused, frighten, disorientened, requiring almost constant attention,
>and a quiet friendly face environment, definately not the multiple,
>constant, & vibeless, stimuli that Cyberfuck offered. When I asked people
>in Florida about the drug most of them said "Brian it's a REALLY 
>TWISTED/WEIRD high.", and that was enough for me not to try it.
>
>	The sypmtoms mentioned are associated with Special K overdose or
>toxicity, and I would be interested in hearing how old the people were who
>had a bad time, how much drug experience they had, and whether or not this
>susbstance was indeed a liquid or not. 
>
>	Special K does come in liquid form from the pharmacy and often,
>but not always gets cooked down to a white power, for ease of dosage
>adminstration and transportation. For if these were either first time acid
>users, and or just plain naive people, then doing either acid, bad acid,
>or god forbid Special K, or even worst multiple drugs, at an event like
>Cyberweird, where you could lose the person next to you in a wink of an
>eye. 
>
>	Then I would say extremely poor judgement was either exerised, or
>extremely poor informtaion was provided to the first time user, or the
>drugs themselves were bad, or not what they where sold as. Or all of the 
>above.
>
>	But of course we will never know the truth, we can only do what were 
>doing here and try and make some sense outta all the data, real, & false 
>provided. 
>
>	Somebody asked what you give people who are freaking out, violent 
>or psycotic. You give them drugs found in the nueroleptic, major 
>tranquilizer family, drugs like, Melarill, Thorazize, ...etc 
>
>	You can't even crack a smile on these drugs, and they are not fun
>to do, PLEASE TRUST ME ON THIS ONE, I will save you the 8 hours of walking
>around like you can't move any of your joints(that's the thorazie shuffle
>that Joey Ramone talks about), or care if they were about to, or were to
>torture you.  It's not care free, it's just like no external stimuli has
>any effect on you, even in 5 points restraits.
>
>	But again it's about choices, knowing your street stuff, and as
>Clint Eastwood put it so well, Every man(womyn, human) needs to know
>his(their) limitations. 
>
>	But some friendly advice for the uninformed, and curious, if your
>gonna do it, do it around and in an environment which is both friendly,
>controllable by you, or someone you trust, around people you trust, and
>like, especially if it's your first time. Also before you do it, and while
>your doing it, talk with that intellect that's firmly grounded in reality
>that most of us have, and say to yourself, especially if YOUR INTERPRETING
>THAT BAD THINGS ARE HAPPENING, that in # hours I will feel much
>differently than I do know. Also, that I'm about to do a drug that will
>twist what I interpret as reality, and I should expect fun, strange,
>wonderful, weird things to happen to me, but they will not hurt me cause
>thay are not real. Also, that I will get through this, it's only a
>temporary drug. Say it as many times as your need to, have others
>constantly reasure you that you gonna be fine. 
>
>	That's what I did, and once I got my LSD legs, & HUD(Heads Up
>Display), I was more than find to venture forth into more unpredictable,
>public spaces. In fact once this level of confidence was established, you
>couldn't keep me insidem a room with four walls.
>
>	USE YOUR HEAD, DON"T LOSE IT
>
>		 Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
>		  a.k.a. Brian DarknEs^2, LMT/EE/CET

right in front of me, I can't imagine trying to figure out what an analog 
clock would look like.   :)

     Hi Gary!  Missed your sunny smile since BM.  Hope all is well.
     
     Are you sure you weren't tripping hard when you discovered the white 
     lines?  ;)  When I was driving home from a party early Sunday morning, 
     the music in my car was in syncopation w/the blinking red and yellow 
     street lights.  It was really beautiful to feel and see the rhythms of 
     life around me.  I wanted to create an instant video recording the 
     random rhythms that coincide w/man-made rhythms...'cause to me that's 
     what going off is all about, hitting a groove and flying with it.  
     
     Hope to see ya soon!
     
     Diane


______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: Graffiti for the soul.
Author:  scary@ix.netcom.com (Gary Burns ) at beluga-mail
Date:    10/2/95 6:38 PM


     
 Not really rave related, but still...
     
 I spent Friday night walking around San Francisco. We were 
 supposed to be going out to have some food, maybe have a 
 drink, but the bulk of the night ended up being spent walking 
 around, enjoying the night.
     
 Maybe somewhere near the misson, I don't know the city that 
 well, we look down and see a mess of white lines all over 
 the pavement - straight, but not really shaped as such.
     
 Looking closer, you notice that the shadows from surrounding 
 objects have boundaries that fall across the lines - parking 
 meters, the bridge overhead, a fence - they're all outlined 
 in white paint. Not completely, that would be too obvious, 
 but just enough so you can be sure if you notice it. 
     
 From the looks of it, the people that do this come out at 
 different times, there's too much outline for one set of 
 shadows. I got to wondering if people do this all over the 
 city, or if I stumbled across the only occurence.
     
 I love intelligent graffiti,
 Gary

Announcing the new Orbitrecords Weblink:

In an effort to promote better communication over the World Wide 
Web, Orbitrecords has completely revamped our site at Hyperreal.  
This new site is designed to be a complete communication interface 
between Orbitrecords and people around the globe.

At our Hyperreal Weblink, in addition to providing graphics, 
high-quality audio samples, and information about our artists, we 
describe how to communicate with us-- how we are able to review demo 
submissions over the net, how to contact us, and how to keep up with 
our current projects.

To: laural@inmark.com

In-Reply-To: <9509028126.AA812670022@ugate.inmark.com>

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


The idea behind the milk helping bring someone down is if it is heated 
thus releasing the chemical tryptophane which is supposed to help 
counteract the effects of the hallucinogen in question. Not sure if it 
works or not I've heard this claim from people for whom it has been useful.

In general I have compassion for those folks who had these megadose 
trips.It's not an easy thing. If psychedelics didn't have such an 
irrational taboo surrounding them it would be easier to disseminate 
useful information and try to cultivate spaces for appropriate use. 
Instead of fretting about people's lack of judgement and prudence we 
should do the best we can to promote education. It is obvious that the 
rave scene is ready for a more intelligent evolution but this must be in 
concert with other social and cultural tranceformations.

Best Regards,
Ronan
