On Tue, 3 Oct 1995, D. Ronan Hallowell wrote:

> In general I have compassion for those folks who had these megadose 
> trips.It's not an easy thing. If psychedelics didn't have such an 
> irrational taboo surrounding them it would be easier to disseminate 
> useful information and try to cultivate spaces for appropriate use. 
> Instead of fretting about people's lack of judgement and prudence we 
> should do the best we can to promote education. It is obvious that the 
> rave scene is ready for a more intelligent evolution but this must be in 
> concert with other social and cultural tranceformations.
> 
> Best Regards,
> Ronan

It's rather a chicken and egg thing, isn't it? If people exercised good 
judgement, we wouldn't have to worry about educating the ignorant, 
because they would have had enough sense to find out what the hell they 
were getting themselves into before playing with the proverbial fire, and 
wouldn't be ignorant. Just a thought....

                                           Black Adder

--- Forwarded Message from Gretchen T. Saegh ---

>Date: 03 Oct 95 14:18:23 EDT
>From: Gretchen T. Saegh
>Subject: virus alert
>To: Elizabeth S. Reder, Kristin M. Sadlon, Lauren@wpi.edu, MSaegh@eworld.com,
begley_larry@bcg.com

Subject: VIRUSES -- IMPORTANT PLEASE READ IMMEDIATELY (fwd)


>> >There is a computer  virus that is being sent  across the Internet.  If you
>> >receive an e-mail message with the subject  line "Good Times", DO NOT read
>> >the
>> >message, DELETE  it immediately.  Please read the messages below.
>> >
>> >Some miscreant is sending e-mail under the title "good times" nation-wide.
>>If
>> >
>> >you get anything  like this, DON'T DOWN LOAD THE FILE!  It has a virus that
>> >rewrites your hard drive, obliterating anything on it.  Please be careful
>>and
>> >
>> >forward this mail to anyone you care about--I have.
>> >
>> >*********************Forwarded Message****************************
>> >
>> >WARNING!!!!!!!!!: INTERNET VIRUS
>> >
>> >
>> >The FCC released a warning last Wednesday  concerning  a matter  of major
>> >importance to any regular  user of the InterNet.  Apparently, a new
computer
>> >
>> >virus has been engineered by  a user of America Online that  is
unparalleled
>> >in
>> >its destructive capability.  Other, more well-known viruses such as Stoned,
>> >Airwolf, and Michaelangelo pale in comparison
>> >to the prospects of this newest creation by a warped mentality.
>> >
>> >What  makes  this virus so terrifying, said the FCC, is the fact that  no
>> >program needs to be exchanged for a new computer  to be infected.  It can
be
>> >spread through the existing e-mail systems of the InterNet.  Once a
computer
>> >is
>> >infected, one of several things can happen.  If the  computer contains a
>>hard
>> >
>> >drive, that will most likely  be destroyed.   If the program is not
stopped,
>> >the
>> >computer's processor will be placed  in an nth-complexity infinite binary
>> >loop -
>> >which can severely  damage  the processor  if left running  that  way  too
>> >long.  Unfortunately, most novice  computer  users  will not  realize  what
>> > is
>> >happening  until it is far too late.
>> >
>> >Luckily, there  is one sure means  of detecting  what  is now known as the
>> >"Good
>> >Times" virus.  It always travels to new computers the same way in a text
>> > e-mail
>> >message with the subject  line  reading  simply "Good Times".
>> >
>> >Avoiding infection  is easy  once the file has been  received - not 
reading
>> >
>> >it.  The act of loading the file into the mail server's ASCII buffer causes
>> >the
>> >"Good Times" mainline program to initialize  and execute.    The program is
>> >highly  intelligent - it will send copies of itself to everyone whose
e-mail
>> >address is contained in a received-mail file  or a sent- mail file, if it
>>can
>> >
>> >find one.  It will then proceed to trash the computer it is running on.
>> >
>> >The bottom line here is - if you receive  a file with the subject  line
>>"Good
>> >
>> >Times", delete  it immediately!    Do not read it!     Rest assured that
>> >whoever's name  was on the "From:" line was surely struck by the virus.
>> >
>> >Warn your friends and local system users of this newest threat  to the
>> >InterNet!
>> >It could save them a lot of time and money.
>> >
>> >
>> >
>> >
>> >
>> >
>> >
>> >
>> >
>> >
>> >
>>
>> Mo
>>
>>
>>
>

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Oct  3 15:54:47 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id PAA07721; Tue, 3 Oct 1995 15:54:47 -0700
Received: from xinet.COM by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id PAA07713; Tue, 3 Oct 1995 15:54:42 -0700
Received: from DialupEudora by xinet.COM via SMTP (940816.SGI.8.6.9/931108.SGI.ANONFTP)
	for <sfraves@hyperreal.com> id PAA02710; Tue, 3 Oct 1995 15:54:11 -0700
Message-Id: <v02120d05ac9779f5a7a7@DialupEudora>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Tue, 3 Oct 1995 15:54:12 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: tony@xinet.COM (Tony Rotundo)
Subject: Bad acid or bad trips?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I'll be brief:

Was it bad acid at Cyberfest, or kids/adults having bad trips?  Hard to
tell.  Probably the latter.  Sounds like a huge event that could get pretty
fucking scary.  If I saw a guy strip naked and try and bite someone's belly
button ring off, I'd probably get a little freaked, even if I was sober.

I have only read a sampling of email responses to this thread, and while
remedies for bad trips are appreciated, everyone is different and what
might calm one person, could enflame another, it's all in the individual
and the individual trip that person's on.

But I gotta say people, between this thread on acid, and the last thread on X...

ENOUGH OF THE FUCKING DRUG EMPHASIS ON SF RAVES!!!

Please, I understand we all mean well, and are only looking out for one
another, but if I didn't know already that this newsgroup can share very
informative news and reviews on raves in San Francisco and abroad (and
maybe even some good stories about particular experiences), then I would
unsubscribe immediately thinking it was just a bunch of druggies sharing
war stories.

Raving, in my oppinion and heart is not about drugs but about music and
people and understanding and a whole hell of a lot more than a trip.  Good
or bad!

Thanks for listening,

Tony


P.S.  I emplore you, before you send a message to SF Raves, or reply to
"all", please think about what you're saying and ask yourself if it is
pertinent to just one person you are agreeing with/disagreeing with, or the
whole group.

Mijos, tanks to Black Adder and Dave Bayer's help, we are online (again). 
"We" does not mean I am possessed by Legion, no, "we" means this account is 
shared by me (Milton), Joy (my better half) and that ubiquitous E-Bee. I 
met Joy at Vision this year, in a pink tu-tu and a rubber fish ( she 
forgave me).
 We will both use the same account, so direct all flames to the correct 
author, or any positive messages. I don't wanna have to excuse myself to 
her anymore than I already do:) 
 My return to SFR as well as to parties was caused by my receiving some 
(heh, heh) good news about a recent development in our scene. That's a 
teaser, I'll rant and rave about it later, but if you know me, you can 
bet your shell account it's about this coming Sunday (hmmm, whazzup?). 
 Joy is new to SFR and is waiting for something worthy to post about. 
I suggested some Zippie haiku, but she declined, so here's mine:
 Project to the infinite

 Find the rise
 Return that overdue book.

-- [ From: Emily Robbins * EMC.Ver #2.5.02 ] --

This virus warning circulated around my office a few months ago (and OF
COURSE I then forwarded it to everyone I knew - and then some...) but,
surprise surprise, the whole thing is a hoax so don't worry about it.  If
you're interested, (don't trust me?) below are the 2 responses to the virus
ordeal which had been forwarded to me.  One is from Borland's IS dept, the
2nd is what's known as ' the "offical" report on the "Good Times" virus from
the DOE's Computer Security group.'  
Have a good one!
Emily

---BEGIN 1st INCLUDED MSG--
Viruses cannot ride on email or .txt files. You can only get 'em from
downloading executables or trading diskettes.  If there's a binary
attachment on a mail, you could become infected by running it, but not by
just opening a mail message.

Particularly like "Other, more well-known viruses such as Stoned, Airwolf,
and Michelangelo pale in comparison to the prospects of this newest creation
by a warped mentality."  Such verbiage.

Here are the main things we can do to prevent virus infections at Borland:

1.  Scan every diskette that you receive before you use it.  Always scan any
binaries you download from any source.  

2.  Backup your hard drive on a regular basis.  This will minimize data loss
caused by viruses.

3.  Attached is the latest scan and vshield software if you are concerned
please unzip the file read the accompanying .txt files and install it
properly on your systems.  Help others in the company do the same.

4.  Report any virus infection directly to xxxxx.

5.  Please do not send out department or company-wide mail regarding virus
scares.  This will only causes undue panic and confusion.  Most common
viruses are easy to deal with and are not a cause for hysteria.  We will
notify Borland personnel of virus concerns as necessary.

Thank You for your patience and cooperation
The IS Department

--BEGIN 2nd INCLUDED MSG--

>Date: Wed, 19 Apr 1995 08:09:31 -0500
>From: Toni Schulenburg <toni@ACCESS.TEXAS.GOV>
>To: Multiple recipients of list ASIS-L
>     <ASIS-L%UIUCVMD.BITNET@uga.cc.uga.edu>
>Subject: Re: Virus Alert
>
>>Date: Wed, 19 Apr 1995 07:56:04 -0600 (CST)
>>From: Ed Stuart <ES12453@swt.edu>
>>Subject: Already Knew About "Good Times"
>>To: toni@access.texas.gov
>>Organization: Southwest Texas State University

>>    Here's the "offical" report on the "Good Times" virus from the DOE's

>>
>>
>>              U.S. DOE's Computer Incident Advisory Capability
>>           ___  __ __    _     ___           __  __ __   __   __

>>Number 94-04c                                               December 8,
1994
>>
>>Welcome to the fourth issue of CIAC Notes!  This is a special edition to
>>clear up recent reports of a "good times" virus-hoax.  Let us know if you
>>have topics you would like addressed or have feedback on what is useful
and
>>what is not.  Please contact the editor, Allan L. Van Lehn, CIAC,
>>510-422-8193 or send E-mail to ciac@llnl.gov.
>>
>>  $-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$
>>  $ Reference to any specific commercial product does not necessarily   $
>>  $ constitute or imply its endorsement, recommendation or favoring by  $
>>  $ CIAC, the University of California, or the United States Government.$
>>  $-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$
>>
>>THE "Good Times" VIRUS IS AN URBAN LEGEND
>>
>>In the early part of December, CIAC started to receive information
requests
>>about a supposed "virus" which could be contracted via America OnLine,
simply
>>by reading a message.  The following is the message that CIAC received:
>>
>> -------------------------------------------------------------------------
--
>>| Here is some important information. Beware of a file called Goodtimes.  
 |
>>|                                                                         
 |
>>|  Happy Chanukah everyone, and be careful out there. There is a virus on 
 |
>>| America Online being sent by E-Mail.  If you get anything called "Good  
 |
>>| Times", DON'T read it or download it.  It is a virus that will erase
your |
>>| hard drive.  Forward this to all your friends.  It may help them a lot. 
 |
>> -------------------------------------------------------------------------
--
>>
>>THIS IS A HOAX.  Upon investigation, CIAC has determined that this message
>>originated from both a user of America Online and a student at a
university
>>at approximately the same time, and it was meant to be a hoax.
>>
>>CIAC has also seen other variations of this hoax, the main one is that any
>>electronic mail message with the subject line of "xxx-1" will infect your
>>computer.
>>
>>This rumor has been spreading very widely.  This spread is due mainly to
the
>>fact that many people have seen a message with "Good Times" in the header.
>>They delete the message without reading it, thus believing that they have
>>saved themselves from being attacked. These first-hand reports give a
false
>>sense of credibility to the alert message.
>>
>>There has been one confirmation of a person who received a message with
>>"xxx-1" in the header, but an empty message body.  Then, (in a panic,
because
>>he had heard the alert), he checked his PC for viruses (the first time he
>>checked his machine in months) and found a pre-existing virus on his
machine.
>> He incorrectly came to the conclusion that the E-mail message gave him
the
>>virus (this particular virus could NOT POSSIBLY have spread via an E-mail
>>message).  This person then spread his alert.
>>
>>As of this date, there are no known viruses which can infect merely
through
>>reading a mail message.  For a virus to spread some program must be
executed.
>>Reading a mail message does not execute the mail message.  Yes, Trojans
have
>>been found as executable attachments to mail messages, the most notorious
>>being the IBM VM Christmas Card Trojan of 1987, also the TERM MODULE Worm
>>(reference CIAC Bulletin B-7) and the GAME2 MODULE Worm (CIAC Bulletin B-
12).
>> But this is not the case for this particular "virus" alert.
>>
>>If you encounter this message being distributed on any mailing lists,
simply
>>ignore it or send a follow-up message stating that this is a false rumor.
>>
>>Karyn Pichnarczyk
>>CIAC Team
>>ciac@llnl.gov
>>
>>
>>------------------------------
>>
>>WHO IS CIAC?
>>
>>CIAC is the U.S. Department of Energy's Computer Incident Advisory
>>Capability.  Established in 1989, shortly after the Internet Worm, CIAC
>>provides various computer security services free of charge to employees
>>and contractors of the DOE, such as: Incident Handling consulting,
Computer
>>Security Information, On-site Workshops, White-hat Audits.
>>
>>CIAC is located at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory and is a part of
>>its Computer Security Technology Center.  CIAC is also a founding member
of
>>FIRST, the Forum of Incident Response and Security Teams, a global
>>organization established to foster cooperation and coordination among
>>computer security teams worldwide.
>>
>>CONTACTING CIAC
>>
>>If you require additional assistance or wish to report a vulnerability,
call
>>CIAC at 510-422-8193, fax messages to 510-423-8002 or send E-mail to
>>ciac@llnl.gov.
>>
>> ------------------- A - T - T - E - N - T - I - O - N -------------------
--
>>| For emergencies and off-hour assistance, CIAC is available 24-hours a
day |
>>| to DOE and DOE contractors via an integrated voicemail and SKYPAGE
number.|
>>| To use this service, dial 1-510-422-8193 or 1-800-759-7243 (SKYPAGE).
The |
>>| primary SKYPAGE PIN number, 8550070 is for the CIAC duty person. A
second |
>>| PIN, 8550074 is for the CIAC Project Leader.  Keep these numbers handy. 
 |
>> -------------------------------------------------------------------------
--
>>
>>CIAC's ELECTRONIC PUBLICATIONS
>>
>>Previous CIAC Bulletins and other information are available via anonymous
>>FTP from ciac.llnl.gov.
>>
>>CIAC has several self-subscribing mailing lists for electronic
publications:
>>1.  CIAC-BULLETIN for Advisories, highest priority - time critical
>>    information, and Bulletins, important computer security information;
>>2.  CIAC-NOTES for Notes, a collection of computer security articles;
>>3.  SPI-ANNOUNCE for official news about Security Profile Inspector (SPI)
>>    software updates, new features, distribution and availability;
>>4.  SPI-NOTES, for discussion of problems and solutions regarding the use
of
>>    SPI products.
>>
>>Our mailing lists are managed by a public domain software package called
>>ListProcessor, which ignores E-mail header subject lines. To subscribe 
(add
>>yourself) to one of our mailing lists, send requests of the following form
:
>>
>>subscribe list-name LastName, FirstName PhoneNumber
>>
>>as the E-mail message body, substituting CIAC-BULLETIN, CIAC-NOTES,
>>SPI-ANNOUNCE or SPI-NOTES for "list-name" and valid information for
>>"LastName" "FirstName" and "PhoneNumber."  Send to: ciac-listproc@llnl.gov
>>not to: ciac@llnl.gov
>>
>>e.g.,
>>subscribe ciac-notes O'Hara, Scarlett 404-555-1212 x36
>>subscribe ciac-bulletin O'Hara, Scarlett 404-555-1212 x36
>>
>>You will receive an acknowledgment containing address and initial PIN, and
>>information on how to change either of them, cancel your subscription, or
get
>>help.
>>
>>To subscribe an address which is a distribution list, first subscribe the
>>person responsible for your distribution list.  You will receive an
>>acknowledgment (as described above). Change the address to the
distribution
>>list by sending a second E-mail request.  As the body of this message,
>>substitute valid information for "list-name," "PIN", and "address of the
>>distribution list" when sending
>>
>>E-mail to ciac-listproc@llnl.gov:
>>        set  list-name  address  PIN  distribution_list_address
>>  e.g., set ciac-notes address 001860 remailer@tara.georgia.orb
>>
>>To be removed from a mailing list, send the following request via
>>
>>E-mail to ciac-listproc@llnl.gov:
>>        unsubscribe  list-name
>>  e.g., unsubscribe ciac-notes
>>
>>For more information, send the following request:
>>        help
>>
>>  If you have any questions about this list, you may contact the list's
owner:
>>listmanager@cheetah.llnl.gov.
>>
>>------------------------------
>>

the

Uhhh... i think this is bullshit:

>> >the
>> >computer's processor will be placed  in an nth-complexity infinite binary
>> >loop -
>> >which can severely  damage  the processor  if left running  that  way  too
>> >long.

Uhuh. Yeah right! THose damn nth complexity infinite binary loops
are just so taxing on a processor. you can almost see the little
thing sweating, and feel the humm of the chipmunks spinning the
program counter... awwwww... much worse than, say 
	0000 NOP
	0001 JMP 0000
yeah, that kind of loop is just easy living. Yea verily!

>Subject: VIRUSES -- IMPORTANT PLEASE READ IMMEDIATELY (fwd)
>
>
>>> >There is a computer  virus that is being sent  across the Internet.  If you
>>> >receive an e-mail message with the subject  line "Good Times", DO NOT read

>>> >to the prospects of this newest creation by a warped mentality.
>>> >
>>> >What  makes  this virus so terrifying, said the FCC, is the fact that  no
>>> >program needs to be exchanged for a new computer  to be infected.  It can
>be
>>> >spread through the existing e-mail systems of the InterNet.  Once a
>computer
>>> >is
>>> >infected, one of several things can happen.  If the  computer contains a
>>>hard
>>> >
>>> >drive, that will most likely  be destroyed.   If the program is not
>stopped,
>>> >the
>>> >computer's processor will be placed  in an nth-complexity infinite binary
>>> >loop -
>>> >which can severely  damage  the processor  if left running  that  way  too
>>> >long.  Unfortunately, most novice  computer  users  will not  realize  what
>>> > is
>>> >happening  until it is far too late.
>>> >
>>> >Luckily, there  is one sure means  of detecting  what  is now known as the
>>> >"Good
>>> >Times" virus.  It always travels to new computers the same way in a text
>>> > e-mail
>>> >message with the subject  line  reading  simply "Good Times".
>>> >
>>> >Avoiding infection  is easy  once the file has been  received - not 
>reading
>>> >
>>> >it.  The act of loading the file into the mail server's ASCII buffer causes
>>> >the
>>> >"Good Times" mainline program to initialize  and execute.    The program is
>>> >highly  intelligent - it will send copies of itself to everyone whose
>e-mail
>>> >address is contained in a received-mail file  or a sent- mail file, if it
>>>can
>>> >
>>> >find one.  It will then proceed to trash the computer it is running on.
>>> >
>>> >The bottom line here is - if you receive  a file with the subject  line
>>>"Good
>>> >
>>> >Times", delete  it immediately!    Do not read it!     Rest assured that
>>> >whoever's name  was on the "From:" line was surely struck by the virus.
>>> >
>>> >Warn your friends and local system users of this newest threat  to the
>>> >InterNet!
>>> >It could save them a lot of time and money.
>>> >
>>> >
>>> >
>>> >
>>> >
>>> >
>>> >
>>> >
>>> >
>>> >
>>> >
>>>
>>> Mo
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>

>From the Chron/Ex, by Arthur McMurray:

Oakland, Ca. Following the Cyberfest debacle last saturday, paramedics 
have isolated a potentially harmful virus, tentatively named "Lucidosis 
freakii" often found on perforated paper squares.
 Researches believe it is transmitted through unsanitary handling of 
blotters,  and unsavory distribution through uncertified distributors. 
Susceptibility is often linked to naivety and over-eagerness to explore 
without guidance, or just random shit.
 Francis Deck, esquire, of the Dopamine, Dopayours Institute for 
Insightful Realizations, advises: " never allow your paper to touch 
other's. Do not consume if you cannot find your ride, backpack, memory or 
the door. This virus can enhance confusion and alter perception of rubber 
fish. Very confusing, but pretty much harmless when not operating heavy 
machinery or handling change at 7-11."
 Symptoms may include sitting, bad posture, a wrinkled brow and phrases 
such as "you just said that", "I got it figured out", "you just said 
that!", and the ever present "wha-what? Oh, man, I'm #ucke$ up!".
 Researches have noted that removing clothing is NOT an antidote.

Just felt I should reprint this, for everyone's safety. 

Lotsa love (wha?What?)
     Milton and the E-Bee

Take a look at what the most people have at least 2 cents to comment on:
fanatical praise of  Sunset and drugs. Oh yeah, and talking about
themselves. This sums up 90% of the last 2 months on here. Everyone
complains about how non-ravers don't see or hear what raving is "really
about," but what choice do they have? Ravers may get a bad rap, and if all
you know is what you see, then that's all they'll ever get. Raving ain't
gonna save the world because it's too busy dosing itself into the hospital.

>> LSD is an extract from a naturally occurring substance, ergot. :)
>	
>	...i believe that lsd was syntesized by albert hoffman around 1946 
>in an attempt to create a compound identical to ergot but not an extract 
>of it...
>
>kevin just my 2 or 3 cents/mics... :)
>

"       LSD was first synthesized in 1938 by Albert Hofmann, a chemist at
the Sandoz pharmaceutical laboratories in Basel, Switzerland.  The work was
part of a systematic investigation into the properties of ergot (a rye grass
fungus) as a source of new medicines...
        Lysergic acid diethylamide was the twenty-fifth in a series of
lysergic acid derivatives.  For laboratory use, the name was abbreviated to
LSD-25.  LSD-25 was specifically created with the idea that might be a
circulatory and respiratory stimulant.  Tests showed that it stimulated
contraction of the uterus, although not as strongly as other drugs.  Sandoz
pharmacologists and physicians found nothing exceptional in these
properties, though, and testing of LSD-25 was abandoned.  Hofmann remained
interested in the drug, and in 1943 synthesized a new batch of LSD-25."

>From _LSD: Still With Us After All These Years
Edited by Leigh Henderson & William Glass, Lexington Books, 1994

From: gthanson@ix.netcom.com (Gregory Tristan Hanson)

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

OK, So I've been lurking about here for a while, and debated about 
whether to post to you all; but here it goes anyway: my belated bio...

First off, my name is Tristan (but poochie is *way* cool too).  I have 
recently moved to Sacramento from Vancouver, B.C. to take a new job.  Not 
knowing anyone in this small town, and being pretty shy admittedly, I 
find that I am working most of the time (there's *really*not*much* to do 
here anyways) which is cool for the career but thats about it.  

I'm 29 y.o. and really dig listening to the music since I hooked into it 
about a year ago or less; this, after being an industrial rat for eons.  
I have to admit, however, that I've never participated in a rave; but 
hopefully this is soon to change.  The peaceful and respectful community 
spirit and total freedom that raving seems to embody is a real turn-on 
for me.  Just reading the posts here daily really brings a smile to my 
face!  :)   You all have crafted something here that will last a very 
long time to come.

I hope to meet you all sometime and somewhere in the future and give out 
Many Merry Hugz and Greetz (tho I have no clue when because with working 
I can barely stay awake past midnight anymore--which really sucks).  

until then: later, pooch




-- 
    poochie     gthanson@ix.netcom.com     tristanh@examen.com
Many shores I have sailed to in my canoe, often against strong winds.
Choose the tree well my brother, if it is to carry you to distant shores.
       --Chief Dan George, "My Heart Soars"

a while.  All I ask is that people do a little research before blindly
forwarding stuff all over the place (not just to sfr).  This applies to 
viruses/news/rumors/mail/etc.  People shouldn't just assume since
they got an e:mail that it is true.

I have directions to Panther but I'm not sure of the exact mileage to
Panther off of Hwy 1 ( does anyone know?). 

Take 101 to 85 Gilroy
85 to 17 Santa Cruz
17 to Hwy 1 North
Look for a pile of rocks with reflective paint on them. 
Turn into the dirt "parking lot" and park yo' car.
Cross the railroad tracks on the beach side of the parking lot.
Go down the little trail (be careful the trail gets a little precarious 
at night)  then look for the crazy group of people sittin' around a fire 
making noise!

I'll  post the exact miles you have to travel on hwy 1 to get to Panther 
later today.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Oct  4 12:05:42 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id MAA25439; Wed, 4 Oct 1995 12:05:42 -0700
Received: from uclink.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id MAA25426; Wed, 4 Oct 1995 12:05:39 -0700
Received: by uclink.berkeley.edu (8.6.10/1.33(web)-OV4)
	id MAA26420; Wed, 4 Oct 1995 12:05:36 -0700
Date: Wed, 4 Oct 1995 12:05:34 -0700 (PDT)
From: Seth Joshua Horvitz <acid23@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Noise complaints
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9510041120.A17176-0100000@uclink.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello everyone,
 
First of all, is there anyone out there who has some hard facts about the laws 
concerning noise in the domestic arena (i.e. apartment buildings, etc.)?  
I know that basically the cops will not respond to noise complaints made 
between 7am and 10pm.  I think there are specific decibel levels which 
cannot be exceeded after 10pm. Does anyone know what they are?  I would 
appreciate a detailed description of these laws, if anyone would be so 
kind to provide it.  I think this info would benifit others on the list 
who live within earshot of people who are intolerant of "repetitive beats."

Now, let me explain why I have just made the above request... 
(personal information to follow- please delete if uninterested)

Two months ago, my girlfriend and I moved into an apartment building in 
Oakland.  The night after moving in, we had some friends over in the 
evening and were listening to music at a LOW level, when the upstairs 
neighbor came down and tried to offer me $20 to keep my stereo off.  He 
accused me of playing loud music for three days, when in fact we'd only 
moved in the day before.  I refused the money, but felt it was necessary 
to talk to these people and come to some sort of agreement, so that we 
wouldn't be getting on each other's nerves.  A few days later, Kristen 
(my girlfriend) and I went upstairs to talk with them.  Upon opening the 
door, the guy started pacing back and forth in the hallway, breathing 
heavily, and accusing me of blasting music 12 hours a day, when in fact, 
I had only played about 1-2 hours of music which even approached being 
loud, and only in the afternoons.  We had a very tense and tedious 
discussion with them, and came to a tentative agreement that I could play 
music loud for 2.5 hours a day, and very soft at other times (we even 
checked the levels on my stereo).  This was a big compromise on my part, 
but I didn't want to be on bad terms with anybody.  
	
About a week later, they called the landlord to complain, when in fact, I 
had not even come close to using my alloted 2.5 hours of loud music.  

Just last Friday night, we had four friends over to celebrate my 
birthday.  I had bought new records that afternoon, so I played them at a 
moderately loud level (not as loud as I had agreed on) from about 
8-10:30pm.  Then, we watched a movie, and afterwords, listened to music 
at a low level while talking.

They called the cops.  The cop was almost apologetic, realizing 
that their complaint was ridiculous.  He told us not to worry, and went 
on his way.

One hour later, they called the cops again.  When the second cop came, 
they filed a formal complaint against us, forcing us to appear in court.

Yesterday, I got home from school at 3pm with some more new records.  I 
started playing them at a moderately loud level.  FIFTEEN MINUTES LATER, the 
manager came pounding on my door, telling me that the upstairs neighbors had 
called and complained to him.

Does anyone know what I can do about this situation?  I would like to 
file a complaint of harassment against them, because this situation is 
getting ridiculuous.  The people who live below us were home ALL NIGHT 
on Friday, and were not even remotely bothered by the music, and never 
have been.  HELP ME PLEASE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

pissed,
Seth

In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9510041120.A17176-0100000@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.BSD/.3.91.951004132513.3236C-100000@get.wired.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


i had the same problem, but lost and ended up in a jail cell overnight.
if someone complains about you 3x in one evening (or day), the third time
they have the right to take you downtown, irregardless of what the
level of music may have been, or even if you were playing music at 
all !  if the complaint is made in error, that gets sorted out 
later.  

so, there is no specific level.

since you just moved in, i would see it through in the courts.  you
should be able to get something from the judge that states something
like 'allowed to play music loud between x and y hours'.  at that
point, your fellow tenant has no recourse during those times.

good luck !

doug

On Wed, 4 Oct 1995, Seth Joshua Horvitz wrote:

> Hello everyone,
>  
> First of all, is there anyone out there who has some hard facts about the laws 
> concerning noise in the domestic arena (i.e. apartment buildings, etc.)?  
> I know that basically the cops will not respond to noise complaints made 
> between 7am and 10pm.  I think there are specific decibel levels which 
> cannot be exceeded after 10pm. Does anyone know what they are?  I would 
> appreciate a detailed description of these laws, if anyone would be so 
> kind to provide it.  I think this info would benifit others on the list 
> who live within earshot of people who are intolerant of "repetitive beats."
> 
> Now, let me explain why I have just made the above request... 
> (personal information to follow- please delete if uninterested)
> 
> Two months ago, my girlfriend and I moved into an apartment building in 
> Oakland.  The night after moving in, we had some friends over in the 
> evening and were listening to music at a LOW level, when the upstairs 
> neighbor came down and tried to offer me $20 to keep my stereo off.  He 
> accused me of playing loud music for three days, when in fact we'd only 
> moved in the day before.  I refused the money, but felt it was necessary 
> to talk to these people and come to some sort of agreement, so that we 
> wouldn't be getting on each other's nerves.  A few days later, Kristen 
> (my girlfriend) and I went upstairs to talk with them.  Upon opening the 
> door, the guy started pacing back and forth in the hallway, breathing 
> heavily, and accusing me of blasting music 12 hours a day, when in fact, 
> I had only played about 1-2 hours of music which even approached being 
> loud, and only in the afternoons.  We had a very tense and tedious 
> discussion with them, and came to a tentative agreement that I could play 
> music loud for 2.5 hours a day, and very soft at other times (we even 
> checked the levels on my stereo).  This was a big compromise on my part, 
> but I didn't want to be on bad terms with anybody.  
> 	
> About a week later, they called the landlord to complain, when in fact, I 
> had not even come close to using my alloted 2.5 hours of loud music.  
> 
> Just last Friday night, we had four friends over to celebrate my 
> birthday.  I had bought new records that afternoon, so I played them at a 
> moderately loud level (not as loud as I had agreed on) from about 
> 8-10:30pm.  Then, we watched a movie, and afterwords, listened to music 
> at a low level while talking.
> 
> They called the cops.  The cop was almost apologetic, realizing 
> that their complaint was ridiculous.  He told us not to worry, and went 
> on his way.
> 
> One hour later, they called the cops again.  When the second cop came, 
> they filed a formal complaint against us, forcing us to appear in court.
> 
> Yesterday, I got home from school at 3pm with some more new records.  I 
> started playing them at a moderately loud level.  FIFTEEN MINUTES LATER, the 
> manager came pounding on my door, telling me that the upstairs neighbors had 
> called and complained to him.
> 
> Does anyone know what I can do about this situation?  I would like to 
> file a complaint of harassment against them, because this situation is 
> getting ridiculuous.  The people who live below us were home ALL NIGHT 
> on Friday, and were not even remotely bothered by the music, and never 
> have been.  HELP ME PLEASE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
> 
> pissed,
> Seth    
>

	Well...here it is, my late bio.  I've only been on SFRaves for a few
weeks now, and I must say that reading all of your posts really makes me
proud to be involved in our scene.  I don't think I've ever seen this much
unity within a bunch of people who don't see eachother every day, and I'd
like to start of by sending EVERYONE a GREAT BIG WARM SQUISHY FRIGGIN' HUG!
                                  *HUG*
                                   =)
	Now, lessee,  I went to my first party a couple of years back, I
thing it was Wicked/ Get Down Get Down Get Down,  and I was glued to the
speakers all night long.  8)~~~  <==*drool*
	Then, I went to *gulp* Cyberfest later on (I know, I know) and,
needless to say, had an ok time? =}
	Ever since then, I've been hooked and I got involved with the Cloud
Factory and Lettuce dance.  I LOVE SMALL PARTIES!!!!  I've been spinning for
about a year now, and would like to thank all of the artists out there who
make it possible for me to enjoy all of the beautiful music that moves me
the oh so incredible way it does.
	I grew up in the ARMPIT of California (Point Arena) and I attend 
UCSC,  I love it down here!  My SO transferred to UCDavis this year, so
I've been a little out of sorts lately.  
	Lets condense this, shall we? =)
1) Due to lack of a tight knit, all american family unit, all of my friends
   are my family, so i guess we're all related now, huh?  8)  (My parent's
   are also way cool)
2) I believe in PLUR, Karma, Beautiful music, understanding, and common
   sense.
3) I also enjoy animals, fuzzy things, and flashing smiles at strangers!
4) I'm a real cornball....

Well, I hope this was, at least, entertaining!  I gotta go to class.

Love and Hugs,
Sabin Cloud

P.S.  Cloud is my middle name and had no influence on the naming of the Cloud
      Factory.  Pretty neat coincidence though, huh?

Jello, mijos!
 There is afull moon this sunday being thrown by a collective of systems, 
djs, and positive people (you know, all those ravers).
 It is being thrown by a large, diverse group to make it a community 
event, where everyone is welcome. It will start early (by full moon 
standards) on sunday nite/monday morning.
The collective intends to make these parties on the full moon 
consistently, and to have the participation of all systems, djs, or 
anyone who wants to help plan, carry, scout sites, or just spread the word.
 Info will be spread by word of mouth and for this party, on several 
system's voice-mails, in different area codes. So just call your friendly 
neighborhood sound system later this week! (I'll post later, thursday 
pm...)
 Remember to spread it word of mouth to non-sfravers, and to tell people 
which systems to call....

Lotsa love (oooh, it's happening!!!!)
 Milton and the E-Bee...

Flowers are our only treasure, and through them our friendship grows 
(Nahuatil poem)

Jello, mijos!
 There is afull moon this sunday being thrown by a collective of systems, 
djs, and positive people (you know, all those ravers).
 It is being thrown by a large, diverse group to make it a community 
event, where everyone is welcome. It will start early (by full moon 
standards) on sunday nite/monday morning.
The collective intends to make these parties on the full moon 
consistently, and to have the participation of all systems, djs, or 
anyone who wants to help plan, carry, scout sites, or just spread the word.
 Info will be spread by word of mouth and for this party, on several 
system's voice-mails, in different area codes. So just call your friendly 
neighborhood sound system later this week! (I'll post later, thursday 
pm...)
 Remember to spread it word of mouth to non-sfravers, and to tell people 
which systems to call....

Lotsa love (oooh, it's happening!!!!)
 Milton and the E-Bee...

	Two albums which do not appear in the 'ambient/techno' bin 
at your local record store, but are nonetheless brilliant ambienty works, 
are:

	Passion (Last Temptation of Christ soundtrack)
	Blade Runner Soundtrack--1994 release

big huge recommendations on these ones from Jon.

> I have directions to Panther but I'm not sure of the exact mileage to
> Panther off of Hwy 1 ( does anyone know?). 
> 
> Take 101 to 85 Gilroy
> 85 to 17 Santa Cruz
> 17 to Hwy 1 North
> Look for a pile of rocks with reflective paint on them. 
> Turn into the dirt "parking lot" and park yo' car.
> Cross the railroad tracks on the beach side of the parking lot.
> Go down the little trail (be careful the trail gets a little precarious 
> at night)  then look for the crazy group of people sittin' around a fire 
> making noise!
> 
> I'll  post the exact miles you have to travel on hwy 1 to get to Panther

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Oct  5 13:55:01 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id NAA24905; Thu, 5 Oct 1995 13:55:01 -0700
Received: from netcom8.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id NAA24883; Thu, 5 Oct 1995 13:54:55 -0700
Received: by netcom8.netcom.com (8.6.12/Netcom)
	id NAA11207; Thu, 5 Oct 1995 13:54:39 -0700
Date: Thu, 5 Oct 1995 13:54:39 -0700 (PDT)
From: Peter Fogel <peterf@netcom.com>
Subject: cooped up, with little room to dance
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9510051316.A8189-0100000@netcom8>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Yes, I've been cooped up all week with a case of the chicken pox.  Yea, 
if you've never had em, your never too old to get em :(
After spacin out for the last few days with up and down fevers, today I 
felt much more energized and was able to do some dancing in my apartment. 

Sporting a new psychadelic look with pokadots all over me, I'm feeling 
back in the groove. Yes the joy of letting the vibrations run through me, 
as I dance are giving me a faster recovery.  With all my pokadots, its 
nice to be able to dance like a freak while I look like a freak.  
Though I probably look kinda freaky without the pokadots as well.  
Probably why I sometimes like to dance freaky.

Even though I'm not able to join all you freaky and non-freaky dancers 
out there on the dance floor just yet, I'm still dancing with you all.
See ya soon,
:)
peter

   No autumn slowdown this year - we have a full weekend again! I can't
   really decide between the four parties on Friday night - check 'em out
   yerselves. On Saturday, there are a couple of cool outdoor
   undergrounds - Frequency 8 and Lift Off!; if you'd rather have hot,
   Wicked is the place to be. Sunday should have some full moon action;
   in addition to the Wicked full moon (if it is on Sunday), some of the
   other collectives are pulling together for another party, call around
   on Sunday night for more info...
   

                               THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/sfrcal.html

Upcoming Parties in the San Francisco Bay Area

   Friday, October 6th - Nomad Interactive invites you to Splish
   An intimate midnight cruise on the bay w/the masters of house Garth,
   Jeno & Tracy. Aqua Ambience with Ameba Hi-Fi gurus Mark, Allen &
   Andrew. Tix $20 presale only, at Ameba on Haight. 415.406.2118
   
   Friday, October 6th - Flowerchild 
   dj's: garth, dutch, simon, emma, spinner, jay-sin, essence, kwashi,
   xl, alonzo. live: fidelity bytes. 415.270.2191 510.321.3269

   Harness. $10, 21+, midnight till dawn. 525 Harrison St, SF.
   415.974.9389 415.543.1300

   Youth. 10:30pm-4am. 415.487.5187

   flashlight. $5. 415.541.5019

   St. @ 21st. $10 donation for new healing center. 510.428.1961

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 9pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 -
       Progressive house, acid jazz and "alternative" music views. (415)
       281-3377.
     * Sunday night mid-3am - "No UFO's" w/Adam from Silent Records KZSU
       90.1 Stanford
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Tuesday noon-3pm - House and techno w/DJ Unknown and guests - KZSU
       90.1 (Stanford)
     * Thursdays 9:30pm-midnight - "Aurora Borealis" w/DJ Seth. Ambient,
       experimental, ethereal, acid-trance-techno, industrial and
       trip-hop on KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Saturday night - "Saturday Night Spin Out" w/Ronnie Libido. Trip
       hop, Jungle, Ambient, Experimental Sounds. 10pm-2am. KFJC 89.7 -
       Los Altos Hills

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.

   
 Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

why.. temporary insanity!)  I'm planning on moving back to San Fran in 
February.

I can remember 2 summers ago,  when "Your Sisters House" featured all
women DJ's,  such as Laura,  Susan,  Polliwog,  and a few others I can't
recall.   They were every Thursday,  and were really great.   I went every

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Oct  5 18:01:49 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id SAA14327; Thu, 5 Oct 1995 18:01:49 -0700

From: laural@inmark.com
Received: (from ugate@localhost) by inmarkinmark.com (8.6.12/8.6.9) with UUCP id RAA28491 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Thu, 5 Oct 1995 17:33:00 -0700
Received: from cc:Mail by ugate.inmark.com
	id AA812941025 Thu, 05 Oct 95 17:57:05 
Date: Thu, 05 Oct 95 17:57:05 
Message-Id: <9509058129.AA812941025@ugate.inmark.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re[2]: YSH (was dj erica :-) )
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


     I was never an active member of the Your Sisters' House collective, 
     but I helped when I could and DJed with them a number of times.
     
     From what I learned from other women who were actively involved, it 
     was a *lot* of work to find an all-ages space every week where they 
     could have a donation-only ($5 suggested) party.
     
     Liz Roberts had a lot of committment and personal energy, and got the 
     YSH ball rolling.  She wasn't working at the time, so was able to 
     spend a lot of hours space hunting.  
     
     Liz moved back to New York in November of 1993 (yes it was THAT long 
     ago).  The remaining Sisters attempted regular parties, but space 
     after space fell through.  Susan and Maui did their best to pick up 
     the ball, and even got a few parties off the ground.  Last I heard, 
     Susan had moved back to Florida to spend a little time with her 
     parents.
     
     I'm a bit out of touch, so feel free to add more information.
     
     Your Sisters' House was a great party, that's for sure!  But I wonder, 
     after looking at the jam-packed SFRaves calendar, if we need another 
     party in this town.  San Francisco has enough going on to make up for 
     the rest of the country it seems.
     
     On the other hand, YSH's mission to provide a space for women DJs and 
     to grow an "old girl's network" was admirable, and I do miss it.
     
     Laura

	I remember when I first stared working with computers, and was 
	introduced to the joys of e-mail & the like. Certain symbols
	put me in mind of one thing or another, and after a little 
	pecking around I came up with the standard :-)

	Hey I thought, great idea, good way to send smiles through 
	wires.

	Imagine my disappointment when somone dumps down a phone book 
	thick printout of the quirky little buggers, complete with 
	explanations for the sometimes puzzling icons.

	Short lived Eureka,
	Gary

Received: from mail.prodigy.com ([199.4.137.13]) by pimaia2w.prodigy.com (8.6.10/8.6.9) with SMTP id AAA29590 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Fri, 6 Oct 1995 00:33:03 -0400
Date: Fri, 06 Oct 1995 00:34:22 EDT
From: GLCM99B@prodigy.com (BLOOM COUNTY)
X-Mailer: PRODIGY Services Company Internet mailer [PIM 3.2-342.56]

Subject: new at this
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello to one and all.
I guess I ought to introduce myself, as I have been lurking on the 
list for a while.. keeping silent... observing.  

I'm 25 years old and just moved here about a month and a half ago 
from Rochester, NY.  My brother moved out here in December and he 
talked me into coming out and living with him.   I have been going 
through a major transitional stage in my life... suffering from some 
pretty heavy depression and I figured some change of scenery would do 
me good.  Instead I found myself in a strange new place, away from my 
close friends and with no job, and very stressed.  Needless to say my 
first weeks in San Francisco were not enjoyable...
The first really good experience I had in San Francisco was my  first 
rave.  It was at Goats Rock and I never experienced anything like it 
in my life.  We didn't leave Berkeley till about midnight and it took 
almost 2 hours to get there.  I had no idea what to expect... all I 
knew was that it was late, I was in a bad mood, and I felt like I was 
being kidnapped against my will.  But when I got there the music was 
just starting and I just felt all this good energy.  Everyone was so 
friendly and unpretentious. For the first time I was able to put my 
anxieties at rest for a while.  I just danced all night.
The only bad part of the night was feeling nausea for a little while 
after I took some e.  I had never taken it before and to tell you the 
truth, apart from the nausea I don't think it really effected me.  My 
brother and his friend both had some also, and they said it was good 
stuff, so I knew it was me.  I gave it a second chance when I went to 
another rave in the City... the rave was just as good, but the 
effects of the e were the same.  
So I was wondering... has anyone else had this experience (or non-
experience)  or know of anyone who did.  Does e effect different 
people differently based on biochemistry et al.? I have the same non-
reaction to pot... people tell me it's because I haven't smoked it 
enough, but I definitely think I've given it more that enough of a 
chance.  It only makes me sleepy and "zone out."  I'm just starting 
to think I'm biochemically out of sink with most people.
Well that's it... thanks for listening... and thanks for the good 
times... like I said raving is one of the few things that has giving 
me true content feelings in a long time.  The two raves I been to 
have been oasis's in an otherwise difficult time in my life.  I hope 
to meet some of you in person soon.

jamie n. k.

*** In coming to know, everything changes, so it is no longer you who 
knows ***

communal full moon gathering.  Contributing sound systems include those 
at Saturday's full moon and future full moons.  The address for the 
planning meeting is 2616 Ashby Ave. before College in Berkeley.  Phone

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Oct  5 23:03:08 1995

Message-Id: <199510060601.AA08309@mail.crl.com>
From: davidmin@crl.com (David Minuk)
To: GLCM99B@prodigy.com (BLOOM COUNTY)
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: new at this
Date: Fri, 06 Oct 1995 05:55:13 GMT
References: <013.02456563.GLCM99B@prodigy.com>
X-Mailer: Forte Agent .99b.112
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello and welcome.  As to whether e effects different people different
ways, as with all drugs, this is the case.  Also, if you're taking any
meds for depression, you will probably feel less effect depending on
what you're taking.

But I doubt that you need to take it at all, or even worry about why
you can't feel it.  Many people don't "get" raves until they take e.
You however, seem it have the vibe spot on already.  I think that if
you are dancing and enjoying the music, you are getting more out of
your activity than perhaps some of those who are high.

In fact, if you are indeed clinically depressed, taking e is a bad
idea.  The comedown can lead to a more depressed state than you had
ever imagined.  Luckily, this doesn't seem to be the case so far.  

The magic of the music and fellowship with those feeling that magic is
a tool you can use for healing yourself.  You have opened your eyes to
the beauty of movement and music;  now if you reflect on how this ties
in with your life and the rhythms of the universe you will have had a
revelation that others have achieved (usually only fleetingly) through
psychedelic drugs.

David

>     I was never an active member of the Your Sisters' House collective,
>     but I helped when I could and DJed with them a number of times.
>
>     From what I learned from other women who were actively involved, it
>     was a *lot* of work to find an all-ages space every week where they
>     could have a donation-only ($5 suggested) party.
>
>     Liz Roberts had a lot of committment and personal energy, and got the
>     YSH ball rolling.  She wasn't working at the time, so was able to
>     spend a lot of hours space hunting.
>
>     Liz moved back to New York in November of 1993 (yes it was THAT long
>     ago).  The remaining Sisters attempted regular parties, but space
>     after space fell through.  Susan and Maui did their best to pick up
>     the ball, and even got a few parties off the ground.  Last I heard,
>     Susan had moved back to Florida to spend a little time with her
>     parents.
>
>     I'm a bit out of touch, so feel free to add more information.
>
>     Your Sisters' House was a great party, that's for sure!  But I wonder,
>     after looking at the jam-packed SFRaves calendar, if we need another
>     party in this town.  San Francisco has enough going on to make up for
>     the rest of the country it seems.
>
>     On the other hand, YSH's mission to provide a space for women DJs and
>     to grow an "old girl's network" was admirable, and I do miss it.
>
>     Laura

Thanx for setting me (us) straight.   Those were the good ol days,  thats
phore shore...

Crunchman

--- begin forwarded text

MIME-Version: 1.0
Date: Thu, 05 Oct 95 16:33:04 -0800
From: vision@well.com
Subject: Beach Blanket Bongos
To: burnman-list@well.com

Still got the urge to burn stuff? There's a party happening on the beach in
Pacifica this Saturday night. Check it, check it.

<---- Begin Forwarded Message ---->
Subject: Beach Blanket Bongos


We were feeling bummed about being back from BM so we gathered at the
beach last week and it was so much fun we are doing it again.
It willl be at Linda Mar Beach in Pacifica (also known as Taco Bell
Beach). We had a gihumungous fire & more drums than we needed, & lots of
other recreational fun stuff. The BM Drummers Collective will be
there again and the only thing you need to bring is something that
burns.

            BEACH PARTY

Drums* Dance* Ritual* flesh

        October 7th, 1995
Linda Mar Beach, Pacifica

>From SF - 280 to hwy 1S 3rd traffic light, turn right into beach
parking lot taco bell will be on the right next to the lot. We will
be located to the North about 200 yrds from the lot.

Bring drums, wine, combustibles, effigies, etc., No ruitual has been
planned but wear white just in case. Low profile in parking lot until
it gets dark. Although no one bothered us last time, some neighbors
around there actually brought drums and joined us. Good vibes.

See you there,
Liquid Cave Babe

<----  End Forwarded Message  ---->

At 10:34 PM 10/5/95 -0700, B.A. wrote:
>>      On the other hand, YSH's mission to provide a space for women DJs and 
>>      to grow an "old girl's network" was admirable, and I do miss it.
>>      
>>      Laura
>
>While I have heard that YSH threw some great parties, is your view 
>that growing any type of "old (insert elitest personage term) network" really 
>admirable? What the hell difference does it make what 
>sex/color/orientation/religious persuasion a D.J. is? If they are good 
>they're good, if they suck they suck. I find it really pitiful that it makes 
>such a difference to so many people.
>

It's great that you have enough experience with women (and other minority)
DJs that you can conclude that "it makes no difference." I, on the other
hand, have not had the opportunity to hear many women DJs. I think they may
have a different approach than what I'm used to and I'd like more
opportunities to find out. YSH's problem keeping spaces is a small (but
crippling) part of how difficult it is to get something new out to people
without a supportive community to push for and inspire continued participation. 

eh

To: ehill@best.com (Eric)

In-Reply-To: <199510060932.CAA23165@shell1.best.com>; from "Eric" at Oct 6, 95 2:32 am

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Black Adder:
> >admirable? What the hell difference does it make what 
> >sex/color/orientation/religious persuasion a D.J. is? If they are good 
> >they're good, if they suck they suck. I find it really pitiful that it makes 
> >such a difference to so many people.

Eric:
> It's great that you have enough experience with women (and other minority)
> DJs that you can conclude that "it makes no difference." I, on the other
> hand, have not had the opportunity to hear many women DJs. I think they may
> have a different approach than what I'm used to and I'd like more

My experience with with "minority" DJs has lead me to conclude that it
doesn't make a difference at all.  I can listen to a tape of a set and
there is no way I could tell the gender, race, religion, sexual
orientation, etc. of the DJ.  This was not what I had expected, and I
think it's a positive sign that musical tastes in our scene transcend
these categories.

The YSH parties did provide a more nurturing environment with cheap/free
food, candles, discussion groups, and a pretty inclusive vibe that many
people liked, and I guess could be ascribed to a more female approach.

There was a perception at that time that there was a male-dominated
network of promoters and DJs that didn't give female DJs many chances to 
spin.  Back then, it was hard for *any* new talent to break into the
scene.  Things are different today though, with many grassroots
sound systems throwing parties.  Even though we still don't see a lot
of female DJs, I don't think it has anything to do with a "good-old-boy"
network.  The males at Pacific invited 4 different DJs to spin a Sunset
this year.  The more female dominated groups (Harmony and Gateway),
certainly haven't made a point of having more females spin at their
parties.  So I've come to the conclusion that the whole gender thing
in regards to DJing is a big non-issue.

Lee
___________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com   (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )   lee@hyperreal.com

Subject: stopping a bad A-trip
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Hey all,

A few years back I wanted to research A so I went to Sac State to look 
at some books.  One book I encountered was written by someone who did 
some studies on the drug.  He said that the best (or one of) the ways 
to stop a bad trip was to take more A!  His theory was that the tripper 
was stuck on a plane of thought and either needed to be elevated above 
it of come down off of it.

I don't know if this would really work but once I was having a very 
uncomfortable trip and had some g-bud.  This made me re-peak and I 
began to feel great!  It mainly had to do with the gb but I definetly 
got way higher than I was before and all my stress and 
uncomfortableness went away.

love chris

	id AA813004324 Fri, 06 Oct 95 11:32:04

Message-Id: <9509068130.AA813004324@ugate.inmark.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re[4]: YSH (was dj erica :-) )
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


     

Black Adder wrote:
     
>While I have heard that YSH threw some great parties, is your view 
>that growing any type of "old (insert elitest personage term) network" really 
>admirable? What the hell difference does it make what 
>sex/color/orientation/religious persuasion a D.J. is? If they are good 
>they're good, if they suck they suck. I find it really pitiful that it makes 
>such a difference to so many people.

Women DJs were such a novelty in the beginning, and there was no real 
community for them.  Sure, there was the community of all DJs, but *THEY* were 
at the time quite an old boy's network.  Although some were nice and 
supportive, others were competitive assholes.  

The kind of mutual support and encouragement that some of the new women DJs 
was looking for was not always being provided, that sort of warm fuzzy 
sisterhood was part of what defined Your Sister's House.

Networking is GOOD, and there are times when people need to and SHOULD build 
networks.  The original old boy's DJ network served them and the rave scene 
well.  The YSH network served some women DJs well.  Remember that this was two 
years ago, and things have grown and changed since then.

If you think about it, this list is a sort of "old raver's network" or maybe a
"hopefully clued-in raver's network."  Is that so bad?

My experience with YSH was good and I enjoyed it.  I vastly appreciate what all 
the sisters were doing and what they accomplished:  throwing a weekly all-ages 
party -- usually a renegade -- in San Francisco.  By giving the spotlight to 
female DJs they encouraged and nurtured their presence in the scene.  Two years 
later, you can look at the SFRaves calendar and see many different women 
spinning.  Three years ago, it wasn't always the case.

Your Sisters' House can be thought of as an incubator -- it gave some women a 
start and a chance.  After that, of course, it was up the the individual.  And 
you can see that there are many women going strong.

In San Francisco for a very long while, it was difficult to get gigs if you were
a new DJ or new to the scene unless you started throwing your own parties, no 
matter how good you were.  The Your Sisters' House collective started throwing 
their own parties in part to get these women gigs and to get women involved with
all facets of rave planning and production.  I don't see anything wrong with 
what they did, just like I don't see anything wrong with the Friends and Family 
network, which basically got started so that the net ravers and net DJs could 
plan, put on, and play at a party.  Or how about when Pacific got started?  
People were joking that Galen had to go out and buy his own sound system and put
on parties just so he'd get a chance to spin:  he's an excellent DJ and at the 
time wasn't heard from that much.  Now that he's gotten the Pacific network 
started, there's been a whole batch of new people (Tracy comes vividly to mind) 
who have gotten going through that and have moved on to other things.

I think the big problem with what Black Adder said is the bit about "who cares 
... so long as they're good."  I agree with the "who cares" part, but the truth 
is that there still are few women DJs and are extremely few other minority rave 
DJs.  I see nothing wrong with organizing parties to spotlight minorities, be 
they stylistic minorities (like techno/hardcore), organizational minorities 
(like net DJs a few years ago), or human minorities (women, african-americans, 
visiting european DJs).  You, the party-goer, DON'T have to attend if you don't 
like the idea politically or spiritually.  But these "spotlight" parties are 
good incubators, and good ways of encouraging the targeted group (e.g. women and
YSH) to get involved.

Laura

Message-Id: <v02110103ac9b34536347@[199.238.226.117]>
Mime-Version: 1.0

Precedence: bulk

>
>Er ... no, this is NOT a good idea.  I think maybe this idea only worked
>for this particular person.  I know that most of the times when I feel
>frightened on A trips its because I already feel like maybe I'm too high,
>so giving ME more A would probably send me into overload ....
>
>I wonder how many folx this guy tried his theory on?  Did the book say?  do
>you remember?
>

I believe I know which book he's talking about. I believe it's from the
"Psychedelic Reader" which is a compilation of medical notes and journals
from well known psychiatrists and psychologists.  I have the book at home
and I'll post more about it when I get a chance.  I believe the entry was
written by a clinical psychologist, possibly even Leary.  The gist of it
was that people get caught in a sort of downward spiral and one of the
techniques that the psychologists used to pull people out of it was to dose
them again.  The context of this literature is set in the early days of
psychedelic experimentation by medical professionals.  Please keep that in
mind.

Please note that I'm posting this for information only.  I am in no way
condoning, or encouraging that people try this.

Tigger

(Read forwards first)

Duuuuuuude!

That's an awesome idea!  I was totally feelin' the same way.  I have *NEVER* 
been to a FMR and am really wanting to experience it, but I had such a great 
time at Freq.8 that I want to go there too.  What to do, what to do!!!  I am 
so, so torn cause I also want to go to WICKED, I *love* those parties!

Maybe if we can get enough people to cheer for it, they'll be into it.  Don't 
want to step on any toes, however.  *PEOPLE*, this would be a lovely and rare 
opportunity to unite and celebrate in a beautiful place with great people and 
music.  

Please support the promoters and DJ's to compromise and agree on a great idea.  
Let's help build unity throughout and throw a gargantuanly good party!

Peace

Rikki

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Oct  6 13:21:27 1995

To: laural@inmark.com

Subject: Re: Re[4]: YSH (was dj erica :-) )
In-Reply-To: <9509068130.AA813004324@ugate.inmark.com>

Precedence: bulk



On Fri, 6 Oct 1995 laural@inmark.com wrote:

> Women DJs were such a novelty in the beginning, and there was no real 
> community for them.  Sure, there was the community of all DJs, but *THEY* were 
> at the time quite an old boy's network.  Although some were nice and 
> supportive, others were competitive assholes.  

Yes, and isn't this true with almost any given group of people, be it 
D.J.'s, Christians, gays, whites, etc.? In any given group you have nice 
people, complete assholes, and all points in between. 

> The kind of mutual support and encouragement that some of the new women DJs 
> was looking for was not always being provided, that sort of warm fuzzy 
> sisterhood was part of what defined Your Sister's House.

I have no issue with YSH. As I have said previously I have heard only 
good things about them.

> Networking is GOOD, and there are times when people need to and SHOULD build 
> networks.  The original old boy's DJ network served them and the rave scene 
> well.  The YSH network served some women DJs well.  Remember that this was two 
> years ago, and things have grown and changed since then.

Networking is good. What I have taken umbrage to is the statement that an 
"old-girls-network" is good. This term holds all the negative 
connotations of "old-boy-network," which include elitism, closed-door 
meetings, and power-brokering, none of which are "good" except of course 
for the members of the network. 
> 
> If you think about it, this list is a sort of "old raver's network" or maybe a
> "hopefully clued-in raver's network."  Is that so bad?

Again, I have no problem with networking, as long as it is not a closed 
loop.

> Your Sisters' House can be thought of as an incubator -- it gave some women a 
> start and a chance.  After that, of course, it was up the the individual.  And 
> you can see that there are many women going strong.

An incubator is for someone that can not survive on their own. Are you 
saying that somehow women D.J.'s were somehow inferior to males, and 
couldn't survive on their own? I don't believe that. It takes the same 
thing it takes to do anything: desire, and drive. With these two things 
if someone wants to do something and an opportunity is not handed to 
them, they will MAKE the opportunity. This is not gender-specific.


> In San Francisco for a very long while, it was difficult to get gigs if you were
> a new DJ or new to the scene unless you started throwing your own parties, no 
> matter how good you were.  The Your Sisters' House collective started throwing 
> their own parties in part to get these women gigs and to get women involved with
> all facets of rave planning and production.  I don't see anything wrong with 
> what they did, just like I don't see anything wrong with the Friends and Family 
> network, which basically got started so that the net ravers and net DJs could 
> plan, put on, and play at a party.  Or how about when Pacific got started?  
> People were joking that Galen had to go out and buy his own sound system and put
> on parties just so he'd get a chance to spin:  he's an excellent DJ and at the 
> time wasn't heard from that much.  Now that he's gotten the Pacific network 
> started, there's been a whole batch of new people (Tracy comes vividly to mind) 
> who have gotten going through that and have moved on to other things.

Thank you for illustrating my point. Desire and drive got all these 
groups where they are. While I do not know enough about YSH to comment, 
with regards to the other groups I can safely say that they invite people 
from different groups to spin. Hell, I saw Galen not D.J.'ing the last 
Sunset just so other people got the chance to spin. That was a truly 
beautiful thing. These groups made themselves. Their vision encourages 
people to come to their gigs. From what I have seen that vision is not 
gender specific with regards to ANY portion of organization of or the 
party itself.

> I think the big problem with what Black Adder said is the bit about "who cares 
> ... so long as they're good."  I agree with the "who cares" part, but the truth 
> is that there still are few women DJs and are extremely few other minority rave 
> DJs.  I see nothing wrong with organizing parties to spotlight minorities, be 
> they stylistic minorities (like techno/hardcore), organizational minorities 
> (like net DJs a few years ago), or human minorities (women, african-americans, 
> visiting european DJs).  You, the party-goer, DON'T have to attend if you don't 
> like the idea politically or spiritually.  But these "spotlight" parties are 
> good incubators, and good ways of encouraging the targeted group (e.g. women and
> YSH) to get involved.
> 
> Laura

I think the big problem with your view is that people, whatever their 
background need prodding and encouragement in order to D.J. If there is a 
lack of women/minorities D.J.'ing in the scene, it is because of a lack 
of desire and drive. The ones that are doing it are there because they 
had these qualities. As far as "spotlight" parties, all this does is 
encourage seperatism, which is something that I hope this scene is NOT 
about. If someone needs special opportunities and coddling to do 
something, they should just stay the hell home, because they obivously 
don't want it bad enough. Welcome to the real world.

                                         
                                             Black Adder


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Oct  6 13:30:18 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id NAA01603; Fri, 6 Oct 1995 13:30:18 -0700
Received: from netcom15.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id NAA01592; Fri, 6 Oct 1995 13:30:13 -0700
Received: from localhost by netcom15.netcom.com (8.6.12/Netcom)
	id NAA09263; Fri, 6 Oct 1995 13:29:57 -0700
Message-Id: <199510062029.NAA09263@netcom15.netcom.com>
To: sequoia1@ix.netcom.com (Chris Chervin )
Cc: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: stopping a bad A-trip 
In-reply-to: Your message of "Fri, 06 Oct 95 10:25:20 PDT."
             <199510061725.KAA01263@ix.ix.netcom.com> 
Date: Fri, 06 Oct 95 13:29:57 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>A few years back I wanted to research A so I went to Sac State to look 
>at some books.  One book I encountered was written by someone who did 
>some studies on the drug.  He said that the best (or one of) the ways 
>to stop a bad trip was to take more A!  His theory was that the tripper 
>was stuck on a plane of thought and either needed to be elevated above 
>it of come down off of it.

I think this is a bad idea. A very bad idea. What a sick n' twisted 
more-is-better solution! There are lots of single books out there that
are utter quackery, and just because one can write a book doesn't mean
you are right. A better bet would be to liberalize the "ethics" behind
having refereed scientific journals, allowing such research to be
judged by scientific peers prior to publication. Although this tends to
keep out lots of interesting fringe, or new-wave findings, it also
tends to reduce the number of snake oil salesmen willing to look like
idiots in front of their peers. After all, if you want to read
quackery, there's always the internet!

>I don't know if this would really work but once I was having a very 
>uncomfortable trip and had some g-bud.  This made me re-peak and I 
>began to feel great!  It mainly had to do with the gb but I definetly 
>got way higher than I was before and all my stress and 
>uncomfortableness went away.

Double plus bad on this if you're actually having a bad trip, as
opposed to just feeling "blah" ... I've seen plenty of bad trips begun
because too much GB was done. (And I'm not talkin' bout limeys
either!). If you're feeling just blah -- definitely take two GBs, along
with a double dose of hardcore dancing preferably with a trip-approved
DJ... And don't forget to call your superego in the morning and tell
him/her what you think... 

If you're feeling worse than blah, try doing something completely
different from the place/situation/people that you're currently in (not
necessarily alone, bring a friend!) -- keep your mind busy by trying to
deal with understanding new external stimuli, rather than doing
infinite positive feedback loops on some thought you're obsessing on.
If you're chilling, force yourself to dance. If you're dancing, force
yourself to chill, if you're indoors, go outside, if you're outdoors go
inside, if you're hot, get cold, and if yer cold, put your clothes back
on and quit biting off that woman's navel ring!

This is all IMHO, YMMV, TANSTAAFL, BIG OLD NO GOOD HIGH INTELLIGENCE TREAT!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
=  Niels Mayer   http://www.cyborganic.com/People/niels   mayer@netcom.com  =

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Fri, 6 Oct 95 12:07:58 PDT
From: Dana Watanabe <DWATANAB@uci.edu>
To: Socal-Raves List <socal-raves@ucsd.edu>
Subject: Carl Cox

Speechless is pretty much the best description i can give.

Musically, incredible.  Going back and forth between 
really housey tracks and solid techno/acidy tracks,
but the beat kept pounding and POUNDING.

at one point it was almost hard to breathe because my 
face/body was vibrating so much.  

But aside from the music, the man is scary.
I mean, not personally, personally, he is this really nice, jovial guy.
Although he would get a pretty intense look while being in the music,
when he looked up at the crowd for a bit, he would get a smile,
and was laughing & joking with people around him.

But his mixing ability is scary.  I know i have never seen
someone THAT in control of his or her records.
I definitely believe he could mix blindfolded and probably with
his hands tied behind his back.

I wish i could describe how amazing it was. If you sneezed when he
started off, he had already mixed through 4 records.  (okay..
it was like in the first two minutes, but still...)

Basically, he would pick out a record, listen in his headphones
to match the beats (which i think always took under a minute
if not 30 seconds) then he'd pull off his headphones,
watch the crowd, rock to the music, or start getting another record.
while he's doing all this, and talking to other people, he's
mixing the records in and out.  One time he was talking to someone
and without stopping the conversation, he started tweaking one of the
spindles to get it right,  then he stopped talking a bit later
to throw in some scratching and finish up the mix, and then hopped
back into the convo.

there were so many times last nite where my jaw literally fell open
at what i was seeing

if you are alive on sunday after moontribe, definitely check
him out in santa monica

 ,
dana

Perhaps a few -- just as there are people willing to live in Orange County."
   - August issue of WiReD

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Oct  7 14:54:26 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id OAA24677; Sat, 7 Oct 1995 14:54:26 -0700

Subject: tonight's mission vortex

Precedence: bulk

hello beautiful people.

i want to share with you a few of my thoughts about the Mission Vortex
experience that's happening in the mission tonight. of course, it's all
conjecture until the moment the rave actually goes off, but i can tell you a
bit about what's been happening behind the scenes, and what the aspirations
of the people who are putting it on are. 

the subname of the Vortex is "a healing rave," and this is the emphasis - one
of them, at least - of tonight's celebration. we're coming together to share
our creative energies, share our lust for life, share our own joys with each
other, and in so doing, heal ourselves. healing implies a previous wound, but
this isn't what i'm talking about. in this case, healing is bringing parts of
the self and the community together to create something new and beautiful
and... enchanted. 

i should tell you now that i'm not the designated spokesperson for the Vortex
- i'm just one of the many volunteers. but among this new community, i am one
of the most active people on sfraves (even though few of you may know me; and
if you do know me, it's probably from my "three c's" posting from many moons
back), so i'm typing you this information on my lunchbreak to appeal to those
of you who have similar ideals to join our celebration. 

art. there's a strong emphasis on art here. artistic expression, artistic
life. i'm a writer and visual artist, and everyone who's involved brings
their own unique talent to the experience. there are poets, dancers,
musicians, painters... 

a few more things before i have to go back to work. i set up a small shrine
near the entrance. you're welcome to bring things to contribute to it, if you
want - flowers, beads, bits of colored string, whatever. 

my name is shalom and i'll be there all night. if you want to find me to
welcome you or just to chat, well, i'm not sure how you'll do that. my
identifying characteristics are this: my facial hair is somewhere between
thick stubble and a young beard, i have shoulder-length copper hair, and blue
eyes. i'm 24.

this should be a wonderful, empowering night. i hope to see you there. things
start early, around 9ish, and go until dawn, i imagine. directions: 2519
mission at 21st. or call dino at 510.428.1961 or me at 510.525.6088.

hope to see you there. 

shalom
