---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Thu, 05 Oct 1995 22:28:43 -0400 (EDT)
From: SCRUTON@delphi.com
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com, socal-raves@ucsd.edu, kevin@physics.arizona.edu
Subject: Maui Rave Report

Scruton here...

trying my best to do a crunch-style rave report from the sunny island
  of Maui (no, i didn't see brian and laura anywhere)   
;) ;) ;) 

first things first; it was HOT there; 90 degrees pluss every day...
  they set record high lows (i'll let you guys figger that one out!)
    on 3 daze...
i was staying in Kihei, a very dry place. Parts looked like the Malibu or
  central Ca coastline, very scrubby and dry; Hana is over 50 miles away,
    over a 10000-foot volcano, where it REALLY rains.  btw, there's a
      killer supercomputer center in Kihei (dat's why iwuz there)
        goto http://www.mhpcc.edu and checkit out...
word came 'round on Friday from a highschool teacher in the supercomputer
  class that there was going to be an event in the Haiku Cannery, in
    the Hookipa area, slightly up-country.  it sounded too good to be true,
      being only about 15 miles from Kihei.

yes, virginia, there Is a scene on Maui.

on saturday, i drove alllll the way to the very north tip of the island, to
  where Karl, the teacher, said i'd find 'hobbit-land', and sure enuf, after
     driving thru about 20 miles of narrow and single-lane roads with 
       700-foot cliffs off the side of the road, no guard rails, and
          speeding yuppies in big,wide cars coming the other way from the
       Kapalua area, there it was.
hobbit-land looks like it gets used as a motocross track a lot; there's lotsa
  dirt tracks going up and down a very hilly and wind-carved landscape.
all around, there were hundreds, if not thousands of little pyramidal stacks
  of rocks, like the kind you find along hiking trails...  along with the 
    crashing, violent ocean, there was a blowhole there (not going off, 
      maybe 'cause the swell wuz from the wrong direction or something), 
      and a very strange rock formation which looked alot like the little
    rock stacks.  all in all, a VERY surreal place; the grass looked like
  it had just been mown, from the intense wind.
i was told that at night, the conditions settle down, and fullmoons and
  such are done out there, VERY far from the real world.

anyway, on saturday, i got down to what appears to be the official Maui
  version of ameba (minus the t-shirts), the New York Deli.  it is across
    the street from Kamaole Beach 1, in Kihei, in the Dolphin Plaza,
      879-1115... when i got there at 9, the crowd had diminished a bit from
    whut it wuz at 7pm, wups! late again...
Karl's brother, Kevin, dropped by around 10, and we swooped by his place
  so he could get shoes and dinner, and made it out to Haiku around 12:30

there was a BIG crowd there, maybe 500 people or more, looked alot like a
  friends&family event, but people were crawling all over the outside of the 
    building outside, and there was a crowd of about 200 outside the main
      door. when we got in, the TOTAL area was about 500 square feet, and
        PACKED and HOT, further driving home the fnf parallels. there was
      a happy-balloon person right next to the concession stand, nicely
    integrated into the operation; there was a nice laser projection
    of space shuttles and whaletales and the like, and the music was pretty
  good, kinda quite, tho.

around 1am, or 1/2 hour after we arrive, the HPD shows up; i'm right next
  to the turntables when an officer states loudly to the DJ (forrest, robbie?)
    to TURN THE SOUND OFF NOW!  he then stentorarily bellows out:
      "the party is over. go home. thanks you for your participation".
    we snuck up to the messanine where the laser was, and sorta slummed
   around for a half hour, and then people started filtering in again.
 the room got packed again, the music started, right back to were it all
  was before, and then the HPD came in AGAIN and  had the DJ rig the 
   headphones into a mike, upon which they said "there are too many people, 
    you are in violation of the fire code" (fnf, anyone???) ;)

welllllll, the promoter said "OK! we're movin g OUTDOORS!" and said
  everyone would show up at the Maui Racetrack (yup, there's one in the
    middle of a bunch of cane fields on the road to Kihei)
we got there at the head of a long procession of clueless people, with
  nice HPD cars waving us on every mile along the road (NARF!!!)
    and drove inland and upland along about a mile or two of gravelly, 
      VERY non-racetrack dirt roads to a large clearing.
ouch. the generator never made it, the dj never made it, it was a 
  big bail.  we stuck it out until 2:30, when Kevin had to split (my ride)
    for a flight to Oahu at 5:00.

moral of the story: there is definitely a scene in Maui, but it needs some
  support and organization.  i begged the people at New York Deli to sub
    to sfraves at least, so they can talk about their scene a little bit
      and maybe get some DJ's in there...
oh, btw DJ Taylor was spinning on Oahu that very same nite ;)

datsallfolks!

Dave Scruton
http://hyperreal.com/~scruton

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Fri, 6 Oct 1995 00:53:12 -0700 (PDT)
From: Jonas Judd <jjudd@sfsu.edu>
To: SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Bad Moon Rising?


Hey everyone,

Lotsa stuff going on 'round these parts. 

I was at Cyberfest promoting. One of the first things that came to my 
mind was how disapointing it was to see all these people wandering 
around "looking for something". After talking with some of the people, my 
impression was that many of them were there because they had heard how 
"special" our gatherings can be. Since they have no conection with the 
underground, this was their "window" to see what raves are all about.

In my obervations over the last few years, I've come the  conclusion 
that there are three types of promoters:

1)	Those who are serious about what they do, but don't care about 
	the people they're providing for.

2)	Those who care about the people, but aren't serious about what 
	they're doing.

3)	And the handful that are serious AND care (truly care, that is, 
	with their heart and souls). 


Seems like the promoter of Cyberfest fit in #1 (he was serious - about 
making money- but didn't care jack for those there, or so it seemed). It's  
too bad, since there were many people receptive and willing to open 
themselves up, but lacked the encouragement of a positive environment to do so.

Which leads me to the topic of environment at our events. 

Seems many of us (including myself) are gettin very picky about the 
environment at parties. From talking with others, it's not so much the 
music anymore, but the environment in which everyone is to enjoy that 
music. 

The music might be great, but if the environment's not conducive to 
relaxing and encouraging openness, or if there's a majority of attitide 
around, then what's the  point?

Further, if the people throwing the party for are doing it for 
"different" reasons (be it self-interest or otherwise), people 
eventually pick up on that and get discouraged. 

It appears some people are discouraged with the way Full Moons are 
conducted and want to try and do something different. For what ever 
reasons, this is creating misunderstandings amony the various 
collectives, thus causing conflict. 

Is this community about conflict? 

I often wonder if we humans will ever get beyond our 
misunderstandings and conflicts, being able to actually work 
together to achieve a common goal. Perhaps it's just an ideal?


Personally, I don't see a problem with two FMR's. Might help to keep 
them more intimate. 

Then again, I don't know ALL the details regarding these misunderstandings, 
so I'm curious to see how things will work out.

Haven't done a boat party yet, so I might see some of you there.

later...

Jonas

On Tue, 3 Oct 1995, Fred Heutte wrote:
> 2.  This is about the 87th time "news" of the so-called "Good Times
>     virus" has made the rounds.  It was and it is a HOAX.

Just to geek out a little bit...

Now that MSN allows transport of executable code over email, code that is 
run without any security checks (i.e., not like Java) then it is entirely 
possible to send someone with an MSN account a program that could do 
anything it wanted to their computer.  Just call the attached program 
"Click me for hot sex" or something to guarantee people launch it.

	Brian

The full moon will be at 8:45 a.m. exactly.  At that moment the sun will 
shine on the visible surface of the moon reflecting the light of the 
sun.  At 9:04 a.m. a lunar eclipse will occur putting the earth between 
the sun and the moon.  Throughout history the full moon has been a crazy 
time.  The magnetic field effects the tides and water.  Being 3/4 made of 
water humans are also effected.  We all love the moon, it reminds us of 
change and the cycles we are in.  How we celebrateit and work within it's 
cycles is special.  respecting and giving to it's energy is important and 
there are many celebrations world wide.  She is not owned and continously 
changes as do most things...  Lets respect each others celebrations and 
love the moon.  Celebrate with your tribe and let others celebrate with 
theirs.  Maybe someday we will be able to give the moon together.

I think people sould get riled up a bit more often. Maybe then they'd get
off their collective ass and do something besides telling other people to
sit down.

You do a good job of telling BA how to conduct a discussion without actually
adding anything to the conversation. "mellow out" "stop" "stay" Very slick.
That, and ending the message with the ideological hammerblow "plur," putting
you in firm possession of The Law, with BA as the transgressor. Forty lashes
with a lollipop.

This is one of the few discussions on here that have _not_ degenerated into
pithy interpretation and reading-between-the-lines - it has stayed pretty
"face-value". There are a few lines of argument going on here, though, NOT
centered on "what COULD be, if.." I am most concerned with "what is," and
frankly I think (and I'm embarassed to say) that the main discussion here
has to do with who's viewpoint provides the most open future for women in
the rave scene. It's kind of like 4th grade recess, but it's sort of a
perverse exercise for me in that way (I liked 4th grade). This is how I
figure out what my point of view is: by talking about it (I could make the
case that, at least around here, "argument" is some sort of taboo to be
avoided and that people will naturally be defensive toward it). I defy you
to identify the one-sidedness operating here, unless you're confusing
"one-sided" with "perspective." That's right, a challenge. But I just want
to know what you're talking about and where you're coming from; it doesn't
mean I want to beat you up.

eh?

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: reza@uclink.berkeley.edu (Full Moon)
Subject: Full Moon info...
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The full moon will be at 8:45 a.m. exactly.  At that moment the sun will
shine on the visible surface of the moon reflecting the light of the sun.
At 9:04 a.m. a lunar eclipse will occur putting the earth between the sun
and the moon.  Throughout history the full moon has been a crazy time.  The
magnetic field effects the tides and water.  Being 3/4 made of water humans
are also effected.  We all love the moon, it reminds us of change and the
cycles we are in.  How we celebrateit and work within it's cycles is
special.  respecting and giving to it's energy is important and there are
many celebrations world wide.  She is not owned and continously changes as
do most things...  Lets respect each others celebrations and love the moon.
Celebrate with your tribe and let others celebrate with theirs.  Maybe
someday we will be able to give the moon together.

From: Amy R Starkey <sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu>
Subject: Arguing vs Flaming
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9510081354.A9647-0100000@saclink1.csus.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


There has been discussions about the discomfort arguing causes many 
people on the list.  I, like many others on the list, try and avoid 
conflict as much as I can - whether that be good or bad is up to you.
However I don't believe in keeping everything sugar coated - it ends up 
becoming fake, and we want to keep our community as real and raw as we 
can, right?   I think there is a BIG difference in disagreeing and just 
calling people stupid and lame and flaming them. The main element we need 
to remember when disagreeing with someone is to ****RESPECT**** their 
opinion.  It is just as valid as yours, and this is a PERSON you are 
talking to, not just words on a computer screen. I don't mind reading 
about arguements on this list - I can learn alot by weighing the pros and 
cons of each side of the arguement and hopefully come away with a better 
perspective on it.   A 
flame war just makes me sad and I push the d button w/o reading the post 
because pointless fighting solves nothing.  I like constructive, not 
destructive.  

love,
Amy

On Sun, 8 Oct 1995, Mary Beth Barber wrote:

> This one lost it at about 1:15am when campus cops came by and
> sent out searchlights, at which point everyone panicked.
> Then again, what else do Davis cops have to do with their time?
> 

As the self-appointed official police negotiator, I got to talk to a very 
amused officer of the UCD police department. He claimed that they had 
recieved a noise complaint and therefore had to shut the party down, 
though he was almost apolegetic about doing it. Where the noise complaint 
came from has us confused, becase the only things out where we were are 
horses, weeds, and I80. But he was nice enough to give me advice on 
less-bustable locations for future events. He also complemented us on 
keeping a low profile and that if they hadn't recieved the noise 
complaint they probably wouldn't have found us.
To those who showed up: We thank you for your support. We hope you had a 
good time, even if it was only for two hours. We're sorry things 
couldn't have gone longer, but that is the nature of outdoor renegades. 
We had used that spot for parties before and gone all night, but this 
time I guess luck was not with us. We will not let this set us back and 
we will continue to throw small parties. Keep your eyes open in the 
future...
To those who didn't: Here's what you missed: A nice lawn surrounded by 
trees in a far corner of the UCD arboretum. A varied crows of 150-200 
peole ranging from ravers to gothics to punks to greeks. First DJ Jim 
(Twitch Records) started off what a nice house set. I followed with
about an hour of electro-breakbeats. Then DJ Thad came on and began
to cut up a wicked jungle set, much to the awe of a group UCD frat-boy 
types. Fifteen minutes later the cops showed up and everybody ran off.
We were out of there by 2 AM and moved the party to somebody's house.
No citations orarrests were issued.
Unfortunately, some piss-poor person(s) decided to show up and smashed 
out the window of DJ Jeyson's truck, stealing his speakers. DJ Flash's 
backpack also disappeared, with his new headphones and about 30 records.
In all, it was not the most positive experience for myself and the other 
members of the DORK posse, but we will try again. We hope to see you soon.

marc

mind in motion

To: Sfraves@hyperreal.com, Lou@wickedhuge.com, Lunar0242@aol.com,
        lestat@hooked.net
Subject: All good things....
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I must say that the frequency 8 end-of-year event was one of the most
mind-expanding, vibe-catching, cool, on-the-mark events Ive been to in along
time....

It seemed even the slightly cold weather made an excuse for all us dancers to
pack together, brining a sense of closeness to the vibe.  And what a vibe it
was!  I haven't danced that much since...well, since last week.  
I'd have to send a shout to all of the DJ's that keept the vibe going w/o any
noticable breaks.  A special commidation to Mars for a command performance.
 He drew the crowd from lulls, to feet stomping, inhibiting releaseing,
make-you-want-to-jump up and down nekkid(which some did) super cool trance.

All in all it was a impressive showing, about 150-200 for a saturday that had
so many other events going on...
 
And catching several of us SFR's together just added icing to the cake (Rikki
remember, #5). It felt like some type of surreal reunion of sorts.  And
although many now can see that I don't socalize too much, for me it's the
vibe that keepsthis engine called Adam agoin'.  
The primary function of rave for me isn't the drugs, nor sex,  but the
vibe.....
(although having thoese two formers in my life dosen't hurt either.... ;->
  )


Smile'o'meter
Sets: 9.5Smiiles (All were tight. Cyr, Mars, Myster-E always tend to offset
each other w/thier styles..)
Vibe:  9.5smiles (just because a 10 would constitute a religous experiance,
or something)
Friendship factor: 9Smiles (happy cheery people,everywhere)
Danceability area: 8Smiles (actually a beach isnt the ideal dancing space,
but, after a whole summer one gets used to it)

Overall: A sound 9 everything was near perfect with the exception of one or
two "low" points in which I will not go into detail since it wasn't any fault
of the F8 crew...

In ending,
I guess that it proves in some sense that our scene is growing positively.
There was approx 5 events going on in the area and experiance tells me that
they all most likley had strong showings as well.  Yet another summer has
ended and usually this is the transition perod for all the big time promoters
to pop up (ie. Cool World's Casper et. al.).  I look foward to the new summer
and it's fresh crop of DJ's and maybe one or two new soundsystems.  But till
then, there's always the renagades and house parties....

Peace and love, 

Adam

"Not 3 weeks and I allready lost my laminate, damn."

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Oct  8 22:00:30 1995

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Vince <vince@vmar.com>
Subject: Freq 8 !!!!!!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey Kiddies,

I haven't been much of a reviewer, but after this weekend, I felt compelled
to throw in my .02 worth.

Friday night we went to Splish. I took my friend Jason, who just moved out
here from Kansas City, to his first SF rave. Needless to say, he had the
time of his life. I was a little disappointed in the harsh ending after we
docked. The trip was about 3 hours or so. I expected this to happen, but
even still, I didn't want to get booted at 4:00. Anyway, there was talk of
this or that still going on, but we decided to head home, big day ahead, ya
know. After about 2 1/2 hours of sleep, I jumped (crawled) out of bed and
blazed up to the Sierras and went Spelunking (cave exploring). This was
beyond incredible, I'm not going to get into any details here, just believe
me this was AMAZING ! I returned home around 9:30, and was totally spent. I
thought I may just stay home and go to bed. I went and saw Jason, and he
was hoping to go to F-8 (like we had originally planned), I had messages
from Wayne that a whole bunch of us would be going also. Then I checked my
e-mail, and say the posts from the great SFRavers going to F-8. OK, I'm
convinced, I really didn't want to miss the last F-8 of the year, and a
Full Moon !! We drug our butts out to the beach, with blankets, sleeping
bags, munchies, and water. We were set for another night of fun. This is a
REALLY beautiful setting, waves crashing, tiki torches burning, campfire
raging, music just flowing (the F-8 guys really have some different,
excellent tunes), and a small, intimate, beautiful, VIBEY crowd. I guess
what I'm trying to say is, this night was pure MAGIC. Well Jason was in
awe, he thought Splish was great, but after F-8 he was just blown away,
Welcome to California !! Welcome to SFRaves ! We crashed out on the beach,
and when we awoke, the place was deserted. Wayne and Andrea were packing
up, the sound system was all gone, we were the only ones left !! We decided
to get moving before the tide washed us away, it was about 5 feet away !!
As we climbed the path up the cliffs, we came upon a large speaker about
1/2 way up to the parking lot ? Hmmmm, I guess the sound system wasn't all
loaded up yet, we started carrying it up the path, after a few breathers, I
saw Jim Cyr up ahead, he was stoked that we were lugging the cabinet up and
he mustered up enough energy to continue on up himself, lugging the
amplifier. Once we loaded up all the equiptment, they invited us back to
Jim's house and out to breakfast, it was a great relaxing morning and some
great food. Jim just couldn't stop, as soon as we got to his place he set
up the turntables and continued to spin some tunes for us. I would give you
a rundown of the music, but I was sworn to a vow of silence, so to those of
us that were there, it will be our little secret. AHHHHHHH,  so now I'm
home, still glowing, and going to bed !

The biggest hug of all,

Vince (one happy camper)


The Happy Rasta Raver
       ^ ____ ^

       {Vince}

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Oct  9 10:31:42 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id KAA20769; Mon, 9 Oct 1995 10:31:42 -0700
Received: from peseta.ucdavis.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id KAA20762; Mon, 9 Oct 1995 10:31:40 -0700

Date: Mon, 9 Oct 1995 10:31:33 -0700
Message-Id: <199510091731.KAA22417@peseta.ucdavis.edu>
X-Sender: szriffle@peseta.ucdavis.edu
Mime-Version: 1.0

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: rdriffle@ucdavis.edu (Rick Riffle)
Subject: Splish review
X-Mailer: <Windows Eudora Version 2.0.2>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I know they always say if you don't have anything nice to say then don't say
anything at all....but...uh...well I feel I need to say something and
promised my disappointed friends I would.  We show up at 11:15 like the
recording tells us and a small crowd is gathering on the dock.  People are
still exiting the boat from a previous voyage.  So we stand there while the
promoters are getting things set up.  Then we stand there some more...and
more...and more...and more.  Then somewhere around 1:00 or 1:30 a.m. a truck
screeches in, the back door flys open and out pops a generator....late!  (My
girlfriend has this theory about raves really being all about generators,
which is proven correct once again)  It's been cold waiting out there for
two hours.  So within a half an hour of the generator arriving we get on the
boat and get a plate of rice which was about the high point of the evening
for me.  The food was free so that was cool.  Remember, this shindig cost
$20 and it left over an hour late.  So then I go upstairs to deck 2 where
the dancing is taking place and Tracy is spinning.  As the boat is getting
underway everything starts vibrating including the needle...right accross
the record.  It sounded really wierd, but Tracy handled it well.  The music
was pretty good all night, but never took me anywhere.  This same feeling
was mirrored by the rest of my group of friends.  It just never got us
going.  The dance space was really compact making it difficult to get from
one end to the other.  Way too many tables.  I'm not sure if they are bolted
down or not, but they should have been removed if possible.  

Now the ambient space was just sad.  "You are planning to have ambient music
in your aqua ambience space arent you?"  This made it difficult for my
girlfriend to do her report with disco and lounge music happening.  Then the
boat operator people come and tear down all the visuals and turn all the
lights on and require it to stay that way.  All the x-ing people didn't seem
to mind all that much, but the whole feeling was just lost IMO.  There was a
small amount of ambient sporatically thrown in.  I have another plate of
rice...yeeeaaayyy :)  Then I go up and watch the dj for a while...I watch
him mix 4 or 5 songs and when I look up we are parked at the dock again.
Check the time and it's only 4:00 a.m.  The music was cut off by 4:30.  They
actuall pulled the plug in the ambient room and the song just slowed to a
stop. reir reir reeiirrr reirrrrr rrirrrrrrrrrrrrrr...  I did run into Lee
Fogel who said he had a good time so I know atleast some people liked it.
The guy on the conga drums was fucking awesome as well.  It was nice to
cruise around the bay for a while.  Not at all worth $20.  Maybe if it went
all night, but not for only three hours.  I really do wish I had more nice
things to say.....but..........good rice.

Rick

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Oct  9 10:51:23 1995

Received: from cc:Mail by ugate.inmark.com
	id AA813260797 Mon, 09 Oct 95 10:46:37 
Date: Mon, 09 Oct 95 10:46:37 
Message-Id: <9509098132.AA813260797@ugate.inmark.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: please stop using PLUR as a weapon
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


     In June of 1993 I went to (and spun hardcore at) a small completely 
     amazing renegade in Washington DC.  Brian Behlendorf was there, and we 
     had a very long conversation about love, raving, and community.  
     
     A few days later I wrote and posted an essay based on that discussion, 
     in which PLUR was articulated as a unified concept.  You can still 
     find the essay on Hyperreal's web site, in the spirit section.
     
     Anyway, in light of this tiff over my word choice when describing my 
     overwealmingly pleasant and positive experience with DJing at Your 
     Sisters' House two years ago, I'd like people to think for a second 
     about how they use PLUR.
     
     I've seen it used as a slingshot to propel criticism at others, and 
     that doesn't seem right to me.  Peace, Love, Unity, and Respect are 
     not something you toss at people when they annoy you, it's how you 
     deal with people who say or do annoying things.  It's not something 
     that you say is dead or missing from a scene or a party, it's 
     something you generate for yourself.
     
     Sometimes I feel sorry that I ever wrote or said anything about PLUR, 
     in light of how people use it to measure each other or hurt each other 
     by accusing them of lacking it.
     
     Laura

Seen in Dr. Dobb's Journal, November, 1995:


Top Ten Anagrams for "Netscape Communications"
(Copyright (c) 1995 by the author, Mike Morton <mike@morton.com>.
All rights reserved.  You may reproduce this, in whole or in part,
in any form, provided you retain this paragraph unchanged.)

10. Companies can't consume it
 9. I cannot compute sans mice
 8. Can't access 'net...I'm on opium
 7. Um, options scam can entice
 6. Net's uncommon capacities
 5. Connect communities, ASAP
 4. Mosaic IPO, etc., can stun men
 3. Optimum 'net access: An icon
 2. Connect it up; amass income

And the number one anagram for "Netscape Communications":
 
 1. Mosaic, minus neat concept

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Oct  9 11:30:05 1995

Rick: 
> [...] I look up we are parked at the dock again.

This was the first boat party I ever went to that had ins and outs. :)

> [...]  I did run into Lee
> Fogel who said he had a good time so I know atleast some people liked it.

This wasn't one of the better boat parties I've been on.  I'm sure if
Alan feels like it he can tell us the gory details of why things went
wrong.  Basically, it appeared that there was some serious miscommunication
with the boat operators.

I thought the party was fine while we were actually cruising.  Smaller
boats are much more fun though.  This one was too big and steady.  It's
the rocking on the waves with everyone falling on each other that make
boat parties such a blast.  

Still, a good time is often what you make of it.  I spent most of
my time socializing and banging my DAT machine against a table in a
vain attempt to get it unjammed.  I do wish that Garth would
get some new records or at least play some *different* old ones.  
I'm really getting tired of hearing "Rockit".
It's nice to hear an old classic thrown into the mix once in a while
but he's been spinning that one since July.

Anyway, the Sunset boat party might be better with a smaller boat
and hopefully a more cooperative crew.

ps. Hey Josh, that was a great set at Sunset!

Lee

>>From owner-ne-raves@UMDD.UMD.EDU Mon Oct  9 05:47:52 1995
>Date:         Mon, 9 Oct 1995 05:43:54 -0400
>Reply-To: "Steven Y. Tsang" <syt@po.CWRU.Edu>
>Sender: NE Raves Discussion <NE-RAVES@UMDD.UMD.EDU>
>From: "Steven Y. Tsang" <syt@PO.CWRU.EDU>
>Subject:      Re: P.L.U.R.
>To: Multiple recipients of list NE-RAVES <NE-RAVES@UMDD.UMD.EDU>
>
>just recently on mw-raves, someone asked what PLUR meant. i tried
>describing it to them as best as i could. here is what i sed. tell
>me what y'all think...
>
>the origin of PLUR
>
>alot of mw-ravers think PLUR is some philosophy dating back to Woodstock.
>true, hippys were big on peace & love. but that's not where plur came from.
>all true old skoolers know about PLUR & its significance to the entire
>rave culture, read on...
>
>frankie bones introduced raves (in the underground party sense) to the
>east coast by throwing a series of big underground partys. they were known
>as the Storm Raves. many promotors give mr.bones credit as the founding
>father of raves in america. it was at one of these Storm Raves that mr.
>bones gave a very important speech after one of his very powerful sets.
>he explained what the scene was about and why he had brought it to NY:
>peace, love, unity, and respect. when he finished everybody in the ware
>house waved their hands in the air in complete unity. for many it was the
>most beautiful speech anyone has ever heard.
>
>when ne-raves wuz started up @ the university of maryland. all the old
>skoolers still talked about frankie's speech. they talked about it so
>much that PLUR became the acronym for peace, love, unity, and respect.
>but it wuz dan freelove, the list adminstrator of ne-raves, to first
>use PLUR in his sig. as a result PLUR became an ne-raves 'thing'.
>
>however more recently the meaning of PLUR started to fade. but one
>netter (from montreal canada actually) tried redefining it the best he
>could. it is his definition that really brought about the PLUR revival
>on ne-raves and it is his definition which i chose to print in a past
>issue of PLRM.
>
>this is ecto's (brad finley's) definition of PLUR as printed in the
>July issue of PLRM:
>
>========================================================================
>we are all connected. and do you know what connects us all? on the net
>it's called PLUR. no it's not a dishwater detergent, its an acronym that
>stands for Peace, Love, Unity, and Respect. these are big words and may
>be difficult to define but here are some ideas:
>
>Peace: the calmness you find with those around you, and also inside of
>       yourself. it's tough, we often have to work at it but when you're
>       at peace with others, with ourselves and with our planet only
>       good can come of it.
>Love:  the caring you feel for friends, for strangers, for those in need
>       and also for caring you show for yourself. it's symbiotic, it's
>       about sharing whatever energy you put into something will be
>       returned to you!
>Unity: this means we all share alot of common things, regardless of our
>       age, gender, race, orientation, whatevah! we are all human beings,
>       we all need other people, & we're all in this for the happiness
>       experienced being around others. though we may have differences,
>       we all arise from the same source.
>Respect: this may mean respect for others, their ideas, their music, &
>       their lives. it's also respect for one's self: one's body and the
>       needs that it has (food, sleep). educating yourself on the
>       substances you ingest shows love and respect for your body;
>       passing on the knowledge to others shows respect and love for
>       your fellow person.
>=========================================================================
>
>that is PLUR as defined by ecto. however how one chooses to practice
>PLUR in their everday life may be different. here is how Spike (Rafael
>C Gonzalez) from ne-raves chose to practice it:
>
>=======================================================================
>    One more thing, as the hippie that i am I believe in PLUR for
>myself, in that I will practice it, and I know that it is an IDEAL, not
>everyone follows it and not everyone believes in it...it is a personal
>choice I make in an attempt to continue to develop new morals and values
>as I continue on through life.  That persoanl choice affects others and
>they react to my choice in a way which they personally choose also, this
>will not make me change my values for them, but it will cause me to react
>to their reactions of my actions.  Thus, i will be forever changing my
>ideas based on the actions of others based on my initial actions...what
>does this mean?  Well, it is just a way of saying that my views of PLUR
>are because I do feel it is possible for me to love until i am acting on
>someones belief that I am not to love.  basically, I give peace when
>given peace; i give love when given love; I am united with one when they
>seek union with me; and I respect when i am respected.
>    For every action there is an equal and opposite reaction.  There
>is evil and ther is good, and without one there can not be the other.  It
>is a philosophy of balance and wholeness that I believe PLUR is.  And no
>i dont always see it, no i dont think it exist everywhere, but I have it,
>and  in a way that is all that matters, since if it is within me, it is
>possible to be everywhere.  one is all.  we are all connected.
>
>            spikE
>=========================================================================
>
>that is how Spike chose to practive it. how u choose to practice it or
>whether or not u choose to practice it is up to u.
>
>for me i chose to practice it, when i started PLRM (Peace Love Rave
>Magazine) a year ago.
>
>PLUR,
>
>--
>________________ _______  __ _____ _______  ___ ___ ____________
>stevie t        /  ___  \|  |     /   ____|/   v   \
>syt@po.cwru.edu|   _____/|  |____ |  |    |         |
>216.556.1485___|__|______\_______||__|____|__|\_/|__|___________
>

Precedence: bulk


Allen wrote:

>Pieman and I went to see John Waters speak Saturday night and he started 
>talking about raves and Ecstacy and how he couldn't imagine a worse thing 
>than to love everybody. 

Waters has a good point here...I experienced a community working out what 
it means to love, and for a while they went through this really saccharine 
smushy state.  In trying to "love" they lost the ability to get along, in 
that any time there was the slightest disagreement many people started 
acting like snubbed or disciplined children.  The community also lost a 
sort of critical faculty:  in trying to "love" everyone and everything, the 
ability to point out what was wrong or at least displeasing was lost.  It 
got to the point that unless you agreed with this tyranny of happiness, you 
couldn't be part of the community.

Things have changed since then, as things do.

A long time ago one of the Pet Shop Boys wrote an article about why anger 
can be a good thing, and why he hangs on to his anger.  I wish I had it 
around to share.  In a world where "love" is "good" and "anger" is "bad," I 
found Neil Tennant's (I think that's the guy) essay powerful in a positive 
way.

I'm not sure where this post is going, so I'll stop here.  I think I want 
to say something about how no matter what anyone says or does or believes 
there will always be differing opinions in any community, and how love 
doesn't have to mean giving up your critical faculties and that 
some E-ing people can forget that, but it's not coming out very well right 
now.

Laura

For those of you who missed it, and there were compelling
reasons to be wishy-washy (ie SoundFactory Location), you 
missed a pretty awesome 4-hour set by Carl Cox.  I was 
afraid that he was going to play down to the SoundFactory
crowd, and not be as intense and hard as I know he can be --
but I was wrong (for the most part).  Hard and high-energy 
throughout, the set was as active (w/out being disjointed) as 
any I can remember (in case you don't know, he _works_ three 
turntables).  You owe it to yourself not to miss Carl Cox the next 
time he comes to town.  Thanks to the Spundae people for giving us 
a taste of the outside flavor.  My only suggestion would be to
have the party somewhere other than the SoundFactory, so that the
foreign talent could get a taste of the SF vibe at it's best, and
least drunk, gold-studded, and limo-driven =). (I do, however, like 
good 21 and up's).  At several points during the set I was thinking 
about how, with a better crowd, this party would have truly gone 
through-the-roof, instead of peaking in the rafters.

-Rok

GOA!!! i have just returned to the states after living 13 years in india, 
and goa was my first introduction to raving.  needless to say, i was 
completely engrossed from the first moment and can't stop since that 
point as well. the ravers there are pretty much all European (and a few 
american) tourists, quite grungy, hippy and friendly. the music is hard 
to describe... i can only say endless, mindless, hard-core, tribal, 
pounding, groovin' trance-acid. and the energy at the parties is 
incomparable, especially at sunrise when you look around and everything 
is as visually exciting as acoutically thrilling. if you are going to be 
there for new years you have struck gold, because it is the biggest 
badest craziest party, and quite the site for someone who had never been 
raving before. if drugs are your thang, then hash is availabe all over 
india for the equivilant of $1 per gram, but more common US drugs like 
acid or e are more expensive than here. definitely though, in the goa 
environment, drugs are all around but quite secondary to the music and 
the vibe... if and when you go i'd love to hear how you like it, i might 
be heading there myself at christmas. happy trippin'!!

On Mon, 9 Oct 1995, T.C.D.Hill wrote:

Hmm. Admittedly I only stayed for the first couple hours of his set, but I
was thoroughly unimpressed. He kept switching from vocal house to techno
and back every three songs or so and never landed in a solid groove,
relying on loads of breaks and weird fader volume tricks that didn't do it
for me. The low point had to be when he played "Higher State of
Conciousness." I got the impression he didn't know what to play to the
Sound Factory crowd. He wasn't bad, but I would've expected someone of his
stature to be better than average.

I also thought it disappointing that they stuck Tony in an upstairs room
the size of my bedroom with two monitors for sound.

Joe

PS - It was entertaining watching Jon Santos demonstrate various house
dancing styles.=)

	I also think that it is hard to READ someones words on the screen with
the exact tone or inflection that that person intended.  It's always hard when
someones opinions differ with your own, and when they appear in B/W on our
screens, it's easy to fly off the handle and imagine that person being pissy
or mean.  I guess sometimes =) and =/ and =( helps, but when it comes down
to it, it's DAMN hard to communicate over a monitor...I'm more of a people
person myself! 8)  
	Everyone has opinions about this or that, and even though we might
not agree with what is said, we can still learn a lot from it.  They make us
think...if everyone agreed on everything, we'd all look like Barney!!! 8P

From: Seth Joshua Horvitz <acid23@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Re: Going to Goa
To: "Archana H. Carter" <archana@dartmouth.edu>
cc: "T.C.D.Hill" <T.C.Hill@sheffield.ac.uk>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <Pine.ULT.3.91.951009170907.16006C-100000@coos>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9510091550.A2363-0100000@uclink.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I spent all of December '94 in Goa, and I have to say, I was totally 
disappointed.  I found most of the European folk to be very cliquish, and 
the drug vibe was just a little TOO heavy for me.  It was to the point 
where you couldn't have a coherent conversation with anybody, and if you 
did, it was probably about drugs.  The music is played only from DATs, 
and trust me, the dj's do not plan their segues in advance.  Eight 
minutes of each track and then BoOmCrRUnCHKAcRuNCHboOmcrrrunChBoomBoomBoom.
OUCH!  It was hard to listen to, let alone dance.  The same dj 
would play for 12 hours straight, all from about a dozen DATs, and the 
music was very ravey sounding high energy acid with lots of insulting 
"throw your hands in the air and scream" breaks.  Also, the cops have 
been demanding much larger payoffs for parties (several thousand 
dollars), so they happen much less frequently (only for X-mas and New 
Year's while I was there).

Even so, I had a really good time hanging out and watching all the freaks 
of Europe congregate on a tropical beach in India to get fucked up and 
dance.  I certainly won't forget it, and I wouldn't advise against going, 
but I would say that if you're going to go to India, spent some time 
OUTSIDE of Goa.  India has some of the most intriguing, inspiring, and 
spiritual places in the world, and Goa isn't one of them...

Seth

It used to be that really clubby clubs were purported to have a 
hairometer at the door to only allow entrance to people with
appropriately big hair.

But why check your weapons at the door when ya can point em at the
ground, fire, and "make 'em dance" just like they used to in the
cartoons and westerns!

Perhaps in the future, we can have ravey clubs with PLURometers,
assuring adequate PLURalism among attendees. Then, on the inside, we'll
be assured that all overheard conversations will sound like these:

	"Hey baaaaaby, come check out how biiiig and fluffy my PLUR is!"

	"Woaaah -- check out the PLUR on that chick!" "Huhuh" "That's Cool"

	"I got more PLUR than yo momma's pimp got duckets"

-- Niels.

PS: interesting note on PLURalism... Defs #2 and #4a #4b sound like
a better definition of PLUR than the acronym itself...

plu-ral-ism n. 1. The condition of being plural. 2. A condition of society 
  in which numerous distinct ethnic, religious, or cultural groups coexist 
  within one nation. 3. The holding by one person of more than one position 
  or office, esp. two or more ecclesiastical benefices, at the same time. 4
  Philos. a. The doctrine that reality is composed of many ultimate 
  substances. b. The belief that no single explanatory system or view of 
  reality can account for all the phenomena of life.

(1) In case anybody was wondering about that "UFO" trailing sparks all
over the sky above the last Sunset -- I was listening to the radio news
on the way home from sunset and heard that it was a soviet built MIG-25
figher being flown "acrobatically" with fireworks spewing out the back
-- it was part of some kind of air show in Alameda. I for one was in complete
awe, and given that I've never seen a plane shooting sparks out the back
while doing a power-dive, I was thinking it was a UFO myself...

(2) And speaking of UFO's ..

------- Forwarded Message

> (UPI) LONG BEACH, Calif. -- Look, up in the sky.  Is it a bird, a
> plane, the space shuttle?  No, it's Larry Walters at 16,000 feet in his 
> lawn chair.
> 
> Walters, 33, a truck driver, spent nearly two hours in the air on 
> Friday in an aluminum lawn chair suspended from a 50-foot cable
> attached to 45 helium-filled balloons. 
> 
> Among other things, he threw a scare into a couple of airline pilots 
> who happened across the path of his weird flying contraption.
> 
> "I know it sounds strange but it's true," said a Long Beach police
> officer.  "The guy just filled up some balloons with helium, strapped 
> on a parachute, grabbed a BB gun and took off."
> 
> But everything didn't go as planned and Walters had a few dicey moments 
> as he started getting numb in the cold atmosphere at 16,000 feet and
> decided to descend -- which he accomplished by popping some of the
> balloons with the BB gun.  As he neared the ground he saw power lines. 
> 
> "That's when I got scared," he said.  "Those things can fry you." 
> 
> He didn't get fried, the balloons draped themselves across the wires,
> leaving Walters dangling in his chair a few feet from the ground and he 
> dropped to earth.  The landing knocked out power in the neighborhood
> for 20 minutes.
> 
> "I have fulfilled my 20-year dream," said Walters, a truck driver for a 
> company that makes TV commercials.  "I'm staying on the ground.  I've
> proved to myself that the thing works." 
> 
> In addition to the BB gun and the parachute, Walter carried several 
> one-gallon water jugs for ballast, a life vest and a CB radio.
> 
> "But the best piece of equipment was the lawn chair," Walters said. 
> "It was a Sears.  It was extremely comfortable."
> 
> Walters told authorities that he was trying to drift to the Mojave
> Desert, site of Sunday's scheduled space shuttle Columbia landing, but 
> the winds didn't cooperate.
> 
> "I wasn't trying to upstage the space shuttle," Walters said.  "I would 
> have landed well away from there.  I just wanted to lay back and enjoy 
> it all, but I had to do something when my toes started getting numb."
> 
> Police said they probably would not file charges against Walters.  But 
> the Federal Aviation Administration was investigating, mainly because 
> of the scare Walters gave the airline pilots who came across him at
> 16,000 feet in his flying lawn chair. 
> 

------- End of Forwarded Message

i guess living in india meant that somehow i could find those tourists 
who weren't drug obsessed and "cliquish", and like all people, every 
tourist is different. the music in '94 was not as powerful as in '93 or 
'92 (i'm sorry to hear that you didn't like it), but it has its own 
attractions if you let it infiltrate your system. the cops in india 
should be taken as what they are, not law enforcers but bribe-obsessed 
and ego-centered people (with a few exceptions), and i find it amazing 
that those who throw parties in goa manage to bribe the cops with the 
little money that they do.  the smaller parties around anjuna and baja 
are worth a try too, the vibe there is a lot mellower and people tend to 
be more sociable then at the major parties of christmas and new years. in 
the end though i totally agree that one should not spend their entire 
time in goa in visting india. for all the time i lived there i didn't get 
to visit all the places i wanted to, and still think about returning to 
do as much as i can. for me, india is the most spiritual and true place 
in the world, and i love it that as a tourist you discovered its 
spirituality in a non-artificial sense. (other tourists would consider 
goa spirtual, i think its more of a fun, lax, party  zone) anyway, i'm 
glad you liked it there....

On Mon, 9 Oct 1995, Seth Joshua Horvitz wrote:

> 
> I spent all of December '94 in Goa, and I have to say, I was totally 
> disappointed.  I found most of the European folk to be very cliquish, and 
> the drug vibe was just a little TOO heavy for me.  It was to the point 
> where you couldn't have a coherent conversation with anybody, and if you 
> did, it was probably about drugs.  The music is played only from DATs, 
> and trust me, the dj's do not plan their segues in advance.  Eight 
> minutes of each track and then BoOmCrRUnCHKAcRuNCHboOmcrrrunChBoomBoomBoom.
> OUCH!  It was hard to listen to, let alone dance.  The same dj 
> would play for 12 hours straight, all from about a dozen DATs, and the 
> music was very ravey sounding high energy acid with lots of insulting 
> "throw your hands in the air and scream" breaks.  Also, the cops have 
> been demanding much larger payoffs for parties (several thousand 
> dollars), so they happen much less frequently (only for X-mas and New 
> Year's while I was there).
> 
> Even so, I had a really good time hanging out and watching all the freaks 
> of Europe congregate on a tropical beach in India to get fucked up and 
> dance.  I certainly won't forget it, and I wouldn't advise against going, 
> but I would say that if you're going to go to India, spent some time 
> OUTSIDE of Goa.  India has some of the most intriguing, inspiring, and 
> spiritual places in the world, and Goa isn't one of them...
> 
> Seth
> ///////{{{{{{{(((((((<<<<<<<<<<acid232dica>>>>>>>>>>)))))))}}}}}}}\\\\\\\
>  
> 
>

---- Begin Forwarded Message

>The Fiber Collective presents:
>
>FIBER: A TRANSMEDIA FASHION SHOW AND CELEBRATION
>OCTOBER 14, 1995
>150 Folsom Street (at Spear)
>San Francisco
>
>Party: 10 pm-6 am
>Fashion show: 12:30 am
>Tickets: $7 in advance/$10 at the door
>Advance tickets available at:
>Bulletproof, 589 1/2 Haight Street
>Fiber information: 415.789.8448
>http://www.newtype.com/NewType/cyber/fashion/fiber/index.htm
>
>SAN FRANCISCO- On Saturday, October 14, 1995, a party called Fiber will
>weave together the digital technology of today with the fashion designs of
>tomorrow in a presentation of new work by Bay Area artists. Fiber shifts
>away from the traditional fashion show paradigm by showcasing the garments
>in the sensory-overloading environment they were created to be worn in.
>Models are replaced with dancers, runways with podiums. Transmedia artists,
>laser technicians, DJs, and musicians are working with the fashion
>designers to create a pure thoughtspace celebrating creativity,
>collaboration and global communication via the Internet. A team of
>videographers will shoot the festivities, mix the images with surreal
>prerecorded footage, textual messages, and computer animation produced
>on-the-fly, and project the visual blends as hypnotic electric wallpaper.
>The entire psychedelic spectacle will be transmitted onto both a World Wide
>Web page and over the Internet in real time for viewing with CU-SeeMe
>desktop videoconferencing software. The Fiber Collective embraces computers
>and the Internet as empowering tools enabling individuals to generate and
>distribute their own media content without the need for deep-pocketed
>middlemen. The process is the product.
>
>Fiber producer:
>-Annie Phyo is a digital video and computer artist, webmistress and
>professional multimediatrix. She has worked with CyberLab7 and is a
>founding member of Dimension7, two experimental media production houses in
>San Francisco.
>
>Fiber fashion designers:
>-Tria Connell was sent here from planet Zartax to design intergalactic
>outfits for the masses.
>-Oliver Helden designs space suits for next millennium's riot nrrrds
>and spent several years breathing fire as part of the tribal noise
>band Crash Worship.
>-Penelope Star, a company founded last year by Susan Robinson and
>Aaron Buhrz, designs and produces mod space clothing for superheroines.
>Their garments are available at Rolo and Villains in San Francisco.
>-Kelly Sparks' line of technofemme sleekwear is constructed from
>photographic slides and holographic fabric. She is an assistant designer
>for Esprit by day.
>
>Fiber DJs:
>The Baroness AKA Charlotte; Bruno; Felix (Black Diamond); Finn
>
>Fiber ambient musician:
>Sound sculptures by Marcus on electrified violin.
>
>Fiber VJs:
>Dimension7: Ani*Mation, Austin Lambe, Ron Ciron,
>Chris Dodson (image muse), Dan Todd, Tom Williams, Kurt Wobken
>
>Fiber lasers:
>Skippy Raftery and Crystal Soiu
>
>Fiber installation art:
>Michael Dates; Nathan Scott; Crystal Soiu
>
>Fiber textual cut-ups:
>David Pescovitz and Jody Radzik
>
>Fiber World Wide Weave page:
>Web Design Group: Annie Phyo and Eli Sagiv
>
>
>FIBER INFORMATION:
>Annie Phyo
>voicemail: 415.789.8448
>e-mail: aniphyo@slip.net

Subject: Re: please stop using PLUR as a weapon
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 9 Oct 95 18:14:22 PDT
In-Reply-To: <199510092244.PAA21094@netcom5.netcom.com>; from "Niels P. Mayer" at Oct 9, 95 3:43 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


What's with this PLUR paranoia, anyway?  Where are all these
high priests banishing heretics from our church for not
strictly adhering to the holy PLUR doctrine?
Does anyone really think that there's some kind of
PLUR fervor taking over the scene and trying to brainwash
everyone near it?

The only place in the rave scene where I see significant PLUR
activity is on the dance floor, where a minority of the party
people hang out.  The scene has matured, most people go to
parties to be with their clique, have some fun, check out the
crowd, see and be seen.  We have promoters with stuff to prove,
plenty of politics, in crowds and out crowds, attention seekers
and egos galore.  So where's all of this much feared PLUR stuff,
that dreaded "weapon" that threatens us all?

Usually, it's on the dance floor, when everyone is dancing and
in sync with the music - that's the only time I really feel
peace and love and unity and respect all at once.  In other
places, like on this list, pieces of it do show up quite often,
but I really wouldn't worry about it *too* much.  It's really just
the dance floor you have to watch out for, especially by the beach 
or on the grass; that's where the horror of PLUR lies waiting...

Lee :)
___________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com   (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )   lee@hyperreal.com

Subject: a Ra for the Full Moon
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Hey all!

Gregg, Mona, Kip and I went to the Full Moon Celebration held on Saturday 
Night with Gateway, J&K Sound and others.  It was hella fun.

We set up a little sand circle altar, complete with  objets de 
force aquired just that day by Gregg and myself, at the Laney College 
flear market.  And Mona contributed her prized star candle. 

It was very satisfying, as many poeple came over to look 
and admire.  My my my, it's nice to be appreciated!

Ethan, by the way, played an absolutely amazingly good set.  I'm not sure 
who it was who went after him as I was dog tired and fell asleep.  I must 
be getting old as for the life of me I just can't stay awake 
sometimes...*sigh*

Kudos to the organizers who had it all down...including a map point along 
with folks to organize parking.  Thankyou!

Also the system was AMAZING.  J&K sound, via Rob (?), donated it!  Top of 
the line equipment with people there who really know how to make the most 
of it.  I was so impressed.

And in the end, we cleaned the beach and made it look more beautiful than 
it already did, as was pointed out to the very friendly park ranger who 
appeared in the morning to collect trash from the bins and basically 
check up on the space.  She was cool.

She also let us in on a little park ranger in-joke.  So, when you have a 
big thousand soul smashup...THAT's a rave.  When you treat the beach 
kindly and there aren't a huge mad ton of people, then that's a "ra."  

See you up at the Tribal Future thang!

love and kisses,

Ann

Subject: PLUR, mission vortex, the sunset, the moon and me
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

hi.

being a writer, or at least thinking of myself as such (oftentimes for no
justifiable reason whatsoever), it's hard to keep myself from writing about
the interesting issues that boil (or effervesce) up on sfraves. so i won't
try.

everything i have to say i want to say first - which, of course, is a logical
impossibility. 

i'm rambling. 

to start: mission vortex was beautiful. i wish every one of you (who wanted
to) could have been there. each of us who worked to make it go off put a lot
of love and sweat into the event, and it showed. from the shrine i created
(from which not a single thing was stolen) to the massage rooms to the
swinging hammock room to the dreampaint room to the soundhealing room to the
main dance hall - beautiful. 

what made the evening especially wonderful was the... what?... the energy of
the people there. it had the magic of what the seasoned old-school ravers
nostalgically look back to when the rave scene was still in its youth. and
what would this be? well i'm not sure, because i'm a new-school raver. PLUR?
yes. passion, joy, curiosity? yes. magic? oh yes, a good bit of magic.

where are we going as a community? are we even going anywhere? no community
can move without movement of the individuals. where are we headed? where are
you headed? where am i headed? 

i'm always wondering, wondering. mission vortex was a departure from the
normative status of rave-culture. no techno - but we danced all night. (well,
almost.) people were giving massages and painting and drumming and meditating
and dancing and just sitting on their haunches, looking into each other's
eyes - no departure from what i think of as a rave experience to be. and yet,
it was very different from the norm.

how do the rave world and the spirit world relate? we're finding out, with
events like the Vortex. 

my hope is that people continue to dare to throw events that depart from the
conventional experience. maybe they won't work. in that case, they're
unlikely to be repeated. but if, on an off chance, they not only work, but
they zing those involved, and if that zing spreads to other events, then
haven't we just grown as a community? 

the truth as i see it is that we grow as a community every time one of us
grows as an individual and shares that new wisdom (or pain) with his or her
neighbor. the macrocosm exists within the microcosm and vice-versa. that's
the only way the whole system that is this cosmos holds together, as i see
it.   

but you know me (no you don't) - communty and consciousness are my fetishes.
and a good thing about these two fetishes is that each feeds the other. 

and then, the next day - sunset! i'll be sad to watch the sun set on sunset,
even if it's only for the winter. [strange thought: winter already? straight
from summer to winter in california. i'm exposing my new england roots, i
know.]

an ode to sunset: thou, smileravey beyond compare, will be sorely missed. 

and the moon! she hung like a gigantic stage prop over the berkeley hills as
i biked home. no, it was as though the moon i'd seen previous was merely a
prop, and now i was finally seeing the real moon, in all her naked living
splendor. 

i don't need a shrink because i dance. okay, sure, i admit it, i've been seen
dancing in masks. this sunset, i was batman. [and yes, i am full-grown. if
you have trouble reconciling those two facts, maybe i can help you - later.]
and so, following this logic, sunset is part of my therapy. big thanks to
pacific for throwing it and to all of you for making it the peaceful joyous
celbration it it. sure, some people are on Style Patrol. but as my favorite
poet, rumi says "dog's saliva doesn't contaminate the Ocean."
 
all forms of sweetness are welcome here. and if you can't give me honey, i'll
even take a pink envelope of saccharine. my point? unclear.

love thyselves. there is much to love. to have an open heart is to live -
and, from time to time, to hurt. god i'm rambling now. but it's fun all the
same. 

[for all of you who made it through this message, a final addendum. our
berkeley co-op is no longer looking for two female housemates - but we are
still looking for one. so if you know anyone who's looking for a warm house
in north berlekey, pass this message along. and if she happens to have 750
amazing techno cd's - shazam! (but not requisite.) requisite _is_ 25+,
however. we're trying to keep an age as well as a gender balance.]

be well, beautiful people. 

from shalom
or batman
or whoever the hell i am...

On Mon, 9 Oct 1995, Joe Rice wrote:

> 
> Hmm. Admittedly I only stayed for the first couple hours of his set, but I
> was thoroughly unimpressed. He kept switching from vocal house to techno
> and back every three songs or so and never landed in a solid groove,
> relying on loads of breaks and weird fader volume tricks that didn't do it
> for me. The low point had to be when he played "Higher State of
> Conciousness." I got the impression he didn't know what to play to the
> Sound Factory crowd. He wasn't bad, but I would've expected someone of his
> stature to be better than average.
> 

Yes, I stayed for two hours of Carl Cox's set, and, was quite 
disappointed. From listening to a hardtrance oriented compilation of his, 
I expected faster and more melodic, but found him instead shifting back 
and forth, seemingly trying reach for something, but not quite getting there.
And I definitively think that this is less a reflection of his DJing 
ability, and much more indicative of the vibe put out by that crowd in 
that space. As a matter of fact, I so disliked the Sound Factory, that 
even if GOD (!), herself, were to spin a set there, I may very well stay 
home instead.

Narnia has been rescheduled for October 21st... My partner and I were 
going to build our Geodesic Dome at Narnia on its originally scheduled 
date. Unfortunately for us the new dates conflicts with our long planned 
film festival, the Low Res Film + Video Festival.

I've gone to every Narnia (there have been 3 so far), while each one has 
been different than the last, I've always enjoyed myself - really the 
best large party I've been to.

If you make it down have a blast, be sure to stay for the sunrise.

You can find all the info you need on their SF info # (415) 437-4065...

By chance you don't go down... (BSP) Please come by our event - we will 
be screening some really great short films including a world premiere 
from Nick Philip (an animated video for a Sun Electric track of sorts)...

You can find all the info you need on our fest at www.lowres.com/lowres/

thanks, Jonathan

Okay yall, here is what happened: 
 
I work for a company thats at 562 Mission St. in The City. It's the
Building to the _left_ of Golden Gate colledge if youre facing the campus.
About two Fridays ago. I was up on the roof having a smoke at around
Midnight. (Were all working real late hours to meet the Xmas crunch) I was
looking down across the street. There were about 15-20 people looking to be
in there teens-early 20s. Just cold chillin across the street. They hung
outside for a bout 5min then all of a sudden they all walked into the
building they were hanging out in front of! After that there was a steady
stream of cars, trucks, ect. dropping off people to go in. Well, before I
went home that night I walked over to take a peak inside. I couldn't see
anything (looked all dark to me) but I could hear some thumping tunes from
somewhere in side.  
 
Anyone know what this party is (was)? Is it a regular thing?   The add. I
think is about 561 Mission St.

>From owner-krak@ugcs.caltech.edu Thu Sep 28 22:42:00 1995

From: Abu Hajj <jihad@ugcs.caltech.edu>
To: krak@mince.ugcs.caltech.edu
Subject: Here is a present to you
Message-Id: <Pine.HPP.3.91.950928223836.14921A-100000@mince.ugcs.caltech.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Status: RO


Here is a present to all of you.  A very entertaining poem by the American
Children's Poet Shel Silverstein.  Hope that all of you find this as amusing
as I just did.

Title:     The Worlds Greatest Smoke Off 
 
In the laid back California town of sunny San Raphael
Lived a girl named Pearly Sweetcake,
You probably knew her well
She was stoned 15 of her 18 years
And her story was widely told,
That she could smoke 'em faster
Than any dude could roll
 
Well her legend finally reached New York
That grove street walk up flat
Where dwelt the Calistoge Kid,
a beatnik from the past
He'd been rolling dope since time began
And he took a cultured toke and said
"Jim, I can rollem faster than any chick can smoke"
 
So a note gets sent to San Raphael
For the Championship of the World
The Kid demands a smoke off
"Well bring him on" sayz Pearl
"I'll grind his fingers off his hands,
 he'll roll until he drops"
Sayz Calistoge "I'll smoke that chick 'til she blows up and pops"
 
So they rent out Yankee Stadium 
And the word is quickly spread
Come one come all, who walk or crawl
Tickets just two lids a hit
And from every town in Hamlet
Over land and sea they speed
The Worlds greatest dopers
With the Worlds greatest weed
 
Hashishes from Morocco
Hemp smokers from Peru
And the Shashnicks from Bagoon, who smoke the deadly Pugaroo
And those who call it 'Light of Life'
And those that call it 'Boo'
 
See the dealers and their ladies
Wearing turquoise,lace, and leather
See the narcos and the closet smokers
Puffing all together
>From the teenies who smoke legal
To the ones who've done some time
To the old man who smoked reefer, back before it was a crime
 
And the 'Grand Old House That Ruth Built'
Is filled with the smokes and cries
Of 50,000 screamin' heads, all stoned out of their minds
And they play the National Anthem
And the crowd lets out a roar
As the spotlight hits the Kid and Pearl
Ready for their smokin' warrrr...
 
At a table piled up high with grass, high as a mountain peak
Just tops and buds of the rarest flowers
Not one stem, branch or seed
I mean a Maui, a Wowie, a Panama Red, Alcopoco Gold
Keef from East Afghanistan, and that rare Alaska cold
And there are sticks from Thailand, Games from the Islands
And Bangkok's bloomin' best, 
And some of that wet imported shit, that capsized off Keywest
There's Wahaukan tops, and Kenya bang, and Riveria fluors
And that rare Manhatten Silver that grows down in the New York sewers
And there's bubbling ice cold lemonaide, and sweet grapes by the bunches
And there's Hershey bars, and Oreos in case anybody gets the muchies
 
And the Calistoge Kid he smiles
And Pearly she just grins
And the drums roll low, And the crowd yells 'go go go'
And the Worlds first Smoke Off begins...
 
Well the Kid he flicks his fingers once, ZAP that first joints rolled
Pearl takes one toke with her famous lungs, and WHOOSH that roach is cold
Then the Kid he rolls his superbomb that would paralyze a moose
And Pearl takes one mighty hit,<inhale sound> that bombs diffused
And then He rolls three in just ten seconds
And she smokes 'em up in nine
And everybody sits back and sayz "This just might take some time."
 
See the blur of flying fingers,
See the red coal burning bright
As the night turns into morning, and the morning fades to night
And the Autumn turns to Summer
And a whole damned year is gone
And the two still sit, on that roach filled stage
Smokin' and rollin' on...
 
With tremblin hands, he rolls his J's
With fingers blue and stiff
She coughs <coughing> and stares
With bloodshot gaze and puffs through blistered lips
And as she reaches out her hands for another stick of gold
The Kid he gasps "Damnit bitch, theres nothin' left to roll"
"Nothing left to roll!" screams Pearl, "Is this some twisted joke.
 I didn't come here to fuck around, Man I come here to smoke."
 
And she reaches 'cross the table, and grabs his boney sleeves
And crumbles his body between her hands, like dry and brittle leaves
Flickin' out his teeth and bones, like useless stems and seeds
And then she rolls him in a Zigzag, and lights him like a roach
And the fastest man, with the fastest hands, goes up in a puff of smoke
 
In the laid back California town of sunny San Raphael
Lives a girl named Pearly Sweetcake,
You probably know her well
She been stoned 21 of her 24 years
And her story is still widely told,
How she still can smoke 'em faster
Than any dude could roll
 
Way off in New York City
On a street that has no name,
There's the hands of the Calistoge Kid
In the Viper Hall of Fame
And underneath his fingers,
There's a little golden scroll
That sayz:
 
      "Beware of being the roller, when there's nothing left to roll."

------------------------------------------------------------------------
Give me ambiguity or give me something else.

On Tue, 10 Oct 1995, Geoffrey Walton Allen wrote:

>   
>   i'm thinking of going to goa this winter as well and was wondering 
>   how one would go about preparing for such an experience. are
>   there any books or websites you'd recommend? how does one go
>   about finding the famed parties? how do other southern locales(kerala,
>   tamil nadu, etc.) compare?  considering that i've never
>   left this country, i'm expecting to be completely annihilated
>   by the sheer otherness of the place, so any advice at all
>   would be deeply appreciated.
>                                 peace,  
>                                    geoff
> 
> 
probably the best book to read would be the lonely planet, its written by 
true travelers who really know the knittygritty of india, other books can 
tell you prices, hotels, restuarants, but they don't cater to the poorer 
type of tourist, who are the ones that end up in the excellent (but 
grungy) hotels and go to all the parties.  from what i know, the parties 
in the summer are up in the mountains (Manali, Nagar, etc) because its 
not freezing then, slowly (i don't know exactly how) the people that 
throw them, and all the people that follow, move southwards (skipping the 
capital) to goa for december. small parties happen the whole month, but 
the biggest ones are on christmas and new years. then they hang around in 
goa for maybe a month more and then start moving again (with people 
following again) to places like kerela. to find out exactly when and 
where things are happening the best way would be to stay in Pahargangh in 
delhi (quite the shithole, but inexpensive and entertaining once you've 
met people), and to ask people there who have just come back from 
following the party scene (don't worry there are plenty of those people) 
where they were and where they think the parties are heading (it would be 
best to ask more that one person, because there will be more than one 
story). like i told dave scruton, if you tell me when you're going and i 
happen to be there at the same time i'd be more than willing to help, i'm 
much more comfortable and knowledgeable in that setting than i seem to be 
in the US (even more so here on the east coast).
one party i heard about is worth describing. the party-throwers had made 
their way to the more southern tip of india and had found the ideal place 
to have a fat party.  to reach it, you had to go in a wooden boat along a 
river that was surrounded on both sides by extremely tall, steep cliffs. 
after awhile on the boat, you came upon a sandy beach sticking right out 
of the bottom of one cliff. at the base of the cliff on the beach was a 
cave where part of the speaker system and the turntables were set up, and 
other speakers were out on the beach area. from what i heard there was 
mass attendance and the party lasted for four days.... god i wish i could 
have been there.
archana
(e racer)

i got all inspired listening to a windup on a dj osheen tape and wrote this:

cheekbones  chins  mouths
suspend
open
in spider webs
of expectation
 
drowsy  deliberate  air
shared
in
lungs drenched
with energy
 
eyes  wide  glued
to
racing
minds,
still floating
in near hesitation

dense  conscious  blood
pounds
tight hearts
 
hands  arms  shoulders
waists  legs  feet
stir
tremble
or
freeze
 
slowly
  then faster
     and faster still
        breath
        beat
        movement
          swell  grow  ache
with uncertainty
          confidence
 
climax
life and
   music
     explode
together
 
souls  thoughts  energy
overflowing
limbs  hearts  screams
of pure ecstasy
and respect
burst in
unity

Hello SFRavers -
 This is a reminder about the "SFRaves Peninsula Picnic" that's happening
next week Saturday , Oct. 21st.

 It will be at Edgewood County Park and nature preserve , near HW 280 at
the border of San Carlos and Redwood City. I will post directions to this 
park next week - it's within 5 minutes of the Edgewood Road exit west
of HW 280. 

 For those of you who enjoy hiking, there are two hiking trails almost 2 
miles in length, one hiking trail of 1.4 miles, and other that's 3/4 mile long.
I haven't tried these trails , but they are supposed to wind through grassland, 
oak woodland, and chaparral . Also a ridge with a great views of Skyline 
Ridge, Huddart Park, the San Anfreas Valley, the Crystal Springs Lake, and 
the Bay.

 As I mentioned before , the regulations say "Loud radios and the playing of
amplified musical instruments are not permitted". So , I am encouraging
folks to bring drums and other non-amplified instruments! I'm not a practiced
musician , but I will bring some conga bells that I will try to discretely 
torture while other folks are making music!

 The park opens at 8AM - I'll be there at that time to reserve a nice picnic
area for us that's in a little valley , but within an easy walk of the 
restrooms and a telephone. I see us being there until 3PM - so show up any 
time before then!

 See you folks next week ...

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

Subject: What 'is' a raver?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The non-techno people I befriend and come to get acquainted with tend to give
me the same reaction when they find that I listen and dance to trance,
breakbeat et. al.  And that reaction is disbelief. 
 Mind you, this isn't all I listen to, I have a myriad of various radio
stations programmed on my car deck, and a fine collection of cassetes ranging
from Beatles to Reggae, Hip Hop to Psychelldeic Furs, Funky disco tunes to
japanese rock.  However, when I toss in some hard trance, first Im asked:
"You listen to this?",
"Um, yeah."
Followed by, "Do you go to like, those raves and stuff?"
"Um, yeah..."
The conversation tends to die off there for a bit.  But this statement ALWAYS
ends the conversation.
"Oh, it's just that you don't look like the kind of person who listens to it
(techno)."

What I want to know is:

WHAT THE HELL IS A "RAVER" SUPPOSED TO LOOK LIKE???

I guess I broke some kinda soical mold.  Since Im hispanic I guess I'm
supposed to be into, like the Isley Brothers or motown or something.....  I
honestly didn'y realise that I have to get a "Techno Seal of Approval".  I
don't have any Alien clothes, I gave away all my funny hats, what else is
there???

I do love the scene and those in it, and would help out in any way that I
can... To me that is a raver....

well enuff jabber for now,

Adam

"Im sick & tired of hearing things by neurotic, psychotic, pigheaded,
politicians. 
All I want is the truth now, just give me some truth"

no one in particular. obvioulsy there is a raver style, but i think 
ravers are people who like to party and dig the "vibe", the feeling 
of harmony and togetherness. no matter how you dress or what you look 
like you have the capacity to enjoy music. people have no right to 
question that.
dima

I get the same reaction, but most the time from Ravers.  Mainly because I 
dress up in club clothes & usually don't wear the stereotypical raver 
clothes.  I enjoy dressing up & fixing myself up; & I love the whole rave 
scene & have met some of the best people through it!!!  Most the time I 
feel like I'm dancing all night with family!!

Remember...don't judge a book by its cover!!

LUV - Teena

Was Jesus a RAVER???

Ten to twenty billion years ago, the big bang brought the universe into 
existence. Eleven to twelve billion years later, life appeared on earth. In 
three to four billion year's time, life evolved from a single microscopic 
point to encompass and change the surface of the earth. From this point, it 
takes only about 500 years for life to devour earth's resources. To survive, 
we either find a better way to husband our resources or leave the planet. 
Ultimately, though, there is no escape, for if we manage to survive resource 
depletion, our descendents will have a mere five to seven billion years to 
escape destruction, when the sun expands and vaporizes earth.

<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<UFO The United Fruitcake
Organization<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<

I get the same reaction, but most the time from Ravers.  Mainly because I 
dress up in club clothes & usually don't wear the stereotypical raver 
clothes.  I enjoy dressing up & fixing myself up; & I love the whole rave 
scene & have met some of the best people through it!!!  Most the time I 
feel like I'm dancing all night with family!!

Remember...don't judge a book by its cover!!

LUV - Teena

Non-ravers just can't concieve that we just *can't* be molded!
I am constantly surprised when I meet sfravers I haven't before.  None of 
you look like I imagined, and I *LIKE* that!  Each of you are so unique 
and it brings such richness to the rave community. God, it would be so 
awful if we all fit into some sort of raver mold.  If someone doesn't 
understand that, I find it useless to explain and I say, "you just have 
to experience it, that's all".  People are too used to making judgements 
by how someone looks.  I know in my heart who I am, and if someone else 
doesn't understand, I'm still comfortable in my identity (now I'm not 
insinuating that you aren't, Adam :):).

love to you all,
Amy

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: right to our self
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This in reply to many
posts about
E and Death

A person has the right
the universal right
to their own body
their own mind
and what they do with it.

Does a person
ultimately have the right
to judge what another person does
to their own body
or mind
that does not appreciably effect
that first person?
How can I say 
what is ultimately "right"
for another
and that one path 
will lead here,
another here?

(and all action effects others actually
but how can we be sure how)

I understand caring
and concern
but each should be
on an individual basis
a specific basis.

In this case
I have the right
to make my own decisions
on what I injest
what risks I will take
and the consequences they may have.

I know there are those
who do not consider
how they may effect others
with their actions
irresponsible.
Do we live for the condition?

Change the environment
and the people will 
change themselves.
   (an idea from Buckminster Fuller)

Love     Throcka
