Hello, all-

     If you don't recognize the name/address, it's because this is my first
post to sfraves.  I've been on for a few weeks and deeply enjoy the
discusions, reviews, even the arguments.  
    First I'll say that I went to my first rave in 93'; I think it was a
Wallyworld.  I heard Dan, Carlos, and Hardkiss for the first time and I
changed religions. --spiritually--
    I was a very shy person when I was young and parting changed my life.   I
wasn't hardcore till this year and now I can't get enough of the love,
family, and equallity this community provides.

I am currently working full time for the Lawerence Livermore National Lab-
doing a student research program.   I also take two night school classes
studing to be an environmental engineer(at DVC).  I am also an individual
distributer of health products.  AND I party every week.

busy busy busy -I wanna throw down a review while I can...
I went to Planet uh-because I wanted to hear my friend eric(Essence) spin
along with Ghost and Simon(Great set- best part of the evening), The space
was at the paint ball arena in S. Clara- it was like a maze w/ green walls
(real phunky/kool)
The worst part of the night was that some fools stole almost everyones stuff-
just walked out with handfulls of jackets, bags, and purses- w/o
confrontation. :-(
Vibe was bad but the friends I connected with and Sunset on Sunday just made
my weekend great...

enough said for now...

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Oct 11 23:36:28 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id XAA11730; Wed, 11 Oct 1995 23:36:28 -0700

From: Sshivaa@aol.com

Date: Thu, 12 Oct 1995 02:35:42 -0400
Message-ID: <951012023539_122017446@emout04.mail.aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
cc: kchance@haverford.edu, TGrenager@aol.com
Subject: thoughts, wishes, ideas, musings...
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

if love was food i would eat all day.
if music was grape jelly i would smear myself with it until there wasn't any
more left in the jar.
if smiles were sunshine, i would tan and be tanned - morning, day and night.

what is a raver? look into her heart, his heart. does she know how to boogie?
does he welcome his neighbors into his family?  do they know the value of
community? can the brother get down? 

i don't give a fuck what you're wearing, or not wearing, how long or short
your hair is, what kind of shades you've got, or if you've got the vogue
slouch. it'll be a black day when these characteristics come to typify the
raver, if they ever do. that's the day i check out. 

what do i think a raver is? an explorer. a celebrant. a person who's so
passionate about the music, the community, the vibe that he or she stays up
all night long, dancing, talking, or just slouching by the speakers,
entranced.  

personally, i rave as a part of my celebration of creation. but i don't
expect everyone to share my views. everyone brings their own two cents to our
community of ravers and when we put them all together... we're rich!      
 
ranting and raving,
shalom

At 12:43 AM 10/12/95, THROCKA@aol.com wrote:
>this in response to many posts
>prompted be "E and Death"
>
>E does not make this person
>who is not prone to having sex
>wish to have sex.
>I can only speak for myself
>I can not speak for all.
>Can you?

        I agree. There is no such thing as an aphrodisiac, only things that
cause subconscious behaviours and processes bubble up to the surface into
behaviours, language, and conscious thoughts.  I do find, though, that one
of the things that e can teach you is the rediculousness of genital-based
sexuality.  Once you realize that sex is just the exchange of energy (in
the form of emotions like love, which is a barely perceptible and
articulable form of energy) you realize that your whole being is what is
having sex, you, your body, your mind not just a little part of your body.
        then again, i've never experienced the two things in combination
and, actually, the one i am trying to transcend and the other i'm trying to
understand (and failing because i don't seem to get enough ;) ha ha ha
        is that ambiguous enough for you =)

                peace,
                        brad

	(( Sorry if this message appears more than once, I'm having some 
	transmission problems.))

Hi-
	I am dave.  This is actually the first time I have posted to 
SFRaves.....though i would have preferred my first posting to be no more 
than an introduction and some reflective thoughts, I also have a great 
favor to ask...
	But first, a brief introduction...I have been partying on and off 
since 1992.   The Basics of Thanksgiving, '92 may have been the 
experience that convinced me of the primal joy and beauty of the rave.  
I'm sure any of you who were there can attest to the epic proportions of 
that particular party.  I went out every now and again in '93 and '94, 
and then early this year I started partying more consistently.  I have to 
say I've had an amazing summer, in large part thanks to the great times 
at sunset, come/unity, and wicked. I've relished the experience of 
feeling bonds with friends grow tighter, and developing new connections 
with people.  I hope to meet more of you all as the party continues. 
	My most conspicuous feature was formerly my mane of dark brown 
hair, which I often wore in a pony tail.  I have since deleted my locks... 
1/4 inch of fuzz remains.  I was also the guy with the camera at a 
few of the Richmond sunsets.
	Well, here is my predicament.  I haven't been out much in the 
last month, because i've been preparing for the subject GRE in biology, 
which is this Saturday.  Needless to say, I'm itching to lift my feet.  
Until today, I was really psyched to go to the sunset boat party (the 
day after my test!!) with three friends.    One of us went to Ameba today 
to get tickets, and she bought the last ONE ticket.   
	What can I say?  We're all really dissapointed, and not really 
sure what to do with that one ticket.   So, if anybody has an extra, so 
that at least two of us could party down on the boat on Sunday, please 
please contact me.  We will be verrrrrryyyy grateful.

	Please resond privately to:

	<chicken@uclink.berkeley.edu> or (510) 654-1755 

	Thank you thank you thank you............-dave.

goa is a place in india on the western coast, near Bombay.  it is on the=20
beach (not as scenic as other beaches in india) and is one of the spots=20
where many tourists go to rave on....

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Oct 12 13:53:10 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id NAA21149; Thu, 12 Oct 1995 13:53:10 -0700
Received: from coos.dartmouth.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id NAA21144; Thu, 12 Oct 1995 13:53:04 -0700
Received: by coos.dartmouth.edu (5.65/DEC-Ultrix/4.3)
	id AA01421; Thu, 12 Oct 1995 16:52:57 -0400
Date: Thu, 12 Oct 1995 16:52:56 -0400 (EDT)
From: "Archana H. Carter" <archana@Dartmouth.EDU>
X-Sender: archana@coos
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: intro
Message-Id: <Pine.ULT.3.91.951012163254.29069D-100000@coos>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

i've been on sfraves for maybe a couple of weeks now... and i slowly 
found out that when people join they intoduce themselves. so i guess i'm 
abit late but here goes:
i'm short, show my half-indian blood through my face, and have dirty 
black dreads that are finally past my shoulders.
i was born in dc, but right after nursery school my father got posted in 
india and took the job because my mother is indian and they both felt 
that their kids should be exposed to indian culture. we ended up staying 
there for good, coming back to the us in the summer.  i really got into 
raving about 2 and a half years ago when i went to goa on a trip with 
friends and ended up at the new years rave and left mind-blown and 
addicted. last summer i was in santa cruz with my best friend, turtle, 
and stayed with her sister, ilana, and ilana's boyfriend (now husband) 
nic (dj jalapeno).  california reminds me a lot of home because it is 
laid back and people welcome you into their hearts without even thinking 
twice.  the parties were even more intense than goa, because i saw for 
the first time a real sense of community and bonding, and i finally took 
a good look at why the music seemed to be going on forever without 
stopping once.  last summer it also came to me in a sudden realization 
that there wasn't anything better than being a dj and providing the music 
for such energy-filled happy people.  this summer i went back to 
california and loved it even more than before: one memorable moment was 
watching the expressions on peoples faces during "I am ready" at ceremony 
at golden gate park.  unfortunately, my dad decided for me that i have to 
go to (an extremely preppie, frat-infested) college in new england, and 
now that i have tables of my own and am craving anybody that appreciates 
house music (the four djs at my school all spin east coast hardcore) i 
feel stranded. sfraves is the only connections (besides phone calls) that 
i have.  anyways, after 8 months and summer road trip i will finally be 
where i want to be... back in san francisco... and this time i won't be 
stopped. 
thanks for reading if you actually got through this excessive description 
of myself.
archana
(e racer)

the sunset boat party on sunday with my SO and would like to offer rides

have one less car on the road.  We have three spaces in our car and are 
willing to pick people up in our area (Berkland or Oakley!!) or at BART 
if you'd like.  We'll most likely return as soon as it's over as I have 
to work pretty damn early on Monday :[

greatly appreciated, but is not requisite :]  Send me email or your phone 
number and I will try to get back to you soon, but it may not be until

Hi-
        I am dave.  This is actually the first time I have posted to

than an introduction and some reflective thoughts, I also have a great
favor to ask...
        But first, a brief introduction...I have been partying on and off
since 1992.   The Basics of Thanksgiving, '92 may have been the
experience that convinced me of the primal joy and beauty of the rave.
I'm sure any of you who were there can attest to the epic proportions of
that particular party.  I went out every now and again in '93 and '94,
and then early this year I started partying more consistently.  I have to
say I've had an amazing summer, in large part thanks to the great times 
at sunset, come/unity, and wicked. I've relished the experience of 
feeling bonds with friends grow tighter, and developing new connections 
with people.  I hope to meet more of you all as the party continues. 
        My most conspicuous feature was formerly my mane of dark brown 
hair, which I often wore in a pony tail.  I have since deleted my 
locks... 1/4 inch of fuzz remains.  I was also the guy with the camera at a 
few of the Richmond sunsets.
        Well, here is my predicament.  I haven't been out much in the 
last month, because i've been preparing for the subject GRE in biology, 
which is this Saturday.  Needless to say, I'm itching to lift my feet.

day after my test!!) with three friends.    One of us went to Ameba today 
to get tickets, and she bought the last ONE ticket.

sure what to do with that one ticket.   So, if anybody has an extra, so

:: ~xmit.link-initiate
:: ~xmit.connect
:: ~xmit.begin

[announce.orbitrecords.or002]

	.or002
	.induction "halodust" single
	.release date
	.october 16 1995

On October 16, 1995 Orbitrecords will release Halodust, the follow-up to
Induction's Attempt 12".  The Halodust single features the tracks
Halodust and 106 on a clear 7" record.

Induction's unique approach to exploring sounds and their music's intrinsic 
emotion allows the Halodust single to transcend musical genres.

Audio samples of Halodust and 106 are available at the Orbitrecords web
site in varying degrees of file size and resolution.

	.communication
	.orbitrecords.weblink
	.http://www.hyperreal.com/music/labels/orbitrecords/
	.voicemail 412.392.1505

Induction are T.Butcher, W.Pearson, and S.Khoury.

:: ~xmit.endlink.detect
:: ~xmit.connection.closed
:: ~eof

From: Jonathan Wells <flux@netcom.com>
Subject: Flux TV - question?
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9510121547.A15734-0100000@netcom>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Almost two years ago I posted asking when would be the best time to air 
our music video program Flux in San Francisco on Viacom Cable.

We are negotiating right now to move the program to a broadcast channel 
which would allow people throughout the Bay Area to see the program, 
rather than just those that live within city limits.

It will take sometime until we complete the move, so we need to come up 
with a new time slot on Viacom cable until that is complete.

Since many on the list have been very supportive of the program, I ask you:

Would rather see Flux aired in San Francisco Tuesdays at 10:30 or Sundays 
at Midnight?

I'm also please to announce that the show is also being aired weekly in 
New York City! We will soon present to you the finest in music videos AND 
interviews with DJs, artists and technology from both coasts.

Thanks again from your support,

I look forward to your choice: TUE 10:30PM or SUN 12MID

Thanks, 
Jonathan
Director, Flux TV

On Thu, 12 Oct 1995 02:35:42 -0400  Sshivaa@aol.com wrote:
>if love was food i would eat all day.
>if music was grape jelly i would smear myself with it until there 
wasn't any
>more left in the jar.
>if smiles were sunshine, i would tan and be tanned - morning, day and 
night.
>
>what is a raver? look into her heart, his heart. does she know how to 
boogie?
>does he welcome his neighbors into his family?  do they know the value 
of
>community? can the brother get down? 
>
>i don't give a fuck what you're wearing, or not wearing, how long or 
short
>your hair is, what kind of shades you've got, or if you've got the 
vogue
>slouch. it'll be a black day when these characteristics come to typify 
the
>raver, if they ever do. that's the day i check out. 
>
>what do i think a raver is? an explorer. a celebrant. a person who's so
>passionate about the music, the community, the vibe that he or she 
stays up
>all night long, dancing, talking, or just slouching by the speakers,
>entranced.  
>
>personally, i rave as a part of my celebration of creation. but i don't
>expect everyone to share my views. everyone brings their own two cents 
to our
>community of ravers and when we put them all together... we're rich!    
  
> 
>ranting and raving,
>shalom

On Thu, 12 Oct 1995, Archana H. Carter wrote:

> goa is a place in india on the western coast, near Bombay.  it is on the 
> beach (not as scenic as other beaches in india) and is one of the spots 
> where many tourists go to rave on....

Check out the "travel" edition of COLOURS magazine.  It describes the 
appalling conditions local Goans live in while the 5-star hotel tourist 
industry booms.  According to this article, there are more tourists in 
Goa than locals.  Is this accurate, Archana?  

>From the people I known who have been there, the interesting days have trickled 
past . . . In fact, some of the European techno crowd who have been partying 
there over the last few years seem to be migrating further south and gracing 
Australia with their own special brand of "Goa" Trance.

Now an introduction :-)  My name's Kathleen and I subscribed to this list 
ages ago, but then technology decided to unsubscribe me, but I'm back on again.

I live in Brisbane Australia, and I'm an active member of our rave list 
here called "Ausrave".  This list covers, believe it or not, the entire 
Australian continent, so even though we don't come into physical contact 
with each other all that often, it's still an excellent way to 
communicate with others in the "rave" community.

I'm planning on visiting a few pals in the US in June/July next year, and 
I intend on collecting a few films for a film festival i shall 
organize here, taking some photos, and very definitely indulging in some 
tranced out, life affirming grooving in the great outdoors :-)

I've subscribed to this list and a few others around the US to hopefully 
make contact with some like minded psychedelic warriors :-)

smiles,
kath

welcome back THROCKA :)  whereya been ?  you are about a month
behind the rest of us :)

the us spends about 100 billion combating heart disease each year.
the majority of people who die each year die of heart disease.  
this is due to poor eating habits, fatty foods, lack of exercise.  
should i walk into macdonalds and start shouting at people ?

what if i choose not to drive an automobile to work ?  autos cause
65% or urban pollution.  should i then yell at people who drive
autos ?  take a deep breath on your walk to work, what do you 
smell ?

it is pc right now for people to thumb their noses at smokers, but
there are so many other contaminants to health and the environment
that surpass the effects of passive cigarrette smoke that your 
arguments are really just smack of political opportunism and jumping on 
the band wagon.

what i believe in is free choice.  restrictions on cigarette smoke 
should be up to the proprietors of restaurants and bars.  if i open
a bar and want to permit smoking, why shouldnt i ?  it's my place.
you can leave.  maybe i dont care if you leave.  

doug

	Hello,

	Well, I just logged in to hear the depressing news that tickets
	for Sundays cruise have managed to sell themself out. Guess this
	should have been expected, and I should have picked one up 
	before now.

	The phone message mentions a slightly higher dock-side fee, does
	anyone know if this is likely to still be the case come Sunday ? 
	Given the fact that its a boat, there must be a set limit on the
	number of bodies they can embark with. How many tickets were 
	sold ? How many people can they have on the tub ?

	If anyone happens to have an extra ticket or, sadly, cannot 	
	make the event - then I'd obviously be interested in taking it
	off there hands. Either mail or call (415-728-8632) if this
	happens to be the case.

	To add weight to the post, transform it into something a little 
	heavier than a shameless ticket beg (though still keep it fluffy 
	enough to float like a bubble)... 

	I've been experiencing some strange radio interferance over the 
	last month or so, and wonder if anyone has happened to be around
	similar goings on. Twice now, once in a mexican take-out, once 
	in the comfort of my home, the radio has suddenly blurted out the 
	theme from close encounters of the third kind. 

	You know, Da-Da-Dum-Dumm-Dummmm. 

	One time the notes broke over a normal radio program, the other 
	time the radio wasn't even tuned to anything (set on phono). Both 
	times its repeated itself twice, nothing else, just Spielberg's 
	immortal jingle.

	Personally, I tbink its pretty special that someone would take 
	the time to do this, Alien or otherwise. Although I'd hope that
	a real alien would choose something a little less hackneyed as
	an introduction.

	If it wasn't for the tweakers, where would we be ?

	Peace,
	Gary

        Jake,

                there is a reason for everything. all hardship has a
purpose and usually that purpose is your own spiritual growth.  i went
though a rough summer where i realized that the only person you can and
should rely on is your own self.  keep in touch with your self, keep
centred as those taoists would say.  remember that there is no such thing
as 'randomnicity' or chaos only more and mroe complex forms of order. look
at your situation and maybe, just maybe you'll be able to see the pattern
forming within it.

   The scene seems alive and well - there's a lot of action again this
   weekend. Basics has sentimental value for us old-skoolers, and the
   Sunset boat party is sure to be a winner (but it seems to be sold out
   now). Every other party has someone I want to hear in the lineup too,
   though. There are a bunch of new weeklies popping up over the last
   month, especially on weekends, but Roots on Wednesday could be the
   sleeper. Send me updates on the weeklies, and thanks to those who have
   been sending updates.
   

                               THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/sfrcal.html

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 9pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 -
       Progressive house, acid jazz and "alternative" music views. (415)
       281-3377.
     * Sunday night mid-3am - "No UFO's" w/Adam from Silent Records KZSU
       90.1 Stanford
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Tuesday noon-3pm - House and techno w/DJ Unknown and guests - KZSU
       90.1 (Stanford)
     * Thursdays 9:30pm-midnight - "Aurora Borealis" w/DJ Seth. Ambient,
       experimental, ethereal, acid-trance-techno, industrial and
       trip-hop on KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Saturday night - "Saturday Night Spin Out" w/Ronnie Libido. Trip
       hop, Jungle, Ambient, Experimental Sounds. 10pm-2am. KFJC 89.7 -
       Los Altos Hills

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9510130904.B27960-0100000@uclink.berkeley.edu>

On Thu, 12 Oct 1995, Doug Fairclough wrote:

> 
> 

> 
> what if i choose not to drive an automobile to work ?  autos cause
> 65% or urban pollution.  should i then yell at people who drive
> autos ?  

Personally, I give a whole-hearted resounding YES.  Cars kill everything!!
Although cars serve their purpose, we really are murdering mother earth 
with them.  It's such a sad thing that California has to be so 
auto-elitist.  If people would only remember that driving is a privilege, 
NOT a right...:]  (Take public transpo, ride a bike, walk, share rides..)

On another tangent, has anyone ever noticed how mean everyone on the 
highway is?  (yes, that means both YOU and ME!)  I think driving brings 
out the worst in everyone.  I think we all feel such power behind the 
wheel because we are connected to a large metal machine.  When we drive we 
act so rudely.  We certainly do things we would never do if we were walking 
in a crowd.  As for people who get mad in traffic jams, I have no sympathy 
because every single person who is in an automobile is responsible!!

Well, that's my polemic for the week. Sorry it's not rave-related, I 
couldn't resist this one.   :]

XXXX  OOOOO,

kirsten

I second that opinion! Growing up in NYC and am living now in downtown SF.
I have spent most of my life surrounded by millions of densely packed
autos. I agree about the meanness, driving a car definitely seems to bring
out my own most aggressive side. I think being in those little isolated
bubbles makes us think we can spew our hostility more acceptably than in
most interpersonal circumstances.

The amount of pollution is also sickening. I live @ 2nd and Mission, in the
midst of a heavy traffic area. I have to go out on my terrace every day to
wipe a thick coating of soot off the furniture in order to sit down. I can
only imagine what I breathe in every day...

My mom developed lung cancer a couple of years ago, and although she smoke
for many years, the doctor's told her that her type of cancer is more
closely associated with pollution than cigarette smoking.

For the first time in my life I am working from home and am so glad not to
have to enter an auto everyday and contribute to the mess.

Peace,
ek



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Oct 13 11:53:35 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id LAA28727; Fri, 13 Oct 1995 11:53:35 -0700

	id LAA16243; Fri, 13 Oct 1995 11:47:15 -0700
Message-Id: <199510131847.LAA16243@netcom4.netcom.com>
To: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Smokin' Highway
Date: Fri, 13 Oct 95 11:47:12 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> Personally, I give a whole-hearted resounding YES.  Cars kill everything!!
> Although cars serve their purpose, we really are murdering mother earth 
> with them.  It's such a sad thing that California has to be so 
> auto-elitist.

Perhaps because we have such a sucky public transport system.... I like
to say i take the train to work (on the one day a week i go to work to
attend meetings). But when push comes to shove (i'm always late) I get
in my car and drive because i can get from SF to Menlo Park in 35-45
minutes, whereas the train takes 50 minutes + 10 minutes for me to get
to the station. That's a lot of wasted time. It's because caltrain
sucks so badly, infrequent schedule, crawlingly slow speed; it's just
lame -- check out a european train (or even a train on the east coast)
if you want to see how a train *SHOULD* operate.

And then there's BART and Muni, which are ok if you're going to the
three places they actually go. And of course, neither BART, Caltrain or
Muni are co-located in order to make transfers easy. What a pile of
crap. THis isn't a public transportation system. It's a joke.

I don't think it's fair to "blame the populace" for continuing to
drive and pollute. Given the alternatives, what would you expect?

Between BART, MUNI, and CALTRAIN, we got a bunch of petty fiefdoms that
refuse to talk/cooperate with each other. A perfect example of the
grand results of free enterprise and competition at work -- resulting
in the usual wasteful, dysfunctional non-cooperating system. Lets
"nationalize" this, centralise control, and do it right, sucking the
money out of massive gas taxes. Fuck privatization and capitalism.

And I won't even go into how the Oil Companies applied
political/financial arm twisting in Los Angeles county to remove the LA
streetcar system (back in the 40's and 50's) so that we could  enjoy
the progress and prosperity of the automobile age. Cough cough.

PS: the other thing is that there are a lot of cars out there that have
old gas guzzling engines that pollute a lot. In fact the  California
emissions controls limits are adjusted so that people don't have to get
rid of their old cadillacs and cutlass supremes, or so that rich people
can continue to drive cars with 400HP engines...

I just got my car smog checked, it's a '86 mazda Rx7 w/ 95k miles on
it; fuel injected, 80 cc rotary engine (150HP), catalytic converter,
mechanically well-maintained, despite the dents in the body... Check
out how this car fares against the "maximums" allowed by the state:

2500 RPM:
	Hydrocarbons -- 1PPM; maximum 220PPM
	Carbon Monoxide -- 0.00%; maximum 1.20%
750 RPM (Idle):
	Hydrocarbons -- 6PPM; maximum 100PPM
	Carbon Monoxide -- 0.00%; maximum 1.00%

In other words, I have to drive *TWO* *HUNDRED* *AND* *TWENTY* *MILES*
to put out the same amount of pollutants as would a "top polluting" car
(e.g. an old amerikkkan gas guzzler) would do in *ONE* *MILE*.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
=  Niels Mayer   http://www.cyborganic.com/People/niels   mayer@netcom.com  =
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

stuff in everyday, with every breath you take, wherever you are.
it gets worse every year.

perhaps they feel better about themselves because they do -> like they
are not contributing to the problem of pollution.  that way, changes
in their lifestyles are not required (keep on driving that 1 mile 
to work).  i think it's hypocritical.

	I offer my sincere apology to anyone out there who I led to 
believe that the sunset boat party was sold out.  i think what happened 
was that my friend bought the last ticket in one of Ameba's batches of 
tickets, and the salesperson didn't know that there would be more on the way.

	:-)  This morning, my housemate cruised over to Ameba and picked up 
our set of tickets  :-)

	Sorry to those who suffered moments of sadness, and thank you to 
those that were helping find tix for us.....

	I hope everyone is as psyched about Sunday as I am...see you then!
	

						-dave.

THis might even be a problem on a global scale. (no, the burrito wasn't
that big!). I've seen reports linking global warming to outgassing of
cows and manure in pastures.

>For someone who can dance the way you do
>for hours at a time, that little jaunt to Menlo Park should be a

If I had the time and the ride wasn't through some of the foulest parts
of the south bay (well, it's all pretty foul air-wise) I'd probably be
up for it. Then again, I get pretty sweaty after dancing for hours on
end, which might not fare well with the "suits". But I've also seen
other smelly, unkempt and ill-tempered programmers significantly
shorten meetings using only pheromones, so perhaps that's a good thing!

At least I am now only working in Menlo Park 1 day a week, the rest is
at home ... so even if I do 60 miles R/T for one such commute, I'm
still doing less than most! And I do actually try to take the train if
I can... (http://www.commerce.digital.com/palo-alto/CalTrain/form.html)

I guess if I was really eco-conscious I would live where I worked --
the only problem is that Menlo Park sucks really badly, even though it
is considered "nice". We like to call it "Mental Dark" ...

        Brian you don't know me, but I wish you all the best. 
         I once lived in SF. Had my grotesquely expensive 360 degree view
apt.  Putted around town on my bad-ass black Hog, had tons of friends, an
unlimited chemical carnocopia, ( E was called MDA back then) threw
gargantuan tilt-boogie-bashes in the Mission.( '79 and  New Wave was..new.)
This was way before the current ravecraze   Life was grand.  etc. etc.
        But, push turned to shove, and shove turned to kick, when my
finances and health took a sudden nose dive.    I ended up sleeping under a
bridge.( 17th and Mariposa on ramp to 280),  because all the folks spouting
platitudes of peace, love, togetherness,( Blah Blah Blah) ditched, snubbed
and scampered out of my life faster then the feas off a fresh road kill.
        When my highs were all  gone and I stood ill, and alone in the dawn,
with little less than lint lining my pockets, it was the Universe's  way of
sifting the multitude of  pseudo brethen  from the few dear  folks truly
worthy of my affections.
        Reality check.  Compassion gushes thick cheap  with "E" 
        Just beacause you party with them don't asume they are
true...anything.    
        
 
My the Cosmos bless you and keep you..

W. Joseph Singleton
who flurished in spite of them all.

Hi everyone! This is my first post to the list although I have been
listening in for several months. I've been raving for a little over a year
now and enjoying it immensely. Six people at the school I go to wanted to
go to a rave for the first time this weekend and wanted it to be a 'big
one' which happened to be LBT (I couldn't convince them to go to either
Basics or SPAZ). :( I thought it was a fairly average event with good sets
by DJ Trance and Darwin Chamber, and the DJ before them.  We left before
Carlos went on but he was out with the crowd as usual, happily blowing on
a whistle. The sound system was small and there was wet paint all over the
walls.  Someone posted earlier this week that Small World was in it for
the $ and at $20 I definately agree. My friends had fun anyway and are
interested in going to future events. I hope to meet more of you in the
near future. :)


Austin


"If rocking the house well is a crime, then let me be guilty" 2BADMICE

Dear sfravers,

	It feels good to be back on sfraves!  Some of you may remember me 
from several months ago, or I may have met some of you at parties.  
Probably many of us have met before without knowing it...

	Anyway, I wanted to make this post to share a little bit about 
myself and hopefully meet some new people, or maybe get reacquainted with 
old friends, or both.

	I'm taking a class at San Francisco State U. right now on the 
recommendation of another sfraver who took it, Susie Kameny (aka party-on 
Susie) who many of you may know.  It's called Cyberspace and the 
Humanities.  The professor, Arthur Chandler, is aware of this list, and 
mentions it from time to time, as do myself and the other sfraver in the 
class, Jon Zimmerman.  We've been talking a lot about virtual communities 
(i.e. communities in cyberspace like this one), which has fueled my 
desire to be more a part of this community (the rave scene, including its 
online component).

	Anyway, a little bit about me.  As well as being a raver, I'm a 
bisexual, vegetarian, libertarian, poet, aspiring writer and journalist.  
I live in the city, take 12 units at SF State, half in my journalism 
major, and the other half consisting of the excellent Cyberspace & The 
Humanities class and another interesting class called Leisure & 
Contemporary Society.  
	I work evenings calling people on the phone for a market research 
company, which has become sort of boring.  This is my way of saying I'm 
looking for a new job; if anyone has any leads, please feel free to give 
me a call at one of the numbers listed below.
	One of the things that attracted me to raves in the first place 
was people's friendliness.  It seemed so much easier to meet people and 
have positive interactions.  I am somewhat frustrated though by the 
transient nature so many of my meetings seem to have.  I would like to 
meet some longterm rave acquaintences to go to parties and hang out with.
	I seem to recall hearing about a "live chat" adjunct to the 
sfraves list, but I've never been on it.  Anyone have more info on this?
	Anyway, I look forward to good conversations & good parties!  
You'll probably be seeing some long, philosophical type postings and 
responses from me from time to time... feel free to ignore them if 
they're not your cup of tea.  |)

	Love & cybersnuggles,

					*** Starchild ***
______________________________________________________________________________
"People who talk about a shared interest, albeit a deep one... don't 
often disclose enough about themselves as whole individuals online to 
inspire real trust in others."
	-Howard Rheingold in "The Virtual Community" (from Cyberspace & 
The Humanities reading list)
______________________________________________________________________________

My first baaaasics. I have good things to say if you're in the mood:

the whistles

the whistles

Where have I been all this time?  Has basics always been like this?

the thick, rich, foamy, fluid that slips under my shoes in certain areas of 
the hardwood floor.  What is it and where does it come from and why is it 
SO GOOD.

there goes the needle-hop again.  You gotta laugh.
it was worth every jump because with vibe this strong, train wreck or not, 
there was simply no turning back.

I started my evening waiting in line at the Small World thing.
Because it was close to home.
Listening to a guy say "we should've gone to basics"
as I waited behind the line jumpers and fake eyelashes
I ran back to my car
I ran to Basics
and I had fun
That guy was right.

I was going to send this only to shalom/batman/whoever, but then I

On Mon, 9 Oct 1995 Sshivaa@aol.com shared:

> hi.
> 
> being a writer, or at least thinking of myself as such (oftentimes for no
> justifiable reason whatsoever), it's hard to keep myself from writing about
> the interesting issues that boil (or effervesce) up on sfraves. so i won't
> try.
> 
> everything i have to say i want to say first - which, of course, is a logical
> impossibility. 
> 
> i'm rambling. 
> 
> to start: mission vortex was beautiful. i wish every one of you (who wanted
> to) could have been there. each of us who worked to make it go off put a lot
> of love and sweat into the event, and it showed. from the shrine i created
> (from which not a single thing was stolen) to the massage rooms to the
> swinging hammock room to the dreampaint room to the soundhealing room to the
> main dance hall - beautiful. 
> 
> what made the evening especially wonderful was the... what?... the energy of
> the people there. it had the magic of what the seasoned old-school ravers
> nostalgically look back to when the rave scene was still in its youth. and
> what would this be? well i'm not sure, because i'm a new-school raver. PLUR?
> yes. passion, joy, curiosity? yes. magic? oh yes, a good bit of magic.
> 
> where are we going as a community? are we even going anywhere? no community
> can move without movement of the individuals. where are we headed? where are
> you headed? where am i headed? 
> 
> i'm always wondering, wondering. mission vortex was a departure from the
> normative status of rave-culture. no techno - but we danced all night. (well,
> almost.) people were giving massages and painting and drumming and meditating
> and dancing and just sitting on their haunches, looking into each other's
> eyes - no departure from what i think of as a rave experience to be. and yet,
> it was very different from the norm.
> 
> how do the rave world and the spirit world relate? we're finding out, with
> events like the Vortex. 
> 
> my hope is that people continue to dare to throw events that depart from the
> conventional experience. maybe they won't work. in that case, they're
> unlikely to be repeated. but if, on an off chance, they not only work, but
> they zing those involved, and if that zing spreads to other events, then
> haven't we just grown as a community? 
> 
> the truth as i see it is that we grow as a community every time one of us
> grows as an individual and shares that new wisdom (or pain) with his or her
> neighbor. the macrocosm exists within the microcosm and vice-versa. that's
> the only way the whole system that is this cosmos holds together, as i see
> it.   
> 
> but you know me (no you don't) - communty and consciousness are my fetishes.
> and a good thing about these two fetishes is that each feeds the other. 
> 
> and then, the next day - sunset! i'll be sad to watch the sun set on sunset,
> even if it's only for the winter. [strange thought: winter already? straight
> from summer to winter in california. i'm exposing my new england roots, i
> know.]
> 
> an ode to sunset: thou, smileravey beyond compare, will be sorely missed. 
> 
> and the moon! she hung like a gigantic stage prop over the berkeley hills as
> i biked home. no, it was as though the moon i'd seen previous was merely a
> prop, and now i was finally seeing the real moon, in all her naked living
> splendor. 
> 
> i don't need a shrink because i dance. okay, sure, i admit it, i've been seen
> dancing in masks. this sunset, i was batman. [and yes, i am full-grown. if
> you have trouble reconciling those two facts, maybe i can help you - later.]
> and so, following this logic, sunset is part of my therapy. big thanks to
> pacific for throwing it and to all of you for making it the peaceful joyous
> celbration it it. sure, some people are on Style Patrol. but as my favorite
> poet, rumi says "dog's saliva doesn't contaminate the Ocean."
>  
> all forms of sweetness are welcome here. and if you can't give me honey, i'll
> even take a pink envelope of saccharine. my point? unclear.
> 
> love thyselves. there is much to love. to have an open heart is to live -
> and, from time to time, to hurt. god i'm rambling now. but it's fun all the
> same. 
> 
> [for all of you who made it through this message, a final addendum. our
> berkeley co-op is no longer looking for two female housemates - but we are
> still looking for one. so if you know anyone who's looking for a warm house
> in north berlekey, pass this message along. and if she happens to have 750
> amazing techno cd's - shazam! (but not requisite.) requisite _is_ 25+,
> however. we're trying to keep an age as well as a gender balance.]
> 
> be well, beautiful people. 
> 
> from shalom
> or batman
> or whoever the hell i am...
>

Dear Kati & All;

	Friday I was diagnosed with a disease so awful, that it almost 
shattered me. It was by a doctor in an Emergency Room who had little if 
no previous knowledge/data on me, indictaing that it was some, if not a high 
probability of being incorrect. But I assure all of you, that one day of 
my childhood, still does not even come close to the pain I experienced 
from the words in humanly printed on the discharge I/O the nurse handed me, 
and that I'm still as strong as I've ever been.

	However, if correct, I WILL NOT let my mind, and the person I've
come to love(myself) crumble, from a person who helped design some of the 
most awesome firepower our country has ever seen, some of the most
environmentally sensative mass transist systems the world has seen, as
well as what I told is some of the most loving, & respectful touch
therapy(massage) my clients tell me I have provided them, into someone
pushing around a shopping cart on the streets of San Francisco. 

	I have traveled to long & hard in this life to allow this to
strike me down at what I believe are my best years. I'm actively pursuing
a much more acturate, and intensive evaluation of my being, through
multiple independent sources, to assure accuracy, thank god I'm still a
Test Engineer. Cause out of all the sciences, and in my opinion, medince is 
the least accurate, clueless, still in the dark ages, and they haven't 
met Brian Darkness head on yet.

	However I hold as part of my truth the words I think Def Lepoard 
put so rightously, that "IT'S BETTER TO BURN OUT THAN FADE AWAY." So not 
to violate the list's purpose please send me your e-mail addresses, if 
your interested in what going on with this ravers life, plus you will 
still see me at events, & hugs will be appreiated.

		 Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		  a.k.a. Brian DarknEs^2, LMT/EE/CET

dedicated to the healing...
Martin sure has his act together.

I've been to every Basics minus one (I was at Burning Man) for
two years now.  I've had a lot of incredible experiences and
met people who have taken on all degrees of meaning at these
parties.  This last Saturday night, I must've run into every
single one of these people, and had to confront each of their
meanings.  People who I haven't seen for a very long time, and
people who I still see but who have gotten lost, and can no longer
see me.  (Those transitory relationships) This night of healing 
found me looking each one of these people in the eye and forgiving
myself for creating the tension that keeps my soul separate from
theirs.  I recovered friends lost, and closed many unfinished
chapters from parties throughout the last two years.  It was
a rebirth of my soul, and I'm glowing.  I know that my story
isn't finished yet, and this will all be yet another chapter
in a much larger story... and so I press on, faith in hand.
the key to healing others is in healing yourself.

But I wanted to take this moment to thank any of you who play your
part, pay tribute to those who spark the life into the dance,
acknowlege Martin for his work and spirit, and encourage anyone
who is listening to never give up your faith.  Meaning will
come to find itself.

I also want to respect all the serious fucking groovers,
Billy and the rest of them, riding the edge between divine
grace and chaos.  I'll be seeing you again soon.

-john.

600 people *by advance ticket only!* Tickets are beautiful, collector's
item, UV-active laminates, cost $5 (or whatever you can afford) each and
will be available at:

 Ameba                     (10.21 thru 10.28)
 Mendocino Mountain Jam    (10.21 & 10.22)
 MAD Monday                (10.23)

Or from any member of our collective after Saturday the 21st. These tickets
will sell out extremely fast so if you want one *please* get one right
away, THERE WILL NOT BE *ANY* TICKETS AVAILABLE THE NIGHT OF THE PARTY!

More info is available at:  http://www.bass-station.com/FnF/

Lots and lots of positive enegry already going into this one! Hope to see
you there. =)

take it easy
ethan

last minute, so why were you still selling tickets you jerk. Not that we mind
the event being cancelled, these things happen, but you couldn't even show up

the choice is yours.

Dear All;

	Last week I decided to pay a visit to Union Square, where all da
rich people shop. So ya say whats so odd or interesting about that? I went
there dressed in black, full bondage attire, including my collar, and Goa
Trance blasting from my headphones. 

	Well, I paid a visit to shops like Channel, Peter Maxx's Gallery
(Great Art Work, Shitty Computer Graphics, he could take a few lessons
from any of us doing visiuals, and I told him that), Sheeve & Co, Neidman
Markus, Hermes of Paris France ...etc. 

	It was a truely interesting experience to say the least, they
didn't know quite what to do with me, or what to make of me, is he someone
famous of just a freak. The lesson learned was how quickly we judge a
novel by it's cover, needless to say the models & store employee's(those
with a sense of humor) loved me, and it always feels good to shake up the
upper crust, it not at least making them squirm. 

	Little did they know that I'm a virgin = >. Isn't life truely &
totally twisted. Any questions, or next time I go out, and if ya want to
come & follow or just walk along with me, I would love your company either
way, thanks. 

		 Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		  a.k.a. Brian DarknEs^2, LMT/EE/CET
	      CT Active Pager & Voice Mail (800)-590-4993

	Internet(Liberty BBS Account):	brianv@liberty.com
        Internet(LINUX Shell Account):	brianvan@liberty.liberty.com

		   GivE mE LibErty or GivE mE DEath
		  BewarE thE Tyranny of thE Majority
		      It's not a CrimE to DancE
		       (MEssagEs for the 90's)

On Mon, 16 Oct 1995, vivian host wrote:

> > Happy Hardcore, Ambient, Jungle, Trance, and Techno in SF, you
> well...you know how that song goes...fuck san francisco, fuck san francisco...
> but seriously folks (i don't want to get a million flames about this)..its
> time for san francisco...ONE OF THE MOST PROGRESSIVE CITIES IN THE COUNTRY
> to get a clue...the sheer lack of music other than house here is depressing
> to me as a dj and a listener...

	There are hard parties out there... You just to look a little 
harder because they are in the DIY vein. Hard trance can be found at the 
Trust parties (140 - 170 bpm depending on who is spinning out of the 
collective or who has been invited). At SPAZ/TAZ you will find a true 
range of music - acid jazz to juggle to the theme from Alice in 
Wonderland to gabber. You might not get 25 billion intellibeams or 20 
megawatt lasers or an amp may blow and the music stops for 15 minutes 
while another is wired in, but you will get a free party most of the 
time, with music that sends people thru the roof...

dave

Subject: fuck the tyranny of the new (was Re: sunset.djs )
In-reply-to: Your message of "Mon, 16 Oct 95 18:51:28 PDT."
             <v02130503aca8597a2db8@[128.32.99.238]> 
Date: Mon, 16 Oct 95 19:30:57 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> lower deck it was darkhorse, malcolm, and two other guys i never heard
> of...why does it matter anyways...all that music just sounded the same..the

Well, it mattered because i wanted to know about the two guys you never
heard of...

Why? So i can either go to or stay away from events with DJ's that I
either liked or disliked.

> lower deck was pure boring dub and the middle was repetitive yukky
> house..that's not to say that the vibe didn't kick..au contraire..the
> cruise was lovely -but you san frandiscans need to wake up and smell the
> new music...being here is like being in a time warp...

For some of us that have been around the loop a few times, statements
like these verge on the nonsensical. i've seen it all before too, but
each time around, it becomes more intricate, blended, and diverse. And
the places I've grown blase about make me see the new territory of the
future in new ways! 

Whether the beats are hard, soft, big, small, fluffy, chunky or
splooshy, it's all been done before -- go dig out some early-mid
eighties underground industrial (TG, Tackhead), or pop (e.g. Yello), or
rap, or even psychedelic jazz (e.g. miles davis "bitches brew"), or
haul out some old dub tunes (e.g. Lee Perry) and notice the "space"...
Notice the past reflected in the future, and the future in the past,
and the mirror in time is you!

Last weekend, I had a listen to some trax off of Marvin Gaye's "I want
you" LP (1976) and I could swear I was hearing arrangements and mixing
that sounded cool and hip RIGHT NOW. It was incredible, and I was
flabbergasted to find out that it was done nearly 20 years ago!!

So lets take all that old/new bullshit a given and move on. Besides, I
like SF's sound. Bigger is not better, and neither is faster, or newer.

I think I'm going to put on something really old (oh, maybe some big
band stuff from the 40's) just to protest this point of view. Just
because our world is accelerating forward doesn't mean one shouldn't
look back and appreciate the places people have gone before with new,
open eyes and expanded minds. 

	"To Know Your Future, You Can't Forget Your Past"
					-- Bob Marley

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
=  Niels Mayer   http://www.cyborganic.com/People/niels   mayer@netcom.com  =
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

At 8:50 PM 10/15/95, Willis Wong wrote:
>My first baaaasics. I have good things to say if you're in the mood:
>
>the whistles
>
>the whistles
>
>Where have I been all this time?  Has basics always been like this?
>
>the thick, rich, foamy, fluid that slips under my shoes in certain areas of
>the hardwood floor.  What is it and where does it come from and why is it
>SO GOOD.
>
>there goes the needle-hop again.  You gotta laugh.
>it was worth every jump because with vibe this strong, train wreck or not,
>there was simply no turning back.
>
>I started my evening waiting in line at the Small World thing.
>Because it was close to home.
>Listening to a guy say "we should've gone to basics"
>as I waited behind the line jumpers and fake eyelashes
>I ran back to my car
>I ran to Basics
>and I had fun
>That guy was right.

It seemed that a bunch of our friends were divided on where to go Saturday
night. A bunch wanted to go to "It's a Small World" thing, but I got the
impression that it was a big, vibeless cash-fest. I tried to get them to
come up to SF to go to Basics w/ us, but they were intent on checking out
the local Santa Clara county happenings. We didn't know it, but they went
there, got in line, and immediately got back in their car and headed north
to go to Basics! What a surprise!

Other than the fact that they used a map point that pointed to the front of
Big Heart City (not the entrance for this party! argh!) instead of the
proper entrance at the back of the club, we had an awesome time! We saw
loads and loads of friends there and danced until the records stopped. It
was my first Basics but I'll surely go to the next one. Charging for water
was a bit bogus, but once you bought a bottle, you could refill it for free
at least...

I know there were SF Ravers there, but I only saw one laminate! Where were
yours?! :-)

We'll be at the Mendocino Mountain Jam this weekend. Hope to camp with a
bunch of you there!

-wdc

> On Mon, 16 Oct 1995, Niels P. Mayer wrote:
> 
> > So lets take all that old/new bullshit a given and move on. Besides, I
> > like SF's sound. Bigger is not better, and neither is faster, or newer.
> 
> It's utterly disgusting to see most of the dj's totaly immersed in
> "American consumerism" when it comes to buying records. Gotta have the new
> "bombs" (pop music disguised with a dance beat that moves the majority)
> can't play those old "bombs" cause their "out", ofcourse they get old they
> have no real substance. You gotta keep spending money buying these records
> that you will be sick of in a month, instead of getting music that will
> last a lifetime.
> 
> This aint no fucking fashion show 
> 
> -josh
> 
I hate too. I can say that music is a very personal experience for 
me. When I spin, it's not the hottest, new trax out there. For me, 
it is the feeling, the primal energy that dictates what I will play. 
I have trax older than 2 years that I still play, just because of the 
energy that they give me. 
I strongly believe in letting myself go, letting the music control me 
instead of me controlling the music. If you let other factors dictate 
what you do, the final product is not from you. Let the music be your 
inspiration and everything you do will have your personal signature 
on it. And everyone will remember it that way, coming directly from 
you...

Peace to all    8)

X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.0 06sep94)

Precedence: bulk

Pardon my annoyance, but if you are so disdainful of the music in SF,
go to different parties, spin some yourself, DO SOMETHING.  I am so
tired of the whining, some deserved and much not, about the state of
the underground music scene in SF.  There is plenty of variety out
there if you're not lazy and only go to the most publicized events.

As for Pacific, Galen, Jon Williams, Solar, Spun, Darkhorse, Malcolm
"and two other guys I never heard of," at least give them some credit
for giving the scene much of what it's needed for the last year or two.
Sunset is a worthy successor to the original Golden Gate park parties
in '92 and Boogie Buffet in '93 as the glue that keeps the scene going.

All I can say is, if you don't like boring yukky house, go somewhere
where they don't play that.

phred

> it is the feeling, the primal energy that dictates what I will play. 
> I have trax older than 2 years that I still play, just because of the 
> energy that they give me. 
> I strongly believe in letting myself go, letting the music control me 
> instead of me controlling the music. If you let other factors dictate

>> can be a good thing, and why he hangs on to his anger.  I wish I had it 
>> around to share.  In a world where "love" is "good" and "anger" is "bad," I

>I love anger.
>Anger is good.
>Anger is power (sometimes).

>I'm all for anger, but you should at least try to be constructive with it.

I'm taking a meditation class at SF State. The discussion revolves around
the different meditative practices of various Eastern religions.

It's mentioned that some yogis use anger as a source of "life energy",
whereas the energy that compromises anger is brought up through the chakras
and transmuted throughout the body. The energy is then as used as a sort of
"boost" to elevate ones conciousness,

Way cool.

Something to think about the next time I'm looking for parking.  ;)

later...

Jonas   


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Oct 17 09:31:20 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id JAA23830; Tue, 17 Oct 1995 09:31:20 -0700
Received: from gw3.pacbell.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id JAA23820; Tue, 17 Oct 1995 09:31:16 -0700
Received: from srv.PacBell.COM (mother.srv.PacBell.COM) by gw3.pacbell.com (5.x/PacBell-9/14/95)
	id AA22204; Tue, 17 Oct 1995 09:31:09 -0700
Received: from pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM by srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/Mother-7/26/95)
	id AA15024; Tue, 17 Oct 95 09:31:08 PDT
Received: by pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA26243; Tue, 17 Oct 95 09:31:02 PDT
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9510171631.AA26243@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
Subject: Ravers Ahoy!
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Tue, 17 Oct 95 9:31:01 PDT
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Nice boat, friendly crew - except for the captain's wife who clearly
didn't like the look of us.  15 minutes before boarding time she told
us that on the main deck dancing was only permitted on the 10 square foot 
wood dance floor which was almost completely covered by speakers and sound
equipment.  Under her watchful glare, we hurridly put back all the tables 
& chairs we had just moved, paying full respect to her very official yacht 
club uniform.  There was talk about moving the main sound system to the 
lower deck which had a larger wooden dance area but then the first mate/
head crewmember told us that the captain's bitchier half wouldn't be coming
with us.  Once we left the dock we were able to rearrange the furniture
once again.

The captain seemed to be a jolly guy, and mainly stayed on the bridge.
I didn't see what happened when the naked raver chick paid him a visit
but he apparently managed to keep us on course.  The head crewmember
kept up a professional, though somewhat bewildered demeanor;
her main job seemed plucking away the incense sticks that kept
sprouting up.  No problem at all with the open pot smoking on the
top deck.  The rest of the crew seemed to be having a blast, one of them
apparently got rather buzzed on something non-alchoholic.

I thought the music was pretty good.  Solar, queasy from the getgo had
a disastorous set, with his records skipping all over the place.  The
problem was more or less solved by moving the coffin to another table,
in time for Spun who gave us a typical trip house set, followed by Galen 
and then Jon Williams who finished things of with some acid/trance. 
The mixing was a bit rough at times, normal for a seafaring setting.
The lower deck was more musically interesting;  Jungle, dub,
trip hop, ambient... It all sounded fresh to me and the sound systems
were as good as any that I've heard on a boat.

The upper, open deck provided a real nice scenic chill area.  I 
especially enjoyed dancing on the bow with the balmy breeze in my face,
the feel of the waves under my feet, and the glittering views of the
city, bridges, ports, Alcatraz, Marin, etc.  The water was fairly calm, 
until we approached the ocean.  Geoff took in a mouthful of seawater and
analyzed its salt-content for me.

The density, with 400 on board was just right; plenty of room, plenty of
people dancing, a great vibe.  Nice lighing too; video projector, strobe,
blacklights, etc.  So this one gets a thumbs up for 6 hours of raver 
fun on the San Francisco Bay.

Lee
___________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com   (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )   lee@hyperreal.com
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

        I have to admit that being angry is a real rush, the problem comes
in when you think about where this energy is focused.  Is it inside
yourself, or at a person, at a concept? I _used_ to direct it at 'the man'
or whatever you want to call it but found that it was kind of a waste
because the societal structure that i was trying to externalize and fight
against was still a part of me.  Tough call, huh?

        brad

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Oct 17 11:39:48 1995

From: laural@inmark.com
Received: (from ugate@localhost) by inmarkinmark.com (8.6.12/8.6.9) with UUCP id LAA25716 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Tue, 17 Oct 1995 11:10:46 -0700
Received: from cc:Mail by ugate.inmark.com
	id AA813955048 Tue, 17 Oct 95 11:37:28 
Date: Tue, 17 Oct 95 11:37:28 
Message-Id: <9509178139.AA813955048@ugate.inmark.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re[2]: fuck the tyranny of the new (was Re: sunset.djs )
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


     

Josh Bates said:
>It's utterly disgusting to see most of the dj's totaly immersed in 
>"American consumerism" when it comes to buying records.

It's soooo easy to fall into, though...you find a record store you like, 
you start going there every so often, and then you start going every week 
when they get the new deliveries, and you suck up new music like 
<name-your-favorite-binge-food-item-here>.

And then, after a while, you realize you have an entire crate full of 
records that are between 0 and 2 years of age that you've never even 
listened to except for 45 seconds in the shop.

(Of course, then you have "new source" for when you've run out of money 
and can't buy more records, or when you're sick of buying more stuff 
anyway.)

I don't see it as being part of a "fashion show" as Josh asserted ... it's 
more of this crazy addiction you get sucked into because it's so much fun! 
Back when I was buying $150 worth of records a week (which was a LONG LONG 
time ago) I wasn't thinking at all about fashion or impressing other 
people, I was like a kid in a chocolate factory stuffing every bit of cool 
sound into my brain as possible.

Laura

you attend (which I suppose is the raison d'etre of this list, in many

feeling of what it was really like to be there, even if I wasn't). Thanks a

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Oct 17 12:32:30 1995

From: rafone@ccnet.com
Received: from [192.215.98.146] (h98-146.ccnet.com [192.215.98.146]) by ccnet.ccnet.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) with SMTP id MAA04841 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 17 Oct 1995 12:28:06 -0700

>>> A long time ago one of the Pet Shop Boys wrote an article about why anger
>>> can be a good thing, and why he hangs on to his anger.  I wish I had it

>
>I'm taking a meditation class at SF State. The discussion revolves around
>the different meditative practices of various Eastern religions.
>
>It's mentioned that some yogis use anger as a source of "life energy",
>whereas the energy that compromises anger is brought up through the chakras
>and transmuted throughout the body. The energy is then as used as a sort of
>"boost" to elevate ones conciousness,
>
>Way cool.
>
>Something to think about the next time I'm looking for parking.  ;)
>
>later...
>
>Jonas


I don't really know much about other traditions, but as a practitioner of
Tibetan Vajrayana (Tantric) Buddhism I can tell you that the alchemical
notion of transmuting "negative" emotions (such as anger, jealousy, greed,
attachment) into wisdom is at the root of tantric meditation practice. The
basic idea is that emotions are just different forms of energy arising out
of emptiness. The energy can manifest either as neurosis or wisdom,
depending on whether ego-clinging is involved. The tantric approach is not
to reject or suppress these emotions, but to actually experience them fully
as possible. The various meditational deities used in tantric visualization
practices represent the awakened wisdom manifestations of these different
energies. The tantric practitioner identifies himself or herself with these
deities as a means identifying with the wisdom aspect of these energies. In
a sense, the "negative" emotions become the fuel for the journey of
awakening.

For example, in this tradition the sharp, cutting quality of anger (when
freed from ego) is transmuted into intelligience; the sharp, clear, precise
quality of intellect (called Vajra wisdom).

just my 2 cents,

Peace,
ek

I have to say that I'm really impressed with KZSU.  I really enjoy their 
programming especially the three hours of techno.  Even tho' I hold CAL 
sacred to my heart, I have to say that Stanfurd for the most part has a 
better (and this kills me :] ) radio station.  I love KALX, but it's not 
nearly as fluid as KZSU.  Plus, I can get KZSU on my radio at various 
places throughout the Bay, but I can't even get KALX at home and I only 
live two miles from the station!!  I have a feeling that KZSU has more 
money.  However, I'm glad that I live in the midst of a plethora of rad 
college radio stations.  Commercial radio stations are such bullsh*t.  I 
get so tired of their propaganda and their D.J.'s with fake English 
accents playing the same song over and over. (and how about their "I'm so 
FUCKING alternative" attitude?)  Anyone want to comment?  I'd love to 
hear responses!!

this sent to me, but meant for whole list:

Hello everybody one and all
 
Let me introduce myself:  I have been part of the SFRave list, off and on,
since last Nov. I live in Victoria, British Columbia and am VERY envious of
the size and quality of the rave scene that you have.  Neither Vancouver or
Toronto can match the scene you have, so give yourself a hand, hug,
lollipop, etc.  After a year of listening, I finally have an opportunity to
visit the SF city and the SFRave scene.  
 
I will be attending the Macromedia Multimedia Conference at the end fo the
month, so I will be in the city from Oct28-Nov1.  I am going to visit "good
vibrations", Burkeley, Chinatown.  Does anybody know of any cool music,
clothing stores or other places  that are worth visiting? 
 
Like Noel, I would like to find out if F&F would be better or the
Anniversary celebrations of FTT??  I have heard lots about F&F so I would be
inclined to go there but I need information as to where. The rave guide
doesn't have any info.  I would like to meet with any other people going,
maybe we can share a ride.
 
See ya later in that place between light and gravity's pull.

John Pavlin
 
Ministry of Attorney General
British Columbia

__________________________
since my original post concerning F&F vs FTT i got several responses.
first, THANKS! for the replies!

to sum up what was sent to me for those who don't already know:
Funky Techno Tribe will be a HUGE event with an impressive line-up and
	all that big rave jazz -- a sure party.
Friends and Family will be a much more intimate party (only 600 tickets) with
	more of a "family" vibe.

i'm going to Friends and Family and i hope to meet some of you there!

noel --@

	yeah, I couldn't agree with you more.  Commercial radio in this country 
is really empty, and it's a shame because the potential for radio to be 
powerful is all there.  Luckily we have a few good college radio 
stations, and of course NPR.  NPR certainly does a great job stimulating 
quality conversation about interesting issues with excellent people.  If 
some of the elements of NPR's approach to radio could be incorporated 
into a station that played modern music,  such that the quality of the 
music could be appreciated in an uninterrupted and cerebral way, life would 
be grand.   Certainly that is a vague description of what a quality radio 
station might be like, and the details could fill out in lots of ways.

	I too, hold CAL(although I don't call it CAL) dear to my heart, 
but KALX is not one of my presets. (Minor's sets used to be good, but that's 
in the past).   I actually can't seem to get KZSU in Berkeley, and I 
suspect I might not live too far from you.  you're lucky...

		Enjoying three hours of silence, -dave.

Not to bring anyone's head down, or anything, but there are at
least 2 items on the ballot for SF City elections worth noting:

First is a measure to extend the city curfew to include 17
year olds (it's currently for 16 & under).  The current law
is set to expire at the end of the year.  This measure will
also extend it indefinately and make the law difficult to overturn.
There's another measure that will beef up police oversight, and
we know that we can't have too much of that.  Sorry for not having
the measure letters handy.

I know that some ravers like to pretend that they aren't a part
of the processes that shape our society, but they are, even if
it's only to step aside to hand things over to the Frank Jordans
of the world.  Anyway, voting is pretty easy, especially if you
use an absentee ballot.  If you don't live in SF, consider
mentioning this stuff to your city-dwelling friends.

ObEntertainment:

To get to the other vibe!

Yeah, KZSU Rocks... I get to listen to it every time I'm working in
Mental Dark or Shallow Alto... Many years ago, I have been known to
guest DJ there, though mostly we just annoyed people that had the
misfortune to be up at 3-6AM (e.g. playing as many copies of Michael
Jackson's  "beat it" as we could simultaenously (including the tape
deck) -- his voice smears quite beautifully after you get about 5
simultaneous but slightly timelagged sources going at the same time...
Or playing selected prank phone call excerpts from John Trubee and the
Ugly Janitors of America's classic LP "The Communists are Coming to
Kill Us" (well before the Jerky Boys were a twinkle in their mother's
pearl necklace).

Oh, while yer at it, check out KFJC 89.7FM (Los Altos Hills). For
example, tHey have good reggae/dub w/ Spliff Skankin on Sunday 2-7PM
and good techno/industrial w/ Mr Goodwrench on Saturday 10-2AM. (Don't
quote me on the schedule -- for more info, check
http://www.cygnus.com/misc/kfjc or email:
kfjc-publicity@wiretap.spies.com). THe sounds and the DJ's vary widely
in relevance to the rave community -- however, if you like diversity
you will find some really interesting shows on there, ranging from
bluegrass/american-traditional, funk, dub, punk, speedmetal, 
techno/industrual, and even rock n' roll. 

Best thing about KFJC is that I can receive it in San Francisco! (I
live on the south bay side of the hills -- 2 blocks up and KPOO takes
over).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
=  Niels Mayer   http://www.cyborganic.com/People/niels   mayer@netcom.com  =
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Not to bring anyone's head down, or anything, but there are at
least 2 items on the ballot for SF City elections worth noting:

First is a measure to extend the city curfew to include 17
year olds (it's currently for 16 & under).  The current law
is set to expire at the end of the year.  This measure will
also extend it indefinately and make the law difficult to overturn.
There's another measure that will beef up police oversight, and
we know that we can't have too much of that.  Sorry for not having
the measure letters handy.

I know that some ravers like to pretend that they aren't a part
of the processes that shape our society, but they are, even if
it's only to step aside to hand things over to the Frank Jordans
of the world.  Anyway, voting is pretty easy, especially if you
use an absentee ballot.  If you don't live in SF, consider
mentioning this stuff to your city-dwelling friends.

	Hey, thanks for the KZSU compliments... I happen to work 
there and will have a techno slot this coming spring term.
	Actually, KZSU has very little money.  Most of the cash we 
get comes from sponsors and donations (which are usually for sporting 
events) and consequently they get sucked up by sporty-type spending.
	A full quarter of our annual budget goes to paying for our AP wire,
which costs $10,000.  That leaves us with little left over for
fancy spending.  You should see the station, it's kinda dumpy.
	The reason you pick our signal up so much more easily 
around the Bay (especially in the East Bay) is not that we have a 
high powered transmitter--it's only 500 watts, compared with Live105's 
10,000 I think....  The clear reception occurs because the Bay is 
flat and hence does not obstruct the signal's zippy flight across the 
water.  KALX, conversely, is situated poorly and surrounded by 
hills and such.  Plus, I think the FCC made them aim their 
transmitter out to sea for certain logistical reasons... was it them?
So, more power to us.
	Keep on listenin!

			jon

From: Seth Joshua Horvitz <acid23@uclink.berkeley.edu>

Subject: KALX vs. KZSU vs. KFJC
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9510171630.A5021-0100000@uclink.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Speaking as a representative of KALX, I can say that the reason most 
people (on this list anyway) are turned off by the station is their 
enforcement of "non-block" programming.  They want every dj to constantly 
change the style/genre/tempo of music during their show.  Unfortunately, this 
leads to a lot of the shows sounding like the same schizophrenic grab bag of 
music, which IMO turns people off.  

HOWEVER, there is at least one good show on KALX...       mine!  :)

Actually, I should rephrase that... There is at least one show on KALX 
which the people of sfraves might have some interest in.  There, that's 
a little less pretentious :)

The show airs at the same time as Minor Minor's previous show, Thursdays 
from 9:30pm-midnight.  My show leans more to the ambient/experimental 
side of things, but I try to throw in at least a couple sets of more 
bootie-shaking music.

As for the receptability, I've found that KALX comes in many parts of San 
Francisco, Marin, and as far south as Los Altos/Redwood City.  In the 
past, KSJS had the same frequency as us (90.7), so it interfered just 
about everywhere, but if you haven't tuned in for a few months, give it a 
try! 

See ya,
Seth

Who says e-mail is impersonal? Here's a dictionary of our favorite emoticons
typeable symbols to say what you feel!

:-(   not happy anymore
:-|    have an ordinary day
:-/   Can't decide
|-O   I'm bored
(-:   I'm left handed
;-"   kiss me, my sweet.
:-{#} I wear braces
C+:-) you cook,    :-9 I'll eat!
:-~)   I caught a cold
:-a      I can touch my tongue to my nose!
O-)      I'm into scuba diving.
|^o       I snore
:-*      just ate a pickle
:-~i     i'm a smoker
:-B      I have an overbite
:-r      Bleahhh!
<:-O     Eeek!
:-{}     Lots of lipstick
{:-)     I wear a toupee
}:-(     wearing a toupee in the wind?
:-))-:  A theater-lover
:>)        from an ivy league school
%-6     been staring at screen too long
8-o       love's suspense movies
:-X       my lipes are sealed

Received: from EAGLE.WESLEYAN.EDU by EAGLE.WESLEYAN.EDU (PMDF V4.2-11 #5526) id
 <01HWK6969LVA8Y57QN@EAGLE.WESLEYAN.EDU>; Tue, 17 Oct 1995 20:38:52 EST
Date: 17-OCT-1995 19:44:29.94
Subject: Introducing:Colin
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-id: <01HWK6969LVC8Y57QN@EAGLE.WESLEYAN.EDU>
Content-type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=US-ASCII
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey now,
	My name is Colin and I'm a newcomer to the electronic version of
San Fran Raves, but I've been doing the real thing for about three years
now. At the present moment I'm marooned in Connecticut attending Wesleyan
University. I'll be done this May. 
	One of the benifits of coming to school out here is that I've had a 
chance to go to raves up and down this coast as well as the left one.   
San Francisco is the place to be. No other city or region I've been to has 
anything which resembles the kind of community feeling that San Francisco has.
Personally, it is the amazing group of people that makes raves (and the rest
of it) so truly special. I cherish the openness, acceptance, sophistication,
silliness, and awareness that this community fosters. It is something found
in very few other places.
	There has been some debate recently about the domination of house
in the SF scene. Even the best Jungle in world is awful in the company of
500 hostile kids from New York. Many events out here have an enourmous variety
of musical styles, but the love is not there to make the party go off. No
amount of drugs can overcome it. (Although people back east seem to be trying
to push the limits of how many drugs you can take) I believe that all the
house in SF tends to bond the community together. Of course, now that we
have such a great group of people together, we might try out some other music.
	
	My important message: VOTE!!! VOTE!!! VOTE!!!
	This November 17(?) Those of us in San Fran can elect a new mayor,
which would probably mean a new chief of police, vote down the curfew law,
elect Cesar to the board of supervisors, and generally help ourselves out.
If you don't go and vote, Jordan and the status quo will only make it harder
to dance. The same is true in all bay area cities. Richmond: The civic center
policy is still in debate, people who live there can use their voting power,
meager though it might be, to influence policy. Ditto for Vallejo, Daly City,
Berkeley, and elsewhere.
	The key to this is to make sure that everybody in the community is 
talking about this. Tell your friends who don't use the internet. 
Get the word out. Promoters should pick up voter registration cards for people
to fill out. Call the people running for office and see how they feel about
your right to dance. Let them know that there is a significant number of
people who care about this issue.

	OK, back down off my soapbox. I'll be back in the bay area Thursday
until Oct. 29th. I'd love to meet some of you in person. You may know who
I am. I am one of the people behind Tribal Funk. If you've been to one of
our parties you've probably seen me running around pulling out my hair. I
was the one talking like an idiot on the microphone at the end of our last
party in Santa Cruz.
	Also, anyone on the East whose out here missing SF, drop me a note.

Much Love to All Those Who Live to Dance
Colin

There is much harder, faster stuff than house being spun all over the bay
area. I can guarantee that there will be some good slamming beats played at
Fnf on the 28th. Check it out, it's an experience. I don't get up to SF
much for the regular parties (I live in Monterey), but at the events that I
have been to, the majority of tracks played were more on the trance side
than house. It seems to me that the more commercialized events and clubs
tend more towards a house beat. The smaller events where the DJs are there
for the music, not the money have always been a better bet in my book.

Tim Gotch
93
