> Not to bring anyone's head down, or anything, but there are at
> least 2 items on the ballot for SF City elections worth noting:
> 
> First is a measure to extend the city curfew to include 17
> year olds (it's currently for 16 & under).  The current law
> is set to expire at the end of the year.  This measure will
> also extend it indefinately and make the law difficult to overturn.
> There's another measure that will beef up police oversight, and
> we know that we can't have too much of that.  Sorry for not having
> the measure letters handy.
> 
Mayor Jordan's curfew proposition is Prop L.

the Prop to increase civilian oversight of the police was put on the 
ballot by tom ammianl's office, and which was informed by and supported 
by numerous police watch dog groups in sf, is Prop G.  it would:

-  amend the city charter so that the occ director must be supported by the 
bd. of supes (right now only the mayor and police commission have a say)

- require the occ to report to the bd of supes 4x a year

- and require the city to pay awards and settlement women as a result of 
police misconduct out of the pd's budget, NOT the general city budget.

(and it would require them to make publice apologies for ever busting any 
raves, and to give out free shiny stickers...uh...mayb e in mydreams...)

monicat (i'm an anarchist and i'm voting! it's not that bad!  it's better 
than going to the dentist!)

Hello SFRavers -
 Here's more information about the "SFRaves Peninsula Picnic" that's happen-
ing this Saturday , Oct. 21st. 

About The Park -
 It will be at Edgewood County Park and nature preserve , near HW 280 at
the border of San Carlos and Redwood City. It has two parking lots , with
the larger lot near the road. There's a nice meadow next to the inner
parking lot, with the picnic areas and restrooms located above the meadow.

 For those of you who enjoy hiking, there are two hiking trails almost 2 
miles in length, one hiking trail of 1.4 miles, and other that's 3/4 mile long.
I haven't tried these trails , but they are supposed to wind through grassland, 
oak woodland, and chaparral . Also a ridge with a great views of Skyline 
Ridge, Huddart Park, the San Andreas Valley, the Crystal Springs Lake, and 
the Bay.

When and Where -
 The park opens at 8AM - I'll be there at that time to reserve picnic area 
#1 , which is a nice picnic area that's next to a little streambed surrounded 
by trees.  You get there by walking up the footpath along the left of the 
meadow, up above and behind the meadow, past picnic area #2. "Our" area
will be on the right of the path.

 I see us being there until 2:30PM-3:00PM - so show up any time before then!

Misc -
  As I mentioned before , the regulations say "Loud radios and the playing of
amplified musical instruments are not permitted". So , I am encouraging
folks to bring drums and other non-amplified instruments! I'm not a practiced
musician , but I will bring some conga bells that I will try to discretely 
torture while other folks are making music! 
  It's a picnic , so bring food & beverages. There's a little barbecue stove
next to the picnic tables , for those who want to scorch their food before
they eat it. I'll bring a bag of coals and fire implements.

How To Get There -
>From North Peninsula:
  On HW280 Southbound, drive south towards San Carlos and Redwood City. 
After the HW92 interchange, drive about 4 miles and take the Edgewood Road 
exit. Turn left onto Edgewood Road and drive under HW280 towards the bay.
The park entrance will be on the right after Crestview Drive.

>From South Peninsula and South Bay:
  On HW280 Northbound, drive north towards Redwood City and San Carlos.
After the HW84 (Woodside Road) interchange, past Farm Hill Blvd, take the 
Edgewood Road exit and turn right onto Edgewood Road. Drive downhil, the
park entrance is 500 ft. on the right, past Crestview Drive.

>From East Bay:
  Take the Hayward/San Mateo Bridge (HW92) to San Mateo. Continue to the
hills, and take the HW280 South (San Jose) exit. Follow the directions above 
for "From North Peninsula".

>From Coast:
  Take HW17 over mountains to HW280, Northbound. Follow directions above
for "From South Peninsula and South Bay", or take HW92 over mountains to
HW280 Southbound. Follow directions above for "From North Peninsula".

--------------------------------
 I know there's going to be a really nice event happening in Mendicino this
Saturday and Sunday called Tribal Future, so I guess a lot of you folks will
be at Mendicino . If not , come on over to Edgewood Park for awhile!

 Is any one of the Friends and Family crew coming to the picnic? If so , would
it be too early to bring some of the F&F Halloween/Samhain party tickets 
for sale at the picnic.

 Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

I'm taking a meditation class at SF State. The discussion revolves 
around
the different meditative practices of various Eastern religions.

It's mentioned that some yogis use anger as a source of "life energy",

whereas the energy that compromises anger is brought up through the 
chakras
and transmuted throughout the body. The energy is then as used as a 
sort of
"boost" to elevate ones conciousness,

Way cool.

Something to think about the next time I'm looking for parking.  ;)

later...

>> Not to bring anyone's head down, or anything, but there are at
>> least 2 items on the ballot for SF City elections worth noting:
>>
>> First is a measure to extend the city curfew to include 17
>> year olds (it's currently for 16 & under).  The current law
>> is set to expire at the end of the year.  This measure will
>> also extend it indefinately and make the law difficult to overturn.
>> There's another measure that will beef up police oversight, and
>> we know that we can't have too much of that.  Sorry for not having
>> the measure letters handy.
>>
>Mayor Jordan's curfew proposition is Prop L.
>
>the Prop to increase civilian oversight of the police was put on the
>ballot by tom ammianl's office, and which was informed by and supported
>by numerous police watch dog groups in sf, is Prop G.  it would:
>
>-  amend the city charter so that the occ director must be supported by the
>bd. of supes (right now only the mayor and police commission have a say)
>
>- require the occ to report to the bd of supes 4x a year
>
>- and require the city to pay awards and settlement women as a result of
>police misconduct out of the pd's budget, NOT the general city budget.
>
>(and it would require them to make publice apologies for ever busting any
>raves, and to give out free shiny stickers...uh...mayb e in mydreams...)
>
>monicat (i'm an anarchist and i'm voting! it's not that bad!  it's better
>than going to the dentist!)

And just as important is WHO becomes Mayor, and WHO becomes DA.

I am split on Jordan/Brown, both hold some postivie elemts that I like.  As
for DA, ahnds down, it's Terence Hallinan.

T. Hallinan would like to do the following:

-Decriminalize drugs in SF.  Most notably Marijuana. (CHECK!)
-Decriminalize prostitution in SF, create a red-light district. (CHECK!)
-Stop Matrix and prosectuion of the homeless on misdemeanor charges.
(reluctant CHECK), I like the concept of Matrix, and I like the result
(pushing the homeless out of SF into neighboring counties have made
everyone aware of the plight of the homeless.  It is now a Bay Area
problem, not just SF), but it is questionable constituionally IMHO.
-Reign in the cops. (CHECK!)

As for Jordan/Brown?  I dunno, Achtenberg is out IMHO.  I am suspicious of
her reluctance in adressing minorities issues, esp. AIDS in the minority
community. I also think she's too pro gay for my tastes, and SF is more
than just a gay mecca.  Other people live here too!

Brown I like, but let's face it, he's a backroom dealer.  Despite that, he
is the one who could get the supes to move on issues.  With Jordan, the
Mayor's office and the Supervisors are at a constant stalemate.

Jordan I like as well.  SF has become a bit safer under his watch.  But
he's too much of a micro manager, and as such is ineffective with the
biggger picture issues.  I also think that there has been too much emphasis
on police in SF, and not enough on job creation/retention in the city.

All are beholden to somebody.

For the most ultra liberal ticket, I choose Brown/Hallinan.( Some might say
Achtenberg/Hallinan)
For the a moderate ticket, Jordan/Hallinan.
Status quo Jordan/Smith <- Mr. Thumbs Up. (this is NOT an option IMHO!)

Ben Hom?  Forget it, all he talks about is business.  And there's more to
SF than that as well.

If you want to make a difference, are tired of laws that suck (a technical
term), want 18+ parties, your had better stop complaining and vote.  If you
have an agenda, organize, and get the vote out!  They can never ignore
numbers.  The Million Man March is proof of that concept.

Much peace,
John

Greetings!

As I am being literally *deluged* with mail asking me to save tickets for
people, I've struck upon the idea of mail order....

If you live:

  out of state
  south of san jose
  or north of san rafael

and you send me a check and a stamped, self-addressed envelope, arriving at
me no later than this Saturday the 21st (ie mail it today!) for at least 3
tickets, (at $5 each) I'll hapilly mail them to you on Monday the 23rd.

Make checks payable to

Ethan Miller
1425 Santa Fe Ave.
Berkeley, CA 94702

Locals, please don't abuse this, I have no time for it, it's merely a
courtesy to our far ranging friends.

Once gain tickets will also be avaible at my house in berkeley, middle of
next week for you east bay folks... details will be posted later.

take it easy
ethan

From: "Josh Johnson" <JJOHNSON@sjhs.sanjuan.k12.ut.us>
Date: Mon, 16 Oct 1995 12:39:37 MST
Subject: (Fwd) Neiman Marcus Cookies 

Forwarded message:
From:          "Mrs. Taylor" <US-UT-K12-SANJUAN-SJHS/ETAYLOR>
Organization:  San Juan High School
To:            WP
Date:          Mon, 16 Oct 1995 12:35:49 MST
Subject:       Neiman Marcus Cookies 

Ok students, here's a chance to make some points with dear ole mom.  
Print this out and take it home for her.  I'm sure--if she loves it-- 
you'll get the benefit by getting to do the taste test thing.
******************
>>I was given this by a friend, and bear with me if someone has already
>>sent this out.  I got this as a photocopy and typed it word for word, so
>>here goes:
>>
>>**************************************************************************
>>
>>This message is sent to you with the hope that you will forward it to
>>EVERYONE you have ever seen the e-mail address of.
>>In the spirit of the originator feel free to post it anywhere/everywhere.
>>
>>Okay, everyone....a true story of justice in the good old U.S. of A.
>>Thought y'all might enjoy this; if nothing else, it shows internet
>>justice, if it can be called that.
>>
>>My daughter & I had just finished a salad at Neiman-Marcus Cafe in Dallas
>>& decided to have a small dessert.  Because our family are such cookie
>>lovers, we decided to try the "Neiman-Marcus Cookie".  It was so
>>excellent that I asked if they would give me the recipe and they said
>>with a small frown, "I am afraid not."  Well, I said, would you let me
>>buy the recipe?  With a cute smile, she said "Yes."  I asked how much,
>>and she responded, "Two fifty."  I said with approval, just add it to my
>>tab.
>>
>>Thirty days later, I recieved my VISA statement from Nieman-Marcus and it
>>was $285.00.  I looked again and I remembered I had only spent $9.95 for
>>the two salads and about $20.00 for a scarf.  As I glanced at the bottom
>>of the statement, it said "Cookie Recipe - $250.00."  Boy was I upset!!
>>I called Neiman's Accounting Dept. and told them the waitress said it was
>>"two fifty," and I did not realize she meant $250.00 for a cookie recipe.
>>
>>I asked them to take back the recipe and reduce my bill and they said
>>they were sorry, but because all the recipes were this expensive so not
>>just everyone could duplicate any of our bakery recipes....
>>the bill would stand.
>>
>>I waited, thinking of how I could get even or get any of my money back.
>>
>>I just said, "Okay, you folks got my $250.00 and now I'm going to have
>>$250.00 worth of fun."  I told her that I was going to see to it that
>>every cookie lover will have a $250.00 cookie recipe from Neiman-Marcus
>>for nothing.  She replied, "I wish you wouldn't do this."  I said, "I'm
>>sorry but this is the only way I feel I could get even," and I will.
>>
>>So, here it is, and please pass it to someone else or run a few
>>copies..... I paid for it, now you can have it for free.
>>
>>(Recipe may be halved):
>>
>>2 cups butter   4 cups flower
>>2 tsp. soda    2 cups sugar
>>5 cups blended oatmeal** 24 oz. chocolate chips
>>2 cups brown sugar   1 tsp. salt
>>1 8 oz. Hershey Bar (grated)  4 eggs
>>2 tsp. baking powder   3 cups chopped nuts (your choice)
>>2 tsp. vanilla
>>
>>**Measure oatmeal and blend in a blender to a fine powder.
>>cream the butter and both sugars.  Add eggs and vanilla;
>>mix together with flour, oatmeal, salt, baking powder, and
>>soda.  Add chocolate chips, Hershey Bar and nuts.  Roll into
>>balls and place two inches apart on a cookie sheet.  Bake
>>for 10 minutes at 375 degrees.  Makes 112 cookies.
>>
>>Have fun!!!  This is not a joke --- this is a true story..
>>
>>***************************************************************************
>>
>>Well, that is the whole thing.  I hope that you wenjoyed it.  As I said
>>before this was forwarded to a friend of a friend of mine, who got it as
>>a photocopy.  Please send it on to others, lists, etc.
>>
>>Have a great day!
>>
>>Tom !-
>>   \__/
>>
>>TOM TAYLOR, JR.                    ************************************
>>TAYLORT@MHD1.MOORHEAD.MSUS.EDU     *  IT IS IMPORTANT TO KEEP AN OPEN *
>>                                   *  MIND, BUT NOT SO OPEN THAT YOUR *
>>                                   *  BRAINS FALL OUT.                *
>>                                   *                                  *
>>                                   * --STEPHEN A KALLIS, JR.          *
>>                                   ************************************
>>
>
>Brandee Thorne
>Utah State University
>NFS
>
>
*********************************************************

jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee):
>As for Jordan/Brown?  I dunno, Achtenberg is out IMHO.  I am suspicious of
>her reluctance in adressing minorities issues, esp. AIDS in the minority
>community. I also think she's too pro gay for my tastes, and SF is more
>than just a gay mecca.  Other people live here too!

Well, I'm voting for Achtenberg -- even though I'm not gay. I think
she's a lot more than just a gay candidate. And besides, having someone
like her in charge will piss off the Christian Right, and I'm all for
that.

Where do you get the suspicion that she's insensitive to minority
issues? Perhaps she doesn't want to harp on AIDS because she doesn't
want to be seen as just a "gay" candidate. Anybody in her community
couldn't possibly stay insensitive to the issues, which is not
something you could say about Brown or Jordan who live their lives
hiding in splendid and extravagant isolation, away from the death and
dying that is going on all around. And i'm not at all sure that Brown
is sensitive to anything or anyone unless they're driving a Mercedes
Benz or a Lincoln Continental.

For more info on achtenberg: http://www.gworld.com/achtenberg.html

hello all...i remember fondly the moment i posted the message "your mail"
and i recall stating that i was going to get many bad posts because of it,
but i had no idea...i'm happy to see you guys are so adamant in supporting
what you like and i'm now going to respond to a few of the comments made to
me and probably dig myself in a deeper hole..hehe.. here i go. [this is a
very long message but i responded to many peoples's criticisms..]
>Basics (no house music).
every time i've been to a basics..the majority of what i heard was house...
> DO you think it might
>be a lack of good Happy Hardcore records?
>I noticed in an earlier post of yours that you
>play Jungle. Maybe you didn't catch that hour of some of the better Jungle
>I've heard on the West Coast on the lower deck (I think it was Malcolm).
>And if I'm not mistaken, it wasn't all house upstairs and there was some
>VERY NEW music.
you are right...i said that all i heard was yukky house music and that's
right because that is BASICALLY what i heard..this does not mean that there
was nothing else played, but obviously the majority was house...perhaps not
yukky, but house nontheless..this, i don't think you can deny unless you
all have thought up some new terms for house which i'm not aware of...i
heard that malcolm played jungle on lower deck and was very happy he bigged
up the jungle vibes..i was, however, taking care of my friend's toe which
happened to be severly crushed by a falling speaker..therefore, i missed
the jungle tings..i Am upset about that one...the dub was good as well, but
in truth, i didn't think there was a great deal of variety to the music
there.

> So this one gets a thumbs up for 6 hours of raver
>fun on the San Francisco Bay.
>Sunset is a worthy successor to the original Golden Gate park parties
>in '92 and Boogie Buffet in '93 as the glue that keeps the scene going.
yes it was fun...i'm not denying that san francisco has a very nice vibe to
its parties, etcetera, because i've certainly been to some of my best up
here...but the music does bug sometimes...

>Dancehall and Jungle
>Riddim and Rewind
>Shoban and Guests
>Saturdays @ top of 424 Haight
>9-2 $2 21+ 415-995-4599

i know of this and i've talked to shoban before but i'm not old enough to
get in...so,sucks to be me.

>Pardon my annoyance, but if you are so disdainful of the music in SF,
>go to different parties, spin some yourself, DO SOMETHING.

i try to go to different parties (hard when you are a student with not
enough money and no car) and i DO something...i spin jungle and a bit of
happy hardcore and i am certainly working on playing out...i also go to
school full time and i'm working on getting a spot on college radio..AND
i'm dedicated to bringing up the jungle vibe everywheres..so you can shove
that..yeah i'm disdainful..but at the same time, i AM trying to change
things in my favor.

>I have trax older than 2 years that I still play, just because of the
>energy that they give me.
>>So lets take all that old/new bullshit a given and move on. Besides, I
>>like SF's sound. Bigger is not better, and neither is faster, or newer.
>>one shouldn't
>>look back and appreciate the places people have gone before with new,
>>open eyes and expanded minds.

i play old tracks as well and i wasn't commenting on the quality of old
versus new music, i was trying to point out that a great deal of the music
that i have heard here since i've been here sounds quite similar to the
music i heard when i went to Basics and Full Moon parties up here two years
ago..of course, if you are into that music, i'm sure you'll beg to differ
with me..But i concur that it is very similar.

> what exactly are you playing that is SO HIP!   Put
>a playlist where your mouth is, let see it.
i am playing jungle and it is arguable whether or not that is "hip" to you
but i think that it is definitely a very interesting and rather "new" form
of music, at least to the west coast (although in England, of course, it is
already surpassing itself by leaps and bounds). playlist...hard to say
because finding new jungle stuff up here is like pulling teeth...but my
style is..
H.M.P. "runin's"
hype "r.I.P. remixes"
aladdin "mash up yer know"
goldie "angel"
dj ss "limb by limb remix"
got some idea i hope? more on the hardstep vibe but a little intelligent
and ladies cru thrown in...

>where else is there more raves
>than San Fransico in
>the United States?  No where!
there's a lot of places with thriving rave scenes in the U.S...i may remind
that S.F. is not the be all, end all of rave culture...chicago, los
angeles, florida, new york, baltimore, minneapolis, philly...there are a
lot of good and interesting scenes everywhere, perhaps more well suited to
my musical tastes than here...and there are not a million raves every week
here..i don't consider this a mecca in terms of choice-either in dj's or
clubs.

>Happy Hardcore and
>Gabber, which is shit music (sorry for the opinion)
>and is basically dead
>everywhere in the world (gabber being a strictly Netherlands phenomean).
>This music is not being produced, made
>etc....by hardly anyone anymore.

okay...i guess portland is more shut off from the world than i
thought..there is a very thriving gabber scene in la as well as other
places around the country...and you may think its shit music but its still
out there and there are still a great deal of records, rotterdam label and
otherwise, out there for gabber dj's.. no there are no gabber records here
that i've scene, as well as there are relatively few jungle records and
probably about three happy hardcore...while it may not be popular here i
think that any city which prides itself on being a hotbed for NEW and
DIFFERENT music would at least provide resources to dj's looking to play
that...?

>> I can guarantee that there will be some good slamming beats played at
>>Fnf on the 28th
i still can't decide on friends and family or funky techno..how many people
do you think weill be at each and what's the line-ups? any ideas guys...

[by the way..if you were at sunset and saw a girl with black hair wearing a
white fuzzy kitty hat and a puffy white ski vest that was me...so next time
you see me you can come up to me and give me a hug or pelt me with
blow-pops for not liking house...your choice. :)

                                                                **starEyes**
                                                        **Big up alla junglette*

hello all...i remember fondly the moment i posted the message "your mail"
and i recall stating that i was going to get many bad posts because of it,
but i had no idea...i'm happy to see you guys are so adamant in supporting
what you like and i'm now going to respond to a few of the comments made to
me and probably dig myself in a deeper hole..hehe.. here i go. [this is a
very long message but i responded to many peoples's criticisms..]
>Basics (no house music).
every time i've been to a basics..the majority of what i heard was house...
> DO you think it might
>be a lack of good Happy Hardcore records?
>I noticed in an earlier post of yours that you
>play Jungle. Maybe you didn't catch that hour of some of the better Jungle
>I've heard on the West Coast on the lower deck (I think it was Malcolm).
>And if I'm not mistaken, it wasn't all house upstairs and there was some
>VERY NEW music.
you are right...i said that all i heard was yukky house music and that's
right because that is BASICALLY what i heard..this does not mean that there
was nothing else played, but obviously the majority was house...perhaps not
yukky, but house nontheless..this, i don't think you can deny unless you
all have thought up some new terms for house which i'm not aware of...i
heard that malcolm played jungle on lower deck and was very happy he bigged
up the jungle vibes..i was, however, taking care of my friend's toe which
happened to be severly crushed by a falling speaker..therefore, i missed
the jungle tings..i Am upset about that one...the dub was good as well, but
in truth, i didn't think there was a great deal of variety to the music
there.

> So this one gets a thumbs up for 6 hours of raver
>fun on the San Francisco Bay.
>Sunset is a worthy successor to the original Golden Gate park parties
>in '92 and Boogie Buffet in '93 as the glue that keeps the scene going.

its parties, etcetera, because i've certainly been to some of my best up

>9-2 $2 21+ 415-995-4599

i know of this and i've talked to shoban before but i'm not old enough to
get in...so,sucks to be me.

Comments: Authenticated sender is <csil@mailhost.hooked.net>
From: "Christopher Silveira" <csil@hooked.net>
To: stareyes@uclink4.berkeley.edu (vivian host)
Date: Wed, 18 Oct 1995 15:27:18 +0000
Subject: Re: the final words
CC: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Priority: normal
X-mailer: Pegasus Mail for Windows (v2.10)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I guess we are adamant about house music (at least I can speak for 
me) because of the unmistakeable feeling it sends out. That 'vibe' 
that we all talk about sooo fondly that brings people sooo close 
together. I'm not saying that other music can't do that, it's just 
that it comes soo easily with house music. I mean the whole scene 
around here thrives on the bonding that can happen soo easily between 
people. And soo much of house music speaks that message.

Now just to clarify, do you group trance in the same realm as house? 
Because I have not been to a Basics, Gathering, Vision, Freedom, etc. YET 
where there has not been some of the HARDEST, MIND-BOGGLING TRANCE
I have ever heard.

So just know that at least speaking for me, there is nothing wrong 
with other kinds of music played at parties. It's just that some of 
us have such very strong emotions and deep-seated experiences when it 
comes to house that we take it very seriously, like part of our 
wonderful, love-filled lives. Just remember to stay strong in what 
you believe in and try to smile to at least 5 people you don't know 
every day!

luv ya!

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Christopher Silveira
aka eric longfellow (the lost dj)
csil@hooked.net
http://www.hooked.net/users/csil/
-=(UDIC)=-     "Junior Dragon"
-  "It makes no difference in our house...and this is fresh!"

>         I'm not one who trusts politics to any significant degree.  But in
> the vote for SF District Attorney, a candidate stands out who GREATLY
> affects the house scene.  Terrence Hallinan is the only candidate who even
> cares about the issues affecting young people, such as curfews, dance club
> sweeps, and stopping subjective police enforcement of cabaret rules.
>         Everyone in the house community knows someone directly affected by
> parties being shut down indiscriminately by out of control cops.  With
> Jordan and the other candidates supporting strong curfews for young people,
> it will only get worse.  (Learn of England's new Criminal Justice Bill w/
> provisions aimed at stopping raves to see where this is going.)  Only one
> candidate will even lend a sympathetic ear to such issues, much less
> support them.  Hallinan has supported the community as a Supervisor.  But
> Terrence Hallinan needs financial support to overcome the better-funded
> mainstream politicos.

On Wed, 18 Oct 1995, Christopher Silveira wrote:

> Now just to clarify, do you group trance in the same realm as house? 
> Because I have not been to a Basics, Gathering, Vision, Freedom, etc. YET 
> where there has not been some of the HARDEST, MIND-BOGGLING TRANCE
> I have ever heard.

	This isn't hard trance you have been listening to. Go to some of 
the record shops that have listening stations and play some of the stuff 
off the Eye Q label, Drop Bass label, or the Harthouse label (the three 
that come quickiest to mind). Drop Bass is probably the best for hard 
trance (some call it noise trance)....

dave

In-Reply-To: <v02130501acaaab5a229e@[128.32.99.244]>

> >Happy Hardcore and
> >Gabber, which is shit music (sorry for the opinion)
> >and is basically dead
> >everywhere in the world (gabber being a strictly Netherlands phenomean).
> >This music is not being produced, made
> >etc....by hardly anyone anymore.

	Gabber is actually thriving in just about every part of the world
except SF. It is one of the main forms of music in the DIY culture - it is
being made and played all over the place - some decent stuff is coming out
of the Mid-west now. As was said in the post this is requoted from, the
problem with it here is you just cannot find it. No record stores stock,
and most will not special order it for you. I have run up a massive phone
bill to British record stores that will do mail orders for me. Until you
dance with at least another 20 people to a gabber set you will not know
what it is about, you will not be pulled into the mass of primal energy
that only comes from having a bunch of nutters dancing to something going 
about 200 bpm. It's like me sitting back and saying that techno is shit 
repetitive music that is dead and only listened to by an infinitely small 
cross section of all the people alive anywhere!

> >where else is there more raves
> >than San Fransico in
> >the United States?  No where!
	Actually, from my friends who throw parties in Chicago, I would 
bet they have more parties (combo of underground clubs and 'raves') than 
we do here. We in SF don't really have an underground club scene. Nor do 
we have raves going on everyday of the week with more than house played 
(I don't really want to start this, but find me a trance party on 
Thursday night).

> >> I can guarantee that there will be some good slamming beats played at
> >>Fnf on the 28th

	Your idea of 'slamming beats' most likely varies from that of 
others. While FnF will have harder, more diverse music, and not the same 
exact sets that you have been hearing for the last 6 months, some of us 
think of slamming as a bit more intense than even those no name DJs who 
are spinning at FnF (but then, I am an intensity junkie ;) ). If you want 
to look at the line up, it can be found somewhere under
http://www.bass-station.com/FnF/

dave

Network "Urban legend" alert!

Although i'm probably as guilty of anyone of (re)posting bullshit,
let's keep this stuff minimized. Basically, apply a rule that should be
applied more often in life (well, at least in mine ...) -- "if it seems
too good to be true, it probably is". Alternately known as there ain't
no such thing as a free lunch (TANSTAAFL).

NP: a tape of Ronnie Libido's show on KFJC from last Satyrday, good
enuf that I'm now adding the following to my "to get" list (which I
never get much from :-( )

	Qabbala, "Dub Infusion" 
	Word of Song Records Label, Brooklyn NY. 
	"Dub of Justice"

	Plague, "Mind over Rhythm"
	Rumble Records Label, UK
	"Departure" 

	Chemical Brothers, Exit Planet Dust
	"Thee Little Birdies Down Beats"

	Cool Breeze,
	Remix of "Can't Deal with this" by Alex Reese (sp?) some jungle guy.
	Dorado Records Label.

	Stereolab, Refried Ectoplasms Switched On Volume 2.
	rereleases of old hard to find stuff...

	Mojave (ex Slowdive members)
	"Love Songs on the Radio"

PS: If anybody has suggestions of where to buy any of these, lemme know!

PPS: non-techno/rave warning on the last two but i like 'em anyways.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Oct 18 19:43:22 1995

Received: from duckman.usfca.edu ([138.202.3.163]) by jeeves.usfca.edu (8.6.9/8.6.9) with SMTP id TAA21524 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 18 Oct 1995 19:36:51 -0700
Date: Wed, 18 Oct 1995 19:36:51 -0700
Message-Id: <199510190236.TAA21524@jeeves.usfca.edu>
X-Sender: reicja00@dons.ac.usfca.edu
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Version 1.4.3b4
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: reicja00@dons.ac.usfca.edu (Jake Reichert)
Subject: Re: SF District Attorney (fwd)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I like all the talk on this subject that has been generated, because I
wouldn't have given it half a moment's thought if someone hadn't brought it
up.  I think this is also true of a lot of the voting population in the rave
community.  So here's an idea:  if there are any promoters throwing parties
in the next few weeks that really care about the possibility of being shut
down (or at least severely hampered), they should somehow slip in what we've
been talking about into the parties.  Just some way to let people know these
issues that they probably wouldn't hear about otherwise.  There are a lot of
people who attend raves that would vote differently if they knew about these
issues, since many people are totally unaware of them.

Jake

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Oct 18 19:58:59 1995

From: laural@inmark.com
Received: (from ugate@localhost) by inmarkinmark.com (8.6.12/8.6.9) with UUCP id TAA06341 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Wed, 18 Oct 1995 19:30:02 -0700
Received: from cc:Mail by ugate.inmark.com

Message-Id: <9509188140.AA814071503@ugate.inmark.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: re: the final word
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


     Did someone say Gabber?  Did someone say hard trance (pricking up 
     ears).
     
     If you're having trouble ordering hardcore/hard trance, try Sonic 
     Groove records in New York City and Planet X records in New Brunswick, 
     New Jersey.  You can get their numbers from information -- 212 for New 
     York City, 908 for New Jersey.  Both do mail order.  I shopped at both 
     stores when I lived back East, and got many a 150 bpm+ record there.
     
     Also, I've had good luck in Los Angeles, specifically at DMC on 
     Melrose.
     
     Some labels to check out:
        Trans' Pact
        EXperimental (you name the style, they'll have an example of it)
        Direct Drive
        Harthouse (be careful, spotty selection)
        Labworks (also spotty selection, but some real gems)
        Dance Opera (although some is cheezy)
        Drop Bass (good 'n' crunchy and noisy!)
        Chocci's Choons (fast-acting aceeeid)
        Overdrive (hardcore noise)
        Frankfurt Beat (was that the name?  I can't recall...sleeves
                are black with holographic silver ink)
     
     If anyone wants to "geek" on hard trance / hardcore, drop me a line!  
     I'd love to talk.  I've recently started spinning again after a 
     one-year haitus, and have taken everything out of my crates that is 
     slower than 140 bpm (I needed to do *something* to help me get 
     organized again).  Unfortunately, in my time off I got really out of 
     touch with the music, so I'd love to know what people are finding and 
     liking on that tip.
     
     Laura

>There are plenty of things that are substandard about the SF underground
>music scene, but lack of variety is not a problem.  The house that's
>played is often fairly boring, but then that could easily be said of the
>trance sound that everyone seems to like so much right now.  At least
>we don't have the problems the east and midwest do with tons of people
>glued into the hard and fast sounds and the hard and fast drugs.

sure..i really don't think that a bunch of people addicted to E's is SO
much better than a bunch of people addicted to other things..i know a
million people will disagree and i see their point but My point is...if the
only reason you are going to a rave is to do drugs, then you are there for
the wrong reason..
        actually, it really doesn't matter to me what kind of drugs people
are doing as long as i'm there enjoying my HARD and FAST music with my
friends, sober and loving it...fuck everyone else if they're only there for
the drugs..
        i may point out that most of the people who are into jungle,
particularly in the uk, are sober or only drink and/or smoke pot..they are
definitely NOT crack or tweak addicts...or anything of the sort...to make
the assertion that the kind of drugs you do is based on the kind of music
you listen to or vice versa seems rather silly to me...i know where you get
that from but i don't think that you can make that generalization
and it really doesn't matter what kind of drugs people are on at what
raves, just because more tweakers might like hardcore doesn't mean they
shouldn't play it, here or anywhere.
and..you admitted yourself that the house played here is often farily
boring..which is the basis of my whole problem...promoters don't want to
promote styles of music unless they're already big, but they can't get big
until someone promotes them...ah, the paradox...and im..outie.
                                                                **starEyes**

On Wed, 18 Oct 1995, 'Dave Bayer' wrote:

> 
> > >Happy Hardcore and
> > >Gabber, which is shit music (sorry for the opinion)
> > >and is basically dead
> > >everywhere in the world (gabber being a strictly Netherlands phenomean).
> > >This music is not being produced, made
> > >etc....by hardly anyone anymore.
> 
> 	Gabber is actually thriving in just about every part of the world
> except SF. 
Hardly.  Maybe it is played in the midwest and chicago but definetly not in 
England, or 
most of Europe for that matter, and just because it is played doesn't 
mean that the tracks are new.  Who is the biggest dj from the midwest? 
probably Dj ESP who hasn't made a track over 140 beats per minute in a 
long time.  I challenge you to name one within the last 6 months even 
though he has released at least half a dozen records in that time.  You 
people seem to be getting "Gabber" and "Fast music, or hard trance, 
techno, acid core etc confused with each other. I said Gabber is dying 
/dead, and when I said Gabber I 
mean stuff like Rotterdam records, Mokum records etc (distorted drum 
beat, 4 on the floor rythym, lots of "Fuck" samples and a few noises,160 
+ bpm's, no bassline etc...this is gabber by defintion....I have my 
own record store and I see the release lists for records every week from 
Watts music the North Americas largest distributor  of underground dance 
music, the 
volume of gabber records being released the last 6 months to a year is 
down to less than at most 3 a week.  You call this thriving?

It is one of the main forms of music in the DIY culture - it is
> being made and played all over the place - some decent stuff is coming out
> of the Mid-west now. 

What?  Drop Bass Network is the only label I can think of putting out 
hard and fast stuff currently, most of which is hard acid, or hard 
techno, not gabber.


As was said in the post this is requoted from, the
> problem with it here is you just cannot find it. 

The reason for it as most of the labels have gone out of business or 
moved on to other styles.  See my next message for details.

No record stores stock,
> and most will not special order it for you. I have run up a massive phone
> bill to British record stores that will do mail orders for me. Until you
> dance with at least another 20 people to a gabber set you will not know
> what it is about, you will not be pulled into the mass of primal energy
> that only comes from having a bunch of nutters dancing to something going 
> about 200 bpm. 
I have, and I am going to say it is an interesting experience, but it 
looses it's flavor real quick.   I 
have yet to see anyone dance for the duration that other people can dance 
to music in the  under 145 bpm's category.


It's like me sitting back and saying that techno is shit 
> repetitive music that is dead and only listened to by an infinitely small 
> cross section of all the people alive anywhere!

I am not meaning to come off like that, I am just saying that Gabber is 
definetly not being made like it used to be.  Hell, Frankie Bones arguably 
the most popular dj in America, and the #1 advocate of it at one time was 
dismissing as dying back in December 92.  "Rotterdam Records has become 
so commercial since we broke it, I won't ever play these records again."  
Under One Sky magazine December 1992.  That was almost 3 years ago.

> 
> > >where else is there more raves
> > >than San Fransico in
> > >the United States?  No where!
> 	Actually, from my friends who throw parties in Chicago, I would 
> bet they have more parties (combo of underground clubs and 'raves') than 
> we do here.

I highly doubt it!



Derek

On Wed, 18 Oct 1995 laural@inmark.com wrote:

> 
>      Did someone say Gabber?  Did someone say hard trance (pricking up 
>      ears).
>      
>      If you're having trouble ordering hardcore/hard trance, try Sonic 
>      Groove records in New York City and Planet X records in New Brunswick, 
>      New Jersey.  You can get their numbers from information -- 212 for New 
>      York City, 908 for New Jersey.  Both do mail order.  I shopped at both 
>      stores when I lived back East, and got many a 150 bpm+ record there.
>      
>      Also, I've had good luck in Los Angeles, specifically at DMC on 
>      Melrose.


This is my final post on the subject of Gabber  :).  But although some of 
these labels are more in the hardcore techno category here is more proof 
that Gabber/you peoples definition of gabber is dying.
>      Some labels to check out:
>         Trans' Pact-haven't seen anything for at least 6 months
>         EXperimental (you name the style, they'll have an example of 
it)- out of business!
>         Direct Drive-Bankrupt! Records released as Direct Drive out of 
Germany now.
 >         Harthouse (be careful, spotty selection)-not putting out the 
hard and fast stuff anymore, more minimalist acid trance always 
under 155 for the last 3 months at least
>         Labworks (also spotty selection, but some real gems) -Out of 
business.  Went under about a month ago.
 >         Dance Opera (although some is cheezy)-it has been a while 
since they have released anything
>         Drop Bass (good 'n' crunchy and noisy!) a lot of hard techno 
and acid, but an equal amount of stuff in the 130 bpm range

>         Chocci's Choons (fast-acting aceeeid)-they are still around, 
but it aint very hardcore stuff anymore
>         Overdrive (hardcore noise)-Not there last 3 releases, more like 
electro techno and sample heavy techno/house in the 125-135 bpm range

>         Frankfurt Beat (was that the name?  I can't recall...sleeves
>                 are black with holographic silver ink)-that is a label, 
but I haven't seen one for at least 6 months

I don't mind harder techno, i just find most of it to be too lame and 
unoriginal, or simply hard for the sake of hard. But I would recommend for 
good harder techno (usually it aint faster than 145 bpm's 
for the most part, and usually no gabber) i would recommend these labels. 
Dance esctacy 2001 
PCP records
Praxis records
Cold Rush records
Synewave records
Planet Rythym records
Hybrid records
Nova Mute
Force Inc
80 Aum records-(they might be out of business though)
I will shut up know :)

Derek

>      slower than 140 bpm (I needed to do *something* to help me get

>      touch with the music, so I'd love to know what people are finding and 
>      liking on that tip.

Subject: Fiber Review
Date: Wed, 18 Oct 1995 21:40:54 -0400

Message-ID: <myahwwEOwGgA084yn@sophistem.com>

Precedence: bulk

Hi All,

Xris, Kathleen (no one you know) and I went to Fiber last Saturday.  I don't
know if many SF Ravers were there, certainly not ones I knew by sight.  I
wasn't expecting it to be very ravey, but I was curious to see some
"cyberfashion".

It was located at the former Cyberlab site (New Years, Burning Man
Afterparty) at the Embarcadero end of Folsom.  The place was vastly improved
in appearence since the last time I saw it.  I was surprised to find that my
friend Peter was one of the new tenents there (sharing the space with
Dimension 7).

There were two video projectors and a laser in use.  The visuals were
colorful, active and mixed live. The meshed well with the music (hip
hop/trip hop).  Before the fasion show could start though, the fire marshall
came can kicked everyone out of the building while he did a surprise
inspection.  Everyone was told to go away and come back in an hour.  Why did
the marshal get tipped off?  A sneaky club owner maybe?

Anyway, my friends and I drove around looking for something else to do, but
were suitably board with the rest of the city.  We came back and found that
the marshal had passed the place (all that fixup went to good use) but that
they were only letting people in with hand stamps.  Needless to say, it was
pretty vacant for an hour or more before people started filtering back in.

The fashion show was cool.  The models came out four different times for the
four designers and danced on elevated podiums.  I wish I had been taking
notes so I could give you some designer names as they all did good work.
One designer had a line of slinky black and white miniskirts and tight
jackets,  Not terribly adventerous but probably something you could wear to
more than a rave (but not to your Mom's house).  Another designer displayed
"moon suits" with silverized, body fitting cloths with cool iconic looking
blue, red, and yellow patches.  The same designer showed some skirts and
jackets made out of hinged plastic blue and red tiles.  Not very
utilitarian, but cool looking.  Another designer went off with some soft
fluffy pastel BIG clothing.  Enormous hats and clothing with foam
pertuberences.   One thing even had spider or crab arms sticking out of it.
More like costumes really.  I think I liked those the most.

Thing seemd to finish up around 4 or 5.

All and all, it was a rather fun thing to do and I did enjoy a lot of the
music.  Big points for the visuals too.  Not a rave thing per se, but
a cool thing to do on a Sat. night.

- PT

-- 
< Purple Tiger (ptiger@sophistem.com) | http://www.cybernetix.com/~ptiger >
< Sophistem = Sophisticated Software Systems >
               Don't let a chromosome determine your gender.

I just heard this through the grapevine, but apparently Alameda County, in
review of the events surrounding Cyberfest have decided that the event was
dangerous, a public embarassment, and a throuroughly un-positive event. As
such they have decided to forbid all future all-night events in Alemeda County.

Does anybody who lives in Alemeda Co. know anything more, such as the specific
wording of their decision?

Does anyone know what issues are on the ballot for Nov's elections in regards
to Alameda Co.?

Who are the people who made that decision, and how do we get in touch with
them to persuade them to change it?

Received: (from ugate@localhost) by inmarkinmark.com (8.6.12/8.6.9) with UUCP id LAA11454 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Thu, 19 Oct 1995 11:00:01 -0700
Received: from cc:Mail by ugate.inmark.com

Message-Id: <9509198141.AA814127276@ugate.inmark.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: musings on music
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


     Now that I've thought about it, Gabber, as such, did start dropping 
     out of my musical awareness back in late 1993.  I started buying 12" 
     techno records in winter of 1992, and was quite fond of hard music.  
     They way I learned it, "Gabber" was a subform of "hardcore." 
     "Hardcore" meant anything with a hard loud distorted 909 kick drum 
     that ran from about 150-210 bpm.  Decorative noises on top of the kick 
     were usually very electronic, buzzy, and dissonant.  Anything from 
     Lenny Dee's "Industrial Strength" label is a good example.  "Gabber," 
     as I said above, was considered a subform of hardcore.  The style was 
     shown by the Dutch labels such as Mokum and KNOR.  What differentiated 
     it from hardcore in my mind was a sort of silliness (and I'm not being 
     derogatory here).  I had one record that used a sampled blow dryer to 
     provide decoration of the kick drum, and many others that involved 
     guys screaming in Dutch.  To me, anything screamed in Dutch sounded 
     silly.  It would make us laugh while we were dancing to it at parties. 
     My friends and I would dance around and hug or tickle each other, or 
     just hold hands and jump around.
     
     Anyway, I was finding interesting records in both the hardcore and 
     Gabber genres up until the summer of 1993.  It seemed that suddenly 
     they were dropping off the face of the earth, or at least the really 
     silly ones were.  I was still finding stuff from PCP, Influence, and 
     Industrial Strength.  My point with all this is that whoever said 
     Gabber was dead does have a point, especially if viewed from the angle 
     of the record-buyer.
     
     While I'm on a roll, let me address hard trance.  I think Hardfloor's 
     classic, "Hardtrance Acperience" (yes, that's how it's spelled) is a 
     misnomer.  I have two or three copies of this record...it clocks in 
     under 130bpm, and while it's an amazing example of what some people 
     call "new acid," it's not at all hard trance.   (Side note:  it's a 
     shame every Hardfloor track sounds like a rehash of "Acperience," but 
     I have a cheezy love for Hardfloor anyway).  They way I learned it, 
     hard trance starts around 140bpm and can get as fast as hardcore, but 
     rather than having major distortion on the kick drum and dissonant 
     noises as decorations, the drum beats are more subtle and there's 
     actual melodic content.  DJ Alex, of the former Gaia Mantra records, 
     walks in this musical neighborhood at times.  
     
     There's a really nice area where trance, house, and acid overlap and 
     intermix, and some of my favorite records fall into that category.  
     For an example, listen to Union Jack's "Two Full Moons and a Trout" 
     (now appearing on a compilation near you).  Sublime.  DJ Ethan works 
     this area excellently.
     
     Laura

   Tribal Future ought to be a lot of fun if you can get to it. On
   Saturday, Larry has organized a small picnic for SFRavers - it's a
   good way to meet a few of the email addresses. The Chemical Brothers
   show on Sunday should be good too, they came through here as the Dust
   Brothers a year or so ago.
   
   Finally, get tickets ASAP for the Friends and Family next weekend.
   They will be on sale at Tribal Future, Ameba (starting on Monday), and
   MAD. There aren't very many, and they will go quickly.

     * The Groove Line - (415) 321.1500 ext.4788

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 9pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 -
       Progressive house, acid jazz and "alternative" music views. (415)
       281-3377.
     * Sunday night mid-3am - "No UFO's" w/Adam from Silent Records KZSU
       90.1 Stanford
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Tuesday noon-3pm - House and techno w/DJ Unknown and guests - KZSU
       90.1 (Stanford)
     * Thursdays 9:30pm-midnight - "Aurora Borealis" w/DJ Seth. Ambient,
       experimental, ethereal, acid-trance-techno, industrial and
       trip-hop on KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Saturday night - "Saturday Night Spin Out" w/Ronnie Libido. Trip
       hop, Jungle, Ambient, Experimental Sounds. 10pm-2am. KFJC 89.7 -
       Los Altos Hills

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

Date: Thu, 19 Oct 1995 15:58:17 -0700 (PDT)
From: Brian Behlendorf <brian@hyperreal.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com, ambient@hyperreal.com
Subject: Hyperreal Down Time
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.91.951019155725.7320Q-100000@taz.hyperreal.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



NOTICE

Hyperreal will be down from 3pm on Friday, October 20th to 3pm on 
Monday October 23rd.  This is due to major electrical work being done at 
Organic, and due to other constraints which are pretty much unavoidable.  
This means the web sites and mailing lists will be down, although hyperreal 
mail will be spooled at other machines to prevent bouncing.  

Apologies for the inconvenience and the short notice.

	Brian

Subject: PARTY! Nov. 18th, sponsored by Community ConneXion

(Apologies if you receive this multiple times)

Mark your calenders...

	Community ConneXion: the Internet Privacy Provider is having a
party! We're partying to celebrate the spread of privacy on the net,
through the increased security of internet products, as well as the
growth of our services. (Many new services and new features on existing
services will likely be announced before the party. Stay tuned.)
	We're inviting all our customers and other potentially
interested parties, which includes you, if you've received this
note. So please join us, and send a copy of this invitation to anyone
else you may know who would be interested in attending.

Where: Icon Byte Bar & Grill
       299 9th Street (at Folsom)
       SF CA 94103
When:  Sat. Nov. 18 1995
       7:00 PM

	This is a good chance to meet and network with the people who
are making privacy on the internet a reality. Find out more about the
HackNetscape and HackMicrosoft contests. Learn about our specialized
web services, found nowhere else but at Community ConneXion. Hear
about the anonymous and psuedonymous servers here and what we're doing
to improve them.
	There will be catered snacks and a no-host bar.

>        October 30th - Our One Year Anniversary, reliving the heady days of
>'94 with....
>                                   ******Thomas*****Phil Smart*****Darkhorse

Is that Thomas as in UK/wicked-affiliated thomas?? 

Damn, where in  da heck has he been? -- i've missed his attitude/taste
in music since the good old days ... damn, where's my blunt, my cane,
and my rocking chair? Step right up to the porch and let me tell you a
story... yeah, back then things were so tough, but we were so cool...
that we'd have to dance backwards just to get ahead! You'd have to walk
30 miles in the snow in pink sateen shorts and bondage gear just to
arrive at skool, recite a meaningless zen koan in a bleak and empty
field, and trudge home. Time moved sideways -- we'd have to wait till
the stop signs changed color before you could go! People ran off pure
alien energy alone --  we never ate and would only drink water to keep
the drugs from cristalizing around our tongues, eyes and noses. Hell,
we were such a public menace that the gum'mint forced us to wear full
biohazard suits just to prevent  people from catching a contact high!
Yeah, you kids nowadays, you have it easy! Damn fuzzy-headed skateboard
totin' 'lil rug-rats!

Anyways, ... if it's really Thomas, I'm there! Lemme know!

PS: Now playing: Just bought this 3CD compilation called "the serious
road trip" from melody maker (UK), 1994. hardbag (ceasefire), laurent 
garnier (rex attitude), leftfield (release the dubs), dust brothers (be
that thing), secret knowledge (nuttin' dub), the aloof (circumstances),
system 7 (desir, live), finitribe (u g t update), higher intelligence
agency (delta, live), drum club (space angel station), lion rock
(soundtrack in a palace of delights, spooky vs chapterhouse (we are
beautiful), loop guru (yayli), banco de gaia (white paint), transglobal
underground (el hedudd), pressure of speech (pressure of speech), ege
bam yasi (eightball), pip (midnight vibration), the orb (plateu of
normality), and the last whole cd is Orbital doing remind (live at
glastonbury). Looked like a good bet for $23.00 and it benefits
children's charity in bosnia... other than that, i had no idea what
this is, but i got the feeling I'd be as happy with it as I was with
purchasing my first Acid House/Rave stuff with "Give Peace A Dance
Volume 1" (1990?).

>silk screen will not be crisp enough, 

you can get really, really fine lines by doing 6+ color separations 
of your screen. You can prit hairlines. It's just a matter of knowing 
what you're doing with the silk scrren... it's really difficult to 
register the screens.

> a bubble jet printer would take a certain type > of iron-on paper

yup. it's out there. I don't know much but that I know I'd seen an as 
somewhere.

> computer(?) doing the printing on the t-shirts. 

As far as I know there's no printer than can run a t-shirt thru it.

Sounds to me like you need a really high-quality photo silk sreen. We 
(me and my coworkers) don't know of any here in the Bay Area, but 
have heard that a place called Graphic Traffic in Emeryville might be 
a good place to check out.

Alissa

Subject: Re[2]: musings on music
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


     

Arther Chandler writes:
______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
  
>But I've been disappointed at the harmonic simplicity of all branches of
>techno over the years. I'm fed up with the old familiar chord
>progressions that betray either a lack of composing skill or a
>too-easily-satisfied ear.

The harmonic simplicity has its good points and its bad points.  The good 
points are that you can get a really good crowd reaction with something 
that follows a particular pattern, for example anything by Hardfloor with 
their big cheezy acid break/build two-thirds of the way through every 
track they write.  I've seen the screaming and whooping and cheering 
during the build up, and then the frenzied dancing when the beats come 
back.  It works.

The bad point about this type of harmonic simplicity is that Hardfloor 
uses the big cheezy acid break/build two-thirds of the way through every 
track they write (but I love them anyway).

>If the composers of techno would pay attention to jazz and classical
>music, maybe they could learn how to weave melodies into the higher 
>harmonies of sophisticated chord progressions.

I think that techno, when done very well, can share something with fuges. Both 
are very mathimatically based, and involve pattern transformations like 
inverting, mirroring, and transposition.  Of course, it's just as easy to write 
a bad techno track as it is to write a bad pop song, and there's a good deal of 
both out there.  For me, the fun lies in uncovering the good stuff, and I can 
see how that gets frustrating.
  
>But maybe I'm just listening to the wrong discs and djs. Can anyone 
>suggest recordings that have the kind of complex harmonic progressions 
>I'm longing for?

It might not be readily present in the form.  Techno primarily exists 
as dance music, designed to cause body movement and emit a certain 
emotional response (which, as near as I can define, is a drive to dance 
more :-) :-) ).  A sub-species of techno/ambient calls itself 
"Intelligent Dance Music" and claims to be more musical and artistic 
than the basic "thump-make-you-dance" track.

Also, with the emphasis on live DJing being to create a smooth set with 
seamless transitions, some of the more complex experimental tracks 
might not get played because they can't be incorporated into the set.

What I'm getting at is that it might be asking too much of the techno 
genre to make it as musically complex as jazz or classical.  I went to 
Jazz clubs a few times in New York city, and no one danced there.  I've 
been to classical concerts, and no one danced there either.  Maybe 
because Jazz and classical elict more of an intellectual response they 
don't make good dance music?

There's people on this list who know a lot more about artists and 
labels who produce "Intelligent Dance Music."  Maybe they can give us 
an overview of who is good to listen to?  We've got some disks by Banco 
de Gaia and Global Communications at home that are quite excellent, but 
I'm sure that's barely a beginning.

Laura


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Oct 19 20:13:58 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id UAA12153; Thu, 19 Oct 1995 20:13:58 -0700
Received: from sierra.zyzzyva.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id UAA12116; Thu, 19 Oct 1995 20:13:38 -0700
Received: from eat.organic.com (eat.organic.com [204.62.129.1]) by sierra.zyzzyva.com (8.6.12/8.6.11) with ESMTP id OAA25613 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 19 Oct 1995 14:28:23 -0500

To: Nvg8r <nvg8r@c2.org>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: There ain't no such thing as a final word... 
In-reply-to: Your message of "Thu, 19 Oct 1995 03:02:22 PDT."
             <Pine.SUN.3.91.951019024221.17742A-100000@infinity.c2.org> 
Date: Thu, 19 Oct 1995 12:30:00 -0700
From: ozymandias G desiderata <ogd@organic.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Ah shit, since everybody else is tossing in their hard techno
recommendations, I guess I'll do the same. There is a _lot_ of high-quality
harder techno coming out right now. I tend to go for the more minimal, dark
stuff (no offense, NVG8R, but too much acidtrance makes me wanna barf).
Stuff like this:

	o Recent Bandulu outings on Infonet
	     I especially recommend "Crisis A'Gwarn / Fight the Oppressors,"
	     which sounds like nothing else out there. Hard as hell, yet
	     dubby at the same time. These guys exist in a realm of their
	     own. Their full-length CDs are all great, although they're much
	     more relaxed than the singles.
	o Djungle Fever / Mono Tone / Structure / Force Inc. / Global
	  Electronic Network / Profan
	     Quality, fast acid, cranked out with incredible proliferacy by
	     a small group (< 6 people) of deranged acidheads originally
	     from Cologne, Germany. Yeah, these labels wobble in and out of
	     existence as the principle crew move from continent to
	     continent (Khan is living in NYC now, so I think that rules out
	     Djungle Fever, and for some reason Force Inc. is putting out
	     Chicago acid house right now). However, the good shit on these
	     labels is _really_ good. An excellent introduction to the
	     Cologne sound is the day-glo _Acid Resistant_ compilation that
	     Sm:)e Communications put out early this year. Another good
	     example of the Cologne sound is the recent stuff by Air Liquide
	     (although I strongly recommend avoiding _The Increased
	     Difficulty of Concentration_. I know that a lot of people like
	     it, but it bores the crap out of me).
	o PCP / Dance Extacy 2001 / Cold Rush / Super Special
	     Hardcore's last great hope. This family of labels has been
	     pretty quiet recently, but _nobody_ has ever surpassed them for
	     that early '91 stadium techno sound. Mean, low, and nasty
	     tunes, totally lo-fi recording, and for the most part
	     minimalistic, ravey sounds.  Some of it is just _brutal_, too
	     (like most of the stuff on Super Special). Hard to find music
	     on this coast, but almost always worth the effort.
	o Out Of Orbit.
	     This ACV sublabel puts out consistently great hardcore,
	     generally with completely bizarre rhythms and incredibly deep
	     bass. The two records on this label that I've been able to find
	     both totally _stomp_.
	o Communique / Analog / Drop Bass Network.
	     The Midwest Hardcorps. Some fast, some slow, some hard, some
	     soft. It's all straight-up acid of one stripe or another,
	     though. I have an old doublepack of Woody McBride's on right
	     now, and it's beautiful music, the sort of music I always hope
	     somebody will throw on the decks at 3 in the morning. If you
	     want to hear what extremes the 303 can be torqued into
	     emitting, here's your chance. Even the slower stuff is pretty
	     damn good. Of course, the odds of any of this material being
	     available on CD is infinitesimal. The people that run these
	     labels barely have enough money to put out 12"s.
	o Generator
	     Since Detroit is synonymous with techno, it makes sense that
	     there would be at least _one_ straight-up hardcore label out of
	     there, and Generator is it. Run by the friendly, sincere, and
	     more than a little bit wicked Alan Oldham (DJT1000@aol.com),
	     Generator puts out some of the most amazingly brick-hard stuff
	     I've ever heard coming out of the states. Most of it defies
	     easy categorization, too.
	o World Power Authority / Underground Resistance
	     If I'm going to talk about Detroit, I have to mention UR. The
	     three World Power Authority singles (literally - each one is
	     one-sided, with the remaining side being used to tell a story,
	     which is engraved in the vinyl) are all underground classics.
	     Anyone that has been to any techno parties in the Bay Area has
	     almost certainly heard "The Seawolf," which is the biggest hit
	     of the bunch with its loads of acid and submarine klaxons. The
	     old UR is classic hardcore, too, although to my ears it sounds
	     somewhat dated now. A good UR CD is the classic _Revolution For
	     Change_, which wanders in and out of print. It's been put out
	     on at least three different labels that I know of, and every so
	     often somebody runs off anothr batch.
	o Synewave NY
	     Damon Wild is a New York acid legend. He's put out more classic
	     hard acid tracks than any other American, period. And this is
	     his label. While he, like almost all of the old-school hardcore
	     folks, has mellowed considerably over the past two or three
	     years, his label still cranks out some great, hard tunes.
	o Reload
	     These guys are the flag-bearers for harder Belgian techno. I
	     particularly recommend Accelerator, volumes 1 and
	     2. Reminiscent of the best old-school Jeff Mills stuff, back
	     when he was a hardcore artist. Dubby, spacy, deep and
	     hard. Reload has a compilation out which pretty fairly
	     represents what it's up to.
	o Disko B / Cheap
	     The most famous artists on this label are DJ Hell and Patrick
	     Pulsinger. DJ Hell is a chimera; no two tracks of his sound the
	     same, and he's been known to be just a tad bit derivative in
	     the past. But when he does things right, he can put together
	     stunning work. Among the classics he's recorded are "Sprung Aus
	     Den Wolken" and "Allerseelen," the latter of which got remixed
	     into a delirious, high-speed nightmare by Jeff Mills.  Patrick
	     Pulsinger is something else entirely. He's really into rubbery,
	     lo-fi acid. It sounds like nothing else, and it's quite often
	     not very hard. It's not very accessible, though.  He's
	     definitely into his own thing.
and last, but certainly not least:
	o Sabrettes
	     A lot of people assume that since this label is a sublabel of
	     Sabres of Paradise (or the family of labels that used to be
	     known as Sabres of Paradise) that the music is similarly
	     friendly and relaxed. Ha ha! Not even close. Totally wicked,
	     banging techno. From the slow crunch of Chelsea Grin's "Animal
	     Factory" through the straight-up speediness of the Turbulent
	     Force EP, these people have all of the hardcore bases
	     covered. Easily my favorite label in the whole wide
	     world. Especially because they put out a lot more than just
	     hardcore: everybody should run out and buy Innersphere's _Outer
	     Works_. The _Pink Me Up_ compilation is worth a listen as well,
	     although it doesn't sound like much of the stuff that Sabrettes
	     has been putting out recently.

Something else worth keeping in mind is that it's getting increasingly hard
to differentiate between hard house and hard techno. Recent releases by
Robert Armani, Mike Dearborn, and DJ Skull completely blur the
line. Hardness is more a state of mind than anything quantifiable, and
although most of the really hard house that I like never strays above 130
BPM, it can be almost unlistenably hard.

Also, because Derek hasn't emphasized it enough, I thought I'd point out
that he runs a really high-quality mail order record service. I would
also say that Derek is one of the few people on this planet that I would
just send money to and say, "Hey, man, send me some good stuff." He's got
impeccable taste in techno (he should -- you should see his bedroom). Drop
him a line (moses@teleport.com) if you ever get frustrated with trying to
find stuff in the Bay Area.

Finally, I think I should also point out that it really doesn't matter
whether the music is hard or soft, fast or slow, grim or happy. This is more
a preemptive strike than a response to anything anybody's said, because it
seems like anytime the techno / house thread comes up, people start to
arguing. Any halfway rational DJ is going to have records that scatter all
over the spectrum, and any healthy raver kid is going to sometimes be in the
mood for harder stuff and sometimes want the warm fuzzy beats that San
Francisco is most famous for. I should know -- I managed to completely burn
myself out on house a couple years ago, but there are still times when I
really crave Wicked's sounds.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Oct 19 20:52:40 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id UAA14519; Thu, 19 Oct 1995 20:52:40 -0700

October 19 1995

Announcing the release of RevoLucid for the SGI!

This message is going out to everyone who sent e-mail to me, requesting more
  information on RevoLucid, the MIDI software which does weird things.

It is now ready, and is scheduled to start shipment October 31.
   (trick or treat...)

The initial delivery of software will be over the internet. You can download
  the software from my ftp site (upon registration and payment) and you will
    also receive a licence key, which can be used to activate RevoLucid. All
      delivery will be handled via the internet.  If you want to arrange for
        a DAT or floppy or 1/4" tape delivery, there will be an extra charge
          for the media used.

Please check the Fractallonomy Homepage at http://hyperreal.com/~scruton for
  any news or updates.  All customers are eligible for all the free tools on
    the page, (heck, anyone can download them) and are also entitled to four
      upgrades for each licence.  The licence is available for USD $200. You
        can get more info by e-mail at scruton@delphi.com  

For ordering, please send a check to:

  Fractallonomy
    512 Avenue G #308
      Redondo Beach, CA 90277 USA
        310.540.5702 

PLEASE write your e-mail address on your check!!!

You can receive RevoLucid in one of three ways 

  1: Direct Internet shipment via uuencoded e-mail
  2: Internet ftp access with the licence key delivered via uuencoded e-mail
  3: US or International mail shipment on DAT, floppy, or other tape.

Limited Demo Licences are also available...

Thanks again for all the interest!

Dave Scruton --- October 19 1995

Subject: To The People Who Care/Update
In-Reply-To: <Pine.SOL.3.91.951019162914.13429B-100000@orion>

Dear All;

	First, I would like to thank all the people who sent the 
wonderful posts of support & love, the helped me through 6 of the most 
awful days of my life. You truely know what it is to see that light that 
shine's from within you, cause you saw it in me. :)

	Well, after a long 2 - 3 days at Alta Bates Hospital, while during
almost constant interviews, testing & evaluation, by NON-intern,
experienced Doctors, an my on-going health care professional (Love ya Dr.
B); which unfortuately, & unpredictablily included an unprovoked attack &
beating; from another patient; in a manic & psychotic state, while asleep
in my hospital room, the diagnose given to me by the IDIOT ER Doctor was
labeled as a misdiagnose, due to insurance purposes(needing a diagnose in
order to bill) :*, lack of a complete history, and my on-going health care
professionals unavailability for consultation. 

	Leaving me with my original diagnose of someone recovering from a
horrific childhood. I'm told that formerly abused children, as adults, are
often misdiagnosed, with everything from, bi-polar disorder,
schizophrenia, chemical depression, paranoia, to the very general border-line
personality disorder, ...etc;  especially when symtomology is looked at
under a virtual microscope, like it is in a hospital emergency room.
 
NOTE; That certain recreactional drugs can contribute, exacerbate, & even
create conditions/symtomology not previously displayed, that can lead to a
misdiagnose. Methaphedamine/Speed/Crank/Quick/Crystal...etc being the
leader in this catogory. This is one drug that I cannot afford to use
anymore, though I still respect THE RIGHT OF OTHERS TO EXPERIMENT WITH IT. 

	So on the positive side, I learned a lot about myself, who my real
friends are, and a lot about the state of medical knowledge/symptomlogy
relating to childhood abuse. It's a shame how little we know still about
the long term affects of childhood abuse, and the fact that the cycle
continues into adulthood due to ignorance & unawareness in our selfs, our 
communities & our medical communities. 

	On the negative side, my celabration over the liberation of that
awful diagnose & those 6 days will have to be postponed until next week,
due to the physical injuries received from the attack at the hospital. I
don't hold any anger or wishful revenge for the person who attacked me, he
clearly was not himself, and I've seen the difference that medication can
make in people suffering from bi-polar disorder. 

	I remember saying that "We All Shine," and even he deserves a lot
of PLUR as do we all.  Who knows, if there was more PLUR in all our lives,
I KNOW that there would be a lot less abuse & mental illness in our world
& our lives.  An as much as it hurt me personally, even the people who I
thought were my friends, who ran from me at a time when I needed them the
most, deserve it as well, so that they can eventually love themselves, 
and at least I know now who I can count on when the real storm comes. 

	But getting back to my personal celabration/victory/vidication, I
guess it will have to be at Friend's & Family, funny how thing's work out
huh = >. Thanks for your love, support, unconditional caring, & wonderful 
hugs, that incredibly stubborn, person sometimes I feel doesn't deserve 
it. But thanks, just the same anyway = > purrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrr

> Brian Darkness shared on Mon, 16 Oct 1995;

> > Dear Kati & All;
> > 
> > 	Friday I was diagnosed with a disease so awful, that it almost 
> > shattered me. It was by a doctor in an Emergency Room who had little if 
> > no previous knowledge/data on me, indictaing that it was some, if not a high 
> > probability of being incorrect. But I assure all of you, that one day of 
> > my childhood, still does not even come close to the pain I experienced 
> > from the words in humanly printed on the discharge I/O the nurse handed me, 
> > and that I'm still as strong as I've ever been.
> > 
> > 	However, if correct, I WILL NOT let my mind, and the person I've
> > come to love(myself) crumble, from a person who helped design some of the 
> > most awesome firepower our country has ever seen, some of the most
> > environmentally sensative mass transist systems the world has seen, as
> > well as what I told is some of the most loving, & respectful touch
> > therapy(massage) my clients tell me I have provided them, into someone
> > pushing around a shopping cart on the streets of San Francisco. 
> > 
> > 	I have traveled to long & hard in this life to allow this to
> > strike me down at what I believe are my best years. I'm actively pursuing
> > a much more acturate, and intensive evaluation of my being, through
> > multiple independent sources, to assure accuracy, thank god I'm still a
> > Test Engineer. Cause out of all the sciences, and in my opinion, medince is 
> > the least accurate, clueless, still in the dark ages, and they haven't 
> > met Brian Darkness head on yet.
> > 
> > 	However I hold as part of my truth the words I think Def Lepoard

> > to violate the list's purpose please send me your e-mail addresses, if

> > still see me at events, & hugs will be appreiated.

Okay, I know it's twice in one week but I might be able to make it worth
someone's worthwile. The standard data:

Space Funk
Oct 20, 10-early

alsos Samo & More

18+
Info: 510-433-9770

This is mostly the trip-hop guys from Your Momma's House.

I have it on good word that the More is another room of faster music put on
by Yours Truly (Chesapeake), Rob Doten, Stephanie (Santa Cruz), and Spesh,
plus two more blokes from Santa Cruz.

In any event, it should be a quixotic blend of basic house, tweakin acid,
jungle (supposedly Stephanie is spot on here), and the San Frandisco sound.
Presuming I don't get bumped, I'm really itching to throw on some Steve
Stoll, Tata Box Inhibitors, and a few Relief Records tracks.

AND, I have two complementary admits to burn. So give me your best sob
story and I'll see what I can do. Contest closes 5:00 pm Friday.

Latez.

Subject: Re[2]: musings on music
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

At 12:49 PM 10/19/95, laural@inmark.com wrote:
>
>
>Arther Chandler writes:

>>But maybe I'm just listening to the wrong discs and djs. Can anyone
>>suggest recordings that have the kind of complex harmonic progressions
>>I'm longing for?
>
>It might not be readily present in the form.  Techno primarily exists
>as dance music, designed to cause body movement and emit a certain
>emotional response (which, as near as I can define, is a drive to dance
>more :-) :-) ).  A sub-species of techno/ambient calls itself
>"Intelligent Dance Music" and claims to be more musical and artistic
>than the basic "thump-make-you-dance" track.
        Hmm this is interesting.  This got me thinking about 'IDM' and as
to whether it's "intelligence" came from harmonics or not.  A lot of things
i find interesting in this genre do have amazingly complex harmonies and
(at best) amazingly complex rhythmns.  Autechre (for me) is a prime
example.  They have it goin' on ALL OVER. Their use of low and high
frequencies, their harmonics, their use of rhthmn, really mindblowing.  BUT
you'd never hear it at a a club (though i have heard things in ambient
rooms a couple times and i was fortunate enought to see them live almost
two years ago).  Another example of harmonics and rhythmns that are pretty
complex is the Irresistible Force (mixmaster morris).  Using samples
primarily and layering like crazy then peeling back the layers, at some
point in his work you can count at tons of different rythmns and harmonics
that are beyond the boom-tsk house stuff.  A lot more "mental" music i
suppose might be an definition of intelligent music.  I've been told i
listen to mental music but at the same time nothing beats (no pun intended)
moving the body that houses (oops, another pun) the mind and soul :)
        Along this point, i would also say that a lot of Goa Trance is
heavily based in harmonics, rather than other types of more percussive
trance.  I find that some of the melodies can be a bit cheesy, a bit to
'anthemic' like "OH MY GOD I'M RUSHING SO HARD" type of melodies.  I guess
i'm into subtlety ;) But otherwise, i think goa stuff is a pretty good
mixture of complexity and dancebility.
        Anyways, it's all good, whatever turns you on :)

        brad
