 ectographics: print design : HTML programming : hugs and smooches
    >> ecto@citenet.net >> ecto@magnet.ca >> http://www.magnet.ca/ecto >>
========================\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/======================

less.

about the dc, baltimore and philadelphia rave world, so i was unable to read
any of your responces. if you wouldn't mind, would you please send me your
responces again? gallons of gratitude gushingly...

connected to the dc, blat and philthy rave world. i'm going there for two
weeks, starting on the 25th. i want, above all, to find a lovely halloween
rave. if the rave had an emphasis on perpertually pagan pantheistic
perpendicular paradoxes, all the better. but really, i just want to see how
they funk it up in the exotic east.

On Thu, 19 Oct 1995, laural@inmark.com wrote:

> Arther Chandler writes:
> ______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
>   
> >But I've been disappointed at the harmonic simplicity of all branches of
> >techno over the years. I'm fed up with the old familiar chord
> >progressions that betray either a lack of composing skill or a
> >too-easily-satisfied ear.
> 
> The harmonic simplicity has its good points and its bad points.  The good 
> points are that you can get a really good crowd reaction with something 
> that follows a particular pattern, for example anything by Hardfloor with 
> their big cheezy acid break/build two-thirds of the way through every 
> track they write.  I've seen the screaming and whooping and cheering 
> during the build up, and then the frenzied dancing when the beats come 
> back.  It works.

KMEL & MTV also "work"
> 
> >If the composers of techno would pay attention to jazz and classical
> >music, maybe they could learn how to weave melodies into the higher 
> >harmonies of sophisticated chord progressions.
>   
> >But maybe I'm just listening to the wrong discs and djs. Can anyone 
> >suggest recordings that have the kind of complex harmonic progressions 
> >I'm longing for?

I think Detroit techno comes the closest to this while still remaining
danceable. It certainly isn't free jazz, but they tend to use the scale
for expressive purposes instead of using it to sell alot of records. 

Some Detroit labels to look out for are...
+8, Transmat, Red Planet, UR & Metroplex. I'm not sure how easy it is to
get stuff on CD's though.

-josh

Hi,

After skimming SFRaves for a few weeks now I thought I'd take a moment to
say hello. My name is Matthew Laubach. I've been going to Bay Area raves
occasionally from 1991 until last spring and much more often since then.
I've probably met some of you without knowing it. I've attended many Sunsets
and a couple of Full Moons as well as many indoor parties whose names tend
to slip my mind. 

I've really been enjoying alternative culture related resources on the net,
including this list. It is amazing to see how naturally high technology and
alternative culture complement one another. I am very optimistic about the
chances that the near future will hold dramatic, positive social changes
made possible through the revolution in global communication which we are
taking part in.

Tonight is the opening night for the Ambient Cafe, which some friends of
mine will be running. It's at 400 Haight St., 415-621-1781. Live music will
be provided by Olive and special guest WEYOUME, and there will be a spun
ambient mix with Mike and Joe. The Ambient Cafe will offer afterparties,
starting before dawn and offering smoothies, sounds, and tranquility.
Tonight the cafe will be open from 6:00 pm until whenever. I'll probably be
by before midnight. 

I look forward to getting to know you, both online and in person!

Matthew

My computer tells me that on Wed, 18 Oct 1995, John S. Lee shared:

> And just as important is WHO becomes Mayor, and WHO becomes DA.
> 
> I am split on Jordan/Brown, both hold some postivie elemts that I like.  As
> for DA, ahnds down, it's Terence Hallinan.
> 
> T. Hallinan would like to do the following:
> 
> -Decriminalize drugs in SF.  Most notably Marijuana. (CHECK!)
> -Decriminalize prostitution in SF, create a red-light district. (CHECK!)
> -Stop Matrix and prosectuion of the homeless on misdemeanor charges.
> (reluctant CHECK), I like the concept of Matrix, and I like the result
> (pushing the homeless out of SF into neighboring counties have made
> everyone aware of the plight of the homeless.  It is now a Bay Area
> problem, not just SF), but it is questionable constituionally IMHO.
> -Reign in the cops. (CHECK!)

I second John's recommendation for Terrence Hallinan for district 
attorney.  As compared to the other two candidates, Hallinan has a long 
record of protecting civil liberties, and if elected would focus on 
prosecuting violent criminals, not persons committing nonviolent "crimes" 
that shouldn't even be against the law.
	
I also feel that Terrence has a lot of integrity compared to most 
politicians.  He spoke to the San Francisco Libertarian Party last month 
and was very forthright.  When he disagreed with us, he didn't attempt to 
deceive us or say what he thought we wanted to hear to get our votes, but 
honestly and politely explained his views. 

> As for Jordan/Brown?  I dunno, Achtenberg is out IMHO.  I am suspicious of
> her reluctance in adressing minorities issues, esp. AIDS in the minority
> community. I also think she's too pro gay for my tastes, and SF is more
> than just a gay mecca.  Other people live here too!
> 
> Brown I like, but let's face it, he's a backroom dealer.  Despite that, he
> is the one who could get the supes to move on issues.  With Jordan, the
> Mayor's office and the Supervisors are at a constant stalemate.
> 
> Jordan I like as well.  SF has become a bit safer under his watch.  But
> he's too much of a micro manager, and as such is ineffective with the
> biggger picture issues.  I also think that there has been too much emphasis
> on police in SF, and not enough on job creation/retention in the city.
> 
> All are beholden to somebody.
> 
> For the most ultra liberal ticket, I choose Brown/Hallinan.( Some might say
> Achtenberg/Hallinan)
> For the a moderate ticket, Jordan/Hallinan.
> Status quo Jordan/Smith <- Mr. Thumbs Up. (this is NOT an option IMHO!)
> 
> Ben Hom?  Forget it, all he talks about is business.  And there's more to
> SF than that as well.

Here I must disagree.  Ben Hom is the best candidate in the mayor's 
race.  He is a businessman -- maybe this is why he understands how the heavy 
hand of government can adversely affect people.  Hom is the only 
candidate talking about reducing taxes and privatizing city services.  
Achtenberg talks a nice game about making San Francisco government more 
efficient, but Hom walks the walk.  The "privatization study" put forward 
by Mayor Jordan (Prop. K) is a sham which will not encourage real 
privatization -- don't vote for it.

I know this isn't directly rave-related, but who's in charge will 
definitely affect us one way or another.  Thanks to Lee Fogel for 
bringing it up.  John is also right for saying if we mobilize, they will 
not be able to ignore us.  Power in numbers.  My general rule when voting 
is this: Yes on any proposition or candidate that empowers people by 
reducing the size or scope of government; no to any proposition or 
candidate that promises to take power away from people or increase the 
government leviathan.

				*** Starchild ***

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

I'm posting this request on behalf of a fellow artist who's looking for 
people with art and expertise who'd like to contribute to the creation of 
a sensory art exhibit, planned to happen this December. I've included his 
description of it below.

The visionary behind this work, Mark Jackman <mark.jackman@etak.com>, is
especially interested in finding people with expertise in audio and visual
displays. So it was a natural that I thought of all the bounty of
creativity among all the folks who are part of the sfraves community. 

Drop him a line if you simply have some art to contribute, or could 
assist with the design and setup of a visual and auditory experience. 

Also, if you know of possible spaces to place the installation, any leads 
would be much appreciated.

James (EyeQ): MinInfo, ConSynPro
www.sanctuary.com/haven/consynpro

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Sat, 30 Sep 1995 16:32:11 -0500
From:jenbose@tiac.net
To: The Art & Technology Society <art-tech@nocturne.sbay.org>
Subject: FUSION 4/5


EXHIBITIONS AND COMPETITIONS


SENSOPHRENIA
CALL FOR ENTRIES

This exhibit can be described in many ways. It's a multimedia sensory
extravaganza, what the inside of your
brain would be like if they had designed your DNA. It's what it would be
like to listen to every radio station and watch every television broadcast
at once. It's an assault on your sensory cortex, a new experience in background
acclimation. It might be pretty insane.

Really it's a room filled with a seemingly haphazard array of video
monitors, speakers, old TV sets, lights, etc. designed under
computer-control to present a fast-cutting audio-video (and possibly
other-sensory as well) montage with two basic principles in mind: First, no
particular image/sound/etc. remains for very long, so that the viewer is
unable to settle in and truly focus on anything coherently to the exclusion
of the remaining cacophony. Second, despite this lack of focusibility, the
design is intentionally made to constantly draw at the viewers'
attention/focus, demanding it first in one way, then another and another.

For example, a plethora of seemingly disconnected images (the Apollo moon
landing, time-lapse flowers blooming, OJ, the Love Boat, cucumbers being
sliced, a live shot from cameras in the room of those currently
viewing,...) is being presented on the various monitors and rapidly
cross-cutting when suddenly four or eight monitors all come into sync with
the same image, or different parts of the same image. Then another
monitor's image and the dominant sound both turn into static. Then an image
begins to propagate from monitor to monitor across the room, demanding that
the viewer pay attention to it, until that demand is eclipsed by another
more urgent, etc., etc.

Some people might manage to mentally withdraw from this sort of barrage,
but the design is intended to prevent that (though of course they can
always just leave). Instead, viewers must give up their desire to focus on
a static/consistent image or presentation and allow the flow of information
to wash over them en masse. As good as the human brain is at acclimating to
sensory input, this multi-sensory experience is an extremely interesting
one to allow to be your "background" level.

I'm looking for interested participants--physical location not
important--to contribute towards an exhibition of Sensophrenia! in several
months (December '95). Video and audio source material is needed, both
newly-generated as well as collection from archival sources. Simply contact
me if you'd be interested in contributing to the pool of material and/or
involving yourself more deeply with the project. If this idea really turns
you on, those interested in contributing to the editing, design of the A/V
computer-control system, administrative, publicity, or any other aspects of
the project that appeal to you are more than welcome.

Mark Jackman
markj@etak.com
(415) 328-1813

From: STAR CHILD <star@sfsu.edu>

To: "Atherton, Darren" <datherton@ea.com>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Leisure & Contemporary Society
In-Reply-To: <30868009@pcsmtp.ea.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.91.951022025752.27709C-100000@orion>

Dear Darren,

My computer tells me that on Thu, 19 Oct 1995, you shared,

> Hay- I have been called a man of leisure many of times in my day and really 
> enjoy nothing more then to lie back on the grass with head phones on and day 
> dream the world away- So I am really curious about this class your in Leisure 
> & Contemporary Society.  What's it all about? 

	This class is part of the Recreation-Leisure Studies Department at SF 
State.  The course catalog describes it as follows:

A critical behavioral and social analysis of the impact of contemporary 
and future leisure trends related to technology, aging, time deepening, 
activity patterns, resources, etc. and their implications for human 
health, happiness, and quality of life.

	What we actually do and discuss in class isn't always quite so 
ambitious as the above may sound, but some of it is quite interesting.  
The "bias" of the course seems to be that our society is dominated by a 
work ethic; that the pace of life is speeding up; that people have less 
true leisure time than they once did; that this is largely due to the 
complex, mechanical nature of our society; that this trend is 
accelerating; and that this is not a good thing.  It is a message that I 
largely agree with, even though I am a firm believer in science and 
technology and their ability to make the world a better place.
	We've been given a lot of information that I think ravers could 
relate to in a positive way.  One recent film we saw called "Humor - The 
Key To Success" described a very interesting experiment...
	...The woman giving the presentation asked for two volunteers 
from the audience.  Two guys came up, and she gave one of them a 
Super-Soaker water gun.  Then she showed the audience a magic marker, and 
told them that when she started the clock, the one guy would have 30 
seconds to get the marker from her.  If he didn't have it by that time, 
the other guy would squirt him with the water gun.
	When they started, the guy tried several different ways of 
getting the marker.  First he asked her to hand it to him -- she 
pretended she didn't know what he was talking about.  Then he tried to 
trick her into putting it down, then he tried to snatch it, all to no 
avail.  He got squirted when his time was up.
	The presenter had asked people meanwhile to be thinking about how 
they would get the marker.  When the exercise was over, she told the 
audience that how they would have attempted to get the marker was the way 
they tended to deal with people in relationships.  The key, she said, was 
honesty.  In her experiment, no one ever came up on stage and just said 
to her, "Hey, I don't want to get wet.  If you don't give me that marker 
in thirty seconds, this guy's going to soak me."  Most people choose 
subterfuge, manipulation, or force.  Kind of depressing, but definitely 
food for thought.  They say that awareness of a problem is the first step 
toward finding a solution.

	Then there's this gem, reprinted on the back of our class 
reader.  I don't know its origin, maybe someone on sfraves does, but I 
rank it right up there with the Desiderata in terms of life wisdom...

##############################################################################
			HOW TO BE AN ARTIST

	stay loose. learn to watch snails. plant impossible gardens.
	invite someone dangerous to tea. make little signs that say
	yes! and post them all over your house. make friends with 
	freedom & uncertainty. look forward to dreams. cry during 
	movies. swing as high as you can on a swingset, by moonlight.
	cultivate moods. refuse to "be responsible." do it for love.
	take lots of naps. give money away. do it now. the money 
	will follow. believe in magic. laugh a lot. celebrate every
	gorgeous moment. take moonbaths. have wild imaginings, 
	transformative dreams, and perfect calm. draw on the walls.
	read everyday. imagine yourself magic. giggle with children.
	listen to old people. open up. dive in. be free. bless 
	yourself. drive away fear. play with everything. entertain
	your inner child. you are innocent. build a fort with 
	blankets. get wet. hug trees. write love letters.

##############################################################################

> I believe in making the world safe for our children, but not our
> children's children, because I don't think children should be having sex.

lol! Depends what you mean by a child though... Romeo & Juliet were 13 
y'know. ;)

				*** Starchild ***

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Oct 23 22:59:35 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id WAA04848; Mon, 23 Oct 1995 22:59:35 -0700
Received: from gw.steam.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id WAA04802; Mon, 23 Oct 1995 22:59:26 -0700
Received: from uclink2.berkeley.edu (uclink2.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.136.72]) by gw.steam.com (8.6.10/8.6.9) with ESMTP id MAA22180 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Mon, 23 Oct 1995 12:09:51 -0700

	id MAA05470; Mon, 23 Oct 1995 12:15:01 -0700
Date: Mon, 23 Oct 1995 12:15:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: Kyung Rok <krok@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Chemical Brothers
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9510231200.A872-0100000@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Checked out the Chemical Bros. last night at the Troc.  Solid party.  
Lotsa faces, new and old, turned out for this one.  Jeno and Garth 
started things out.  Garth played a Chemical Bros. remix of "Tow Truck"
as a harbinger of things to come.  And then to the main event...
They were good, very good.  But great?  Well, that might depend on 
how familiar you are with "Exit Planet Dust".  Personally, I've owned 
this cd for a couple of months, so I had mixed feelings about hearing 
4 or 5 tracks that I've almost come close to burying into the ground.
Yet, it was still good to hear these "oldies-but-goodies" =) (a couple 
of nice remixes).  A couple of small train wrecks... well, maybe more like 
minor derailments -- but, hey, they're only human.  After their 45-minute 
set (yes, 45 minutes) about half of the jam-packed dancefloor filtered out,
leaving folks more room to dance as Jeno and Garth came back on for some
tag team (The New British Bulldogs? =).  100% drop-off in "eweh-eweh" 
(sorry, pet pieve).  Many thought that the Chemical Bros. were 
"incredible".  If I hadn't heard their cd already, i might have agreed.  
No "Life is Sweet" for the alt-rock crowd.  Just some good and dirty 
"trance"-"funk"-"triphop"-"breakbeat"-"techno"-"etc" "=)".       

-Rok         

ps. the upstairs chill room was really nice.

Bahia is at 1600 Market @ Franklin.  It only costs $1.00 before 11 and 3$

dear sirs and madams,

this is shalom writing a hasty pre-work note to share my wish with all of you
that each of you lives the life you wish to live at this exact instant. 

here's where this wish comes from: i've decided that i can no longer delay my
life. i'm forgetting the word tomorrow and diminishing the overblown
importance of Yesterday. it's simple, yes, it's even cliched, and it's true:
now is the only time i've got. 

on the cosmic timetable, we hardly even register on the screen. we're
supermini-blips that are over even before they've begun. and at the same
time, each of us contains the entire cosmos within our breasts. [yes, men
have breasts (private argument, unrelated).]

so why am i writing? because these thoughts are too Uuumph to keep all
inside, all to little me. 

i'm leaving for the east coast early early wednesday for two weeks. i'm going
to try to find a halloween rave out there. a few of you have helped me find
connections that will make this possible. to each of you who helped, great
thanks.   

            wisdom tells me i am nothing.
            love tells me i am everything.
            and between these two my life flows. 
                    - swami iforgetwho

be beautiful, as you already are. 
shalom

No, I am not scalping tickets. :)

The F&F tickets dispersed very quickly.  Many of them in large chunks.  I
estimate that people will have surplus tickets without anyone to give them
to.

Obviously, there are people who want to go.

I volunteer my services to hook the ravers with tickets with the ravers
that do not.

If you have extra tickets or think you might have extra tickets (you don't
know yet because your friends Rex and Melinda haven't called back yet) send
me email or give me a call.  Include a phone number or pager I can reach
you with and give me an estimate of how many (a range is fine) you might
have.  I'll call you (probably on Saturday) to see if you have extras that
need placing and make arrangements for the exchange.  Note that I will only
broker tickets at or below face value ($5).  Also, if you happen to find on
10pm on a Sat night that you have an extra ticket, definitely call me or if
you're at F&F, just find me.

If you need tickets, email or call me.  Tell me how many you want, and how
I should contact you on Saturday.  Since tickets could turn up during the
party, be sure to let me know if you want to be contacted after 10pm.  

How will I distribute them?  I will make a list on Friday night of the
people who want tickets.  I will sort it randomly.  I will give them out in
pairs (unless you only need one).  I will break up orders of more than 2
into multiple entries (if you want 10, your name will appear 5 times, in
random order).  On Sat. I will call/email everyone on the list letting them
know what order they are on the list and if I have tickets for them.  If I
can't make contact by 8pm, that person drops to the end of the list, and
I'll start calling the next person in line.  I suspect after 8pm things
will get hectic.  Since everyone will know what their order on the list is,
you'll know how much hope you have for tickets.  If you do get tickets
through me, we'll make arrangements for transfer as I may not have gotten
the tickets from the seller.  

I hope everyone thinks this is a fair way of doing it and those of you with
extra tickets see fit to place them with me.  If you want to give your
tickets away for free, let me know and I'll pass the free ones on based on
ability to pay.  If, through some mistake of my own, I end up with more
money than when I started, I'll give the extra to Komotion.  I'll eat the
losses too.

How to contact me:

	Purple Tiger aka Grant Blaha
	email: ptiger@sophistem.com
	pager/voicemail: 415/406-2109

I'll be packing a cell phone all week, so if you page I can call you back
immediately, or if you page me with a pager number, I can page you back to
the cell phone.

Finally, this could be a lot of work for me to do.  If anyone wants to
help, please don't be shy.  Also, please keep this to the list.  I don't
want my voicemail number ending up on some info line somewhere.

I'll see you all at F&F, I'll be the guy that glows purple in the dark.

PT
---
Purple Tiger
ptiger@sophistem.com

	- Sunset Boat Party

     Chemical Brothers...
     
     God the Troc is hot.  I had to imagine I was in a sauna sweating out 
     the butterscotch chip cookies I had binged on to deal with it.
     
     I was happy to hear the wall of noise swooping square wave sound of 
     the Chemical Brothers after an hour of melody and piano riffs.  Big 
     bass is the way to go:  I never really appreciated the Orb until I 
     heard them live on their HUGE sound system, and ditto for the Chemical 
     Brothers.  
     
     Imagine this:  The Chemical Brothers vs. Meat Beat Manifesto, live on 
     stage, playing back and forth off of each other's music.  Now that 
     would be something to see.
     
     MaD...
     
     Okay, so I haven't gone out much this year at all, but it was the best 
     party I've been to all year.  Joe Rice got really crunchy toward the 
     end of his set, with stripped down stuff that had a reverberating edge 
     and sounded pleasantly harsh and mechanical.  You may think this is a 
     contradiction in terms, but there's only so much lushness I can take.  
     The pure electonic feel of his and Sho's sets were exceedingly 
     refreshing.  
     
     Sho carried on Joe's mood, and gave us a tour of some Detriot-style 
     classics, including the definitive "Energy Flash."  It still sounds 
     good after all these years!  Sho also got technical on his mixes, 
     doing some cuts and transforms that added extra interest to the set.  
     It's really cool to hear two tracks you know and be able to appreciate 
     that the DJ is playing around with them.
     
     I'm sorry I missed Jon, but it was past my bedtime :-)  But thanks for 
     the party Jon, Joe, Sho, Alex, Ethan, and Nantsee.
     
     Random thoughts...
     
     I have found a mecca for the Junglists out there:  if you haven't 
     discovered Primal records in Berkeley yet, check them out.  They are 
     quite the Jungle crew and will talk the talk, find you killer records, 
     and point you to parties and the like.  So the next time you sigh that 
     there's not any jungle in the Bay Area, talk to them and they'll help 
     you find it.  
     
     I also really appreciate that they have THREE turntables with 
     headphones on which you can preview records, and that the staff 
     doesn't bother you or give you a hard time about using them.  No 
     signing out the headshell or applying for a special DJ card that lets 
     you preview things if the management feels like it.  For example, 
     Rasputnin's has a great selection, but it really sucks that it's so 
     difficult to get permission to actually hear anything.  
     
     Does anyone know what day Primal gets its shipments?  The selection 
     seemed REALLY picked over when I was there on Sunday.
     
     Laura

  I'm going to add my thoughts to laural's perceptive comments:
  I realize that dance music has to have an emphatic, or at least 
"moving" beat. But I've been disappointed at the harmonic simplicity of 
all branches of techno over the years. I'm fed up with the old familiar 
chord progressions that betray either a lack of composing skill or a 
too-easily-satisfied ear. If the composers of techno would pay attention 
to jazz and classical music, maybe they could learn how to weave melodies 
into the higher harmonies of sophisticated chord progressions.
  But maybe I'm just listening to the wrong discs and djs. Can anyone 
suggest recordings that have the kind of complex harmonic progressions 
I'm longing for?

In repsone to those who have asked me what DIY culture is, I am attaching
a little ditty I found out on the web... I think it gives you a decent
idea of what is going on and through that, you get a good picture of what
DIY is about. The following is from:
http://www.cityscape.co.uk/users/bt22/party.html

so if you have a web browser handy, it will look a little nicer if you run
over there...

anyway, the text should follow...

dave

---------------------------------4572978502042302518662472
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1

DIY culture, Justice? and Exodus

Free parties

An obvious progression from Acid House parties was to link up with the
mobile sound systems of the free festival circuit that has toured Britain
since the sixties. The summer of 1992 was the honeymoon period for the
marriage of ravers and travellers. The culmination of these festi-raves was
an event held at Castlemorton at the end of May. Estimates of the numbers
present vary from 25,000 to 40,000; for many there it was the ultimate
party. The media depiction, however, was of a marauding invasion and the
public outrage sowed the seeds of the Criminal Justice Act 1994.

The tightening up of legislation aimed at stopping illegal parties has had
three results. The first is that the new laws have successfully forced some
people back into licensed events and nightclubs. The Government's action is
justified as protecting people by only allowing them to dance in venues that
comply with safety regulations, although in practice it is in the licensed
venues where people die.

There has been a death here in Bedfordshire, says Glenn Jenkins of Exodus.
Not at one of our 72 harmless dances, but in a club. It's one of those clubs
that is supposed to hold 500 but they pack in 1000. A guy collapsed in there
and he got barred  people monging out are bad business. His mates had to
take him to hospital in their car but got lost on the way. He died, but he
hadn't taken Ecstasy, he'd had two wraps of speed.

They're saying E's killing people at raves - 'the dance of death'. I'm
saying if it's E that kills then there'd be millions of people dead. It's
the heat and environmental conditions that kills people - you can't blame
Ecstasy. We have watched the harm creeping into the scene. I've stood on a
dance floor and sweated without even moving. You don't have to be a
scientist to know that's highly dangerous.

The second effect of the increase in legislation has been an emigration of
sound systems. After Castlemorton ten members of the Spiral Tribe sound
system were taken to court and charged with causing a public nuisance. The
trial in 1994; cost 4 million176 yet the defendants were freed through lack
of evidence, a local councillor admitted to me that because they had a high
media profile they had been made scapegoats. Spiral Tribe and other sound
systems have found a more cooperative response from foreign authorities. The
free party scene now encompasses many parts of the world from Goa to the San
Fransisco bay area.

The third effect became particularly noticeable with the passing of the
Criminal Justice Act. People have been so outraged by the draconian powers
to prevent parties that they appear to have become determined to create
bigger and better events. It has also seen the politicisation of the scene
with the Advance Party and United Systems voicing protests against the new
laws and forging links with other groups affected. Gail, who organises
illegal parties with the DIY collective Justice? in Brighton, describes how
the Act has affected them:

Because of the CJA we are even more determined to have better parties, so we
have to make them tightly organised. It's a lie that only licensed venues
are safe. We don't turn the water off, it's always cheap and freely
available. We make sure the venue is spacious, airy and well lit and that
there is a chill-out area. People are free to walk in and out if they want
to sit down, or take a breath of air. It may appear like it's disorganised
but we have our own form of stewarding, we have nurses attending, we have
fire extinguishers. We make sure that there are always people there who can
cope if anything bad happened. I think there will be more parties but I
don't know if it's a good idea to have them too large as it's not so easy to
keep an eye on what's happening. I think we probably do take advantage of
the E vibe that means people take care of each other.

DIY Culture

DIY (Do It Yourself) culture is experiencing a renaissance. Cosmo from
Justice? explained why:

In the eighties, a lot of people who were hacked off with the way we were
living, or were just plain bored, got off their arses and did something
about it. Free festivals, squat culture, the traveller movement and later
Acid House parties pay testament to the energy and vision of people who
decided it was now time to take their destinies into their own hands.

Now more and more people are getting exasperated with the way politicians
are out of touch, and their frustration turns to action when the people at
the top won't listen. This was especially true when the Criminal Justice Act
tried to criminalise the very lifestyles I have mentioned.

DIY culture was born when people got together and realised that the only way
forward was to do things for themselves. The term covers everything from
taking direct action against a road that is being bulldozed through your
area to campaigning for equal rights for the disabled. Ingenuity and
imagination are the key ingredients.

Justice? was born out of a desire to raise public awareness about the
Criminal Justice Act. One of their first high profile initiatives was to
squat a disused courthouse and turn it into a thriving community centre. The
squat was opened one Sunday night and by Monday a caf, information centre
and exhibition room were opened. Classes in Tai Chi, yoga and Shiatsu
happened regularly, there was space for artists to work, a crche, advice
for squatters, a visiting hairdresser, music evenings. Justice? were evicted
but have moved their community centre to another derelict building.

A sign in the courthouse summed up DIY philosophy:

1. This is going to be huge - realise it. Grow fins and swim

2. Listen to new people

3. Share responsibility

4. Nip egos and attitudes in the bud - no power struggle

5. Communications stop ructions - talk

6. If you are feeling stressed pass the job on and go!

7. Never laugh at fat bastards in clouds

A lot of money for renovating Justice?'s squatted courthouse was raised by
collections at parties. Gail explained the link:

The CJA is the main reason why theres a strong link between DIY and the
dance scene - theres lots of free parties and that's one obvious thing the
CJA attacks. DIY culture is about people getting annoyed with the system and
deciding to do it themselves, whether creating entertainment, food or
energy. You dont wait for these things to be provided.

DIY culture relies on people doing things without payment. We operate with a
different set of rules - most people put in work with the only reward being
the personal satisfaction of seeing other people having a good time. You
don't have to listen to rave music  we have poets, all sorts. People from
all walks of life all coming together, thats what it's about.

Desert Storm is another free party organisation based in Glasgow. As well as
putting on parties in Scotland, notably at the protest against the M77
extension through Pollok Park, they spent New Year taking their brand of
entertainment to war torn Bosnia. Desert Storm raised enough money to fund
their trip and a new lorry  their old one was painted in camouflage which
they were afraid might lead to problems!

Desert Storm and the Full On Dance Squad from Nottingham drove in the aid
convoy for 13 days arriving in Split in time to erect a makeshift nightclub
and host a Christmas party for refugees, UN soldiers and NGO workers. Unlike
Britain the Bosnian police insisted that Desert Storm turned the volume up
for their New Year party in Tuzla. They were amazed by their warm reception
from small children to elderly ladies in their dressing gowns crowding to
dance where it was sometimes too dangerous to walk.

Exodus

It seems strange that the Government is so opposed to what seems just 'a bit
of harmless fun'. Perhaps it is because such fun is "economically
unacceptable" as Jim Carey suggested in Squall, August 1994, or there may be
deeper reasons. In an interview with Sunscreem we discussed the significance
of their single 'Exodus': "It's saying come through the door - here we go.
Come along with us, or don't - it's about making a change." Glenn Jenkins of
Exodus agrees:

We called ourselves Exodus because what we were doing was knocking extortion
out of our lives. Exodus indicates a large number of people moving from one
lifestyle to another. Our inspiration came from Bob Marley who took his
inspiration from the Bible. It's all about freedom of thought. Emancipate
yourself from mental slavery - Bob Marley sings our anthems. He could see
that if we could hold down racial divisions and so on, then there would be
harmony. Harmony means heaven - heaven on earth is harmony on earth. We take
the Rastamen to be our forefathers, they played a large part in our
consciousness forming. Rastaman is a spiritual tag not just a black thing,
it's a soul issue, not a skin issue. Were the Rastamen that Bob Marley
inspired by coming here and making the album Exodus.

My first experience on MDMA was a really profound experience because
overnight it put machismo, ego, pride, good looks, good clothes all into
perspective. You get to realise the hollowness of all that and it rattles
you. It's dangerous for a society that draws its kids into materialism, it's
threatening. I think it goes a lot deeper than Ecstasy. It is a vision of a
trouble-free yob-free society, but they feel threatened by these five
million kids who they can't do anything with. Their tricks don't work any
more. We've got the means for a celebration dance and they can't deny that
there's a returned sense of community in what we do. Not just at raves -
we're trying to spread it into the rest of our lives too, weekends are not
enough.

Exodus began in June 1992. They have provided a roof for homeless people in
a once derelict building, Haz Manor, and set up a community farm. Glenn
described how the impact of Exodus on local people has been much more than
simply providing parties:

We've got our own heart beat, we've got our own moral economy, it's much
more moral than theirs because it's not about exploiting each other. Haz
Manor has been built on the same principle. There might be trade but trade's
different from exploitation  making a living is different from making a
killing. I don't know why they can't see we're their dream come true because
we're not asking for handouts, were saying we're able to help ourselves. I
think they feel threatened by it simply because when you put a diamond in a
pile of shit, you know it's shit.

We're not revolutionaries, we're freedom fighters. The Criminal Justice Act
is about freedom to make profit, freedom to build roads without people
interfering, freedom to siphon people into pubs and clubs rather than fields
and churches. That is why it is heavily sponsored by the Tory party.
Underlying it all, they fear rave culture because it's an anarchist culture.

When Exodus parties are running there is a 40% drop in trade in the town's
pubs. Exodus is convinced the brewery's influence over the local newspapers
has been the cause of the negative image they portray of the collective.
Further than this, a public enquiry has been called into allegations of
police misconduct. Journalist Tim Malyon wrote the following piece to
demonstrate the extent the authorities are prepared to go in order to stop
this revolution:

The Trials of Exodus

On New Years eve 1992/3 Exodus held its largest party with ten thousand
people present. Two weeks later it supported the squatted occupation of a
derelict hotel and started channelling money from the collections and soft
drink stalls at the dances into squat renovation. Exodus is a force for the
good, bringing hope, joy and community where before there was desolation.
But some police officers saw a different picture. Chief Inspector Mike Brown
cooperated with Exodus in helping make venues safe and trying to locate
legal venues, until his superiors at force headquarters blew the whistle.

A series of massive police operations ensued, costing over 103,000, on the
squatted hotel, on Exodus' Long Meadow Community Farm, and on the pre-dance
assembly point. Thirty one criminal charges arose out of these operations
for which there was just one conviction, itself highly dubious. The charges
served to paint a devilish picture of Exodus.

After the hotel eviction police officers are alleged to have copied into
their notebooks crucial information written on a blackboard by a sergeant at
Luton Police Station. This was used as evidence in order to procure public
order convictions and convictions against collective members arrested for
alleged violence and abuse. In another trial arising out of an earlier raid
on the hotel, at least 13 police officers failed to produce their pocket
notebooks after being ordered to do so by the trial judge, causing cases to
be dismissed. Could it have been because they contained lies?

Then there was an alleged drugs find. During a raid by more than 100
officers on the Exodus farm, Ecstasy worth 2,200 was found in Paul Taylor's
bag. Taylor is a prominent black member of the collective, one of those
responsible for forging the black/white union which is the bedrock of
Exodus' power for the good. The house had already been searched once by
Luton Drugs Squad who had failed to find drugs in an obvious place for which
Taylor could be held personally responsible. Police admit Taylor had ample
forewarning of the raid, so could easily have removed the drugs if they were
his. After Luton Drugs Squad had finished their search, an officer from
force headquarters entered the darkened house, spent thirteen minutes inside
it, then called in another officer and took two minutes to lead him to the
drugs in the bag. At Taylor's trial, the defence barrister summed up, "This
case stinks, it stinks of a plot." Taylor was found not guilty.

During the trial the head of Luton drugs squad admitted to a serious
disciplinary complaint, involving mishandling of the drugs. It was also
alleged that there was a rogue cache of drugs at Luton police station,
origin and destiny unknown. The Bedfordshire Deputy Chief Constable, despite
his reputation as a strict disciplinarian, failed to take action after any
of the Exodus cases. Nobody has been disciplined, not for the 'missing'
notebooks, not for the blackboard incident, not for the drugs.

All three political parties on Bedfordshire County Council, as well as the
Police Authority have now voted for a public enquiry to be chaired by
Michael Mansfield QC into "Bedfordshire Police and others' activities"
against Exodus. A retired police inspector told me before he was gagged from
talking to the press: "Licensed premises were experiencing a fair amount of
loss of trade, loss of customers. Some licensees were starting to get into
real financial trouble." He added not only that alcohol-related offences
dropped when Exodus put on dances, but also that political pressure was
being brought to bear on the police by local members of Parliament to get on
the case.

Luton is a brewery town. Whitbread have dominated it for many years.
Hopefully Mansfield's public inquiry will find out who was really
responsible for trying to destroy this movement, a movement which is
transforming the lives of thousands of Bedfordshire's youth.

By Mary Anna Wright from Ecstasy and the Dance Culture

---------------------------------4572978502042302518662472--

Subject: How can we keep the scene "true"

How can we keep the scene from being sold-out?

This is a big worry of mine, every scene eventully is digested by
corporate/profit intrests.  For -example Hip Hop ("Beat Street) and
Rap(Vanilla Ice and MC Hammer).  What I 'm talking about is a scene not
played out because of quick profit intrests.  How can we prevent this!!?? 
I'm already starting to see events where they blatantly lie on the flyer
about how long the event will last or about "goodies" which never show up
(not that you realy need them).  We need more events like Harmony or F&F,
to name a few.  Everyone likes to make a couple of extra bucks, but it cant
be at the price of honesty and integrity, once that starts happening raves
will start looking like Vegas side shows (Cyberfest).  But until then I'll
enjoy it while it's still around and I got the energy!!!!

I dont mean to sound to negative, but I think this is important to talk
about and this list seems like a good place.

See Ya 
Mark

From: laural@inmark.com
Received: (from ugate@localhost) by inmarkinmark.com (8.6.12/8.6.9) with UUCP id LAA24672 for inmark!hyperreal.com!sfraves; Tue, 24 Oct 1995 11:50:12 -0700
Received: from cc:Mail by ugate.inmark.com
	id AA814562418 Tue, 24 Oct 95 12:20:18 
Date: Tue, 24 Oct 95 12:20:18 
Message-Id: <9509248145.AA814562418@ugate.inmark.com>
To: hyperreal.com!sfraves@inmark.inmark.com
Subject: Re: How can we keep the scene "true"
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


     

Mark Piercy writes:
______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
>I'm already starting to see events where they blatantly lie on the flyer 
>about how long the event will last or about "goodies" which never show up 
>(not that you realy need them).

"Starting?"  I've seen stuff like this since 1992, and it hasn't "killed" 
the "scene" yet.  Promises of DJs who were never actually even booked, 
promises of lasers that never appeared, promises of going a certain number 
of hours and then getting closed down because the party wasn't making enough 
money, etc etc.

Remember, it's hard to kill something that doesn't physically exist.  Good 
parties exist because good people exist who like to put them on.  As you 
said, Harmony and F&F are good examples, as was the killer CDC party I went 
to at Richmond back in January.  

Cyberfest is an aberration, don't worry so much :-)  And if you are worried, 
then hook up with the good people surrounding you and keep supporting them 
by either being a regular at their events or actually helping to put the 
events on.  

Raves started "looking like Vegas with sideshows" years ago.  1993 was a 
particularly big year on the east cost for things of that ilk.  But as you 
can see, two years later, good events are going strong.

Laura

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Oct 24 13:20:44 1995

From: drenalin <drenalin@OREGON.UOREGON.EDU>
Subject: Re: How can we keep the scene "true"

Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

part of keeping the scene true is keeping true to yourself.  I havent 
paid more than $10 to go to a party for almost two years as a promise to 
myself that I wouldn't support parties that are *big business*.  I've 
been tempted many times to break that promise but I don't and its hard 
when all your friends may be going to a big party and want you to 
come...but the people that have listened to what I had to say and 
contemplated eventually have told me that usually (but not always) the 
bigger parties they go to turn out to be something different than they 
were looking for...bascially if you like smaller parties and people who 
go to tparties for to share themselves/help create a special 
place/vibe/atmosphere/world then go to parties like F&F, Harmony, 
Frequency 8, Lettuce Dance, Justice League, Liquid, Gateway Systems, 
Trust, and the Cloud Factory ;), and many others...the fact is in San 
Francisco we are blessed 
with one of the most solid underground scenes in the world right now!!!
Take advantage of it and support it!!!!


love drenalin

>FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE                                  23 October 1995
>
>                        BANCO DE GAIA PACK UP THE GEAR
>                                       FOR A U.S. TOUR
>
>Planet Dog/Mammoth Records artist BANCO DE GAIA (a.k.a. Toby Marks) has
>announced US tour dates in support of its recent release LAST TRAIN TO LHAS=
A
>and the reissue of 1993's MAYA.  With his debut tour kicking off Mid-Novemb=
er
>and continuing through till December (Toby Marks had performed a one-off at
>CMJ in 1993), he will be hitting all the major cities and many smaller
>markets in between. Touring with multimedia performance artists Emergency
>Broadcast Network, BANCO DE GAIA has established itself as a premiere touri=
ng
>outfit in the UK, as part of the mobile rave extravaganza MEGADOG (which wi=
ll
>finally make its US debut Spring '96).
>
>Now as the first artist from Planet Dog to launch a full-scale tour across
>the States, Toby Marks will be testing the waters for see if the New World =
is
>ready for the heady music that's been buzzing about the UK for the last
>decade.  From the looks of his recent press, the atmosphere looks promising=
:
>
>          "With a consistent display of subtlety and exquisite
>          taste, Marks has created a fantastic body of work,
>          successfully blending world-beat sounds and styles
>          with cutting-edge MIDI technology while completely
>          avoiding pandering to audience naivete that afflicts
>          so many of his lesser peers."
>                                                  - LA Weekly
>
>          "An evocative work that propels both the body and
>          spirit, LAST TRAIN is equally suited for close listening
>          or frantic dancing, informing the listener on an emotional
>          level through sound, not language."
>                                                  - Alternative Press
>
>          "...this Banco De Gaia is the shit."
>                                                  - Magnet
>
>So welcome BANCO DE GAIA into the country, as he makes his maiden journey
>through this foreign land.  And as he has demonstrated before, once he gets
>his foot on native soil, new worlds spring forth.  Hey, he did it with the
>Tibetans with LAST TRAIN TO LHASA.  Who knows what he=EDll drum up with his
>trek through the US.
>
>I will be setting up interviews with Toby Marks prior to his trans-Atlantic
>voyage.
>So call me for more information, music, and interview requests.
>
>Cheers,
>
>Rey
>Mammoth

Subject: Re: How can we keep the scene "true"
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

At 11:54 AM 10/24/95, Mark Piercy wrote:
>How can we keep the scene from being sold-out?
>
>This is a big worry of mine, every scene eventully is digested by
>corporate/profit intrests.  For -example Hip Hop ("Beat Street) and
>Rap(Vanilla Ice and MC Hammer).  What I 'm talking about is a scene not
>played out because of quick profit intrests.  How can we prevent this!!??
>I'm already starting to see events where they blatantly lie on the flyer
>about how long the event will last or about "goodies" which never show up
>(not that you realy need them).  We need more events like Harmony or F&F,
>to name a few.  Everyone likes to make a couple of extra bucks, but it cant
>be at the price of honesty and integrity, once that starts happening raves
>will start looking like Vegas side shows (Cyberfest).  But until then I'll
>enjoy it while it's still around and I got the energy!!!!
>

There will always be people who can only see and are only attracted to the
glimmering lights and shiny objects that float on the surface.  Those who
know that the true force of the current lies beneath will be there in the
flow.  I believe that the best that any one of us can do is to lead by
example and to develop an awareness of ourselves and the landscape in which
we travel.  The kinds of events that I've truly enjoyed and have gotten the
most out of are events that are formed on the "grass roots" level.  With
everyone contributing to make things happen.  Everyone dealing with each
other from a parallel  perspective as opposed to an heirarchal one.  All
easier said than done for this goes counter to a lot of conditioning that
our society and culture imposes upon us. Never the less, it is a lot easier
than one would be led to believe as well.

Peace!

Tigger

	id AA26032; Tue, 24 Oct 95 15:19:28 PDT
Received: by pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA24986; Tue, 24 Oct 95 15:19:27 PDT
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9510242219.AA24986@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
Subject: Tribal Future
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Tue, 24 Oct 95 15:19:26 PDT
Cc: jlf3@mofo.com
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I had an absolutely fantastic time at Tribal Future.
How does one create a raver's paradise?  It helps if you start out with
the Garden of Eden, which is the only way to describe the beautiful
property owned by Allen's Uncle in the Mendecino Mountains, less
than 3 hours from the city.  Sprinkle the site with exotic sculptures, 
colorful banners, fountains, hot tubs, fireplaces, and christmas lights.
Throw in a communal kitchen, caring hosts, and an abundance of vibeful
people for an atmosphere of free expression, fun, and tribal unity.  And 
don't forget a kick-ass Wicked sound system and a slew of inspired DJs 
continuously pumping out loads and loads of great music. 

It was very warm in the sunlight, but cold in the starlight which kept a
lot of people around the fires in the evening.  I wasn't bothered by the
cold at all, especially during Garth's fantastic 3 hour set.  Actually, 
everyone had great sets; Fred, Ethan, Tracy, Carlos, and a bunch of others
I didn't recognize. (Does anyone have the complete lineup?)  Besides
Garth, the other standout set for me was Pollywog's 3 hour eclectic 
stew of noisy, dubby weirdness that included some Jungle and stuff that
I can't even begin to categorize. 

We left on Sunday at 3pm and missed some more good stuff I'm sure, but
we were more than satisfied with the 24 hours spent there.

Much thanks to Mark, Allen and his gracious Uncle for one of the best 
gatherings I've ever been to. It really was much more than a "rave"
or a party.  It was proof once again that the scene really can function
as a mini community or tribe, at least on occasion.  Tribal Future gave 
us a sense of belonging to a special family of people that represent
many of the ideals that raving attempts to aspire to.  Can't wait for
the next one.

Lee
___________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com   (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )   lee@hyperreal.com
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

> 
> >>...its time for san francisco...ONE OF THE MOST PROGRESSIVE CITIES IN 
> >>THE COUNTRY to get a clue...the sheer lack of music other than house 
> >>here is depressing to me as a dj and a listener...
> 
> >So,  if you don't like house,  then get yourself a pair of 1200's,  a
> >generator,  and a sound system and put on your OWN Happy Hardcore rave.
> >We need more Happy Hard in SF,   we just don't have a big enough group of
> >people to put one on.
> >
> >Crunchman
> 
> You're missing the point if you think adding happy hardcore is the
> solution to the lack of music diversity.  The keyword is "other than,"
> which means a variety of styles and sounds.
>

> Mohsen
> 
> 
> 

I am truly tired of trollers, and lame ass baiters.  If it's not that 
then it's the continuing repetition of history that plagues this list.

Get a clue Mohsen, and all others who have ANY problem with SF:
If you want to create more diversity, then there is nothing stopping YOU 
from doing it.  RULE #1!


If you want to go to a hardcore party, then create one.  Same goes for 
Full Moons, Half Moons, and Half Baked Pies as well as Ideas.  GO FOR 
IT!  RULE #2!


You don't like circle dancers?  Don't go where they dance.  Start a party 
called PLUNCiD (Peace, Love, Unity, No, Cirle, Dancers).  RULE #3.


As a matter of fact, with all the complaints and noise surrounding what's 
not being played, there should be plenty of people who want to hear what 
you want, so you have a base right there.  If you remain true to the 
game, in time they will tire of hardcore and complain about the lack of 
diversity in music in the hardcore scene...whatever.


Point is, we've gone thru this shit over, and over, and ovwer on this 
list.  120 bpm versus 580 bpm.  WHO CARES?  I don't!  Neither do many 
others, I would even suggest the majority.  Either you're well on your 
way to finding that which caters to you, or you're well on your way to 
create that which suits you.  If you're complaining about the lack of 
something, and not doing anything to change it, you're wasting my time, 
as well as everyone elses.  Get a posse together, even if it may be a 
posse of one, and do something about your choices!

Same thing goes for 18+ parties, same thing goes for no smoking events, 
same thing goes for no-booze, samer thing goes for benders, same thing 
goes for hardcore, jungle, 140bpm++ stuff, same thing goes for  
everything.  DIY, DIY, DIY!

Now, can the discussion move from what SF is lacking, to what you're 
doing to make SF lack less?  Thank you!

BTW - Draper, I agree 100% with what you said.  And If I got the message 
of Draper's message I fail to see why you or anyone else did not.

Scientific Paper to follow.

John

Hey goodfolk,
	
	This is a rather provocative thread.  Long live good discussion!
	I figured I might as well throw my hat into the ring.
	I can't help but wonder how long it will take that other 
corporate entity, Hollywood, to pick up on the mystique of the rave scene 
in an attempt to capitalize on yet another alterna-hip subculture... 
I can see it now, some hellish money-making behemoth-amalgam of Saturday 
Night Fever and Kids.  Starring: Leonardo diCaprio as Smiley, Christina Ricci 
as Fluffles, Tom Hanks as DJSlipshot, and Brad Pitt as the Evil Dealer.  
	Hmmmm..... now that I think about it, those Hollywood dogs are pretty 
smart, so they just might cast no-names in an attempt to disguise the 
film as an indy.  Feh.  I'll rue the day.


			jon


p.s.  Until that day comes, lets enjoy our (relative) anonymity and live 
it up at great parties like FnF.  See y'all there!!

Thanks to everyone who responded to my first post on a new time slot for 
Flux. Unfortunately the 10:30PM slot that everyone recommended has 
fallen through. My partner and I are in a heated argument about which of 
the following airtimes would be best:

Friday Midnight
Tuesday Midnight
Thursday Midnight

I tend to lean towards Friday airtime because it is the one night everyone 
is up that late for sure, and if the go out you could set your VCR. My 
partner thinks that is bogus and insists Tuesday is better.

We leave to SFRAVES to settle this dispute once and for all. Thanks for 
your input. -Jonathan

mindless complaints. but with constructive criticism, an open mind to all 
kinds of music (which doesn't mean you have to like it all) and tastes,

my last message for weeks... tomorrow i'm east coast-bound.

as i was doing nothing at my job today (true, although i wish it were
otherwise), a few thoughts came to me that i'd like to share with all. here's
one: a sfraves potluck/joydance/gathering of the tribe. i'm not sure about
the where, when and the how, but the technicalities aren't obstables unless
we think of them as such. 
 
the potluck idea was in my head because i just hosted an enchanted potluck
last sunday at my house. five social circles touched and, for at least a few
hours, merged. it was wonderful. 

being relatively new to the List, almost all of your faces are unknown to me.
that's another reason i thought of helping to host a gathering of the tribe. 

anyway, this is just one of the many ideas that's been bubbling in my
champagne glass.

about keeping our rave culture safe from the vultures of commercialism, i
think awareness is the answer. awareness of self. awareness of community,
real community. awareness of the shearing forces at work on us 24/7:
heartless, profit-driven industrialization, institutionalized reactionary
fear... you know what i mean. as long as we know in our hearts what it is
that gives us real strength and clean power, the flashy-feathered
commercial-cults won't have any point of entry.

we help each other, teach each other, learn from each other. when something
feels wrong, we tell each other and try not to experience that again. and
when something goes right, really right, brother and sister, we do it again
and again... 
                                                            and again...





                                                                          and
again...  

i've lost my thread. the post "Free parties DIY culture (long)" addresses
this issue periphally. [incidentally, it is well worth the read.]  it speaks
of a consciousness-centered community of british ravers and celeberants
called Exodus who are working to improve their town and nation as best they
can.

maybe that's the answer to safegaurding our community from commercialization:
work on community-development. las vagas and hollywood would never touch
that. if you read the post, you'll have a better understanding of what i'm
saying. [to whomever forwarded it, big thank you.]

anyway, i've rambled long enough. since i'm going to be gone for two weeks,
i'm going to <unsubscribe sfraves> for a while. but my "disssolve" account
will reamin active, so send any ideas you might have to me personally, if you
want me to read them. 

with a flower raised aloft, 
grinning wide,
and tapping toe to transcendent tunes,
dSiHssAoLvOeM

>part of keeping the scene true is keeping true to yourself.  I havent
>paid more than $10 to go to a party for almost two years as a promise to
>myself that I wouldn't support parties that are *big business*.  I've
>been tempted many times to break that promise but I don't and its hard
>when all your friends may be going to a big party and want you to
>come...but the people that have listened to what I had to say and
>contemplated eventually have told me that usually (but not always) the
>bigger parties they go to turn out to be something different than they
>were looking for...bascially if you like smaller parties and people who
>go to tparties for to share themselves/help create a special
>place/vibe/atmosphere/world then go to parties like F&F, Harmony,
>Frequency 8, Lettuce Dance, Justice League, Liquid, Gateway Systems,
>Trust, and the Cloud Factory ;), and many others...the fact is in San
>Francisco we are blessed
>with one of the most solid underground scenes in the world right now!!!
>Take advantage of it and support it!!!!
>
>
>love drenalin

Hello,
    I have much to say on this, but also have much school work to do, 
so I will try to keep it short...

Drenalin wrote:
>part of keeping the scene true is keeping true to yourself.  I havent 

    Of course! Each and every one of us should support the parties that 
we think should get it. If you are worried about the scene becoming a 
circus side-show, then don't support those parties. Personally, when 
ever there is a new party coming out I usually go and see what the 
promoters are trying to do with their expressions. That is what I think 
throwing parties is all about, (at least to us). For us, it isn't how 
many people can we get?, or how can we make money?, it is how can we 
express our personal vibe to the raving community? Harmony, is a way 
for us to communicate with the scene. We can get our ideas out, and 
have a blast doing it!!! The other alternative (at least for me) is to 
support the many other parties that are doing good for the scene, (at 
least when I am not overloaded with school :).
   
>...bascially if you like smaller parties and people who 
>go to tparties for to share themselves/help create a special 
>place/vibe/atmosphere/world then go to parties like F&F, Harmony, 
>Frequency 8, Lettuce Dance, Justice League, Liquid, Gateway Systems, 
>Trust, and the Cloud Factory ;), and many others...the fact is in San 
>Francisco we are blessed 
>with one of the most solid underground scenes in the world right 
now!!!
>Take advantage of it and support it!!!!
>
>love drenalin
>
Perfectly said Scott... Support the underground!!! C-ya @F&F!!!!!!!

Peace,

Greg :)

OK, first off hello everyones.

I 've been incognito for a while but I'm glad to report that I'm safe and
alive and somewhat (in)saner than usual. But I diverge from the topic at
hand....

I've been readin' the "True Scene" posts and decieded to say what I feel (as
I believe we all should).  
To me, the scene will always stay true. I remember the hoopla of 92' and 93
and remember it virtually disapearing (for me) last year.  I truly think that
it's not the scene that waxes and wanes but ones perception of it...   Your
scene is what you make it.  If you stay informed then you'll always have a
place to go to. If you "fall out" of 'the circle' then you be as ignorant to
the vibe train as the countless other newbies and new-to-be ravers.  Hell, I
even think the term "rave" is passe now. I see everyone calling them
"events", gaterings, renegades etc al.  (pls. refer to "Pop Quiz" post).  The
scene changes and we must change with it.... I know 'events' that aren't
posted onto hyperreal. and respect them.  I know of soundsystems that believe
SFR is too good enuff for them (Translation: They think they suck) and
respect that too. In time I know they'll turn around.

Do you remember X-parties?  I recall, years ago, calling a few(4-5) of my
friends and telling em that I was spinning some new stuff @ my house, and to
drop by if they wanted to hear it...  3hrs later my garage would be housing
20-30 people, most X'ed out saying things like "good party dude".  Party?
Scene?  Again the scene is what you make it....

I enjoyed helping out the F8 crew, come dawn luggung the equip. up the crazy
cliffs (and believe me they ARE crazy cliffs, I have the scars to prove it).
Cos it brings the scene closer to me.
Helping out SPAZ was the same way as well as helping you out, dear raver (or
whatever you wish to call yourself nowadays), for rides to and fro, moving
ect...
So well that's my input and well, Im really antsy to go dancing (haven't been
on the dance floor in a week and a half).  So I hope ta see some of yer
smiliey faces at Roots 2morrow.

Spins,
Adam

"There is no disgrace in failure, with the exception of failing to try...."

Jonathan Mark Logan writes:

 >I can't help but wonder how long it will take that other 
>corporate entity, Hollywood, to pick up on the mystique of the rave scene 
>in an attempt to capitalize on yet another alterna-hip subculture... 

Hollywood already tried, and it failed.  Back in 1993 there was a movie 
set in the rave scene (New York) called _Cyberstrom_.  It starred 
Christina Applegate (of "Married with Children") as a raver who supported 
herself by selling jewelry at parties.

I never saw it (it was a huge flop), but I'm told that the story involved 
some guy who was a reclusive engineer type becoming homeless due to some 
evil plot and going to sleep in a warehouse...he wakes up in the middle of 
a rave, meets Applegate, and the two join forces to strike back against 
the evil plot that got him where he was.  In the process, Applegate and 
her happy raver friends teach him how to love, have fun, and not be such a 
recluse.

So, once again, don't worry so much...to tell the truth, rave-as-fad has 
come and gone.  And if you are worried, just keep hooking up with people 
who you like, trust, and know can provide an honest good time.

Laura

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

How can we keep the scene "true?"

You can't. 

Since everyone is different, each person has a different idea of what a
"true" scene consists of. The only way to approach reconciling all of those
ideas is for people to start giving up aspects of their image of a true
scene until the lowest common denominator is agreeable to everyone.
Unfortunately, the aspects given up by one person are held near and dear to
others and vice-versa.

eric


p.s. October is Head Injury Month.


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Oct 25 11:48:55 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id LAA03612; Wed, 25 Oct 1995 11:48:55 -0700

Received: from netcom6.netcom.com (mayer@netcom6.netcom.com [192.100.81.114]) by gw.steam.com (8.6.10/8.6.9) with ESMTP id LAA00993 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 25 Oct 1995 11:30:18 -0700

	id LAA04869; Wed, 25 Oct 1995 11:45:50 -0700

Subject: Re: Rave the vote 
In-reply-to: Your message of "Fri, 20 Oct 95 16:39:10 PDT."
             <Pine.SOL.3.91.951020162203.879A-100000@apollo> 
Date: Wed, 25 Oct 95 11:45:50 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>Here I must disagree.  Ben Hom is the best candidate in the mayor's 
>race.  He is a businessman -- maybe this is why he understands how the heavy 
>hand of government can adversely affect people.  Hom is the only 
>candidate talking about reducing taxes and privatizing city services.  
>Achtenberg talks a nice game about making San Francisco government more 
>efficient, but Hom walks the walk.  The "privatization study" put forward 
>by Mayor Jordan (Prop. K) is a sham which will not encourage real 
>privatization -- don't vote for it.
>
>I know this isn't directly rave-related, but who's in charge will 
>definitely affect us one way or another.  Thanks to Lee Fogel for 
>bringing it up.  John is also right for saying if we mobilize, they will 
>not be able to ignore us.  Power in numbers.  My general rule when voting 
>is this: Yes on any proposition or candidate that empowers people by 
>reducing the size or scope of government; no to any proposition or 
>candidate that promises to take power away from people or increase the 
>government leviathan.

You've got to be kidding. Ben Hom is a major *MAJOR* asshole. Rather
that taking starchild's patently bogus advice, you all should have
heard some of BH's pathetic answers at that recent mayoral "debate". If
the man has a brain, he gave no indication he makes any use of it. He's
an idiot -- gives shallow answers to deep questions, and doesn't even
realize that some questions exceed the depths of his pockets.

Read some of his literature. Oh, you make less than $200K/year? He
ain't interested in you. You're not an entrepreneur or small business
owner -- he ain't interested in you. You like to do anything that will
make it difficult for businesses to operate (e.g. protests, sit-ins,
being up past midnight (because you'll be too strung out for the
boss-man to be whipping your ass when you get in to make him rich when
your work day begins at 8AM).)

Like JSL said, Ben Hom is strictly about business. He isn't interested
in "us" in any way shape or form. He wants to separate you the people
from your money, and make sure that money ends up in the hands of the
friends to which he'll dole out "privatization" boondoggles...

Privatization is a joke. In the moneyocracy that we're now running in,
we get those currently in power to set up their friends or family to
take over running a governent service as a business. But rather than
being responsive to the customer, the new privatized business is only
responsive to political forces that set them up in the first place.

Meanwhile the privatized business empowers those friends/family with
money and clout to continue lobbying the govt to let them continue
running and profiting from a government-funneled business. This further
empowers the new wealthy owners of privatized businesses with more
capital and contacts by which they can bribe politicians to allow them
to further expand their business. (The #1 imperative of business is
unchecked growth -- well past the point of need -- and unchecked
amalgamation of power. So don't be surprised when the privatized
services become an uncontrollable force that becomes a corrupt little
mini-government on it's own. (General Electric, or Westinghouse for
example.))

People like to tout the wonderfulness of "competition" involved in
privatization, but they never take a deeper look into the politics of
privatization, which are easily more corrupt than anything a
centralized government service could come up with (the ability to "buy"
gaggles of full-time lobbyists, the ability to "buy" politicians with
gifts, bribes, campaign contributions, etc.). You see, there's not that
much money in local government, therefore not that much power, nor
motivation for people to grab more power. By tapping into private
capital and mixing that into public government structures, that's when
you tap into the real power that can properly destabilize democracy.
(note the truism that power==money)... 

Give me a centralized organization with proper checks and balances over
privatization any day of the week. Give me businesses hamstrung by rules
and regulations over unchecked competition.

Oh, and if you doubt me, please take a look at our "privatized"
military-industrial complex, or our privatized energy industry. Yeah,
there's a bastion of competition and efficiency.

And unless you're a raving libertarian idiot, please don't vote for Ben
Hom.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
=  Niels Mayer   http://www.cyborganic.com/People/niels   mayer@netcom.com  =
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

From carol.lembcke@3do.com Wed Oct 25 10:21:25 1995
Date: 25 Oct 1995 09:47:41 -0800
From: "Carol Lembcke" <carol.lembcke@3do.COM>
Subject: Stop Nuclear Dump - URGENT
          Date:
                                                                     10/25/95

Hello all-

Several weeks ago, I sent you all email about a proposed Nuclear Waste Dump
site to be constructed in Ward Valley in the east Mojave Desert.  

It is with a great sadness in my heart that I must convey to you that in spite
of many months and much hard work by environmentalist, Secretary of the
Interior, Bruce Babbitt, announced on Monday his *definite* intention to
transfer the Federally Preserved land of Ward Valley to Gov. Wilson so that
construction of the dump may begin.   

WHAT YOU CAN DO!  Please now more then ever your voice could make a
difference...use it...speak!

Please call Sen. Feinstein at 415-536-6868.  Calls must be received TODAY in
order for her to take action in time.

Let your voice be heard...let it say that dumping HIGH and LOW level Nuclear
Waste in Ward Valley is UNACCEPTABLE!  Please don't let this pristine land
become a painful festering wound that will harm us all.  

Thank you for choosing to make a difference.  My original post with all the
background on this dump is below for reference.  Please pass this post on to
anyone who can help.

Peace, Love and Understanding - now more then ever!
Carol 


ORIGINAL POST REGARDING WARD VALLEY
     
A Proposed Nuclear Waste Dump to be constructed in Ward Valley.
     
BACKGROUND
Ward Valley is located 22 miles west of Needles, CA in the beautiful East 
Mojave desert.  Plans are to bury long-lasting and highly dangerous 
radioactive wastes from nuclear power plants in shallow, unlined trenches 
above an aquifer and just 18 miles from the Colorado River.  Ward Valley is 
located directly adjacent to the new Mojave National Preserve and is 
surrounded by five wilderness areas.  Area Indian tribes consider Ward Valley 
sacred homeland and Ward Valley is critical habitat for the threatened Desert 
Tortoise.  Secretary of the Interior, Bruce Babbitt has announced his 
intention to transfer the land at Ward Valley to the state of CA.  Once 
Governor Wilson gets hold of the land construction of the dump could begin 
within a few months.
     
ACTION BEING TAKEN
I will be in Ward Valley as a representative on my own organization, For the 
Animals, along with Greenpeace, BAN, California Communities Against Toxics 
among others, to let Mr. Babbitt and Gov. Wilson know that dumping toxic 
waste in California or anywhere on mother earth is NOT acceptable.
     
WHAT YOU CAN DO
If you would like me to deliver a message on your behalf or if you would like 
to make a donation to assist in this demonstration, please get it to me 
before this Friday.   Or you may call BAN directly at 415-752-8678.
     
Thanks for doing what you can for mother earth.  PLEASE SPREAD THE WORD! 
Carol
     
  The 3DO


  The 3DO


----- End Included Message -----
