>Date: Wed, 25 Oct 1995 21:55:30 +1000
>From: Simon Rumble <simonr@widewest.com.au>
>X-Within-Url:
>http://www.magna.com.au/~simonr/ausrave/media/telegraph-mirror.25-10-95.html
>To: ausrave@student.adelaide.edu.au
>Subject: telegraph-mirror.25-10-95.html
>Sender: owner-ausrave@student.adelaide.edu.au
>Precedence: bulk
>X-UIDL: 814641064.060
>
>
>Telegraph-Mirror October 25th 1995
>
>
>     _________________________________________________________________
>
>                         TEENAGER'S TRAGIC DANCE PARTY
>
>By NIGEL VINCENT and LUCINDA DUCKETT
>
>
>
>   The parents of Sydney teenager Anna Wood watched yesterday as her life
>   support system was turned off -- three days after she fell into a coma
>   after taking the drug ecstasy.
>
>   It is believed she tried the drug after paying $70 and taking it
>   before she entered a city dance club on Saturday night.
>
>   Within hours she had suffered a violent reaction and was vomiting
>   uncontrollably.
>
>   By Sunday morning she had slipped into a come.
>
>   Yesterday afternoon she was dead.
>
>   A police spokesman said: "The life support machine was turned off
>   shortly before 4pm."
>
>   A Royal North Shore Hospital spokeswoman could not comment on whether
>   Anna had suffered an allergic reaction to the drug.
>
>   Friends spoke yesterday of how excited Anna had been about going to
>   the party to celebrate her new job as an apprentice beautician, which
>   she was due to start on Monday at Skin Vogue Beauty Salon in Belrose.
>
>   It would have been the 15-year-old's first job after leaving Forest
>   High School two weeks ago.
>
>   On Saturday, Ana joined friends and headed into the city for the
>   Apache dance party at the Phoenecian Club in Ultimo.
>
>   Yesterday, at about 3.55pm, with her family by her side, Anna dies at
>   Royal North Shore Hospital.
>
>   Police said they believed Anna fell ill after taking only one ecstasy
>   tablet.
>
>   She was taken immediately to a friend's house in Belrose, where she
>   spent the night.
>
>   Detective Senior Constable Stephen Page, from Frenchs Forest police,
>   said Anna was looked after by her friend, but began to experience
>   difficulties.
>
>   "She was monitored all night and when the difficulties began, an
>   ambulance was called," he said.
>
>   A friend said yesterday: "I saw her about 5.30pm on Saturday and she
>   said she was going to the rave with about three girls and mabye some
>   guys.
>
>   "That was the last time I spoke to her."
>
>   Another friend said: "Anna bought the ecstay tablet but must have had
>   an allergic reaction to it."
>
>   An ambulance spokesman said they received a call at 11:10am on Sunday
>   to a house in Hews Pde, Belrose.
>
>   "We had a report that a 15-year-old girl had vomited -- when we got
>   there the girl was not breathing," the spokesman said.
>
>   Paramedics attempted to resucitate th teenager for some 25 minutes
>   before rushing her to Royal North Shore Hospital.
>
>   As she lay in a coma on a life support machine her parents and elder
>   sister Alice were by her side.
>
>   "By all accounts she was a lovely young girl," Detective Senior
>   Constable Page said.
>
>   "Hospital staff have told me how distressing it was to see such an
>   angelic looking girl in medical difficulties."
>
>   The detective said it was believed the girl had paid between $70 and
>   $100 for the ecstasy tablet.
>
>   "We don't know why it affected her so badly," he said.
>
>   Senior Constable Page said what happened to Anna could have been the
>   result of a chemical imbalance in her body, and issued a warning to
>   other youngsters not to experiment with drugs.
>
>   A police spokesman said the decision to switch off the life support
>   machine was taken shortly before 4pm.
>
>   Forest High School principal Pat Kidd said Anna had left as a Year 10
>   student a fortnight ago.
>
>   "We had discussions with her about taking the job with the beauty
>   salon and we all agreed it was the best move for her," Mr Kidd said.
>
>   "She had many friends at the school who are very distraught and we
>   have been offering counselling to the students over the last two
>   days."
>
>   The school held seminars for students warning them of the dangers of
>   taking drugs, Mr Kidd said.
>     _________________________________________________________________
>
>                             ANNA'S DEADLY PARTY
>
>
>
>   Blurb on "The ecstasy culture" to be scanned
>     _________________________________________________________________
>
>                           GAY COMMUNITY LED THE WAY
>
>
>
>   Dance parties, such as the one Anna Wood went to last Saturday night,
>   are the discos of the 1990s.
>
>   They are the offshoot of parties held by the gay and lesbian community
>   in the late 80s, including the Mart Gras, Sleaze Ball and the New
>   Year's Eve RAT part.
>
>   Dance parties have become more mainstream with several hundred youths
>   and people aged in their 20s attending.
>
>   The crowd is young, hard bodied, fashionably dressed and mixed -- gay,
>   lesbian and straight.
>
>   The hard-core techno music and high energy dancing of rave parties --
>   which started in Europe in the 1980s -- have been replaced by smoother
>   sounds and a slower atmosphere.
>
>   About 10 dance parties are held each weekend, mostly in nightclubs and
>   "special venues" such as warehouses and rarely cost under $20 to get
>   in.
>
>   The big parties, like Icebox at Kings Cross, cost up to $50 a head to
>   go all night.
>
>   Advertised mostly by flyers and "street" newspapers, the parties
>   attract the most popular DJs from around the world.
>
>   Most dance parties are followed by a "recovery party" which runs the
>   following day at other venues.
>     _________________________________________________________________
>
>                          POCKET MONEY IS DRUG MONEY
>
>By NIGEL VINCENT
>
>
>
>   The principal of the school where Anna Wood was a student until two
>   weeks ago said teenagers with too much money in their pockets were
>   easily able to buy drugs at well-known public places.
>
>   Forest High School principal Pat Kidd said some youngsters were paying
>   up to $60 for ecstasy tablets.
>
>   He suggested that parents monitor more closely where children spent
>   their money.
>
>   "Some kids in this area have fairly large amounts of money in their
>   pockets," Mr Kidd told The Daily Telegraph Mirror yesterday.
>
>   "I've heard the going rate for an ecstasy tablet is about $60.
>
>   That means kids are spending $60 plus a bus fare, plus the cost of
>   getting into the venue.
>
>   "We're talking about kids going out on a Saturday night with a minimum
>   of $100.
>
>   "Parents should monitor their children's spending habits more
>   closely."
>
>   Mr Kidd said teenagers bought drugs from well-known places in the
>   area, including Chatswood bus exchange and Manly Wharf.
>
>   "If I go down to these places no one will sell me anything," he said.
>
>   "But if a 15-year-old kid goes there something will offer them drugs
>   within five minutes."
>
>   Mr Kidd said it was easier for a teenager to buy some drugs than to
>   buy cigarettes .
>
>   "We warn them that this [drugs] is not life, this is death and the
>   people who sell this death are the ones we need to get rid of," he
>   said.
>
>   Mr Kidd spoke out following the death of former Forest High School
>   student Anna Wood, from Belrose.
>
>   Anna, 15, dies yesterday after taking an ecstasy on Saturday night.
>
>   Anna left the school two weeks ago for a job as an apprentice
>   beautician in Belrose.
>
>   She had been working there part-time for about five weeks, when she
>   was employed full-time.
>
>   Anna was due to start her new job on Monday.
>
>   "We discussed with her about becoming a beautician," Mr Kidd said.
>
>   Mr Kidd said students were warned about the dangers of drugs as part
>   of the school's personal development program, but many children
>   ignored the warnings.
>
>   He blamed the media and rock music as part of the image of a
>   successful young person.
>
>   Everyone at the school was distressed over the tragedy.
>
>   Mr Kidd said seminars were held at the school on a regular basis.
>
>   Guest speakers from the Salvation Army and Health Department were
>   often asked to talk to the students.
>
>   "She has many friends still at school who are very distraught," Mr
>   Kidd said.
>
>   "We have been offering counselling to the students over the past two
>   days.
>
>   "Anna was a lovely girl, very beautiful, with lovely skin.
>
>   "She had a great future ahead of her, but when a child leaves school
>   they are the parents' responsibility.
>
>   "She was a lovely young lady and the whole school is distraught at
>   what has happened.
>
>   "But she was no longer a student at this school and is completely
>   outside the control of the school.
>
>   "I am deeply distressed that kids resort to taking drugs.
>
>   "When I was younger you celebrated a new job with a couple of beers
>   with you mates, not by taking drugs."
>
>   Mr Kidd said the whole community should take responsibility for what
>   had happened.
>
>   "When a kid leaves school and is out of here, they are the parents'
>   responsibility.
>
>   "What they do on a Saturday night is the parents' responsibility.
>
>   "But the whole community should take responsibility for what is
>   happening in our cities."
>
>   Meanwhile, police intelligence experts said yesterday they were
>   closely monitoring Sydney's rave and dance part scenes.
>
>   But they said they did not believe there was any current upsurge in
>   the use of ecstasy and amphetamines.
>
>   "Underground" dance parties have long been a drug distribution point
>   in Sydney.
>
>   But now with health, hygiene and financial considerations coming to
>   the fore, many events ae held openly in more regular venues.
>
>   "It's not as secret as it used to be, market forces have overtaken the
>   events and there's money to be made," one commentator said.
>
>                   'ALL THINGS INTERESTING' THE AD PROMISED
>
>
>
>   The Apache party on Saturday began around 10pm, with disc jockeys
>   including DJ Arthur, DJ Eden and Nik Fish entertaining the crowd until
>   about 6am on Sunday -- well after the sun came up.
>
>   Above the dance floor, scores of sweaty young bodies crammed into the
>   two balcony levels and the "ambience room, for your relaxing
>   pleasure".
>
>   The party was advertised in the dance bible, 3D World, on October 16.
>
>   It was promoted as "the combination of all things interesting" and
>   included lasers and pyrotechnics displays.
>
>   Tickets were sold at the Phoenician Club in the city and at
>   alternative record stores for $20.
>
>   Although mainly a band venue which has hosted Angels and Nirvana, the
>   club has recently branched out into dance parties.
>
>   The club was closed in 1992 following a police raid, but re-opened the
>   following year.
>
>   A new team of managers has been appointed in the past six months.
>
>   The "recovery party", where people go to carry on the celebrations,
>   was held at Sundaze in George St, from 6am on Sunday.
>     _________________________________________________________________
>
>                        DRUGS ARE DESTROYING OUR FUTURE
>
>
>
>   Anna Wood should have been celebrating her first days of work in the
>   adult world this week but instead her family is mourning the loss of
>   a daughter and sister today.
>
>   Yesterday afternoon her parents agreed to the removal of artificial
>   support systems which had kept their 15-year-old's body alive since
>   she collapsed in a coma after taking what was believed to be the drug
>   ecstasy at a party on Saturday night/
>
>   No decision could have been harder for a family to make and the
>   anguish suffered by the Woods is shared in every parent.
>
>   Anna Wood was yet another victim of the criminals who peddle their
>   evil products in this country seemingly immune from prosecution.
>
>   Ecstasy enjoys a false reputation among its users as a benign drug. It
>   is not. It is pushed by dealers who capitalise on its glamour image
>   and its association with the mindless giltterati.
>
>   But the drug is a killer. On December 13, 1992, three people lost
>   their lived and others were injured in seperate car crashes caused by
>   youths who had taken ecstasy.
>
>   Unless the tougest measures available to the courts are taken, more
>   lives undoubtedly will be lost.
>
>   Anna Wood and the two young men involved in the collisions all had
>   been exposed to some degree of drug education during their schooling
>   but remained impervious to its message -- drugs kill.
>
>   Clearly the ineffectual education campaign should be re-examined.
>
>   Last week, Premier Carr announced the creation of the Council on Crime
>   Prevention with a charter to develop a network and advise on crime
>   prevention programs. As a matter of urgency the council should look at
>   means of totally eradicating the use of illegal drugs of all types in
>   NSW.
>
>   Evidence presented to the police royal commission indicated that drug
>   dealers ply their trade with immunity, in part because of corruption
>   entrenched within sections of the police force. This situation cannot
>   be permitted to continue one day longer.
>
>   Broader society however also must take responsibility for Anna Wood's
>   death.
>
>   As a start, some of her young associated might consider launching
>   their own anti-drug campaign among their peers using the trauma they
>   have suffered through their friend's death to drive the project.
>
>   Others from her community might also seek to turn this tragic loss
>   into somethign positive.
>
>   Every drug death impoverishes our nation immeasurably. It would be
>   unpardonnable if we now ignore this most recent tragedy and permit
>   the insidious murderers of our young people to continue destroying
>   the future of our country
>
>   This opinionated waste of paper did not have a by-line. Underneath the
>   column, in tiny print is written "Responsibility for election comment
>   is taken by the Editor, Colin Allan." whatever that means.
>
>

on a related note:

KGO 810 reported this morning that the FDA was looking into the 'Herbal Ecstasy' 
stuff being sold in stores and advertised as being safe. They quoted some
doc saying "no,no, this stuff is bad, it raises cardio-somethingorother,
gives you artythmis***, and is baad.".

The newsman then said, at least 12 people have died and aobut 350 "injured"
as a result of taking E this year, in the US.

Harsh mentions:
>KGO 810 reported this morning that the FDA was looking into the 
>'Herbal Ecstasy' 
>stuff being sold in stores and advertised as being safe. 

When "herbal ecstacy" first appeared, my friend Mark went to talk to the person 
selling it to find out what was in it so he'd know what he'd be getting into.

*The personal selling it wouldn't say, not even in general terms.*

This is not good.  Some people have sensitivities to "safe" things -- even as 
well-known as aspririn or caffiene -- and should not use them in any form.  So, 
it stands to reason that there could be things in "herbal ecstacy" that 
individuals could be sensitive to, also.  I find it very irresonsible on the 
part of the "herbal ecstacy" manufacturers/resellers that they wouldn't reveal 
what was in it.  

Their argument was that they didn't want to divulge their secret formula, but 
that doesn't seem valid when you consider that someone taking it might be very 
sensitive to Kola (something we guessed that might be in it, based on the taste 
and smell of the powder) and get irregular heartbeat from the stimulation.

I haven't looked at a label for "herbal ecstacy" lately, so *hopefully* this 
policy of secrecy has changed...can someone tell me for sure?

Personally, I think "herbal ecstacy" is a load of snake oil...if we knew what 
was in it we could whip up our own for a LOT cheaper by visiting the local Whole
Foods or Chinese herbalist.  Mark suspected that there was Mau Haung, Ginseng, 
Kola, and some Betel Nut in it.


Laura

  *12:01(am)- proceed to party at mind numbing pace
  *6:00(am)-  collapse into bed  
  *6:05(am)-  dream of translucent iceburgs with a trance backbeat
  *12:01(pm)- wake up and say "hello San Fran"
  *1:00(pm)-  drift over to the Haight/Berkeley area, hangout and browse.

  *all day - Conference stuff
  *11:30(pm)- Bahia Cabana (only $3)

  *all day - Conference stuff

  *all day - Conference stuff

way home.

ive never had a bad experience on it except i do tend to feel a little sick
because i dont do well with those wierd herbal things...they kind of fuck
with my stomach...its not a real e but in my experience its been worth it
to keep up and keep out of the whole lying in a heap in the corner
experience...a lot less confusion, but not THAT much ecstasy either...its
kinda like ephedrine...its five bucks a "hit" and you might need more than
one...you get it at raves, although i usually see it a lot more often at
bigger events, its called cloud 9 or herbal bliss...what ive tried is the
bliss...they also sell it at some "raver" stores or sex shops and i wager
its probably more expensive there...

in British Columbia and

>was legal in the US.  Is this true??

through mail order from england...ketamine or special k is a from of animal
tranquilizer favored by new york club kids...legal for vetrinarians, my
friend...but not for you.

i think thats it...if any of this info is wrong, please dont hesitate to
correct me...

Jonathan Mark Logan writes:

 >I can't help but wonder how long it will take that other 
>corporate entity, Hollywood, to pick up on the mystique of the rave scene 
>in an attempt to capitalize on yet another alterna-hip subculture... 

Hollywood already tried, and it failed.  Back in 1993 there was a movie 
set in the rave scene (New York) called _Cyberstrom_.  It starred 
Christina Applegate (of "Married with Children") as a raver who supported 
herself by selling jewelry at parties.

I never saw it (it was a huge flop), but I'm told that the story involved 
some guy who was a reclusive engineer type becoming homeless due to some 
evil plot and going to sleep in a warehouse...he wakes up in the middle of 
a rave, meets Applegate, and the two join forces to strike back against 
the evil plot that got him where he was.  In the process, Applegate and 
her happy raver friends teach him how to love, have fun, and not be such a 
recluse.

So, once again, don't worry so much...to tell the truth, rave-as-fad has 
come and gone.  And if you are worried, just keep hooking up with people 
who you like, trust, and know can provide an honest good time.

Laura

> questions...Has any body had any bad experiences with it?  Does it feel like

as far as i can tell from myself, its caffine. say for example you drink 
around 30 Cokes, it would produce the same effect. if i ever get 
something that makes me too wired, say like drinking 4 mochas or 
something, i start grinding my teeth, as well as a few other things, such 
as my body needs to rest, but i cant. my eyes are dialated...and im sure 
that lots of people experiance this. so, its up to you, you can buy the 
herbal e and see how it feels, or buy the real stuff and have more fun. 
if all you want is something speedy, then just take some no doze and a 
few sodas and some esspresso, smoke a lot of cigs, and hey, you got 
herbal e!

>   "When I was younger you celebrated a new job with a couple of beers
>   with you mates, not by taking drugs."

Okay, this pissed me off more than anything in the article.  I don't want to
get back into the whole beer vs. drugs thing, but it's hipocracy like this
that I find so incredibly absurd.  It's okay to celebrate with a nice, legal
drug (although he doesn't seem to recognize it as such, which is another
plague of the world), but _not_ with those bad illegal ones.  And of course
beer is safer, because governments only have the people's best interests in
mind.  They don't care about making money or anything like that...

God, I hope 20 years from now I don't think I'm right by virtue of the fact
that I'm older and _obviously_ wiser.

Peeved,
Jake

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Oct 25 20:04:00 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id UAA11045; Wed, 25 Oct 1995 20:04:00 -0700
Received: from jeeves.usfca.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id UAA11035; Wed, 25 Oct 1995 20:03:57 -0700
Received: from duckman.usfca.edu ([138.202.32.150]) by jeeves.usfca.edu (8.6.9/8.6.9) with SMTP id TAA26343 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 25 Oct 1995 19:57:21 -0700
Date: Wed, 25 Oct 1995 19:57:21 -0700
Message-Id: <199510260257.TAA26343@jeeves.usfca.edu>
X-Sender: reicja00@dons.ac.usfca.edu
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Version 1.4.3b4
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: reicja00@dons.ac.usfca.edu (Jake Reichert)
Subject: Vasopressin & herbal E
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Regarding these two:
Vasopressin is definitely a smart drug.  I can't remember exactly what it
does, but I recall from my reading it is one of the more interesting ones.
I think it comes in a spray bottle and you inhale it nasally every few
hours, but I could be mixing it up with something else.  Can anyone help me
out with this?

As far as ketamine goes:  It's pretty strong, from what I've read.  Only try
it in a safe environment with people you trust, at least at first.  I've
never tried it, but it's up there with things like scopalamine.  About the
only drug that's readily available that has similar effects is DXM, found in
several brands of over-the-counter cough syrup.  Basically the same effects
but not as pronounced.  More than anything, it's a narcotic (although it's
sometimes called a dissociative).  Note on the cough syrup thing:  since
I've mentioned it I should say that if you were planning on doing this, DO
NOT do it until you've read up on it.  DXM is very safe, but the other
ingredients many times are not.  Make sure you get something with only DXM
in it.  A lot of the other things, like psuedoephedrine and some
antihistamines, could kill you in large doses.

Jake

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Oct 25 20:04:14 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id UAA11073; Wed, 25 Oct 1995 20:04:14 -0700
Received: from jeeves.usfca.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id UAA11065; Wed, 25 Oct 1995 20:04:10 -0700
Received: from duckman.usfca.edu ([138.202.32.150]) by jeeves.usfca.edu (8.6.9/8.6.9) with SMTP id TAA26349 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 25 Oct 1995 19:57:43 -0700
Date: Wed, 25 Oct 1995 19:57:43 -0700
Message-Id: <199510260257.TAA26349@jeeves.usfca.edu>
X-Sender: reicja00@dons.ac.usfca.edu
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Version 1.4.3b4
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: reicja00@dons.ac.usfca.edu (Jake Reichert)
Subject: Re:  herbal e
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>>>KGO 810 reported this morning that the FDA was looking into the 
>>>'Herbal Ecstasy' 
>>>stuff being sold in stores and advertised as being safe. 
>>
>>When "herbal ecstacy" first appeared, my friend Mark went to talk to the
>person 
>>selling it to find out what was in it so he'd know what he'd be getting into.
>>
>>*The personal selling it wouldn't say, not even in general terms.*

Well, generally it's a mix of several herbs, predominately ma hung, also
known as ephedra (a natural form of ephedrine).  So esentially it's more
like "herbal speed."  And for those of you who have tried it you know that
it feels a lot more like speed than E.  It also contains ginseng, ginko,
gotu kola, kola nut and other common herbs sold in health food stores, just
in much larger amounts.  It is quite possible that many people can have
adverse reactions to any of these.  Ma hung accelerates heart rates a lot,
so of course there's danger in that, and many people have allergic reactions
to Kola nut especially.  It is known to induce heart attacks in some people,
even in small doses.  I know that I personally have some kind of reaction to
one of these; I have some ginseng and ginko vitamins that contain some of
these herbs, and occasionally, depending on what I've just eaten, it causes
me to get red, flushed, hot, and itchy.  Not pleasant.

Hope that all helps.

Jake

the dj?" and I asked Garth and he said  " I don't know but It's Funky!"

was the first time he had heard it and he played on it as the party really 
started to get Psychedelic (his car was broken and his kid asleep).
12-2  Tracy played a set which  we are already making money on!
2 -4 Garth played a full set of Funky High Energy Cold Fighting ...
When a Wicked Dj gets on the Turbo Sound Sure Sympathizes.
4-6am Carlos Hurtled in as the last arrival straight from NY city and then to 
Spundaes after. His energy was Fabulous. And his set was Smooth.

step on my trails of my foot prints. I had some kind of Tribal Dance 
revelation during this.

mixer tricks like no one.. where did he learn this?

because no one disturbed me.

Willits (Penelope's Web)... ambient kitch?

most. I actually beat - matched 2 records.

and (mark broke a Piniada to jungle)

N..I...C..E as it could be!!!!
4:00- I left at dark Solar playing the endless good vibe Indian Summer and I 
was So relaxed at this point.... 3 hot tubs help...

Hello everyone, I would like to introduce myself to the list.  I sent a
message 2 days ago, but it never seemed to have been put out to the list,
so I am going to type it again. :)

My name is Craig, and I have been living in New York City for the past 8
months, but I am returning to my home, which is in Harrisburg PA in a week
or two.

The reason for this message, is that I plan on going back to Harrisburg and
saving up some more money, and then in the next year (March or April
hopefully) I am planning on making the move out to San Francisco.  So, I
decided to post this message in hopes that I can start meeting some new
people and ask a few questions along the way.

I only know a few people from VRave, so I hope that this message will have
alot of you writing back to me, and hopefully we can start some sort of
contact, so when I make the move out there, that I will have some people I
have to meet, and not be all lonely. :)

The main point of this email, is that I am going to be looking for someone
to move in with when I get out there.  I want to room with someone for a
short period of time, so I can get a job, and my own place.  I know its
still a few months away, but the faster I get this sorted out, the faster
and easier this move will be.  So, if you or anyone you know would be able
to have me as a house guest for a short period of time, I would like to
hear from you.

I have a bunch of small little question I would like to ask, but I will
save that for when people write me back.  I am not sure if it is good to
send this kind of a message out to this mailing list, but I figured you
guys would be the best people to help me out..

Quick little rundown about me.   As I said, my name is Craig, and I am 20
years old.  Born in Hershey, PA, and have been a resident of NYC for the
past 8 months.  I have been DJing for a period of time now.  I spin all
kinds of music (All types of house, all types of trance (goa, soft, hard,
acid) some jungle, some gabber, some ambient.  I like everything. :)
In my time in NYC I have been working as an HTML designer, and that job
ended 2 weeks ago..

My reason for moving out there, is because I have heard the stories, and
all the stuff about the people out there, and with my type of lifestyle, I
think SF would be the place for me.

Well, I think this has letter has gotten long enough, so I look foward to
talking with you people very soon!!   Please write to me at fssc@panix.com
and I hope to hear from alot of you soon!!

Love,
Craig


   ---------------------------------------------------------------------
    Craig D. Israeloff              "If it were not for the last minute,
    fssc@panix.com                   Nothing would ever get done."

> years old.  Born in Hershey, PA, and have been a resident of NYC for the
> past 8 months.  I have been DJing for a period of time now.  I spin all
> kinds of music (All types of house, all types of trance (goa, soft, hard,
> acid) some jungle, some gabber, some ambient.  I like everything. :)
> In my time in NYC I have been working as an HTML designer, and that job
> ended 2 weeks ago..
> 
> My reason for moving out there, is because I have heard the stories, and
> all the stuff about the people out there, and with my type of lifestyle, I
> think SF would be the place for me.
>

Greetings =)

Just wanted to express our regrets to those of you that ended up or will
end up without tickets to Friends & Family this saturday. We had hoped we
could make some available in the east bay this week and were unfortunately
caught totally by surprise at how fast they went --  600 were gone in 48
hours! We had quite honestly thought we might have a hard time getting rid
of 600 in a week...

Too, I hope it's apparent that we made an honest effort to make tickets
available to people outside the immediate bay area. That doesn't mean we
(or you) succeeded, but we did try --  I posted mail order instructions on
the tuesday preceding the saturday on which we actually got the tickets. I
think this left *plenty* of time to get us an SASE by last saturday morning
(at which point there were still 600 left...) Strangely, I only received 3
requests that day...

In any event, when all is said and done, it's only a party, and there are
other good parties that night. So, wherever you end up, we wish you an
absolutely  wonderful time. Many thanks for your love and support.

take it easy
ethan

    "Keeping your VRML scenes under 100KB is an engineering challenge,
  but definitely doable," says Brian Behlendorf, chief technology officer
  with San Francisco-based Organic Online (http://www.organic.com).  VRML
  lets developers change the level of detail in a scene, so that as a user
  zooms in on an object, additional detail is downloasded from the server
  instead of being sent initially as a single large file, says Behlendorf,
  who manages the VRML mailing list on the Net.

  "The Scene Is Set for Multimedia on the Web"
  New Media magazine, November 1995, p. 49

Re: herbal e

>Well, generally it's a mix of several herbs, predominately ma >hung, also
>known as ephedra (a natural form of ephedrine).  So esentially >it's more
>like "herbal speed."  And for those of you who have tried it you >know that
>it feels a lot more like speed than E.  It also contains ginseng, >ginko,
>gotu kola, kola nut and other common herbs sold in health food >stores, just

This is all predominatly true.  I have tried herbal e a few time and never
had a bad time, however on the flip side I have never had a mind-blowing
night of uphoria, like the real thing.

Ginsig also elevates your heart level and is one of the predominat
ingredents. A friend of mine took 30 tablets of the Herbal E brand and like
speed, had the energy to be up all night and day.  He also spent most of his
time sweating even when he was sitting- a good sign your heart is pumping TOO
fast.

I independently sell products from Results Inc. and one of their products is
called New Attitude.  This is a health tonic that is a combination of 33
chinese herbs- the main being Siberian Ginsig.  I found that this product
does the same thing as herbal e but A LOT cheaper  (aprox. 35-40$ will last a
month if you took 1 tsp a day)  I also found that after a phun philled night
of groovin', movin' and partyin' this tonic provides a great recovery.   I
feel like a new man and ready to party another 24 hrs. the next day.

Hi All,

I've got a list of 15 SF Ravers seeking 30-62 tickets total.  My goal is to
at least get a pair out to each of them.  On the available tickets side,
I've got a range of 2 to 5 tickets available.  While it looks bleak, I
expect to see more extra tickets to break loose from their owners,
especially at the last minute.

Please, if you think you might have tickets at the last minute, don't be shy
about it.

If you want to get on the ticket exchange waiting list, send me email with
your name, the number of tickets you want, and a way I can contact you on
Sat, maybe even at the last minute.

If you have tickets you might make available at the last minute before the
party, email me or page/voice mail me (Grant) at: 415-406-2109.  If you
arrive at F&F with an extra ticket, look for me, I'll be glowing purple and
I'll be trying to hook people up with tickets all night.

Luv,

My computer tells me that on Wed, 25 Oct 1995, Niels P. Mayer opined,

> You've got to be kidding. Ben Hom is a major *MAJOR* asshole. Rather
> that taking starchild's patently bogus advice, you all should have
> heard some of BH's pathetic answers at that recent mayoral "debate". If
> the man has a brain, he gave no indication he makes any use of it. He's
> an idiot -- gives shallow answers to deep questions, and doesn't even
> realize that some questions exceed the depths of his pockets.
> 
> Read some of his literature. Oh, you make less than $200K/year? He
> ain't interested in you. You're not an entrepreneur or small business
> owner -- he ain't interested in you. You like to do anything that will
> make it difficult for businesses to operate (e.g. protests, sit-ins,
> being up past midnight (because you'll be too strung out for the
> boss-man to be whipping your ass when you get in to make him rich when
> your work day begins at 8AM).)
> 
> Like JSL said, Ben Hom is strictly about business. He isn't interested
> in "us" in any way shape or form. He wants to separate you the people
> from your money, and make sure that money ends up in the hands of the
> friends to which he'll dole out "privatization" boondoggles...
> 
> Privatization is a joke. In the moneyocracy that we're now running in,
> we get those currently in power to set up their friends or family to
> take over running a governent service as a business. But rather than
> being responsive to the customer, the new privatized business is only
> responsive to political forces that set them up in the first place.
> 
> Meanwhile the privatized business empowers those friends/family with
> money and clout to continue lobbying the govt to let them continue
> running and profiting from a government-funneled business. This further
> empowers the new wealthy owners of privatized businesses with more
> capital and contacts by which they can bribe politicians to allow them
> to further expand their business. (The #1 imperative of business is
> unchecked growth -- well past the point of need -- and unchecked
> amalgamation of power. So don't be surprised when the privatized
> services become an uncontrollable force that becomes a corrupt little
> mini-government on it's own. (General Electric, or Westinghouse for
> example.))
> 
> People like to tout the wonderfulness of "competition" involved in
> privatization, but they never take a deeper look into the politics of
> privatization, which are easily more corrupt than anything a
> centralized government service could come up with (the ability to "buy"
> gaggles of full-time lobbyists, the ability to "buy" politicians with
> gifts, bribes, campaign contributions, etc.). You see, there's not that
> much money in local government, therefore not that much power, nor
> motivation for people to grab more power. By tapping into private
> capital and mixing that into public government structures, that's when
> you tap into the real power that can properly destabilize democracy.
> (note the truism that power==money)... 
> 
> Give me a centralized organization with proper checks and balances over
> privatization any day of the week. Give me businesses hamstrung by rules
> and regulations over unchecked competition.
> 
> Oh, and if you doubt me, please take a look at our "privatized"
> military-industrial complex, or our privatized energy industry. Yeah,
> there's a bastion of competition and efficiency.
> 
> And unless you're a raving libertarian idiot, please don't vote for Ben
> Hom.
> 
> =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
> =  Niels Mayer   http://www.cyborganic.com/People/niels   mayer@netcom.com  =
> =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Dear Niels,

	Well, I guess you'll just have to consider me a raving 
libertarian idiot!  |)  As far as privatization, you've got it all wrong, 
but I don't feel like debating the question on the rave list.
	And I never claimed Hom was great -- although he's nowhere near as 
bad as you'd have us believe.  He only looks great compared to the other S.F. 
mayoral contenders...

	Hugzzz,

>>corporate entity, Hollywood, to pick up on the mystique of the rave scene

>Hollywood already tried, and it failed.  Back in 1993 there was a movie
>set in the rave scene (New York) called _Cyberstrom_.  It starred
>Christina Applegate (of "Married with Children") as a raver who supported
>herself by selling jewelry at parties.
>
>I never saw it (it was a huge flop), but I'm told that the story involved
>some guy who was a reclusive engineer type becoming homeless due to some
>evil plot and going to sleep in a warehouse...he wakes up in the middle of
>a rave, meets Applegate, and the two join forces to strike back against
>the evil plot that got him where he was.  In the process, Applegate and
>her happy raver friends teach him how to love, have fun, and not be such a
>recluse.
>
>So, once again, don't worry so much...to tell the truth, rave-as-fad has
>come and gone.  And if you are worried, just keep hooking up with people
>who you like, trust, and know can provide an honest good time.
>
>Laura

               I would totally love to see this movie! i remember seeing
posters for it coming back from a party actually :) (it was called
"Vibrations" though).  Now, HERE'S  a story about integrity: Originally the
movie makers shot some sequences of rave in new york but needed some more
footage so, of course, they come to montreal (where the american dollar is
like 1.40$ now :P) and they gather together all the promoters here and
pitch them this idea: "ok, we'll give you 50, 000 to throw a party, you get
all the djs and all that we just give you the money, the only thing is we
have to film at the party." So, everyone here watches some rough cuts of
this movie, laughs their asses off, and leaves.  It made me proud :)
        brad

        Hey craig, brian and all;
        Well, it may seem like a cheesy NE-Coast cliche but "i'm thinking
of moving to san francisco" too :) Actually i have a plane ticket bought to
visit and make some contacts from Dec 26th-Jan 6th (whassup for new years?
;).
        I dunno, there are a lot of reasons to go out to San Fran (and
leave Montreal) but i find it strange that so many people want to migrate
en masse to SF, why not Hoboken, NJ? ;) Well, i want to go because:

        -The economy in montreal sucks
        -There's a referendum that will decide whether Quebec will separate
from Canada or not on Monday (and, regardless of the outcome, the economy
will still be screwed, the canadian dollar is now worth .60 US. :P)
        -san fran is warm, montreal is not (well, in the winter at least)
        -san fran has a better context for art/tech/computers/graphics jobs
than montreal
        -didn't the term "free love" come out of san fran? ;)
        -i love happy house (just kidding)
        -west coast people seem to me a bit warmer than people on the
NE-coast. and i like happy people :)
        -i want to be known as the person who brought ambient gabber to san
fran :)

        are there any other reasons why san fran is so great? i just keep
thinking about a culture and a city that has been affected to its roots by
numerous cultural influences that make it interesting.
        peace,
                brad

Subject: Fwd: (Fwd) bricklayer's accident report (fwd)
Date: Thu, 26 Oct 95 08:54:07 -0500
From: Emily Robbins <erobbins@borland.com>
X-Mailer: E-Mail Connection v2.5.03

Kinda sick thing to be laughing at...but oh, well...I still thought it was
funny.. ;^)
Emily

> This guy evidently watched way too many Wile E. Coyote cartoons during
> his childhood.  Meep, Meep!
>
> >  This is a bricklayer's accident report that was printed in the
> >  newsletter of the English equivalent of the Workers' Compensation
> >  Board.  So here, thanks to John Sedgwick, is this Bricklayer's
> >  report.
> >
> >>  Dear Sir;
> >>
> >>  I am writing in response to your request for additional
information in
> >>  Block #3 of the accident reporting form.  I put "Poor Planning" as
the
> >>  cause of my accident.  You asked for a fuller explanation and I
trust
> >>  the following details will be sufficient.
> >>
> >>  I am a bricklayer by trade.  On the day of the accident, I was
working
> >>  alone on the roof of a new six-story building.  When I completed
my
> >>  work, I found I had some bricks left over which when weighed later
> >>  were found to weigh 240 lbs.  Rather than carry the bricks down by
> >>  hand, I decided to lower them in a barrel by using a pulley which
was
> >>  attached to the side of the building at the sixth floor.
> >>
> >>  Securing the rope at ground level, I went up to the roof, swung
the
> >>  barrel out and loaded the bricks into it.  Then I went down and
untied
> >>  the rope, holding it tightly to insure a slow descent of the 240
lbs
> >>  of bricks.  You will note on  the accident reporting form that my
> >>  weight is 135 lbs.
> >>
> >>  Due to my surprise at being jerked off the ground so suddenly, I
lost
> >>  my presence of mind and forgot to let go of the rope.  Needless to
> >>  say, I proceeded at a rapid rate up the side of the building.
> >>
> >>  In the vicinity of the third floor, I met the barrel which was now
> >>  proceeding downward at an equally impressive speed.  This explains
the
> >>  fractured skull, minor abrasions and the broken collarbone, as
listed
> >>  in Section 3, accident reporting form.
> >>
> >>  Slowed only slightly, I continued my rapid ascent, not stopping
until
> >>  the fingers of my right hand were two knuckles deep into the
pulley
> >>  which I mentioned in Paragraph 2 of this correspondence.
Fortunately
> >>  by this time I had regained my presence of mind and was able to
hold
> >>  tightly to the rope, in spite of the excruciating pain I was now
> >>  beginning to experience.
> >>
> >>  At approximately the same time, however, the barrel of bricks hit
the
> >>  ground-and the bottom fell out of the barrel.  Now devoid of the
> >>  weight of the bricks, the barrel weighed approximately 50 lbs.
> >>
> >>  I refer you again to my weight.  As you might imagine, I began a
rapid
> >>  descent down the side of the building.  In the vicinity of the
third
> >>  floor, I met the barrel coming up.  This accounts for the two
> >>  fractured ankles, broken tooth and severe lacerations of my legs
and
> >>  lower body.
> >>
> >>  Here my luck began to change slightly.  The encounter with the
barrel
> >>  seemed to slow me enough to lessen my injuries when I fell into
the
> >>  pile of bricks and fortunately only three vertebrae were cracked.
> >>
> >>  I am sorry to report, however, as I lay there on the pile of  bricks,
> >>  in pain, unable to move and watching the empty barrel six stories > >>
 above me, I again lost my composure and presence of mind and let  go of
> >>  the rope.

Hi ----ABOUT            -I N T E R E A T

Hay Designers----
Don't Forget our Competition Deadline-For Electronic Tables.

D E A D L I N E ::::on Nov 1, 1995


Here is the entryform if you don't have it-

=46ORMAT (We can Accept JPEG___________Name OF Server____________NO oF Files=

OR NUMBER OF SKETCHES BY POST_____________________________________________


SENT BY EMAIL OR POST?_______________DATE________________________________

SIGNED__________________________________


PRESS RELEASE-


INTER-EAT-
A Competition for the Design of Tables incorporating Computer Terminals and
internet access.

The entry form it is available on the Web at
www.uni-karlsruhe.de/~zkm
Go to Homepage and Click on News-Intereat comes up then you can find the
Entry form to download.

WHAT IS INTEREAT-INTER-EAT-
A Competition for the Design of Tables incorporating Computer Terminals and
internet access. It is an exciting Competition organized through the Net,
for Industrial Designers, Artists and Students from around the world. The
emphasis should be on creativity, functionality, outstanding design and
technical innovation.
The ZKM | Media Museum in Karlsruhe is planning an permanent Internet Cafe
called 'Salon Digital' as an integral part of the ZKM Museum Cafe in 1997.
(Some people may have encountered our successful prototype at the
MultiMediale 4)
The cafe will be designed, with special attention to the relationship
between sensuous (eating, drinking, talking) and digital communication.
One of the major problems is to invent a table which can incorporate in the
design, a "food and spill proof computer terminal".
The aim of the competition is to invent a design which combines a special
shaped computer monitor and keyboard under the surface of the table,
although other inventive proposals are encouraged.
Each table should stress the virtues of communication, both real and virtual=

From: David Kilimnik <davidk@nature.Berkeley.EDU>

Subject: Re: herbal e
In-Reply-To: <199510260257.TAA26349@jeeves.usfca.edu>

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello-
	About herbal e: don't buy it.  It's a rip-off, and no doubt the 
guy who makes it is turning a huge profit (although he does seem to have 
a big advertising campaign).   Herbal e itself is not a bad eperience, 
and luckily its an experience that can be had for a fraction the price by 
going down to your local herb/vitamin store and selecting a concoction 
marketed to increase energy that has the same ingredients (ma huang, gotu 
kola, ginseng, guarana, gingko, cayenne, etc...).  One particular product 
that we've used costs about $15 for 60 pills.  About 2-3 of these can 
give you the energy to jump 'til dawn.   The discovery of this stuff has 
really been a gift, since there are those times when you want to avoid 
certain substances.   Sometimes you just don't want an overwhelming 
experience, and you never want to do anything that would turn you colder 
towards others and/or make you depressed the next day.  These herbal 
stimulants are really not herbal speed or herbal e. They give you all of the 
energy (well, almost), and none of the fall-out.   They don't give you 
any emotional release or intense euphoria.   But if you just want to 
groove and sweat all night, you'll have the gas...---dave

On Wed, 25 Oct 1995, Jake Reichert wrote:

> >>>KGO 810 reported this morning that the FDA was looking into the 
> >>>'Herbal Ecstasy' 
> >>>stuff being sold in stores and advertised as being safe. 
> >>
> >>When "herbal ecstacy" first appeared, my friend Mark went to talk to the
> >person 
> >>selling it to find out what was in it so he'd know what he'd be getting into.
> >>
> >>*The personal selling it wouldn't say, not even in general terms.*
> 
> Well, generally it's a mix of several herbs, predominately ma hung, also
> known as ephedra (a natural form of ephedrine).  So esentially it's more
> like "herbal speed."  And for those of you who have tried it you know that
> it feels a lot more like speed than E.  It also contains ginseng, ginko,
> gotu kola, kola nut and other common herbs sold in health food stores, just
> in much larger amounts.  It is quite possible that many people can have
> adverse reactions to any of these.  Ma hung accelerates heart rates a lot,
> so of course there's danger in that, and many people have allergic reactions
> to Kola nut especially.  It is known to induce heart attacks in some people,
> even in small doses.  I know that I personally have some kind of reaction to
> one of these; I have some ginseng and ginko vitamins that contain some of
> these herbs, and occasionally, depending on what I've just eaten, it causes
> me to get red, flushed, hot, and itchy.  Not pleasant.
> 
> Hope that all helps.
> 
> Jake
> 
>

On Thu, 26 Oct 1995, ecto wrote:

> 
> > >I can't help but wonder how long it will take that other
> >>corporate entity, Hollywood, to pick up on the mystique of the rave scene
> >>in an attempt to capitalize on yet another alterna-hip subculture...
> >
> >Hollywood already tried, and it failed.  Back in 1993 there was a movie
> >set in the rave scene (New York) called _Cyberstrom_.  It starred
> >Christina Applegate (of "Married with Children") as a raver who supported
> >herself by selling jewelry at parties.
> >
> >I never saw it (it was a huge flop), but I'm told that the story involved
> >some guy who was a reclusive engineer type becoming homeless due to some
> >evil plot and going to sleep in a warehouse...he wakes up in the middle of
> >a rave, meets Applegate, and the two join forces to strike back against
> >the evil plot that got him where he was.  In the process, Applegate and
> >her happy raver friends teach him how to love, have fun, and not be such a
> >recluse.
> >
> >So, once again, don't worry so much...to tell the truth, rave-as-fad has
> >come and gone.  And if you are worried, just keep hooking up with people
> >who you like, trust, and know can provide an honest good time.
> >
> >Laura
> 
>                I would totally love to see this movie! i remember seeing

> "Vibrations" though).  Now, HERE'S  a story about integrity: Originally the
> movie makers shot some sequences of rave in new york but needed some more
> footage so, of course, they come to montreal (where the american dollar is
> like 1.40$ now :P) and they gather together all the promoters here and
> pitch them this idea: "ok, we'll give you 50, 000 to throw a party, you get
> all the djs and all that we just give you the money, the only thing is we
> have to film at the party." So, everyone here watches some rough cuts of
> this movie, laughs their asses off, and leaves.  It made me proud :)

The Bay Area is sooooo wonderful.  I've been here for almost five years, 
and although I may have to leave, I hope to come back some day.  I grew 
up in rural California (yes, it exists) in a town of 60 people (NO, I AM 
NOT KIDDING) and it really sucked.  Can you say REDNECK MENTALITY?  I 
hide every time I go home to see my folks, so I don't have to see people 
from high school.  You should try to have grown up there, and then you'd really 
appreciate the Bay Area.
  
Food for Thought,

kc

Hello Brothers and Sisters,

Yesterday, while driving home on the 101N back into The CIty, I saw the unseeable (at least I had never seen this before),the sign as you enter SF from the 101N that says "South San Francisco The Industrial City"  was changed to "South San
Frandisco The Idustril City".  I laughed so hard I cried.  I figured it had to be someone familiar with our dance/rave culture, since that term is used so often to describe our city.

Hope it's still there when I go home today!

SF IS DA BOMB!!!!!!!!!

JSL

I heard lat night on the fairly conservative channel 4 that
Roberta Actenberg is basically tied with both Jordan (hiss)
and Brown (less hiss, but still hiss).  In fact, channel 4
even said that the two most likely outcomes were Actenberg
winning or Brown winning, but they said both of these were
more likely than Jordan winning.  They were saying that the
most dramatic surge have been for Actenberg supporters, and
place a reasonable likely on her being the next mayor of
San Francisco.  I personally think she would be by far the
best, particularly in terms of making P.G.&E., Viacom and
other downtown business interests (who get away with out
even paying taxes under Jordan) pay their fair share and
stick to their contracts (another thing Jordan let them get
away with was not sticking to the terms of their contracts).
Brown, because he has so many large downtown business clients,
would not as likely enforce this stuff like Actenberg would,
who has no similar conflict of interest and has consistently
shown her constituents support in her voting patterns.

Oh well, I'll just go out and say it, since I've come so
close already... both Actenberg and Hallinan, particularly if
you *really* want accountability and change!


========================================
Reverend Jack Diamond

Church of the Everlasting
Planet Earth

Hi there:

O.K.  I was avoiding using the name of the product because i wanted to be 
clear that I have no affiliation with its manufacturer, and have no 
interest in its promotion, except that, of course i want to pass on the 
word about something that works great (for me) to others who could benefit.
So, that being said, the name of the stuff I've had success with is "up 
your gas" (tee hee).  There are numerous other energy mixtures out there, 
e.g. "happy camper" and others (Rok: care to fill in some blanks?), but i 
think the main concern is to get something containing ma huang.  So, hey, 
have fun, but be careful-- this stuff does apparently speed up heart 
rate, and I've even heard, in a very indirect and unreliable way, that 
it could be worse for your body than e (which feels pretty damn good 
to my body).  I would think it wouldn't be a bad idea to talk to a doctor 
about this stuff if you think you might induldge regularly.  
	You can find this type of stuff at most herb stores, whole foods 
markets, GNC, and just about any place that has a big vitamin selection.
	
					Bounce well, -dave.

> --M
> --------------------------------------
> Date: 10/26/95 11:00 AM
> To: Mark Camp
> From: David Kilimnik
> Hello-
> 	About herbal e: don't buy it.  It's a rip-off, and no doubt the 
> guy who makes it is turning a huge profit (although he does seem to have 
> a big advertising campaign).   Herbal e itself is not a bad eperience, 
> and luckily its an experience that can be had for a fraction the price by 
> going down to your local herb/vitamin store and selecting a concoction 
> marketed to increase energy that has the same ingredients (ma huang, gotu 
> kola, ginseng, guarana, gingko, cayenne, etc...).  One particular product 
> that we've used costs about $15 for 60 pills.  About 2-3 of these can 
> give you the energy to jump 'til dawn.   The discovery of this stuff has 
> really been a gift, since there are those times when you want to avoid 
> certain substances.   Sometimes you just don't want an overwhelming 
> experience, and you never want to do anything that would turn you colder 
> towards others and/or make you depressed the next day.  These herbal 
> stimulants are really not herbal speed or herbal e. They give you all of the 
> energy (well, almost), and none of the fall-out.   They don't give you 
> any emotional release or intense euphoria.   But if you just want to 
> groove and sweat all night, you'll have the gas...---dave
> 
> On Wed, 25 Oct 1995, Jake Reichert wrote:
> 
> > >>>KGO 810 reported this morning that the FDA was looking into the 
> > >>>'Herbal Ecstasy' 
> > >>>stuff being sold in stores and advertised as being safe. 
> > >>
> > >>When "herbal ecstacy" first appeared, my friend Mark went to talk to the
> > >person 
> > >>selling it to find out what was in it so he'd know what he'd be getting
> into.
> > >>
> > >>*The personal selling it wouldn't say, not even in general terms.*
> > 
> > Well, generally it's a mix of several herbs, predominately ma hung, also
> > known as ephedra (a natural form of ephedrine).  So esentially it's more
> > like "herbal speed."  And for those of you who have tried it you know that
> > it feels a lot more like speed than E.  It also contains ginseng, ginko,
> > gotu kola, kola nut and other common herbs sold in health food stores, just
> > in much larger amounts.  It is quite possible that many people can have
> > adverse reactions to any of these.  Ma hung accelerates heart rates a lot,
> > so of course there's danger in that, and many people have allergic reactions
> > to Kola nut especially.  It is known to induce heart attacks in some people,
> > even in small doses.  I know that I personally have some kind of reaction to
> > one of these; I have some ginseng and ginko vitamins that contain some of
> > these herbs, and occasionally, depending on what I've just eaten, it causes
> > me to get red, flushed, hot, and itchy.  Not pleasant.
> > 
> > Hope that all helps.
> > 
> > Jake
> > 
> >

>BEGIN QUOTE FROM Jake Reichert:
>: 
>: It's okay to celebrate with a nice, legal
>: drug (although he doesn't seem to recognize it as such, which is another
>: plague of the world), but _not_ with those bad illegal ones.
>: 
>
>Actually, to a majority of people, this is exactly correct.  Civil
>disobedience is a choice few really make.  

I guess I wouldn't have a problem with it if people really stayed away from
drugs because they were illegal.  That's a choice I can respect, even if I
don't necessarily agree.  However, my experience has been that most people
believe drugs are illegal _because_ they are harmful, so if alcohol &
nicotine are legal they must not be harmful.  It's sad, but true, that there
are people who believe this.

Jake

>>Okay, this pissed me off more than anything in the article.  I don't want to
>>get back into the whole beer vs. drugs thing, but it's hipocracy like this
>>that I find so incredibly absurd.  It's okay to celebrate with a nice, legal
>

>*australian*. most people are 80% water. australians are 80% beer. it's just
>the way it is (unfortunately).

I know.  And I think that's part of the problem is that beer is accepted
simply because of culture.  It's been around for a while, _and_ transplanted
westerners happen to be the dominant cultural body in Australia.  You know,
if Native Americans had conquered Europe 500 years ago, he would be saying
"when I was young, people would celebrate a new job by going out and
lighting up a few bowls with some mates, not taking drugs", in response to
the article "TEEN DIES AT ALL-NIGHT DANCE PARTY AFTER CONSUMING ALCOHOL."

Just a thought, 

Mr. Jake

Cc: howard@cats.ucsc.edu

Precedence: bulk


i had to be dragged kicking and screaming to my first rave.
it was going to be lame. it was going to be a bunch of smoking,
self-conscious, pretentious club-goers. i was so wrong.
the community, the parties and the people i have all found
to be fairly amazinng. not to mention the music- the harder
faster and crunchier the better!  being the nerdy anthropologist
that i am, i am writing my thesis on "Rave as Ritual, Creating
Community in a PostModern Society" pedantic title, yes, but
i have a serious commitment to do it justice. not to mention
my fieldwork is going to be a blast (if you see a girl with
a cast on her leg and pad in hand at fandf, that's me).

as members of this community, i'm asking you to contribute your ideas.
some things i'm interested in: trance and dance, the history of raves,
the drugs, the vibe, the media and the police (the Institutions)
if there are any dj's out there who'd share their thoughts with me, i'd
love it.

please mail me: howard@cats.ucsc.edu

i'm looking forward to seeing many of you at fandf. i missed the last
one (but was there in spirit) because i had a full leg cast on 
(rollerblading accident). maybe i'll even get to dance a little *grin*

eden

Well, I wasn't trying to make any big fuss or anything.  Let's put it
this way, Harrisburg ain't as bad as some of the rusty old towns
around there in PA.  They're just closing Bethlehem Steel for the final
time, it's the end of an American era in that region.  They have
difficult problems but they're Americans, hell, they're *people* too
there, and even if they have to escape like Craig (and so many others),
they bring part of that experience to us as well.

geographically yrs,
phred

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Oct 26 15:30:54 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id PAA13064; Thu, 26 Oct 1995 15:30:54 -0700
Received: from mail04.mail.aol.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id PAA13057; Thu, 26 Oct 1995 15:30:51 -0700
From: MsPhink@aol.com
Received: by mail04.mail.aol.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id SAA21926 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Thu, 26 Oct 1995 18:30:17 -0400
Date: Thu, 26 Oct 1995 18:30:17 -0400
Message-ID: <951026183012_90495657@mail04.mail.aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: My history-long!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello everyone!
Just wanted to write a little about myself before I start posting stuff all
over the place! I hope this doesn't ramble on too long.
I have been going to raves/events/what have you in the sf area for about a
year now. Prior to that I was very involved in the DC/Baltimore scene for two
years. My relationship with raves has been sort of rocky. When I first
started going, it was like I had found God himself. I was SO happy to have
found this whole culture that I really felt I belonged to. Our scene was
small enough that all of the regulars knew each other, and it was like being
like part of a family (awww, ain't that sweet?)

Somewhere along the line things started to get out of control. I don't mean
to say anything bad about the scene out there, but my involvement in it was
getting crazy. I was spiraling downward into more drug use, and I started to
have doubts about whether these ravers I knew were really my friends. Also, I
felt as though the quality of events was on a decline. I then began to feel
as though I would die or be trapped in the rave scene if I didn't get out of
it somehow. About this time, my boyfriend (now hubby) got a job offer in
California, so we decided to bail and move out here. Before we left, we went
to one final event which truly sucked for me. I thought the energy was very
low, and we were saying good-bye to all of these people we knew who (it
seemed) couldn't give a shit less what happened to us. Brrrr. I was feeling
really negative at this time. I also said some nasty things about ravers in
my zine, HAZMAT which I now regret, but it was how I felt at the time and I
was trying to be honest.

After we moved out here, I had grave doubts as to whether I wanted to go to
any more raves. I really did a lot of soul-searching at this time. Finally
what brought me back into it was the love of the music and the spirit of the
rave which I had found at the beginning. I missed it! I posted a message on
alt.raves and this really nice person (whom some of you know as Sy) answered
it, and invited me to come out with him & his friends. 

My first SF rave was Kundolini, last year! I must say I was very skeptical at
first about the scene out here. But after meeting so many nice people, I have
been transformed! Also going to a lot of great events helped. Esp. F&F,
Harmony, Sunset, and a little party called Syntonic which my friends threw.
After almost a whole year of being out here, I am finally READY to be a
positive part of the scene. I know a lot of my newer friends think I am
weird, since I am still a bit jaded & cynical. It's just that I'm not so
naive as to think that the rave is some fairy-tale world, where nothing bad
ever happens and everyone hugs each other. 

But having said that bit of nastiness, I am really glad to see quite a few
older people out there (I am 27), and a lot of people who are genuinely
concerned with having a rave "community". I am going to try meeting some more
people now, and to give back some of the love and positive energy which so
many have given me.

Hope to meet some of you soon-I have my sfraves badge from Wayne so I am all
set!

MsPhink

   Friday, Stompy has the lineup and track record to be guaranteed to be
   bumpin'. On Saturday, Funky Tekno Tribe is the only one-off event I
   know of that you can still get tickets to ;). Sunset might be back on
   Sunday, and on Monday night the Gardening Club hits its one-year
   birthday. Tuesday is Halloween, and Wednesday, if you're still with
   me, is Come-Unity. Whew!

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 9pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 -
       Progressive house, acid jazz and "alternative" music views. (415)
       281-3377.
     * Sunday night mid-3am - "No UFO's" w/Adam from Silent Records KZSU
       90.1 Stanford
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday noon-3pm - House and techno w/DJ Unknown and guests - KZSU
       90.1 (Stanford)
     * Thursdays 9:30pm-midnight - "Aurora Borealis" w/DJ Seth. Ambient,
       experimental, ethereal, acid-trance-techno, industrial and
       trip-hop on KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Saturday night - "Saturday Night Spin Out" w/Ronnie Libido. Trip
       hop, Jungle, Ambient, Experimental Sounds. 10pm-2am. KFJC 89.7 -
       Los Altos Hills

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

     [ Doug and Phred suggest going as "ravers" ]
     
     Ohhh, brilliant idea!
     
     I used to have a fondness for bike gloves, fuschia eye liner, "manic 
     panic" hair dye, glow sticks, dangly earrings, purple sunglasses, and 
     lots of stuff hanging around my neck (badges, mini flashlight, weird 
     jewlrey).  
     
     I should go dig all that stuff out.  Maybe I can even find my hot-pink 
     tie-dye denim shorts.  Actually, they wouldn't fit anymore. :-(
     
     And then there was the napsack full of things (toys, kaleidoscope, 
     more clothes for when I got sweaty, bored, or cold, fig newtons, amino 
     acid tablets, extra toilet paper) that I'd carry around, always highly 
     amusing to rummage through when my mind was "rummaged" itself, so to 
     speak.
     
     I don't know which ex-pat East Coasters are reading this, but I still 
     have that grey blanket with the black flowers on it -- you know, 
     Laura's infamous "rave blanket."  I'm sure Rishad knows the one I 
     mean.  Many a NE-Raver crashed on or curled up in this :-)
     
     10 points for anyone who brings diffraction grating.  20 for a pocket 
     laser.
     
     Laura
     
     P.S. If anyone out there actually *remembers* seeing me with/in any of 
     this, drop me a line (privately ) :-) :-)

For those SF ravers who are a bit out of touch with styles other than 
Deep House and any other House style which I love to death myself!!

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Thu, 26 Oct 1995 17:48:44 -0700
From: Chuen-Pei Ng <teknosis@ucla.edu>
To: socal-raves@ucsd.edu
Subject: Jungle 101 at Socal-Raves University 

Alright Groodies,

I will begin a series of jungle lessons =) from today ...
The first lessen will be given by our guest lecturer DJ Casper (Julian
Carow) from Boston who defines the jungle/happy hardcore music as the
following:

UK Hardcore is a style of fast (around 165 beats per minute) underground
dance music which is based on the use of a "breakbeat". Hardcore is very
diverse and has many different sounds.

Basically there is Jungle (a.k.a. Drum & Bass) and there is Happy Hardcore
(a.k.a. 4-Beat). Although the similarities between the two are disappearing,
both stem from the same '91/'92 Hardcore years. In 1992 rave music reached
its commercial height with many happy breakbeat piano tunes being quite
popular. In 1993, Hardcore went back underground with a style called
Darkness which featured eerie sounds. By 1994 Jungle and Drum & Bass were
emerging with more complex beats and basslines. Dancehall and R&B samples
became more influential. At the same time a newer style of hardcore was
emerging called Happy Hardcore aka 4-Beat which was a throwback to the days
of '92, with pianos and happy techno sounds. Besides having a breakbeat,
most Happy Hardcore trakcs today also have a 4/4 beat over the top as well
which gives it an added kick (hence the name 4-Beat).

Today both Happy Hardcore and Jungle are highly popular in England and
around the world. In North America Jungle is most popular in Toronto and
Chicago.

JUNGLE / DRUM & BASS

Jungle is very complex music that ranges from heavily ragga and dancehall
influenced tunes to deeper melodic tracks called "intelligent". Ragga was
very big this past winter and has pretty much died out at the moment.
Currently intelligent drum & bass is my favorite style. Some of my favorite
UK Jungle DJs are Hype, Rap, Fabio, Phantasy, Kenny Ken, Darren Jay, and LTJ
Bukem.

"Jungle is England's culture. England never had a culture before Jungle
started. Jungle in England is what Hip Hop is for the USA. But at the end of
the day, we didn't make it just to be English, we made it so that the whole
world would appreciate it and so far we haven't done too badly. Jungle is
gonna be a universal thing, different styles are put together and people can
relate to that."
-Kenny Ken (Eternity #31)

HAPPY HARDCORE / 4-BEAT

In addition to Jungle, there is Happy Hardcore / 4-Beat which has less
complex beats and often has a 4/4 beat along with it. Pianos and female
vocals reign supreme in Happy Hardcore which makes you want to smile and
throw your hands in the air. It is HUGE in England. Some of my favorite UK
Happy Hardcore DJs are Sy, Slipmatt, Dougal, Vibes, and of course the DJ
Seduction.

Unfortunately Happy Hardcore is not very popular in North America. Its
counterpart Jungle is much more popular here although nowhere near as
popular as house and trance. The few DJs who do spin it are Phil Free Art
(Chicago), Intensity (New Mexico), Ruff Rida (Toronto), and Casper
(Boston/Chicago).

Stay tuned for tomorrow's lesson given by JJ Jellybean (Want to know what's
Amen??? that will be in tomorrow's lesson)...

May the force be with you ...

--Chuen

==============================================================================
Chuen's pick of the week:  RMB, Love EP, Brainstorm Label

"The first duty of love is to listen." - Paul Tillich
==============================================================================

Date: Thu, 26 Oct 1995 18:30:24 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: tony@xinet.COM (Tony Rotundo)
Subject: Article in The Face about E and Raves
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

'Sup!?

There's an interestiong article in October issue of The Face, a U.K.
publication covering music,a nd music scenes, etc.

There's an interesting article on E, and an article on Nicholas Saunders
the author of "E is for Ecstasy".

The article on E called "E Ten Years on the Pill" relates to SFRaves
because it highlights a very cool "illegal but government-sanctioned Safe
House Project in Amsterdam."  Essential, what they do is test drugs for
people.  In fact, they set up a table at raves (parties, what have you) and
people line up to have what they have just purchased from a dealer tested
for it's approximate chemical make-up.  That is, "To identify one, they run
the chemical test, measure its circumference and depth, then note its
colour (sic:) and markings.  They have lists of known specimens, pages and
pages of them..., with the details compressed into a 13-digit code.  When
they find one which corresponds exactly, they know what they're dealing
with."  It goes on about people tossing tabs if they don't get a match,
etc.  One very, very cool thing mentioned is the curbing of bad hits at a
party:  "As soon as anything dodgy is discovered, he has the authority to
stop the music and make an annoucement, advising people to identify and
eject the dealer."

Hmmm...that would certainly make one think twice about selling bad shit, eh?

Anyway, the article goes into E and raving and has interesting side-bars on
the history of E, raving and an a neat chart showing the history of
increased BPM through out the last ten years, i.e., "1985 Rare groove, Jazz
funk, uptempo R&B 92-96bpm...1989 Rave anthems 124bpm...1994 Gabber breaks
big in Holland and Scotland 180-200BPM...Also Moby's extraordinarily bad
"Thousand", at 1,000BPM 1993."

It's an interesting issue, and if you don't want to pay the $5-6 for it, I
recommend you read it in the magazine store.  The Face isn't easy to find
(I got mine in Seattle), but I know it's out there.

Peace ya' all!

Tony

FYI, to the caffeine junkies: -A toxic dose of caffeine is 1gram...
                                roughly the equivalent of 5-6 cups of coffee
                                Toxicity= Rapid heartbeat, gastrointestinal
                                          disturbances, anxiety, insomnia
                                          and more...
                              -Lethal dose= 10grams (about 50 cups)

unfortunately my source was not up on the 90's coffee conscious culture, 
so the above figures are not applicable to anything else but the average, 
watery american brew...

On Wed, 25 Oct 1995, Jake Reichert wrote:

> 
> As far as ketamine goes:  It's pretty strong, from what I've read.  Only try
> it in a safe environment with people you trust, at least at first.  I've
> never tried it, but it's up there with things like scopalamine.  About the
> only drug that's readily available that has similar effects is DXM, found in
> several brands of over-the-counter cough syrup.  Basically the same effects
> but not as pronounced.  More than anything, it's a narcotic (although it's
> sometimes called a dissociative).  Note on the cough syrup thing:  since

As far as Ketamine (Ketalar), it is in the same class as PCP, being 
considered a psychedelic anesthetic. I've heard that it can be smoked, 
but the full effects occur via the injection route, in which case it 
produces a state of dissociation, loss of awareness of current time and 
space. Along with PCP, it is the only psychedelic that is 
self-administered by monkeys, ie- it probably stimulates brain reward 
pathways, ie- it is the only psychedelic that seems to be addictive,
and highly so. This observation seems to be corroborate by individual
experiences that I have read about. High doses induce a state of stupor 
or coma, massive overdoses are potentially lethal, may cause seizures, 
and can have as aftereffects states of confusion and delusion that may 
last for as long as two weeks. Sounds like fun, no?

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Fri, 27 Oct 1995 10:10:55 -0700 (PDT)
From: Eric Snowdeal III <snowdeal@elwha.evergreen.edu>
To: David Ginsberg <ginsberg@uclink4.berkeley.edu>
Cc: Paul Anthony Rose <trose@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Re: Vasopressin (fwd)

Well, I'm not a doctor and I don't even play one on T.V., but  I 
really don't think inhaling vasopressin would be a good idea - 
vasopressin is also known as antidiuretic hormone, and it's released by 
the posterier pituitary gland after recieving signals from the 
hypothalamus.  Vasopressin acts primarily on the kidneys promoting water 
retension (hence it being known as an antidiuretic), and it also promotes 
the constriction of blood vessels.  Both of these actions increase blood 
pressure.  Normally the release of vasopressin in under tight 
negative-feedback regulation, and is released only in >small< 
quantities.  In this case, more would not be better, because of increased 
stress on blood vessels.  As with all things biological, this is not to 
say that vasopressin doesn't also do other things, although I've never 
heard it in the same breath as memory - but keep in mind that its primary 
action is on the kidney which cycles more blood that you want to know, and 
contains lots of little blood vessels, which are sensitive to increases in 
blood pressure.  Renal failure and blood in the urine isn't my idea of a 
fun time.

Valete.

-E

sequoia1@ix.netcom.com (Chris Chervin) wrties:
>My girlfriend is in a 
>drug education class and the teacher recommends saving >money by buying 
>a bottle of mini-thins.  You'll get the same high for a fraction >of the
cost!

Some one I met at a club and used to be friends with smashed up mini-thins
and caped them;  claming they were speed or something. They are basically
caffien pills like No-Doze.  They help clear the lung pasages and increase
the heart rate- ment for asthma sufferers..   If you take 5-10 you will stay
awake a long time.  I had friends smoke a J or two or three and then pop
these to stay awake...   the effect is like a cane blunt in a way..
I personal didn't see the point in it and even Mini- thins ( sold at almost
any gas station) can still be dangerous if not take seriously.
    By the  way he eventually got caught and went to jail for a month for
pretending to sell illeagal substances.

>Does anybody have solid info on the dangers of ephedrine? I 
>am sure you are finding it mixed heavily with what is being >sold as E in
the Calif. 

Actually, I am pretty sure that ephedrine is a precursor to Ectascy. That's
why the sales of it are now closely monitored by the federal government. 

The only bad side effect I have noticed (from max-alerts) is they make your
lungs hurt the next day (because it is a broncho-dilator), and when it wears
off you feel SOOOOO tired. I would definately not take more than 3 at once.

Also, max-alerts are great for people with allergies and asthma, they make
you feel much better for opening up those breathing tubes. 

-MPhink

the making,  "E-mail Withdrawl for Dummies".
