like that Russian astronaut that stayed in outer space for a year and when
he landed there was no Russia, anymore.  It had broken up into more pieces
than a Ravensburger puzzle.  

I can relate to this guy.  Let me elaborate,  I leave from Canada tomorrow
for SF and I return next Wed.  Anyways, on Monday, Quebec (our francophone)
province will vote on seperation(!) from Canada.  Monday will absolutely
change the face of Canada one way or another.  

Do you know what Canada needs?? A cross-country rave!  One big heaving love
nest of trance, house and assorted phat beats would cure any talk of
"distinct society" or "distinct culture".  What would be better than one big
group hug of love and unity.  I think the Feds should make it mandatory for
the whole country to rave and in fact they should subsidize everybody's
purchase of rave tickets, candy, etc.  In fact, the feds would probably make
certain promoters public like the Canada Post(or US Mail).  Imagine FnF as a
standard cross-country party where everybody would be obligated to go.  On
second thought it would probably take all the fun out of it.

Just ranting...  

See you soon!!!!
Yippie!!!!
Over and out!!!!
John

On Wed, 25 Oct 1995, Jake Reichert wrote:

> Regarding these two:
> Vasopressin is definitely a smart drug.  I can't remember exactly what it
> does, but I recall from my reading it is one of the more interesting ones.
> I think it comes in a spray bottle and you inhale it nasally every few
> hours, but I could be mixing it up with something else.  Can anyone help me
> out with this?

	I have done vaopressin a couple times, and you are correct in 
it's description.  It is naturally a brain hormone.  Certain drugs 
create a depleation of it, namely marijuana and lsd, maybe others, I'm 
not sure.  Taking it when you don't need it does little to nothing, you 
might feel a buzz for 2-3 minutes, but is definetly not worth the $1 
per hit cost.  BUT after a trip or an intense smoking session a hit of 
vasopressin will instantly revive you from that dopey state.  Also in 
combination with marijuana is nice, crystal clear awake highs.

	info assimilated from H20listic brain soups.

	e

nice...I had I guess about a half of what I would want to takeif I was to

of coffee and I started chewing on a tablespoon or so of the stuff...

minutes...as I was sitting in my cs lecture I couldnt stop my leg from 
bouncing up and down! I gave the same amount to a friend and she said 
that the sky seemed more there?

Hello again,
	well I guess that I am kind of still up... and I figured that it 
was time for me to stop being rude and introduce myself as it seems that 
I am having lots of fun in this list!. My name is Tony...I am a student 
at berkeley studying an independant major combining aspects from computer 
science, math, philosophy, and cognitive science. I am interested in how 
the mind works, AI, cool technological things, and I love music...I have 
gone through aloty of musical styles from industrial to pop, grateful 
dead, etc...one common theme in my love for music has always been for the 
more trippy spacey ambient sounds like skinny puppy, GD's space and more 
recently irresistable force, aphex twin, Banco, and children of the bong 
are some of my favorites. and of course dancing!
	On the technological side, one thing that I love that about the rave 
scene is the use of technology inb a way that is not purely business 
oriented. I am really excited that people are able to make music and 
express themselves more easily than ever before with technology. Not to 
say that it is easy to make good music( I am still trying to figure out 
what to do with the samples that i just learned to take through my cd-rom 
on my computer!), but accessible.
	One of my most recent things that I have n\been thinking about is 
that is there really an emergent global culture arising through the 
internet and through rave culture. Things like Banco De Gaia's music 
which is so multicultural, Mod Lang in berkeley expanding their dance 
section (YES!), 40,000people raving at one party in england, germany had 
a one week rave party last year, and the fact that we are all communicating 
and creating a 
new kind of community over the internet seem to be really positive 
indicators that maybe 
there is an emergent phenomen happening on this little planet of ours. 
And it all seems so positive.  And even in the sciences...the progressive 
thought seems to be more and more holistic, chaos theory, Penroses' 
quantum computers etc...but maybe I am rambling here... oh well... I am 
still working out if I really think that there is an emergent phenomenon 
happening or if it is just that you see what you look for in life...ahhh 
shit oh well...I think that I will go to sleep... 
-The Hierophant

        Ha ha, i always wonder that too. You really can edit reality based
on your own desires but i DO think that there IS a huge emergent phenomenon
of spirituality, intelligence and evolution (in the best meaning of the
word) going on right now.  Just the simple fact that you can talk to a real
human being one on one (well, through email) without the media mediation
will go a long way to opening lines of communication and blurring borders,
cultural identities etc.  I can sense intuitively the connection between
the emergence of raving, electronic culture and (to be honest) the increase
in the use of certain drugs.  All of these things seem to be bringing us
all into denser and denser and more complex forms in interconnecting with
each other. And, personally speaking, other people can be a source of
strength and knowledge, to push you higher and all that :)

        densely yours,
                brad

From: Scott C Sattler <kimmel@gwis2.circ.gwu.edu>
Subject: Re: ephedrine
To: JohnX A Wetlesen <JohnX_A_Wetlesen@ccm2.hf.intel.com>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <Fri, 27 Oct 95 16:47:14 PDT_7@ccm.hf.intel.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9510282017.A26702-0100000@gwis2.circ.gwu.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

you're wrong John. the synthetic base for mdma is methyl-amphetamine. 
Ephedrine is 
used medically in coulple of different ways. First, you can use it as a 
decongestnt, as is promotes small vessel vasoconstriction, ie in nasal 
mucosa. It can also be used in truama/resus situations as a pressor 
agent. It has the disadvantage of being a non-selective vasoconstrictor, 
clamping down on the systemic and renal pre-capillary beds, but it is 
used. Its side effects are what you would expect from a alpha-agonist. It 
raised systemic blood pressure peripherally, has some CNS stim effects
and has beta 1 agonist activity at very high doses ie, abuse doses. This 
latter effect is what gets people in trouble...basically the stuff will 
make you tachycardic, and throw the user into arrythmia if he.she is 
predisposed to arrythmia. Not a benign compound. Everything in 
moderation, folks.
scott
 On Fri, 27 Oct 1995, JohnX A Wetlesen wrote:

> Ephedrine is a precursor for meth-amphetamines/amphetamines and the like.  
> It is not a precursor for XTC.
> 
> John
>

	ephedrine is a precursor to speed. Making speed from ephedrine
is pretty easy. I'm not sure about mdma though.
	(I think the eph->speed path is *very* easy...)

> 
> Actually, I am pretty sure that ephedrine is a precursor to Ectascy. That's
> why the sales of it are now closely monitored by the federal government. 
> 
> The only bad side effect I have noticed (from max-alerts) is they make your
> lungs hurt the next day (because it is a broncho-dilator), and when it wears
> off you feel SOOOOO tired. I would definately not take more than 3 at once.

> Also, max-alerts are great for people with allergies and asthma, they make
> you feel much better for opening up those breathing tubes.

     I moved out to the west coast, thinking 'how much different can the vibe
be from NY?' but I supposed I was proved wrong comepleteley.  When the people
I went with & I arrived there, I wasn't particularly impressed, but as the
crowd became at ease with eachother, and the vibe began building, I was
totally amazed.  At most of the raves in the east I went to, the crowd kept
pretty much to themselves, kids from brooklyn only associating with the other
brooklyn kids, the kids from newburgh keeping to their own etc., but the
scene at friends and family had such a feeling of community, I was at ease
with people I had just met like I'd known them for years (although I think I
ended being a bit irritating to a few by being so damn happy and friendly).
     X-tra special thanks go out to Sabin & Matt, who got me there and got me
in, and Bobby too for giving me that phatty hat, and everyone else for being
there- you contributed the energy for one of the best raves I've ever been to
;'D.

      Hugs, Wurz

Phelps and I were truely impressed.

grabbed my soul and showing me I was in the presence of family.

amazing live set.  You surely know you anchor the light to this planet and
spread it amongst us all.  Phelps thanks you for being the light being you
are. It was funny cuz it took her several minutes before she could talk or
really function normally after you finished....and to think she almost

Date: Fri, 27 Oct 1995 14:15:27 -0700
From: Jason Yu <jasonyu@microunity.com>

Subject: FWD

Mail*Link(r) SMTP               Halloween Tips


Good Advice from Nick Stern for you halloweeners
NICK:  I added one at the bottom.

* Never read a book of demon summoning aloud, even as a joke.

* Do not search the basement, especially if the power has just gone out.

 * When it appears that you have killed the monster, *never* check to see
if it's really dead.

* If you find that your house is built upon or near a cemetery, was once a
church that was used for black masses, had previous inhabitants who went
mad or committed suicide or died in some horrible fashion, or had
inhabitants who performed necrophilia or satanic practices in your house,
move away immediately.

* If your friends speak to you in Latin or any other language which they do
not know, or if they speak to you using a voice which is other than their
own, shoot them immediately.  It will save you a lot of grief in the long
run.
NOTE: It will probably take several rounds to kill them, so be prepared.

* When you have the benefit of numbers, *never* pair off or go it alone.

* As a general rule, don't solve puzzles that open portals to Hell.

* Never stand in, on, above, below, beside,or anywhere near a grave, tomb,
crypt, mausoleum, or other house of the dead.

* If you're searching for something which caused a noise and find out that
"it's just the cat," leave the room immediately if you value your life.

* If appliances start operating by themselves, move out.

* Do not take *anything* from the dead.

* If you find a town that looks deserted, it's probably for a reason.  Take
the hint and stay away.

* Don't fool with recombinant DNA technology unless you're sure you know
what you are doing.

* If you're running from the monster, expect to trip or fall down at least
twice, more if you are of the female persuasion.  Also note that, despite
the fact that you are running and the monster is merely shambling along,
it's still moving fast enough to catch up with you.

* If your companions suddenly begin to exhibit uncharacteristic behavior
such as hissing, fascination for blood, glowing eyes, increasing hairiness,
and so on, get away from them as fast as possible.

* Stay away from certain geographical locations, some of which are listed
here: Amityville, Elm Street, Transylvania, Nilbog (God help you if you
recognize  this one), the Bermuda Triangle, or any small town in Maine.

* If your car runs out of gas at night, do not go to the nearby
deserted-looking house to phone for help.

* Beware of strangers bearing tools such as chainsaws, staple guns, hedge
trimmers, electric carving knives, combines, lawnmowers, butane torches,
soldering irons, band saws, or any device made from deceased companions.

* If you're caught in the rain with a flat tire and you and your fiance
decide to knock on the door of that castle over there, and the doorman is
real wierd looking and the castle's owner is a transvestite, run like hell.

Well I haven't been gettin out much the last couple of months, but I'm 
happy I didn't miss the last sunset.  As usual a great vibe.  Sorry I 
missed fnf, but it was nice to pick up on the afterglow from those fnf 
attendies at sunset.

nice upbeat sounds which got people dancing.

the energy.
I left before Phil Smart came on, feeling good from a good hard dance 
session which I havin't been doing to much lately.

mode, lazers, other visuals, tight well connected indoor vibes on the 
dance floor, and lots of sweat (yummee).

Text item: 

>you're wrong John. the synthetic base for mdma is methyl-amphetamine.
>Ephedrine is
>used medically in coulple of different ways. First, you can use it as a
>decongestnt, as is promotes small vessel vasoconstriction, ie in nasal
>mucosa. It can also be used in truama/resus situations as a pressor
>agent. It has the disadvantage of being a non-selective vasoconstrictor,
>clamping down on the systemic and renal pre-capillary beds, but it is
>used. Its side effects are what you would expect from a alpha-agonist. It
>raised systemic blood pressure peripherally, has some CNS stim effects
>and has beta 1 agonist activity at very high doses ie, abuse doses. This
>latter effect is what gets people in trouble...basically the stuff will
>make you tachycardic, and throw the user into arrythmia if he.she is
>predisposed to arrythmia. Not a benign compound. Everything in
>moderation, folks.
>scott
> On Fri, 27 Oct 1995, JohnX A Wetlesen wrote:

>> Ephedrine is a precursor for meth-amphetamines/amphetamines and the like.
>> It is not a precursor for XTC.
>>
>> John
>>

        I think that people need to realize that just because there is an 
Methamphetamine trail in the 3,4 methylenedioxymethamphetamine molecule does not
mean that it is automatically a precursor chemical to it.  I may be wrong (and 
if I am I will be mighty red in the face) but after doing years of research on 
XTC I have never seen or heard references to it being made with Ephedrine or 
Amphetamine or Methamphetamine.  The most common method is to combine Piperonal 
acetone and Methylamine to reach the desired goal.  Now if we had said 
Methylamine is a precursor for XTC I would have agreed totally, and yes 
Methylamine is a precursor for MethAmphetamine as well.  It is what gives you 
the Meth and the Amine in the Methamphetamine.  
        Is there somebody out there that can elaborate a little more 
scientifically on this subject?

John

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Oct 30 11:02:20 1995

Received: from cc:Mail by ugate.inmark.com
	id AA815082946 Mon, 30 Oct 95 11:55:46 
Date: Mon, 30 Oct 95 11:55:46 
Message-Id: <9509308150.AA815082946@ugate.inmark.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Harthouse question
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


     

Jon Mark Logan writes:

>Could any Harthouse-savvy citizens out there recommend another good 
>Harthouse album, be it a compilation or just one artist?  I really love 
>acidy, darksider, trancey-techno-house.  
     
I have found Harthouse releases to be majorly spotty.  Like, you'll find 
something great but there will be 10 other mediocre to just plain bad releases 
for every good one.  Unfortunately, I can't think of anything off the top of my 
head BUT...Rising High (another label) has either 4 or 5 compilations out called
"The Secret Life of Trance."  These are all HIGHLY recommended if you like acidy
dark trancey techno with some housey influences thrown in for good measure.

Now, a word on the import versus domestic versions of these:  The UK versions of
these Rising High comps usually come out on 3 or 4 slices of vinyl or two CDs.  
Instinct, a US label, has re-issued these domestically BUT they did a 
slice-and-dice job on them.  What I mean is that they'll take one of the UK 
"Secret Life of Trance" comps and carve it up into two separate CDs, with some 
overlapping tracks and some altogether missing tracks.  So, I prefer getting the
UK issues because they're more complete.  I've had good luck getting these at 
Mod Lang in Berkeley.  I'm sure Rasputnin's has them too.  I've seen the 
Instinct US versions at Tower Records on Market in SF.

Laura

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Oct 30 11:37:49 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id LAA13946; Mon, 30 Oct 1995 11:37:49 -0800

Received: from cc:Mail by ugate.inmark.com
	id AA815085360 Mon, 30 Oct 95 12:36:00 
Date: Mon, 30 Oct 95 12:36:00 
Message-Id: <9509308150.AA815085360@ugate.inmark.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: musings on music
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


     Ob. F&F statements:
     
        1)  I've been saying for years (well, 2 of them) that the music 
     Ethan spins should ideally be heard at 3:00 am in a warehouse lit by a 
     blue intellabeam.  Well, F&F went one better, providing a green laser 
     instead.  It was killer!  Thanks to everyone that made it happen.
     
        2)  Who was playing that spaced out alien dub music?  Where can I 
     get a CD comp for home use?  Please make a recommendation!  I'm 
     specifically looking for the 
     dub-outer-space-noises-from-beyond-proxima-centauri sound.
     
        3)  alt.carpet.the.earth
     
     Went record shopping Sunday, this time to Frequency 8 in the Haight.  
     Major points to the store set-up:  the turntables with attached 
     mini-crates are very classy.  And instead of providing someone's 
     ancient beat-up 1200 and a blown amp to listen through, there's all 
     new gear.  Very classy.  Good coverage of trance/acid labels, although 
     the current stock seemed lacking in US releases.  But then maybe US 
     releases/labels have been lacking lately?  I'm a bit out of touch.
     
     I listened to 33 records (bought 8) and have a few things to say about 
     the current state of trance/acid trance.
     
     First, it's really good to see so many labels still supporting the 
     genre.  I saw several releases from Time Unlimited (a German label).  
     The very first time I bought records as a DJ (mid-1992) I got 
     something from Time Ulimited, and I hadn't seen much from them in the 
     intervening years.  I guess they're on a comeback.
     
     However, I was disappointed by the number of mediocre tunes I 
     encountered.  I fear that trance could be stagnating as a genre.  If 
     it stagnates, it will go the way of hardcore (i.e. become a fondly 
     remembered thing of the past).  So many tracks are using big swirly 
     string buildups, it seems a bit saccharine.  Similarly, there were a 
     large number of numbingly non-descript acid noodles.  The genre needs 
     to sound innovative and fresh if it's going to survive.  Another thing 
     that hit me was that the old "Waldorf" buzzy sound and the famed 
     "Belgian hoover" noises are coming back...1991 techno sounds that 
     sound cheezy and dated now.  I heard a few records that sounded good 
     until they broke into buzzy cheeze sounds.  Sigh.
     
     That said, it should be noted that there was good stuff in there too, 
     so all is definately not lost.  October is usually a bad month for 
     european techno, anyway:  so many people take off the entire month of 
     August that it takes until November for fresh sounds to start coming 
     through the pipeline.  One particularly interesting thing I noticed 
     was a combination of Detroit-style machine sounds with the faster, 
     lusher German trance style.  The sharp "clean" noises were there, but 
     not in such a stripped-down background as with true Detriot acid.
     
     Laura

Subject: F&F Healing
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I know that everybody and their mother has already posted about what went on
at F&F, but I have to say that it was especially important to me.  I hadn't
been out in a couple of months, mostly due to the fact that some part of me
just didn't feel that warm happy feeling I got all summer when I went to
raves.  I think a lot of it had to do  with the fact that I was going to
some of the larger venues, forgetting how much easier it is to meet people
and create a sense of community at smaller gatherings.  It was a big healing
proccess for me, because it really made me remember what raving is all
about.  I went with a fantabulous group of people that I kept seeing all
night, and their smiling faces kept me smiling, too.  I also ran into a lot
of people I hadn't seen for a looong time (some not since my first rave),
many new people that I'm looking forward to seeing again, and a few really
good friends that I'd lost touch with.

I guess I'd kind of forgotten how easy it is to just walk up to people and
say hi.  At some of the larger parties it's easier said than done (I wish it
wasn't like that, but it is).  Thank you to everyone I went with, especially
Wayne for the ticket, Amy for being a super friend, and Greg's uncle for
letting us have a killer space to party in.

Thanks y'all,
Jake

Subject: Save Gilman St.!
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I am taking the liberty of forwarding this posting about the effort to
maintain 924 Gilman as an independent music and cultural space.  I'll
let the posting speak for itself, but as someone who came along when
independent music-making and performances were even harder to pull off
than now, this is an important issue.  Part of my musical history was
the early punk days in Washington, DC (chronicled in the early part
of the book Banned in DC), where bands like the Bad Brains got their
beginning in places like Madam's Organ on 18th St NW.  Punk long ago
ossified, in my view, but there is a need for that scene and any other
where independence of expression and enjoyment are supported.  And as
Ethan and I and a couple of others can attest from a stellar event
at 924 Gilman a couple of years ago, where Garth just blew the doors
off the way he almost never does these days, that location is also 
emblematic as a haven for our kind of dance music as well.  

Enough of my posturing, here's the post . . .

--------

>From owner-sf-list@netcom.com Sat Oct 28 12:51:30 1995
Date: Sat, 28 Oct 1995 12:15:15 -0700
From: Steve Koepke <skoepke@netcom.com>
Subject: 924 Gilman Street Press Release


Due to the large number of requests for this, I am sending this out to
the whole sf-list mailing list.  

The new date of The Zoning Board meeting is now 7:15pm, November 13, 1995
at the Berkeley City Hall.

Members from 924 Gilman are planning to meet before the meeting at 6:45pm
on the steps of the Berkeley City Hall.

For more info, call the 924 Gilman Street info line at 510-525-9926.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------

For Immediate Release: October 22, 1995

Berkeley, CA

924 Gilman Street is in jeopardy.  The only consistently all-ages, alcohol
free youth center in the bay area, best known as the premier underground
punk venue in the nation, is threatened by an out-of-state brewery's plan
to open an upscale bar and restaurant directly across the street.  The
project, which is currently under review by the Berkeley Zoning Board,
includes plans for a 250-seat restaurant/bar, a 100,000 sq. ft. brewery,
and only 70 indoor parking spaces.

924 Gilman is run by youth for youth.  Anyone who wants to get involved
can. In addition to being the breeding ground for such current acts as
GREEN DAY, OFFSPRING, RANCID, and JAWBREAKER, it is a volunteer-run
collective, which has existed in the same location since 1986.  Besides
being an important stop on the international d.i.y. (do-it-yourself) music
circuit, Gilman has hosted amateur theater, spoken word, art shows,
self-defense courses and numerous political and community benefits over the
years.  No bands on major labels are allowed to play.  924 Gilman actively
opposes racism, sexism and  homophobia.  Its low prices, informal
atmosphere, and commitment to a fun, safe, alcohol and drug free space for
local youth has created a strong sense of community among otherwise
alienated kids.  The sense of accompishment that youth gain is unparalleled
in the bay area.

We only oppose the proposed large bar and restaurant: we welcome the jobs
that the proposed brewery will bring to this low-income industrial section
of Berkeley.  The irony of local residents being unable to afford the
restaurant/bar's prices (aka gentrification) is one of many concerns,
including massive problems with traffic, parking, drunk driving, and
potential culture clashes.  We also question the wisdom of putting a bar
directly across the street from a community center that actively
discourages alcohol and drug use.

Increased police presence and both wealthy businesses and young,
upwardly-mobile clientele clamoring for a more upscale dining and drinking
environment will quickly spell the end for 924 Gilman's unique community
center.  Our current location was chosen for its relative isolation from
retail and residential neighborhoods, thereby allowing our alternative
community to thrive.

The Zoning Board meets to discuss this issue Monday, Novermber 13, 1995, at
7:15 in the Berkeley City Hall.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Oct 30 13:51:07 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id NAA28608; Mon, 30 Oct 1995 13:51:07 -0800

Date: Mon, 30 Oct 95 13:50:15 -0800
From: swoosh@ucscb.UCSC.EDU (John Elias Darrow)
Message-Id: <9510302150.AA25352@ucscb.UCSC.EDU>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Funky Tekno Tribe
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

For reasons of my own I chose Funky Tekno Tribe over Friends
and Family.  (Don't worry, I'll make the next one...)  

Although it was true that there were a lot of newbies at this party
and people who are still pretty confused about themselves and how
to share energy to build a vibe, it is also true that Funky Tekno
Tribe threw an awesome party.  In fact, part of my reason for choosing
this party is to confront unfocused energy like this and find the
strength within me to focus into an incredible experience.  It is
how I grow strong and increase my will and conviction.  It is also
very hard sometimes, and a challenge, because you have to trust yourself
and your beleifs in the face of despair... but you always come through.
and in the end, you know who you are to a depth you were never aware of
before.  You have also steered all those unfocused people towards
a coherence that will bring them closer to themselves.  This is how
people will come to understand, through the healing of their confusion.
And when all those people start losing their fear and start giving 
themselves, all that energy will come back to you.

and I really admire Funky Tekno Tribe... because of this same reason.
All these people searching for pieces of themselves they don't think 
they have, running around in circles, alone and afraid.
but FTT stood there undeterred in their mission.  No amount of confusion
will shake them from their vision, and they press on, healing and
healing...
With wicked music and a beautiful light show.  A perfectly balanced
sound system, just rocking the house.  Actually the sound was really
well done... Totally crisp and clean, powerful without hurting your
ears, and with just enough bass to keep your bones vibrating.  
Same with the ambient area, which was actually much more of a jungle
area... but I liked it.
I liked it a lot.  True, it's probably not as much fun as Friends
and Family, but the benefits for me were well worth it.  Seeing all
those people inspired by the dance and the pierce of your gaze
is reason enough for me to feel all that pain.  I had an incredible
night.  so for me now, shaken, but never deterred, I press on, smile
in hand.

be seeing you...
-john.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Oct 30 16:27:19 1995

<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<UFO The United Fruitcake
Organization<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<


Peruvian Whistling Vessels

                                ...the Doorway Re-opens 

                                      by Don Wright


Millennia ago, a technology was born that was to continue being a part of a 
people's life for over two thousand years. A discovery utilizing sound that 
could transport human beings into a new and unique realm 
of experience...possibly to other worlds of existence. This sound was not 
music, but instead a special toning of whistles which, when blown together 
with other such vessels, had the ability to induce what has been
described as a "trance state of a spiritual nature." The sound was produced 
by a clay instrument which was such a personally treasured item to its owner, 
that it was not passed on to another person when he or she died,
but followed the owner to the grave. 

After being part of the life of two thousand years of generation after 
generation of people, the "technology" apparently was abruptly stopped and 
hidden when their land was invaded and conquered in 1532 AD. 

Peruvian whistling vessels are instruments of sound, tuned, not by 
electronically controlled measuring and adjusting mechanisms, but by 
utilizing an innate expanded human sensing ability. While it is an ability 
which we all have, few realize or consciously experience this state. This 
particular sense is one which may be closely described as a perception 
resulting from a mixing or blending together of several senses (synesthesia), 
so that they become a single new sensory input. 

The toning of the vessels is such, that one does not hear music when several 
vessels from one of the originating cultures are blown together, but rather 
is "shifted" into another realm and state of being for the duration of the
whistling session. 

The first experience of this is often recognized as being familiar, yet new. 
It seems to include a profound enjoyment of an emotional/kinesthetic/sound 
creation which one not only shares in creating, but also essentially
becomes. An awareness also seems to develop of the participation of other 
beings, not of our material world, yet clearly kindred in spirit. When within 
this realm, timeflow awareness, self-observation, past and future
preoccupation, constant internal self-dialogue, and instinctual concerns such 
as hunger, thirst, or sexual desire clearly diminish. 

The effect of the vessels may, in fact, be the only existing doorway to this 
beautiful and intensely profound type of experience that doesn't require 
altering the body chemistry with an ingested entheogen (shamanic
inebriant such as peyote, ayahuasca, psilocybin mushrooms, etc.). Because 
there is no lingering substance in the body, shortly after the whistling 
session has stopped, everyone returns to their pre-experience state,
beautifully enriched by the memory of what happened. 

For several seconds, to usually less than five minutes, after the session, 
most people realize an empathetic and almost sibling feeling for other people 
in the group, even though they may all be complete strangers. Most
people also discover a heightened enjoyment and appreciation of sound, humor, 
and softness in speaking. After a few minutes I have, upon occasion, ended 
the silence which follows a vessel session,m by playing a recording of 
Pachebel's Cannon in D, frequently observing one or more members 
of the group crying with joy in the beauty of the music. 

"Where in the world did they come from?" "What did the people who made them 
use them for?" "Why, after two thousand years of making them, would they 
suddenly stop?" These are questions often asked when I present a set of 
vessels. They originated in pre-Columbian Peru. As to how they used them, and 
why they stopped, we don't know. The vessels, made by those pre-Columbian 
cultures in Peru, appear to have been personal, treasured possessions, even 
to the extent of being placed into the grave with its owner. There has
even been speculation that extraterrestrial tehnological contributions to 
ancient these Peruvian cultures which could possible alsobe reflected ib the 
vessels. 

I find it profound that a people, culture after culture, through two thousand 
years of making and having whistling vessels as part of their life, would 
abruptly cease making and using them. They stopped making them
when the Spanish conquered their land around 1532 AD. 

Not only did the Spanish--who kept copious records of the cultures they 
conquered--not mention the vessels, but the Peruvians themselves did not, in 
any way we have yet discovered, create images of the vessels and their
use. Because of this, we don't have a clue as to how or why they were used. 
Recent research, however, has proven that the vessels were in fact finely 
tuned, with each culture having it's own primary frequency around
which the culture's vessels were tuned. Because of the difficulty of such 
precision tuning, it is only rational to assume that the whistle was not a 
novelty afterthought in a drinking pot, a theory often proposed in scientific
articles about vessels of this period. 

We don't have language sufficient to describe the experience of the vessels, 
or scientific knowledge of its precise method. I have tried to describe it 
somewhat in this article, but my only tools to accomplish this are
metaphors which barely carry the same "flavor or feeling tone" of the 
experience itself. While similar to an "out-of-body" or hallucinogenic 
experience, analogies simply do not exist. Someone might say that an aspect of
the experience is "being in an ocean of experience when a wind of sound, 
physical feeling, and emotion drifts over and enters your body flowing 
inside, and then moves out and on to somewhere else." This makes writing
or talking about the vessels quite difficult. 

A PERUVIAN WHISTLING SESSION 

Participants at a typical "whistling session" as we call them, might be 
described as sober, non-altered people of different age, education, 
experience, physical condition, etc., often  strangers to one another. This 
group will sit down on the floor together in a close circle. After brief 
instructions, without any common goal, or clear expectation of what is about 
to happen, they put the spout of the clay pot they are holding to their 
mouthes and blow into them, creating a unique "whistle." They blow 
continuously from forty-five minutes to hours without a break, doing nothing 
else, with nothing else occurring in the room. 

The "participants" usually will be completely surprised about the length of 
time they were blowing the vessel, and will feel deep gratitude for having 
had the experience, often expressing regret that it is over. I can't recall
one group process, other than a Peruvian Whistling session, that commands the 
absolute attention, without cough, without quiet whispered remarks or 
conversation between participants, without spontaneous sighs, yawns, 
stretches, or looking about, for even a fraction of the time most 
groups blow the vessels. 

Daniel Statnekov, a wealthy antique collector, after being told this was a 
rare artifcat at an auction, purchased a special vessel, which was ultimately 
to have a profound affect upon his life. He discovered their special
capability, and developed a way to reproduce them. Statnekov was, in my 
opinion, selected through a very special whistling vessel whose mission was 
to bring vessels once again into human experience. 

The vessel, wending its way for over four hundred years, from person to 
person, avoiding being broken or lost, century after century, finally reached 
the point in time and space where it would intersect with the path of a
"reincarnated Peruvian Whistling Vessel O'Sensei", a person who was most 
perfectly suited in all ways to restore the existence of the vessels into 
human experience. 

This point in time and space was at an estate auction on the East Coast. The 
rest of this story can be found in Statnekov's book: Animated Earth, by 
Daniel K. Statnekov (North Atlantic Books, CA, ISBN
1-55643-000-0). 

I met Daniel during my studies at Boston College, where I was studying 
psychology and theology. My interest and direction of study was to discover, 
understand, and utilize techniques of consciousness self-manipulation
and control. This interest was instrumental in my discovery of a set of 
vessels that Daniel Statnekov had made and given to Professor Baer, a 
psychology professor whom I greatly admired. Professor Baer "presented" the
vessels to a gathering of people that I attended. At this gathering, and my 
first experience of the vessels, a recognition of, and bond with, the vessels 
occurred for me that would ultimately result in my becoming a vessel
maker. 

Since my apprenticeship with Daniel in the northern mountains of New Mexico 
in 1980, where he passed on to me his tools, molds and spiritually charged 
clay, I have been growing in my understanding and ability to create
the vessels. 

I am tremendously excited about having the boundaries of our world, once 
again, expanded and redefined by experiences of these incredible instruments. 
Peruvian whistling vessels, unavailable to human experience for
hundreds of years, have once again entered our lives. New Frontier has made 
arrangements with Don Wright to conduct a National Peruvian Whistling week, 
September 16-22 (4 hrs daily whistling) at the Nepal Institute in
the Great Smoky Mountains. For details contact New Frontier Magazine, PO Box 
17397, Asheville, NC
28806, 704/251-0109, E-Mail 73072.2140@compuserve.com. 

c 1995 New Frontier Magazine, PO Box 17397, Asheville, NC 28806 Subscriptions 
$18/yr, $30/2yrs,
Foreign $38/yr, $72/2yrs Air. US Funds.

"Sometimes emotions just get out of hand. I went to the emergency room to get 
something to calm me down and they said they were gonna check me in ... Once 
they decide that, they take your keys so you won't poke your eyes out or 
something"

Kristin Hersh-

From: Amy R Starkey <sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu>
Subject: ok, my f&f report.....
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9510301707.A15086-0100000@saclink1.csus.edu>

Precedence: bulk


Of course it rocked my world til I almost fell off!
Andrew, Tracy, and Ethan stand out in my mind as just indescribable 
heaven weavers. o-my-god!!
I was transported back into time when Michael showed the Burning Man 
footage.  I felt such a connection with people who went - they felt like 
*FAMILY*. I was happy that those who didn't go got the chance to see some 
of what it was like. To all the wonderful sfravers I met for the first time: 
Starchild, Thursday, Gerard(?the cow guy?) John from Canada, and Noel 
from New Mexico, & RobertJ, not to mention all my sfrave friends who I 
already know.  Friends & Family. That says it all! :):):):)

I was only disappointed in 2 things:
1. It got *way* too hot and stuffy 
inside.  I didn't want to stop dancing, but I had to as I couldn't 
breathe! If there is better ventilation, I can dance longer and not miss 
anybody's set.
2. I got tired rather quickly.  My energy can be very unpredictible.  I'm 
just now getting over a cold and as much as I wanted to stay inside and 
dance all night, my body said NO NO NO!! :(  So I made the most of it and 
lounged in that CUSHY ambient area (the big one).  I did like the smaller 
ambient area too, the dj's played some most interesting things.  
Sometimes I felt like I was being told a story and it would get very 
mellow, then a loud screaming sound would suddenly rip through the air 
and scare the shit out of me - I loved it! 

Then we went out to the last Sunset party out at Pt. Volate and I met up 
with some nw-raves friends of mine from Seattle & Vancouver BC.  They 
went to FTT though. The music was great as usual and it got rather chilly 
once the sun set.  Whatdaya expect - November is practically here! :) So 
I'm glad I didn't miss the last one of the year.  Well, til the next 
party, I'll say bye for now!

love,
Amy

hello all,
	This is so fun to talk to everyone about music. I wanted to say 
how awesome F&F was, and to thank purple Tiger for coming through with 
tickets so that me and all of my friends could get in. If you saw me, I 
was the guy dressed as a Hierophant...sparkly hat...Big fluffy star 
necklace...and a red and blue robe, my best friend and girlfriend was 
with me and she was dressed as a ballerina...as we do not wish to promote 
excessive toxicity in our bodies we tried to keep the energy level up by 
using a more natural Ma Huang, balck tea and ginseng mixture, which 
worked pretty well...altough w couldnt stay going all night we stayed up 
till about 4:00 until going to sleep...the only effect that bothered me 
was whaen I went to sleep I woke up later drenched in sweat 
(?)...anyhow...the party was great...good people, good vibe!
	To muse a little on music...I spent the better part of an hour at 
the new store F 8 on saturday...It is a really nice place...The listening 
stations are very nice and the store guy is really nice and helpful and 
spins some groovy stuff.. He must ahve recommended me 10 records, I 
finally decided onJuno Reactor...beyond the infinite...What I really 
discovered is that from now on I will buy vinyl unless there are alot of 
vocals...before F&F I listened to it at 45 rpm...like the record says, it 
is great stuff, worked welll to get me hyped for the evening...then when 
I came home and was ready to soothe my ears a bti ...I played it at 33 
1/3 rpm andit came off great as a nice ambient chill tune!
	Unfortunately I cant write too much for a bit since I found out 
today that there are 2 midterms for me next week...I should pay more 
attention to the syllabi! but oh well...until next time.

-Hierophant, (I go by tony...but since someone else is already tony on 
this list, to avoind confusion i will just alias myself ashierophant:)

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: tim@redshift.com (Tim Gotch)
Subject: Fnf/intro/mixed-up
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hi, I'm Tim Gotch, from Monterey, CA (the place that is really cold right
now). I've been lurking for several months now, not having an amazing
amount to contribute 'cause I don't make it up to the SF parties much. But,
fortunately, I was at Fnf, one of the best parties of the year. You may
have met me there, because I was checking tickets outside for the first two
hours. I was wearing a Fnf T-shirt, a lot of tattoos and a hysterical
smile.
Down in Monterey, we have our own little collective that I try to help out
with, the Cloud Factory, of which Drenalin, Tim Mcknew, Cloud, Deaks, Elmo
and many others are a part of. CF does most of it's stuff during the
summer, so hopefully I'll be getting up to the Bay area more this winter. I
really want to check out MAD one of these Mondays.
On the personal side, I'm about 6'2", have alot of tattoos, spend almost as
much time at goth clubs as I do at raves, and play in a band with Tim
McKnew called Angel Bait. I go to college full time, work, make music and I
don't really have a social life outside of music stuff. I survive by
programming HTML and editing ad copy for a graphic design firm that a
friend of mine runs in Monterey.
Friends and Family was an experience, to say the least. On the way up from
Monterey, we watched a huge fire near the highway in Castroville, and it
seemed to be an omen that the night was going to be unusual. At the party,
I didn't actually get inside until Tracy had started spinning, but she was
great and really helped to get my energy up for the rest of the night.
Andrew was amazing, but I missed Ethan's set for reasons beyond my control.
I did catch Tim McKnew's set outside in one of the ambient areas, and even
though I have heard him spin many times, he managed to suprise me as
always. After Tim's set, I wandered around and while I couldn't name anyone
in particular, everything I heard was great. Fell asleep for an hour or so,
then awoke to the fine sounds of Allen Ameba (I think) who was just to the
left of my car. Then switched between Jon Carel and the gabber guy for the
final sets. A beautiful experience all in all and I hope that there are
many more to come. Much love and thanks to everyone there.
Well, I think I've run my mouth enough, so I end here. Hope to meet each
and every one of you that I haven't already.

Love
Tim G.
93
tim@redshift.com
http://www.redshift.com/~montpres/hdt.html (my work)

>      the current state of trance/acid trance.

>      However, I was disappointed by the number of mediocre tunes I

go through atleest 100 records to find 8 that are worth buying. I realy 
wouldn't be to worried about the state of trance. IMHO I don't think 
there ever has been any "genre" of music that has been spared from an 
overwelming number of mediocre releases.

josh

Oh yea, I forgot to mention how much I liked the music that the fist dj
(Alex?) was spinning.  It was totally crazy weird shit.  Really hard with
really strange sounds, I guess like hard Aphex stuff.  It made me bug out
and dance into really contorted positions.  It was the first time I really
let go and had the music take over my movements in a long time.  I loved it.

Hi all,

  Listen up ambient afficiandos--there's a new album being released on
  November 7, called "Original Soundtracks 1" by The Passengers.  It's
  actually a collaborative effort by Brian Eno (whose music gave birth
  to the term 'ambient' back in the 1970's) and the four members of U2,
  complete with a vocal opera loop laid down by Luciano Pavarotti...hmmm
  I know the link to rave culture here is a tenuous one--just thought  
  some of you might be interested :) ...

  I had a great time at Friends and Family this weekend--it was nice to 
  see so many of you again.  One of my friends got sick and needed to leave, 
  though, so my night was cut a little short.  Too bad I didn't get to dance
  to John Carel and Dave Bayer, although I did manage to catch Ethan's and 
  Tracy's sets, which were absolutely *driving*  
  Thanks again to Ethan and F&F; I'll see everyone again (I hope) at 
  the Gateway party on the 17th!

trick-or-treat,
Timothy

Hello all - Happy Halloweeeen

I got a few requests for more info on this stuff so here it goes..

The product is called:  New Attitude and is a performance tonic
basically it is a combination of Eastern and Western herbs, fruit extracts,
vitamins, and amino acids

 Contains(not a total list):
    in purified water, Siberian ginseng, Chinese red ginseng, echinacea
pupurea, echinacea angustifolia, licorice and chickory root, burdock root,
wood betony, black walnut hulls, fo-ti, rose petals  :), cloves, honey, rose
hips, potassium somethin'-or-other(6 different kinds of K) , lemon jucie,
apple extract, oganic boron, etc, etc, etc, the list goes on

Distributed exclusively by Results Inc. of Pleasanton Ca. (my home town)

The Performance tonic story: ( From the side of the bottle)
"...the Chinese have focused much of their medical practice towards the
treatment of "chi", the vital life force that flows through our
body....Today, many Western herbal scientists have disscovered what the
Chinese have known for years, that tonic herbs help the body take care of its
self...." talks about the blending of 33 herbs and organic compounds

Well the stuff works in every day usage by giving the recipient extra "will"
or energy throughout the day.  I feel almost happy and wired after doubling
or tripling the daily dosage before a rave.  I took some before FTT and
danced..for almost the whole eight hours I was there.  I know people who quit
smoking after using the product 

Well if there are any more questions you can call me and I will either answer
them or direct you to some one who can.

Thanks for the time   Austin
510.806.1026

porch with cloth hanging from f-n-f (yes, definitely still holding the vibe
with every stray strand that flies in the wind), black lights irradiating
the glow in the dark spider nestled in his web, and that damn huge pumpkin
with the f-n-f grin from ear to pumpkin ear with nothing else but nag
champa sprewing an odor of delightfulness to the senses inviting the
trick-or-treaters down the chosen path  (you have to understand we live in
a house behind a house so we must invite the gobblins down the driveway to
visit us).  some say ooooo... that pumpkin smells strange, and some say
what's that smell,  but what stands out the most?  weird blinking lights
spinning an entrancing web of aural ecstacy toward the street, beckoning
the little kiddies to their DOOM!!!!!!

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Tue, 31 Oct 1995 19:55:00 +1600 (PST)
In-Reply-To: <30957860@pcsmtp.ea.com> from "Atherton, Darren" at Oct 30, 95 05:09:00 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL24]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 1244      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


The combination of certain pure, steady tones has long been known
as an interesting way to tweak mental state.

Combine this with threshold hyperventilation caused by blowing these
Tibetan whistles and you can _really_ alter yourself.

More recently, La Monte Young has done some very interesting soundscapes 
using this technique -- playing many high harmonics of the same fundamental
through many speakers simultaneously, resulting in a thick sonic
texture that changes radically as you move throughout the room and
sounds cancel or reinforce each other.  Cool stuff.  I'd like to do a 
one-off chill night like this if I had the time.

In many of my ambient works I have tried to set up a soundscape entirely
made of changing texture, without any sudden 'events'.  This is in radical
opposition to the keyboard-driven MIDI triggering of most electronic music,
and can trigger a serious mental trip if played in the right set and 
setting.  Strangely, I don't experience feelings of peacefulness and inner
harmony after listening to my own music -- I feel like I have fallen back
from the threshold of lycanthropic change, and return to my body somewhat
bemused.  Weird, eh?  I guess I have not achieved samadhi yet.

Enough rambling,

// g
